PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Leo McLeay) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON FINANCE AND PUBLIC ADMINISTRATION

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday I informed the House that I had concluded that issues raised by the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin) on behalf of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration were sufficiently important to have counsel seek leave to appear on my behalf in the Supreme Court of New South Wales in an action taken by Westpac Banking Corporation against a witness before that Committee, Mr J. R. McLennan.

INTERJECT.PARA: I now advise the House that counsel representing me appeared in the proceedings and, following that intervention and discussions between counsel representing Westpac Banking Corporation and me, assurances were given to the court to the effect that, first, any injunction which Westpac Banking Corporation seeks against Mr McLennan seeking restraint on him will be qualified to exclude disclosure or use of documents by him to the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration and, second, Westpac will not seek, without first giving notice to the Speaker or the Australian Government Solicitor in Sydney, any order for production of any document on such terms as might preclude Mr McLennan from producing the document to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration.
I now table the memorandum supplied to me by counsel and will have it incorporated in Hansard.
The document read as follows-
THE SPEAKER OF THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES OF THE COMMONWEALTH OF AUSTRALIA
PARLIAMENTARY PRIVILEGE
MEMORANDUM

Westpac Banking Corporation has commenced proceedings in the Supreme Court of New South Wales against John Ross McLennan seeking orders restraining him from disclosing certain information claimed to be confidential to the plaintiff, including information contained in documents, and other ancillary orders. An interlocutory application in connection with the matter was listed for hearing today before the Honourable Mr. Justice Powell at 2 pm.

Mr McLennan has made a submission to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration in connection with its Inquiry into the Australian Banking Industry. The Speaker of the House of Representatives was concerned to ensure that submissions should be put to the Court so that no orders were sought which might be construed as breaching the privileges of the House of Representatives. These privileges arise under Section 49 of the Commonwealth Constitution and Article 9 of the Bill of Rights, 1688 and are amplified by the Parliamentary Privileges Act, 1987.

We were instructed to seek leave to appear amicus curiae before Mr Justice Powell on the instructions, through the Australian Government Solicitor, of the Speaker of the House of Representatives, to put submissions on the question of parliamentary privilege. After Senior Counsel had announced our appearance, and sought leave to put submissions to the Court amicus curiae, Mr Stephen Charles QC, who appeared for the plaintiff, Westpac Banking Corporation, handed up some proposed orders which contained the following:-

``1. Pending the determination of the proceedings or earlier further order, the defendant be restrained from disclosing or using the plaintiff's confidential information, being the documents and the information contained in the documents referred to in the Schedule hereto (``the plaintiff's documents'') other than to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, or any representatives thereof.''

None of the other orders which it was proposed that the Court should be asked to make today required Mr McLennan to take any steps which would preclude him from producing any documents to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration.

During a short adjournment of the application, while the Court disposed of a part heard matter, Mr Charles gave us further assurances the text of which will be set out below. We were then instructed that, subject to making a statement within the Court setting out the assurances we had been given, we should seek leave to withdraw our application to be heard amicus curiae.
When the Court resumed, Senior Counsel made the following statement to the Court containing the assurances we had been given:-
``Mr Charles on behalf of the plaintiff Westpac Banking Corporation has informed me:-
1. That any injunction which the plaintiff seeks will be qualified in accordance with the qualification contained in paragraph 1 of the draft Orders presented today; and

2. That the plaintiff will not seek, without first giving notice to the Speaker of the House of Representatives or to the Australian Government Solicitor in Sydney, any order for the production of any document on such terms as might preclude the defendant from producing the document to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration.
In those circumstances I have been instructed, for the moment, to withdraw my application to be heard amicus curiae.''
Thereafter we withdrew from the Court.
CHAMBERS
20 February 1991
Garry Downes, QC. Stephen Gageler

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:

PETITION.TITLE: Australian War Memorial
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The Speaker and The Honourable Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament. The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:

``We, the undersigned, wish to signify our strong opposition to the proposal that an admission charge be made for entry into the Australian War Memorial. We believe that it was erected as a Memorial to the dead and that the material on display is as much of a memorial nature as the building itself''.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Andrew (from 45 citizens), Mrs Gallus (from 132 citizens), Mr McLachlan (from 38 citizens) and Mr Wilson (from 23 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Christian Commonwealth
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we, the undersigned, call for the full and total recognition by Federal Parliament and the High Court and all government agencies that Australia is a Christian Commonwealth according to law and its heritage traditions and customs.

That as Australia prepares for the Centenary of Federation on 1st January, 2001 AD, we celebrate our Centenary as a Christian Commonwealth as described by the Founders of Federation such as Sir John Downer, who said ``The Commonwealth will be from its first stage a Christian Commonwealth'' and as stated in our Federal Constitution-``humbly relying upon the Blessings of Almighty God . . .''
That our Federal Parliament therefore implement the following policies before 1st January, 2001 AD.
1. The Adoption of a Christian National Anthem-``God Bless Australia'' to the tune of ``Waltzing Matilda''.
2. The Adoption of a Christian National Motto-``One Nation Under God``, for use on our coins, banknotes, etc.
3. The appointment of practising Christians as Vice Regal Representatives of our Christian Queen, Elizabeth II.
4. The retention of our Christian Prayers at the daily opening of Parliament in the standing respectful presence of all Members of Parliament.
5. The retention of ``God Save the Queen'' for Vice Regal Functions as our Royal Anthem and as our National Hymn for all other civic functions.
6. The retention of Christian Christmas Carols in our State Schools and other civic functions during the Christmas Season.
7. Officially inform the United Nations and all the other nations of the world that Australia is a Christian Commonwealth.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will reaffirm our Christian Heritage as a Christian Commonwealth.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Dr Harry Edwards (from 24 citizens), Mr Gayler (from 7 citizens) and Mr Newell (from 18 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Citizens' Initiatives
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament of Australia assembled.

The Petition of certain Citizens of South Australia, wish to draw to the attention of the House our desire that the Swiss system of Citizens Initiative, Referendum and Recall be introduced as an addition to the present mode of government in this Nation.
- To ensure that all Australians have a proper say on important issues which affect them.
- To ensure that the decisions of government are made in the best interests of all Australians.
- To encourage electors to become more responsible by direct and timely involvement in the political processes.
- To encourage a Democratic process whereby electors can more effectively participate in the formation of new laws, and in the revision or repeal of existing laws.

Your Petitioners, therefore, pray that your honourable House will call upon the Government of Australia to hold a Referendum in this matter, at the first opportunity, so as to determine the will of all Citizens of this Nation.
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Downer (from 717 citizens) and Mr McLachlan (from 152 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Middle East
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of the undersigned electors of the Commonwealth of Australia sheweth:
Your petitioners,
While believing that the Australian forces presently in the Persian Gulf region must be properly and fully sustained and supported;

Being deeply concerned by the prospect of a long and potentially widespread conflict arising from the present actions in the Persian Gulf region, and the damage to Australia and Australians which would result if more of our forces are committed to that region;
Do humbly pray that there be no increase in the level of Australian forces committed to the Persian Gulf region.
And as in duty bound your petitioners will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Law
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia, do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government will consider the plight of the father in the Family Court.

Fathers, according to the Laws of Australia, should have equal rights to their children, in both custody and access applications before the Family Court. Immediate amendments to the Family Law Act should be implemented for inclusion of parental rights as distinct from children's rights. It should be made possible for fathers to obtain a fair deal in the Family Court and be able to continue involvement in their siblings upbringing at all times throughout every stage of their children's development, thus being in the best interest of the children themselves; without incurring exorbitant legal costs and manipulated by many of the legal profession.

Access Orders from the Family Court should be implemented without delay and at no cost to the non-custodial parent, thus eliminating denial of access. We humbly urge Parliament to direct the Family Court by way of immediate legislation to jealously guard visitation rights and become more liberal with them.

We further do humbly seek that a private members bill be introduced on an urgent basis to consider the plight of Mr John Zabaneh, a fellow citizen and a father of four young children whom he had no access to for nearly five years despite that he had obtained unenforceable orders from the courts. John Zabaneh has been denied any input in his children's development and upbringing and has little or no knowledge of his children's progress and wellbeing.

As this matter is of human-rights nature, or paramount importance, it is specially requested that this petition be read to Parliament assembled in full. And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Rights of the Child
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

1. that ratification of United Nations Conventions, such as the above, by the Federal Government, without Parliamentary debate or consultation with the people through a referendum, is a gross abuse of the Australian Constitution and is contrary to democratic principles;
2. that the Convention's philosophy of parent/child relationships is based on a false premise and embodies the totalitarian principles of State ownership of children;

3. that the Christian principle of parental authority is essential for the proper functioning of society, but phrases in the Convention implying parents' rights are virtually meaningless, with escape clauses permitting the widest of interpretation;
4. that Articles 12 to 16 giving children the right to seek, think, say and be whatever, wherever and with whom they wish violates the common sense of any normal parent;
5. that some Articles contradict other Articles and imprecise wording adds to the confusion by providing loopholes for the protection of paedophiles and certain types of child traffickers;

6. that some of the proposed rights are inappropriate for immature child minds and have no logical connection with the protection of children from abuse or deprivation, such protection being already provided by existing Australian laws.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to legislate or provide for:
(a) a twelve month Moratorium on the ratification of the Convention to enable the people of Australia to discuss and examine in detail the 54 Articles;
(b) a referendum to follow the Moratorium, seeking public approval before ratification of the Convention.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Rights of the Child
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House their deep concern that the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child:
1. (a) makes inadequate provision for a subjective judgement by parents as to what is in the best interests of their children
(b) makes inadequate provision for parents to use their discretionary powers to act on such judgements.
2. creates the potential for conflict between parent and child (rather than the atmosphere of happiness, love and understanding mentioned as valuable in the preamble.
3. will produce closer monitoring by Government agencies of relationships between parents and children.
Your Petitioners therefore pray that:
1. By Act, Parliament ensure that all international treaties (excluding national security) are debated by the Parliament.
2. The Parliament take action to have the Convention amended in order to pay the highest regard to the importance of the family unit, and to the rights and responsibilities of parents.

PETITION.TITLE: Hostel Care Subsidy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that:
(a) The signatories express deep concern that the hostel care subsidy will be abolished as from January 1991:
(b) This budget decision will cause hardship to residents of hostels; or
(c) Will seriously damage the financial stability of hostels forcing many to make callous decisions in regard to hostel residents.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House of Representatives will call on the Government to reinstigate the hostel care subsidy for nonfinancially disadvantaged persons.

PETITION.TITLE: Wool Quotas
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament; the Petitioners of the State of Western Australia point out to the House:
a) We have no capacity to diversify land usage upon Pastoral leases,
b) Estimated carrying capacity of WA Pastoral leases is legislated by the Pastoral Board of WA, and
c) The climate establishes natural production limits within the arid rangelands by its unreliable and low rainfall.

Your Petitioners therefore pray that the House will not introduce Wool Quotas. If wool quotas are forced upon Australia, then we most earnestly pray exemption for the Pastoral Areas of Western Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
- That every abortion kills an unborn human baby.
- That the right to life of all humans is the most fundamental and essential of all human rights.
- That the Government's first duty is to protect this right to life.
- That the most defenceless and threatened lives are those of unborn babies for whom the Government is duty bound to take extra steps to protect.
- That in 1987/88 taxpayers funds through Medicare provided medical benefits for 61,879 abortions totalling $6.4 million.
- That in the same year Commonwealth grants to the States indirectly financed the deliberate killing of thousands of other unborn babies in State Public Hospitals.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament carry out its duty to protect the right to life of Australian babies by ceasing to fund abortions through Medicare, restricting grants to the States and by all other means at its disposal.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Rights of the Child
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain residents of the State of South Australia draws to the attention of the House our concern with particular aspects of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child in that some of the Articles of the Convention, as they are presently drafted, do not recognise the rights and responsibilities of parents towards their children and may diminish the parent/child relationship.
- Namely, the Convention declares that children have the right to ``freedom of expression'', a right described as including:
``. . . freedom to seek, receive and impart information and ideas of all kinds, regardless of frontiers, either orally, in writing or in print. . . .''.
- The Convention declares the right of ``freedom of association and freedom of peaceful assembly''.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House take action to have the Convention amended to give adequate recognition to the rights and duties of parents with respect to the education as well as the physical, social and moral development of their children.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

This petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully draws the attention of the House to the Government's actions in relation to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme which has severely affected the viability of our community pharmacies and their ability to provide the quality and quantity of service to which we as Australians have a right.

Your petitioners respectfully request the House to urge the Government to guarantee an adequately funded Pharmaceutical Benefit Scheme, so as to guarantee the continued viability of neighbourhood pharmaceutical services through our local community pharmacies.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Aid
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned citizens, wish to record our support for the One World Declaration:
- to focus Australian aid, and policies at the World Bank, IMF and Asian Development Bank, on fighting poverty and protecting the environment;
- to restore Australian aid to 0.5% of GNP, cut military spending by 1% and work for a fairer international economic system;
- to promote human rights through aid and a code of conduct for companies.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives call upon the Government to implement the above.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian War Memorial
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain residents of the State of ACT. draws to the attention of the House.

1. We, undersigned, wish to signify our strong opposition to the proposal that an admission charge be made for entry into the Memorial. We believe that it was erected as a memorial to the dead and that the material on display is as much of a memorial nature as the building itself. We urge you to rescind the decision.
2. We urge you to request the AWM Council to reverse their decision.
Your petitioners therefore ask the House to urge the Australian War Memorial Council to reconsider its decision to charge an entrance.

PETITION.TITLE: Rights of the Child
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House their concern about the implications of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child. The petitioners are concerned that the Convention as drafted erodes the rights and responsibilities of parents in relation to the care of their children and threatens the family unit.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House make appropriate reservations to the Convention prior to ratification in order that the rights and responsibilities of parents in relation to their children be protected.

PETITION.TITLE: Hot Air Balloons
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain electors of the Division of Macarthur draws to the attention of the House:
We the undersigned object to the presence and the peculiar noise of hot-air balloons flying low over our property causing stock to panic and injure themselves and distress to domestic pets.

In particular the very low flying activity on Sunday September 2nd 1990 between 7.00 am and 7.30 am resulting in the death of a valuable stock animal owned by Mr. P. Tyrrell plus fences broken by panicking stock. Your petitioners therefore pray that the House legislate to restrict the flight of hot air balloons over rural land.

PETITION.TITLE: Freedom of Association
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
re Freedom of Association (Article 15 and Article 13 and 29)

PRAYER Your petitioners therefore pray that your Honourable House will acknowledge the right and duty of parents to supervise the associations that their children keep in accordance with the fundamental importance of the family unit.

PETITION.TITLE: Ownership of Press
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia wishes to draw the attention of the House that we are deeply concerned at (1) concentration of ownership of the Press which is unprecedented in Australia's history and unparalleled in any Western Democracy-(2) The unacceptable concentration of power, the restrictions on the diversity of information and ideas, the barriers to entry and other aspects of market failure, the diminished localism of content and accountability, the debilitating impact on journalistic culture and the conflicts of interest which this concentration of ownership involves.
Your petitioners respectfully urge the House to support the establishment of a Royal Commission to inquire into the Press including:
(a) The extent of concentration in the ownership and control and the effects of that on:
(i) the provision of accurate, fair and comprehensive news;
(ii) the diversity of opinions and the opportunities for expression; and
(iii) the practice of journalism; and
(b) the regulatory framework in Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Middle East
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain residents of the state of New South Wales draws to the attention of the House that we do not believe that it is in the economic interest of Australia to support military intervention in the Gulf or that war is a morally justifiable means of solving conflict.
Your petitioners ask the House:
1. To support the sanctions imposed by the United Nations by demanding that they be given time to work regardless of how long that may take.
2. To support the re-establishment of democracy in Kuwait which was suspended in 1967.

PETITION.TITLE: Third World Debt
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament.
The petition of the undersigned shows:
That we are concerned about the increasing poverty and misery of people throughout the developing world due to the debt burden placed upon Third World nations.
Your petitioners ask that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled should:
Act in co-operation with other national governments and international agencies to ease the burden by the immediate implementation of one or more of the following solutions.

The rate of interest on loans can be decreased; Aid to Third World nations can be increased and/or; a world development fund could be established into which all debts would be placed, to be redistributed as aid by a governing body, which ensures the money is wisely spent.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian War Memorial
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate assembled in Parliament. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:

1. We, the undersigned, wish to signify our strong opposition to the proposal that an admission charge be made for entry into the Australian War Memorial. We believe that it was erected as a memorial to those who served their country and paid the supreme sacrifice and that the material on display in the galleries is as sacred and as much of a memorial nature as the building itself. We seek your assistance in having this decision rescinded.
2. We urge you to direct the Australian War Memorial Council to reverse this decision.

Your petitioners therefore ask the Members of the Senate to disallow the regulations as tabled in Parliament empowering the Australian War Memorial Council to charge an admission fee to any section of the Memorial.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

The petition of certain residents of the State of Western Australia draws to the attention of the House the Government's recent decision to introduce an assets test restricting Family Allowance Payments and points out that this will disadvantage many low income rural families by denying them assistance because of their assets, including the family farm, exceeding $300,000 in value.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to support rural families by opposing the Government's decision.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Mr H.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Community Affairs, I present the Committee's report entitled You have your moments, a report on funding of peak health and community organisations, together with the minutes of proceedings and evidence received by the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since the 1950s, the Commonwealth has funded organisations to operate national secretariats in the community services, health and housing areas. In the intervening period there have been a number of internal and interdepartmental reviews resulting in various changes, including transfers of responsibility from central control in the Department of Administrative Services to program departments such as the Department of Community Services and Health. However, there had not been a full and critical review of national secretariat funding administered by the Department of Community Services and Health. This inquiry is the first such comprehensive public review of this funding program by the Parliament. It comes at an appropriate time at the end of the 1980s when a new range of consumer representative organisations has emerged and, in some cases, received funding.

SPEECH.PARA: The organisations considered by this inquiry are representative bodies set up around a common interest. Some are concerned with a specific issue, such as the Australian Cystic Fibrosis Associations Federation, some represent broad constituencies in particular program areas, such as national shelter in the housing sector, and some have interests which extend beyond the Community Services and Health portfolio, such as the Australian Council of Social Service, which deals with social security issues, amongst others.

They are often groupings of organisations whose grassroot members are consumers, parent and service providers. Their national secretariats' main activities include the following: information dissemination, consultation, policy development, lobbying government and bureaucracy, public awareness, public education, and public debate. The advantage of proximity to government, the Parliament and the Federal bureaucracy has led to many of these organisations being based in Canberra.

The Committee found that there is a vital role for such organisations in the community. Most importantly, they give disadvantaged people an opportunity to comment on and influence policy and programs which affect them. This assists government to take broad community needs into account in decision making. On occasions their obligation to represent their constituents brings them into conflict with government, hence the title of the report, You have your moments.

It is the view of the Committee that the community needs organisations which can challenge government and the bureaucracy. This report sets out to provide a constructive, accountable environment in which such criticism and possible disagreement can take place. Since the members of the funded organisations are people who, in the main, have low disposable incomes, a degree of Commonwealth support is often necessary. The $6m spent on national secretariats is a small proportion of the total community services, health and housing budget which assists the community to deal with issues in a mature, considered, democratic, open and informed way.

There is no need for overall funding to be significantly increased, but two points should be made. First, the freeze imposed on funding levels for some organisations needs to be lifted to allow annual indexation. Second, there needs to be flexibility to support new representative organisations which may emerge from time to time in areas of need.

The Committee in its report encourages organisations to continue to explore their potential to raise income themselves through various means, including membership fees and subscriptions, publications, sales, fund-raising and corporate sponsorship. Such income should be taken into account and set in funding levels, but without creating disincentives.

Overall, the Committee found inconsistencies, inadequate accountability and a lack of strategic approach in the past administration of national secretariat funding by the Department of Community Services and Health. The most striking inconsistencies concerned grant amounts, which vary enormously and inequitably. Other specific shortcomings include: a lack of competitive advertised selection process for funding; uncertainty about funding approval from year to year; absence of a review-evaluation process to determine whether continuation of funding is warranted; and inadequate support for seed funded organisations. In part, these problems are due to funding having been provided through two departments and numerous programs.

The Committee's report suggests a framework of funding to supersede the previous ad hoc approach. This has the following elements: firstly, equitable distribution of national secretariat funding between the community needs addressed by the Department's programs; secondly, separate funding of organisations representing consumers and non-profit service providers where necessary, although combined organisations are preferable; and, thirdly, three categories to define the roles of organisations and determine the level of funding they require. These are: summit organisations, which have a leadership and coordination role across a range of areas; umbrella organisations, which represent broad constituencies in particular program areas; and satellite organisations, which are concerned with a specific issue.

One of the Committee's priorities is to ensure that only organisations which are authentic representatives of broad community constituencies are supported. Organisations should, therefore, satisfy certain requirements. They should have democratic election processes; be controlled by an elected governing body and executive rather than by paid secretariat staff; have good, regular communication between the membership and leadership; and avoid fixed political allegiances.

In examining funding arrangements, the Committee concluded that a major overhaul is needed. In particular, secretariat funding needs to be isolated from funding for programs and projects and there should be standard, indexed funding levels with limited scope for variations.

The main cost item is salaries. The model recommended by the Committee allows for an executive officer plus a maximum of six staff for summit organisations, an executive officer plus three staff for umbrella organisations, and one full or part-time employee plus secretarial assistance for satellite organisations.

To give organisations some security for planning and staffing, funding should be approved for several years at a time. The Committee has suggested four years. Terms will be punctuated by annual accountability requirements and a major evaluation towards the end to determine whether funding should continue or cease.

Finally, the Committee has recommended the consolidation of the existing seed funding program. Funding is provided for several years to enable the organisation to become financially self-sufficient. This is an excellent cost-effective way to encourage community development. The program needs enhancement in several ways. These are set out in chapter five of the Committee's report, as follows: it should be advertised annually and all new applicants for secretariat funding should apply through this process, including any which may qualify for ongoing funding from the outset; approval should be notified six months in advance; both the timing of approval and the Department's support should be geared to achieving financial self-sufficiency during the funding period; and links with larger, established organisations should be encouraged.

This inquiry is part of a general process of increasing accountability of expenditure of public funds. Community organisations, as well as government, are coming to terms with greater accountability requirements by developing better ways of measuring performance against stated objectives and defining their roles more clearly. This report aims to assist this process and has been completed in a short time frame to enable its conclusions and recommendations to be taken into account as part of the Budget process for the next financial year.

The reference was adopted on 24 July 1990, and advertised in all major metropolitan newspapers on 4 August. The Committee received 66 submissions and conducted in Canberra, Sydney and Melbourne public hearings at which 37 organisations gave evidence. It would not have been possible to complete the task in the seven months time frame without the cooperation of the Department of Community Services and Health and, in particular, the assistance of a departmental officer, Mr David Hobbs, whose knowledge of the Department's operations and programs was invaluable. The efforts of the Committee secretary, Bjarne Nordin, and support staff, Shirley Hunter, in the conduct of the inquiry and in ensuring the timely presentation of this report are acknowledged and greatly appreciated. Likewise, I place on record my appreciation of the interest and diligence of the members of the Committee.
I trust that the Minister for Community Services and Health (Mr Howe) finds the Committee's report constructive and acts on its recommendations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gallus Mrs C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to commend the Chairman of the Standing Committee on Community Affairs, the honourable member for Scullin (Mr Harry Jenkins), for the time and effort he has put into the report, You have your moments, and commend also the secretariat staff. It was only last Wednesday that we actually approved this report and I am quite surprised to see it so soon presented to the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: I hope the recommendations of this report will be taken up because there is a greet need for a greater accountability in the so-called peak organisations-community organisations that receive funding from the Government. Up till now there has been a very ad hoc way of looking at these organisations and they have, in fact, not been subject to any review. The 30 or so peak organisations that have been receiving funding have been going on from year to year and expecting a continuation of that funding.

If these recommendations are taken into account there will be year by year examinations of the accountability of the organisations plus a four-yearly review of the principles on which they are funded. There should be much more representativeness from the grass roots, as these recommendations include recommendations that the organisations look at their grass root membership and see that has a truly good chance of getting on to the executive and making their voices heard, because one of the dangers that we heard of in these organisations is that the executive itself takes on the responsibility of making decisions and does not necessarily go back to the grass roots to find out what, in fact, the members would like.

It is also important that the funds that are available from government go to the organisations that need it most. For that reason, included in the recommendations is the suggestion that only those organisations that do not have access to professional funds should get money from the Government. I think everybody would agree that those organisations that have access through their membership, who have large salaries, should not also be getting large funds from the Government.
Finally, I want to state that I do have disagreements with some of the recommendations in the report and I do not support recommendation 16, which reads:
The Committee recommends that all grants should be indexed and that they should be indexed against Average Weekly Earnings and the Consumer Price Index for salary and other components respectively.

We disagree with that. We do not believe that these organisations should be separate from the rest of the community, which does not have this guarantee of being tied to the consumer price index and average weekly earnings. It is locking in organisations with grants. That is not appropriate and, as I said, is not usual for other organisations in the community.
The second recommendation I do not agree with reads:
The Committee recommends that adherence to relevant awards should be a requirement for funding and that DCSH should monitor organisations' practices to ensure that award wages are paid.
We do not agree that this is appropriate for these organisations because sometime in future it may be possible to break the nexus between these types of things.

TALK.START.PARA: —You're kidding!
—No, I am not kidding. I would not have said it if I was kidding.
—Order! The honourable member for Brisbane!
—With the exception of those two recommendations, I would like to highly endorse this report and hope that the Government will act on its recommendations.
—The discussion on this report is concluded.

DEBATE.TITLE: UNITED NATIONS CONVENTION ON THE RIGHTS OF THE CHILD

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House calls on the Government to undertake that in the event that Australia ratifies the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child, reservations will be lodged to safeguard the inalienable rights of parents, in particular insofar as those rights concern freedom of expression (Article 12), education (Articles 13 and 28), religion (Article 14), freedom of association (Article 15) and privacy (Article 16).

Ratification has in fact occurred since this motion was placed on the Notice Paper. This House has been denied the opportunity to debate such a United Nations convention and I am determined to move the motion notwithstanding the fact that the ratification process has been gone through by the Executive.

Pope John Paul II once said that children are, `that precious treasure given to each generation as a challenge to its wisdom and humanity'. Children throughout the world are vulnerable and to a large degree they are powerless. It is for this reason that the international community has worked towards securing increased protection for children. That work started with the Geneva Declaration of 1924 and has recently culminated in the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child, which Australia ratified on 18 December last.

There is no doubt that the aims of the convention are quite laudable. Had we been in government we would have ratified the convention, but we would have ratified it with reservations to particular articles of fundamental importance to the interpretation of that convention. There are many people in the community who have real and deep concerns about some aspects of the convention. I would not dismiss those concerns in the contemptible manner in which the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) did on 22 November 1989, when he told the Senate that such concerns constitute `lunatic misapprehensions which seem to be current in certain quarters of the community about the impact of the convention'. The Minister went on to say that he did not want to go into the matter in any detail for that `would only give currency to the crazed loons around the place who have congenital misapprehensions of things, who jump at shadows and spooks'. Given that contemptuous attitude displayed by the Minister it is little wonder that many people continue to have very deep concerns about the convention. The Government has done very little to make out its case in support of the convention.

Naturally, having read the convention as a whole, we are in favour of many elements that most people, in terms of the behaviour patterns that they cover, would be understandably opposed to-child prostitution, child slavery, et cetera. The aims of the convention, taken overall, are laudable, but there are very real concerns in the minds of many citizens revolving around the whole concept of parental control and parental rights over their children before they reach the state of adulthood.

There are two issues that I want to address this morning. The first relates to the rights and responsibilities of parents and the second to the relationship between the convention and the external affairs power. These are two contentious issues that are commonly raised by people who do have concerns about the convention.

I turn to the first issue. The motion I have moved refers to some specific articles in the convention, namely, article 12, concerning freedom of expression, articles 13 and 28, relating to education, article 14, which deals with religion, article 15, conferring a right of freedom of association, and article 16, concerning the rights of children to privacy.

These articles need to be read in context with other provisions found in the convention. In this respect, I make particular reference to article 5 and the preamble to the convention which expressly recognises the fundamental importance of the family unit and the rights and responsibilities that all members of the family unit, including parents, have.

When we look at articles 12 to 16, we see that unfortunately those articles have been drafted in a way which fails to give express recognition to the importance of parental rights and responsibilities. Parental rights and responsibilities do receive some recognition, albeit in an implied sense, when one has regard to article 5 and also to the preamble. It is this lack of express recognition or reference which caused the coalition in late 1989 to form the view that ratification should only take place subject to reservations being made against these articles.

It is fairly normal for governments, in ratifying conventions, if they are concerned about particular elements, to say, `We are in favour of the convention as a whole. We don't want to deny the operation of the laudable aims of the convention, but we have some concerns with particular articles. Therefore we will not only sign and ratify the convention, but express reservations as to particular elements within the convention'. It is not only sensible but it is provided for in international law for governments to ratify in that manner-but not this Government.

Many international reservations give express rights and responsibilities to parents. If we look at education, which is referred to in articles 13 and 28 of the convention, we see that article 26 (3) of the United Nations Universal Declaration of Human Rights states that parents have the `prior right to choose the kind of education that should be given to their children'. Similar expressions are used in principle 7 of the UN Declaration of the Rights of the Child, article 13 (3) of the UN Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights, and article 18 (4) of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.

Furthermore, in terms of just looking at the law with greater clarity, it has to be borne in mind that rights contained in various international instruments are, of course, interdependent with each other. There is no earthly good in ratifying a convention which would have in part, if not in total, the opposite effect of other conventions one has ratified. The Government has said to me, on the occasions on which I have raised this matter, `Read the convention as a whole, and if you take it as a whole, everything is all right'. It is not, because there is not express reference in the manner that I have just indicated. Furthermore, there is this conflict between elements of other international conventions and this particular one.

I stress again that the coalition is in favour of the Government having ratified the convention, but what we have stressed all along is that, where it is abundantly clear that elements of the convention run counter to the fundamental beliefs of most Australians in terms of a parent's right to control the education, et cetera, of their children, then that reservation ought to be entered into where there is a concern, and not glibly passed aside or, indeed, in the phrase that I have mentioned from the Foreign Minister, contemptuously cast aside.

It must be borne in mind that rights contained in various international instruments are interdependent with each other. Given some of the inconsistencies between the convention and other international instruments, it is simply a matter of common sense that appropriate reservations be made to address such inconsistencies so that the provisions of the convention can be read in the light of other international instruments.

Appropriate reservations that one would make would be similar to those made by the Holy See when it ratified the convention on 20 April 1990. It, too, was concerned about elements of the convention. It, too, wanted to ratify the convention. It ratified the convention and expressed some reservations. It said that it would interpret-and I quote:

. . . the Articles of the Convention in a way that safeguards the primary and inalienable rights of parents, in particular insofar as these rights concern education (Articles 13 and 28), religion (Article 14), association with others (Article 15) and privacy (Article 16).

That is an altogether commonsense and appropriate course of action. Indeed, at one stage it seemed that the Government had in mind making similar reservations. One of the problems in studying the actions of this Government is that it is virtually like a collection of human hiccups: we hear a viewpoint expressed by one Minister countermanded by another-because on 7 November 1990 the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs, Senator Tate, advised the Senate:

. . . when the Australian Government ratifies the convention, should it do so, one would find that those same understandings as to the pre-eminent role of the family would be acknowledged. It would be surprising were that not the case . . .

The Minister would now have cause to be surprised given that, when Australia did ratify the convention, the Government failed to make the reservations of the type contemplated by the Minister for Justice.

I now turn to consider the second issue, namely, what intentions, if any, the Government may have to legislate in areas that fall within the purview of the convention. In mid-1989, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commissioner, Mr Brian Burdekin, wrote:

It is now clearly established that the external affairs power under the Federal Constitution enables the Federal Parliament to legislate to implement treaty obligations such as those to be provided for by the Convention on the Rights of the Child.

Let us contrast this statement, which is obviously a cause of concern for many people, with comments made by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Gareth Evans, in the Senate on 22 November 1989. The Minister claimed:
. . . no Australian law is in contravention of the provisions of this particular convention . . .
He went on to say:
It is not my belief that there is any intent at all within the Government to legislate federally on child welfare issues based on the authority that a treaty of this kind would give to it . . . .

I commend the Minister on this occasion for the restraint he has shown in this instance. However, there are many others who do not share the Minister's view that Australian laws conform with the provisions of the treaty. For example, a letter from the Attorney-General's Department dated 21 June 1990 said:
Preliminary consultations-
that is, with the States and Territories-
have revealed laws inconsistent with the terms of the Convention.

In November 1989, Justice Elizabeth Evatt of the Australian Law Reform Commission indicated that, in order to bring Australia's laws into basic conformity with the convention, it may be necessary for legislative action to be taken in many areas, including family law, marriage, children's legal services, social security and adoption. That was in November 1989 and I suspect, in pointing to these areas, Justice Evatt had in mind that Federal and State parliaments should, prior to ratification, review their laws and, where necessary, make changes in order to ensure that prior to ratification Australian laws conform with the provisions of the convention. That was certainly the practice adopted in my time as Minister for Foreign Affairs but, as we all know, it is not uncommon for this Government to first ratify and then to legislate.

This is a very sensitive issue to some. We in the Opposition have been in favour of ratification, but with the reservations referred to. I have to say on this issue that the Government has been arrogant in its pursuit of ratification and delinquent in not expressing reservations. Such reservations would have been proper; such reservations would have clarified the inconsistencies I have referred to with other international instruments; and such reservations would have underlined a proper concern for parental rights.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bevis Mr A.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), both in his speech and in moving the motion, is seeking to play to an audience of fear and ignorance. It may be that in the twilight of his political career he is reverting to a well tried and tested approach to politics which he learned in his youth in this place during the 1960s, when fear politics dominated the national Parliament. In his speech he referred to various conventions and issues but seldom actually referred to the document the subject of the motion.

SPEECH.PARA: I propose to deal with a number of those clauses he referred to and to set in context those matters that he has in his motion taken out of context. The question of the opportunities and rights of children not only in Australia but also throughout the world is an important issue. The honourable member referred in passing to the preamble. The preamble is important because it sets the tone and the basis upon which all subsequent articles should be read and interpreted. It is worth quoting two sections of the preamble, which clearly put in context those matters that the honourable member for Kooyong has sought to misrepresent:

Convinced that the family, as the fundamental group of society and the natural environment for the growth and well-being of all of its members and particularly children, should be afforded the necessary protection and assistance so that it can fully assume its responsibilities within the community.
Recognising that the child, for the full and harmonious development of his or her personality, should grow up in a family environment, in an atmosphere of happiness, love and understanding.

Those clauses from the preamble clearly give a commitment to the overriding importance of the family as the basis upon which development and protection of the child should occur. Not only has this view been adopted by the Australian Government but it has also been unanimously endorsed by the countries of the world. Within Australia it has received the endorsement of groups involved in church and welfare activity. Let me refer to just a couple. In May 1990 the Age reported the endorsement by the Catholic bishops of the United Nations convention. On 7 May the Age reported:

The Roman Catholic bishops' conference yesterday strongly recommended that Australia ratify the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child. The bishops, who are holding their biannual conference in Sydney, expressed `wholehearted support' for recent international moves to overcome abuse of children's rights, including cruelty to and torture of children and the forced separation of families, especially refugees.

That is the very point of the United Nations convention: it sets out to protect children in less advantaged situations, not only in relatively wealthy countries such as our own but also in those poorer nations of the world where the rights of the young are ignored and abused. But it was not just the Catholic bishops who held that view. The Uniting Church issued a statement earlier in November 1989. The President of the Uniting Church, Sir Ronald Wilson, welcomed the United Nations convention and he said:
The Convention gives strong support to all countries of the world in their efforts to protect children from sexual exploitation, physical abuse or separation from parents.

As a church leader of some renown in this country, he urged the Government to sign the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child. In May 1990 we had not signed, and Sir Ronald Wilson again went to the press. On 9 May the Age reported:
Sir Ronald, a former High Court judge, who is also national president of the Uniting Church, attacked the `misinformation' spread by groups opposed to the convention . . .

It is that misinformation that the honourable member for Kooyong is peddling here today. He is seeking to play on that misinformation and the concerns within the community which that misinformation has generated. On 9 May Sir Ronald Wilson criticised the Australian Government for not having signed the convention. So we have both the Uniting Church and the Catholic bishops very early in the piece supporting the convention and urging the Australian Government to become a signatory to it.

There is no doubt that the convention, firstly, enshrines the pre-eminent role and responsibility of families, and, secondly, makes clear some basic principles upon which the rearing of children, their rights in a civilised community, should be protected.

It has not been just the Commonwealth Government that has been involved in this process; the States have all been consulted throughout the development of this convention. As the honourable member for Kooyong knows only too well, that convention has been developed over a 10-year period. An entire decade was devoted to the discussion and development of those principles that were unanimously adopted by the United Nations. Every State of Australia was involved in those consultations with the Commonwealth. Every State of Australia agreed that the convention should be supported. I believe that at the time that included a National Party State government in my State of Queensland-a National Party government which was not all that well renowned for respecting civil liberties.

There are, of course, many other aspects of the convention which clearly demonstrate the protection afforded to children, but in a sensible and controlled manner. There are too many for me to refer to here. I thought I would illustrate just a couple. It might be best if I start with those that the motion specifically refers to. The honourable member for Kooyong has referred to articles 13, 14, 15 and 16. I want to refer to a couple of those because the same sorts of safeguards are built into each of them. Article 13 deals with the child's right to freedom of expression. The very next sentence, which the honourable member for Kooyong failed to relate to the House, says:
The exercise of this right may be subject to certain restrictions . . .
It then lists the restrictions, which are:
For respect of the rights or reputations of others;
and the next one, which is important:
For the protection of national security or of public order, or of public health or morals.

I, along with many people in this chamber, have received letters of concern and phone calls from constituents who believe that the moral upbringing of their children is somehow put at risk by this United Nations convention. Nothing could be further from the truth, for this convention protects those very rights. In selectively quoting and dealing with the United Nations convention, the honourable member for Kooyong and those who have adopted his position in this debate ignore the safeguards that are built in and ignore the intention of the convention to adequately protect the interests of the young people of the world.

There are, as I said, many countries that have signed endorsement of the United Nations convention. At my last look at the records, 130 nations had endorsed it. They include, just to mention a few, Canada, France, Greece, Israel, Italy, Japan, New Zealand and the United Kingdom. I select those because in some respects they have cultures and backgrounds similar to our own, and in some respects they have governments of a far more conservative persuasion, and in some cases a strongly religious persuasion. Yet each of those countries has signed the convention without qualification, because they understand, as the honourable member for Kooyong should, the intention of the convention and realise the safeguards which have been built into it.
The other clause which it is important to place on the record is article 5 of the convention, which again restates the importance of the family. Article 5 says:

States parties shall respect the responsibilities, rights and duties of parents or, where applicable, the members of the extended family . . . as provided for by local custom, legal guardians or other persons legally responsible for the child, to provide, in a manner consistent with the evolving capacities of the child, appropriate direction and guidance in the exercise by the child of the rights recognized in the present Convention.

That is important because it refers to parental control being provided in a manner consistent with the evolving capacities of the child. I have had people come to me who say that signing this convention will mean that their 13-year-old teenagers will be able to walk the streets, go down Kings Cross, go to whatever shows they like, and do whatever they may wish to do, without any intervention on the part of parents, because this somehow gives them that right. It is a nonsense to suggest that-for two very important reasons. First, the existing laws of the country and the States do not allow it. For any of these things to have an impact, we all know in this place that the laws must first be changed by due process in this Parliament. That is a matter which has been overlooked by those opposite. Secondly, it is nonsense because the convention very expressly points out that it is according to the `evolving capacities of the child'. That is clearly left to the states parties to the agreement to determine.

Nowhere in the United Nations document can one draw evidence to sustain the quite erroneous and mischievous arguments that the honourable member for Kooyong has put today and which those pursuing that line have peddled throughout the country in recent months. In putting their view, those opposite should talk to the Bishops Conference and the Uniting Church and explain their perverted view of the United Nations convention because it is not a view shared by those religious bodies, nor is it one shared by the rest of the world-certainly the 130 nations which have signed the convention, most without qualification.

But for the restrictions of time, I could quote chapter and verse other sections of the convention which include similar riders as to the rights that, on reading selectively, might be misinterpreted as giving children some claim over and above the authority of parents and the laws of the state. But I think I have illustrated adequately in the clauses to which I have referred the fact that the convention is designed to enshrine the role of the family.

I would like to say in conclusion that this motion and the debate which has been fostered around it are mischievous. They play to an audience of ill-informed but honest and caring parents. In talking to those honest and caring parents, I am distressed to witness their anguish caused by this mischievous debate. The mover of this motion is, by his actions today in the Parliament, in the same class as those scaremongers who, out of ignorance or malice, misrepresent the United Nations, this convention and the Australian Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fisher Mr P.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion moved by the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) which seeks to ensure that the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child safeguards the inalienable rights and responsibilities of parents. In particular, the coalition's concern relates to articles 12, 13 and 28, 14, 15 and 16 which refer respectively to the freedom in expression, education, religion, association and privacy.

SPEECH.PARA: I had the opportunity to attend the forty-fourth session of the United Nations General Assembly as one of two parliamentary advisers. It was at this forty-fourth session that the Convention on the Rights of the Child was adopted. It was the culmination of 10 years of debate, compromise and effort to establish a standard in the field of human rights, in this instance, children's rights.

The United Nations (UN) has many failings. We can question its cost, its lumbering bureaucracy, the loss of impact as it strives for consensus, its frequent interference in matters of a domestic nature and its selectiveness of action, particularly in relation to breaches of human rights. We can be concerned that since its formation in 1945, its political make-up has not favoured the democratic private enterprise philosophy that many of us in Australia pursue.

On this point I note that this session of the UN corresponded to a period of rapid and extreme change in eastern Europe, where people in Poland, East Germany, Czechoslovakia and Bulgaria repudiated their communist regimes and where the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics changed its approach to the United States and her allies. Such radical changes will no doubt bring significant changes to voting patterns and the range of issues pursued. The recent stance of the United Nations in relation to the invasion of Kuwait by Iraq is the first major example of this and provides the UN with a real opportunity to exert a positive role in the area of disarmament, removing oppression and peacekeeping.

It is difficult for most of us living in Australia to comprehend the concerns expressed by the members of the United Nations at the forty-fourth assembly at the horrible abuse of children in many parts of the world. This convention therefore was not born out of a desire for some sinister form of social engineering, as some attempt to destroy our moral fibre and standards or some insane attempt to reduce personal responsibility or initiative to mediocrity. It was born out of a genuine desire to eradicate the exploitation of children in so many countries where children are treated as no more than chattels, countries where some children are maimed so that they will be physically more conducive to begging, countries where young children of 12 and 13 years of age are sent to war, countries where young girls or eight and nine are forced into prostitution, countries where children are sold for human organ transplants and countries where poverty and child labour offends basic human dignity.

I can understand the concerns of parents in Australia who have watched the decline of the family in Australia at policies they believe promote an anti-child, anti-family mentality. I can also understand the concerns of the community at the growth of social counselling services, most of which operate with integrity and compassion, but with some who become social detectives with a capacity for overriding and interfering with parents' legitimate and responsible controls and discipline within the family.

However, I am appalled at the false information which has filtered around the network of our community scaring parents and offending the truth on this issue. One of the most extreme and silly suggestions that we have heard is that the convention will even stop parents removing smelly socks or stale lunches from children's schoolbags. I particularly wish to refer to an advertisement placed through a large number of newspapers in my electorate during the last election campaign. I wish particularly to refer to those articles of the convention on which this concern is expressed. For example, this advertisement reads:
Parents are not allowed to place any restrictions on what a child sees, reads, hears, is taught at school or experiences in any way.
It refers to article 13, and I wish to read that from the convention:

The child shall have the right to freedom of expression; this right shall include freedom to seek, receive and impart information and ideas of all kinds, regardless of frontiers, either orally, in writing or in print, in the form of art, or through any other media of the child's choice.
But it has a second clause. That second clause says:
The exercise of this right may be subject to certain restrictions, but these shall only be such as are provided by law and are necessary:
(a) For respect of the rights or reputations of others; or
(b) For the protection of national security or of public order, or of public health or morals.
I also refer to another point in this particular article:
Parents are not allowed to influence in any way a child's view of morality or religion.
We can go to article 15 of the convention to see what it does say, and it says:
States Parties recognise the rights of the child to freedom of association and to freedom of peaceful assembly.
Part 2 says:
No restrictions may be placed on the exercise of these rights other than those imposed in conformity with the law-
I emphasise `our law'-

and which are necessary in a democratic society in the interests of national security or public safety, public order, the protection of public health or morals, or the protection of the rights and freedoms of others.
It is this type of misinterpretation or acceptance without question that inhibits, in this country, rational debate and understanding of this sensitive issue.

The coalition, I believe, and in particular the honourable member for Kooyong have rightly expressed reservations about the interpretation of this convention. My colleague, as I said, has explained these. The family is a network, and a fundamental group in society. It is the unit where children are best nurtured, loved, given affection, develop good relationships and learn how to participate in that society. The family in law has prior rights over any State laws, including those domestic laws enacted as a result of an international agreement. This law cannot be too strong, as breach of that law and errors in the exercise of that law have produced isolated but tragic outcomes.

There are, however, two dangers with the convention which I wish to emphasise in conclusion. Firstly, the ratification of this convention must not become a cover-up for the neglect of children at home or abroad. I have already mentioned some policies which many people consider promote anti-child and anti-family mentalities. Each of us would classify within our own views many of these.

On the overseas front we see some paradox-some would say hypocrisy-that in a year of the ratifying of the Convention of the Rights of the Child, we have seen overseas aid has been slashed by this Government by $98m. At the same time the Government has increased grants to some dubious international groups, through the United Nations, which support unacceptable population control programs and gross violations of human rights. Secondly, there is the issue of misinterpretation by enthusiastic social engineers, by United Nations monitoring committees, or even, at times, by our own judicial system.

The Government takes the view that Australian laws conform with this convention, with the exception of article 37(C) and its requirement that child and adult criminal offenders be imprisoned separately. Accordingly, Australia has, quite rightly, lodged a reservation to article 37(C). In light of the fact that the Government believes that Australian laws are consistent with the convention it is not envisaged that there will be any changes to domestic laws as a result of ratification.

I conclude by saying that the convention provides that parties may make reservations at the time of ratification. The coalition has always maintained that before Australia ratified the convention appropriate reservations should be made in order to expressly respect the rights and responsibilities of parents. I believe that the time has come when this Parliament should have a greater role, particularly in regard to some of these important conventions which cause concern in the community. I believe such conventions should be debated more fully within our parliamentary process before ratification takes place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr L.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the few minutes left in this debate on the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child I will also try to allay some of those fears expressed by the Opposition today. Some of the misleading statements made in the community since the convention was first mooted concern me greatly. It is a disgrace that in some quarters this has been done to play politics more than anything else. I doubt very much that those honourable members opposite, if in government, would not accept the convention as it stands.

SPEECH.PARA: Like other members of this House, I am sure, I have a great respect for the family unit in our society. The family unit is something we have argued in favour of for many years. For example, one important aspect of industrial relations is the provision of proper standards and conditions for people in the work place. When we look at the history of the trade union movement over many, many years we see that it has done a lot to protect families; parents have more opportunities to spend time with their children, and children are not forced into slave labour-as was the case before the trade union movement hit its straps. We see that honourable members opposite now wish to try to erode many of the tremendous things the trade union movement has developed over many years to protect the rights of individuals.

I was concerned this morning to hear the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) stating on radio what the Opposition would do if, by some great tragedy, it were ever returned to the government benches. Fortunately for the Australian people, I cannot ever see that happening with some of the policies the Opposition is planning at the moment. The very things that the honourable member talked about on radio represented an attack on our families and, of course, the rights of the children in those families. When he talks about trading seven days a week, 24 hours a day, we realise that the people who would really suffer would be the individuals and their families. I think it would be of great concern to us all if that were ever to happen.

One of the important matters overlooked in this debate is article 5 of the convention. That article is extremely important because the pre-eminent role of the family is recognised. Indeed, the Australian delegation to the United Nations can take pride in the fact that article 5 of the convention was actually inserted at its initiative. This article confirms the overriding role of parents in the development of children and their right and responsibility to provide direction and guidance to children in the exercise of the rights set out in the convention.

It is often forgotten that we do not own our children; we are probably only loaned our children for a short time. They are always a great source of enjoyment to us. They are not a chattel, as the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Peter Fisher) mentioned before; certainly not. Children are individuals and have rights. We as parents have the obligation to look after them and to try to guide them in the best way we can. In no way is that inveighed against in article 5. Certainly it is not the case that parents can think they own their children. Effectively, they are only on loan to us. It is our right, our responsibility more so, to bring the children up in a society that we believe is a good place for us all to live in. Certainly the convention in no way attacks that responsibility.

Two errors have been floundering around in this debate. Firstly, there is the failure to apply correctly the rules of the treaty interpretation that are set out in the Vienna Convention on the Law of Treaties, which Australia ratified in 1974 and which actually came into force internationally on 27 January 1980, when the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) was in fact the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Of course, the second error is a failure to apply correctly the basic rules of construction of the English language. Those two aspects have been misconstrued throughout this whole debate.
I realise that I have run out of time, but I have welcomed the opportunity to say something about this matter today and to oppose the motion put forward by the honourable member for Kooyong.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday. The honourable member will have leave to continue his speech when the debate is resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scholes The Hon G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House:
(1) is concerned at the enormous growth in the amount of goods stolen from private homes and the apparent failure of police forces to uncover the disposal networks which clearly must exist; and

(2) calls on the Minister for Justice to establish a special Commonwealth/State task force drawn from the various law enforcement organisations to carry out a comprehensive investigation into the movement of, and subsequent disposal of, the extremely large amounts of goods being stolen from private homes.

My purpose in moving this motion is to draw attention to the need for far greater levels of resources-and that may mean additional resources allocated to police forces-to be devoted to combating the extraordinarily high incidence, and very low recovery rate, of goods which are stolen, mainly from residential dwellings, in Australia. Unfortunately, statistics are normally a couple of years old when one gets to them, but the statistics for the breaking and entering of dwellings are alarming, to say the least. Ten per cent of the population of Australia are affected by break-ins; something like 1,700 to 1,800 dwellings per 100,000 were broken into in 1988-89. The volume of goods being stolen is enormous. We all hear of minor break-ins where a few valuables are stolen, but an increasing number of break-ins involve the removal from the property of almost its entire contents-a furniture van has pulled up at the house and, in broad daylight, every item in the house has been removed.

Thousands and thousands of tonnes of household goods, ranging from clothing to television sets to jewellery, are being stolen every week. This cannot be disposed of through non-organised marketing; there are just not sufficient outlets without a proper sequence of events from the person who has committed the break-in to the person who is really making the profits-that is, the person who is fencing and disposing of the stolen goods.

These are not the sorts of items one will find resold in shops and they certainly are not disposed of, as rumour would have it, at a table in the pub or across the bar. They are being disposed of professionally by networks that are organised for that purpose and that are targeting areas for break-ins and robberies. Accompanying this is a growing degree of violence. For instance, recent headlines in the Canberra Times indicate that there has been a trebling of the incidence of violence and juvenile break-ins in the Australian Capital Territory-not one of the more deprived communities in our society.

In some parts of Australia, the premium on insurance paid by every householder merely to cover dwelling break-ins is now in excess of $50 a year.
