Police resources in large numbers are devoted to traffic violations usually of a relatively minor nature, because nowadays traffic violations tend to mean exceeding the speed limit and nothing else, where there is an automatic fund raising exercise for the various State governments. Police resources are also devoted to operations against drugs. I do not disagree with that: however, marijuana operations seem to take up an enormous amount of resources.

There is a need to deal with the crime which affects the majority of the community in the most difficult way. Those people who have had their homes broken into feel a very significant psychological effect. It is a personal thing. Whilst the difficulty of detection or prevention of individual break-ins is extremely difficult-we just cannot have armies of police going up and down every street- the disposal of the goods that are stolen, given the volume and nature of those goods, should at least be capable of being dealt with. There can be no doubt that the disposal networks have to be highly profitable, highly organised commercial organisations, probably posing as legitimate business.

Some statistics that I have been able to find-unfortunately, a lot is confidential-indicate that in 1989 burglaries accounted for property valued at $1.2 billion. In anyone's language, that is a very big business and, I would suggest, a highly profitable one. The number of convictions, and the rate of recovery, is extraordinarily low. In fact, it rarely achieves a level above 10 per cent of the total, which means that burglary is not only a highly profitable crime, particularly for those who do not actually carry out the break-ins but sit in the background and collect the money-that seems to be the nature of criminal activities-but is also a criminal activity which has a very low risk of detection.

Again using figures a couple of years old-and they probably have not changed materially-the number of break-ins of dwellings which have resulted in convictions is well below 10 per cent. If one considers the sentences that are imposed and the way in which the court goes about hearing cases of burglary, one could get the impression that some sections of the courts believe that it is a social ill, not a crime. If someone arrives at their home after having been away for a day and finds that because the burglars could not get the carpets up they are left but everything else has been stolen or carted away-their wedding presents-and the things that they value have been destroyed as a result of the burglars looking for more valuable goods, then that is a personal crime of great magnitude to that individual.

I ask that the level of resources be increased and that a coordinated task force, and there may well be one in existence, of Commonwealth and State police be devoted to seeking the outlets, the people who buy the goods and encourage the theft-the Mr Bigs. I suggest that to do that adequately there will have to be special funds made available and the Commonwealth will have to contribute.

I reiterate: one in 100 Australians will have their homes robbed this year. On average they will lose more than $1,000-I think the figure is $4,000-worth of goods. Some will be totally wiped out. Every Australian will pay at least $50 extra insurance because of this. It is not too much to make a special effort, because theft and burglary affect far more Australians than some of the more publicised areas of police activity-areas to which a great deal more funding is devoted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ronaldson Mr M.J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe) is anxious to speak, but he will get his chance in due course. I hope the honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes) does not think that I am gunning for him because I happen to be speaking on his second private member's motion in a week.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not think that someone whose house has not been burgled can really appreciate the magnitude of the problems caused by crimes such as burglary. My wife Cate and I were in that unfortunate situation about 18 months ago, and it is a fairly sickening experience. I know it took Cate quite a long time to get over it, and we did not have much to knock off. I suppose in that respect we were luckier than others. To be subjected to that is a sickening and frightening experience.

As the honourable member for Corio said, one in 100 is a very frightening figure. I spent three-quarters of my former life in the courts; and a not inconsiderable time was spent representing people who allegedly or actually had been involved in crimes such as burglary. I do not disagree with the honourable member's motion, but I think it contains a touch of motherhood, and I do not think it really addresses the key issues involved. The honourable member has sought to dissociate drugs from the crimes referred to in his motion, and I would suggest that from my experience--

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I did not do that.

—I appreciate that, but drugs are very much an integral part of this social crime, as I think it is probably best described. I do not believe personally that there is an organised network that disposes of a large percentage of household burglary items; they are disposed of in hotels or retained for personal use. To some extent there is a circuit within which those goods are disposed, whether or not it is highly organised, and its members certainly do not come before the courts. That probably supports the motion of the honourable member for Corio when he says that these people are not coming before the courts.

SPEECH.PARA: I think we should appreciate that there are a large number of factors in this. I do not disagree with the honourable member's statements or with the motion as such, but I think we should have a look at the situation in Victoria, for example. The honourable member for Corio is a Victorian; what we are seeing in Victoria at the moment is a sad and sorry sight. The reality is that we can set a task force up; it might come back with a report, go through the House and we will all say, `Hear, hear!'. But, in the end, what really comes out of it? What will be achieved? What I would like to see achieved is what is not happening in Victoria at the moment. The honourable member for Burke will no doubt address this in due course.

Let us look at the situation in Victoria. We have had a litany of lies and broken promises about the level of policing from Victorian Labor Party Ministers, one of them being Mr Crabb. When Minister Crabb had the job some time ago-I do not know whether he still has the job now-the big claim was that Victoria would have 10,000 police. There are approximately 9,200 police in Victoria at the moment. This was to be the big goal-increase the police numbers and we will save the State. Like so much that has happened in Victoria over the last 12 months, it is lies and further lies. What was claimed has quite simply not happened.

Take Ballarat, for example. This will horrify you, Mr Deputy Speaker. On the night shift in Ballarat, there are a sergeant, six men and two divisional vans. Do honourable members know the area that they potentially cover? The honourable member for Burke and the honourable member for Corio will know the area that I am talking about. Those police go as far as Beaufort, Skipton, Ballan, Clunes and Lexton.

I invite honourable members to get out a map of Victoria, look at where those areas are and talk about this motion. Let us talk about what the real problems are. The real problem is that the police in Victoria quite simply cannot get within a bull's roar of solving the problems that the honourable member for Corio has addressed, problems that I fully concur exist. It is an absolute disgrace.

We have in Ballarat a mini brawl van. Over the last 12 months, there were a large number of trainees in Ballarat. I am sure that they were just put there to calm the troops down for a while. When they were there, the mini brawl van was in use. At the moment, it is sitting idle at night. A sergeant, six people and two divisional vans in an area the size of Ballarat! Mr Max Burnett, who lives in my electorate, is a member of SOLO-that is, Supporters of Law and Order. This is not some right wing organisation, but a group of people who are genuinely concerned about the level of their security.

Twelve months ago some idiot was trying to break into the house of one of my former legal colleagues. The man breaking in was potentially violent. My colleague, at home with his wife and three children, was told when he rang the police that potentially it would be an hour before someone was there-an hour! Here was this fellow at the front door ripping the fly wire screen off, and my colleague was told that it was going to be an hour before someone got there.

This motion looks good on paper. I do not disagree with it. But let us get down to the root cause of the problem-to the reasons why there are these enormous crimes and to the significance of the number of crimes being committed. There quite simply is not significant police membership in Victoria. The situation is deteriorating.

I am pleased to say that after the recently negotiated pay rise-which, mind you, will take 18 months to come into effect-at least we have seen a reversal of the trend. In 1990, 800 recruits were inducted, but there were also 457 resignations and 81 retirements. The Police Academy, the organisation that is training future members of our police force, was closed last year from September until January. The Academy was closed! The homes of a hundred people will be burgled-and that is just the tip of the criminal iceberg-yet the Academy was closed for in excess of three months. I think that is an absolute disgrace.

I suggest to the honourable member for Corio that having moved his motion he go back to Premier Kirner in Victoria and say, `Premier, let's do something about the police numbers in this State. Let's get serious about crime prevention'. I will be bitterly disappointed if the honourable member for Corio is not on the front page of the Herald-Sun tomorrow as having attacked Premier Kirner for not doing something about this. If he is genuinely concerned about the problem, as I am sure he is, that is where he will be directing his attention.

I will support this motion, and I am sure that the honourable members on this side of the House will also support it. But if we are really serious about addressing this extremely important problem, we are going to have to do something about police numbers. My colleague the honourable member for Moore (Mr Filing), a former policeman-and a very good one too, they tell me-I am sure will address this question further. He is also an excellent member of this House.

TALK.START.PARA: —He could have been Chief Commissioner.

—He may well be still, in about 20 years time when he leaves this House. What we should be doing about this is addressing the root cause of the problem. In my electorate, there is an area called Wendouree-and the honourable member for Burke will know the Wendouree area. People in that area have been trying now for in excess of five years to get an increased police presence. It is a rapidly growing area; it has a significant crime rate, as exists right across Ballarat; and the people have pleaded with the Labor Government to do something about it. But their pleas constantly fall on deaf ears. The Government is not prepared to do anything about Wendouree; it is not prepared to do anything about the state of the police force in Ballarat; and it is not prepared to do anything about the state of the police force in Victoria generally.

SPEECH.PARA: I am running out of time and I want to give my colleagues the opportunity to speak further on this matter. But let us start looking at the root cause of the crimes, the abhorrent crimes, that the honourable member for Corio has quite rightly indicated, both in his motion and in the matters he has raised before the House today. I will conclude on the topic of broken election promises.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not enough time.

—That is right. I have only about 30 seconds, not the 10 hours which I would need to talk about broken promises from the Victorian Labor Party. There was a promise of one extra sergeant and six permanent men for the Camp Street police station; one additional divisional van; a brawl van, which is sitting there idle at night; an increase in the neighbourhood rural watch program-what better way to address the question of hideous social crimes than to have a rural network, a community network, to stop these people; and the establishment of a police-in-school involvement program. All these promises have been broken; it goes on and on and on. I agree with the honourable member for Corio, but let us see how serious he and his Party are about addressing the real cause of the problem he is referring to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Keefe Mr N.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had intended to speak in support of the motion and I will do so, I guess, in a rather analytical and statistical way. But I suddenly find myself embraced in a debate with the honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Ronaldson) over a number of quite spurious claims that he has just made, which I will address myself to in a moment. First of all, I want to say that I am seconding the motion of the honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes) because I want to add at least my own perspective to this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: I agree that there has been an increase in the number of break-ins and thefts from homes, but it is a trend that is not new. It is a trend that has been with us for many years and is almost an endemic part of the problem of crime in society. One myth, though, that does exist and is commonly perpetrated about this-and to an extent I think the honourable member for Ballarat ought to give some thought to this-is that this is all in some way caused by the drug problem. Much of the information coming through from police and other evidence is that in fact housebreaking and stealing and the organised nature of that-and I do not use that term in the terms of organised crime and Mr Bigs and that kind of thing, but the organised and structured way by which goods are stolen and then fenced off-is, in fact, not drug related, but is simply the result of a professional approach to housebreaking and stealing. In many instances we hear this myth that somehow it is crazed druggies running around and breaking into people's homes.

I think it needs to be understood that, if it is a professional and organised structure, then it requires professional and organised structures to deal with it. For as long as police have been chasing criminals, we in the parliaments of the world have been asking why do they not have more success in these fields. I would put to honourable members that it is because the traditional forms of policing just simply are not able to cope with these kinds of trends without added weapons.

Some of the weapons that have now been added to the police armoury are very significant. They include moves to the money trail and to the freezing of assets-the ability, in other words, to have a look at the financial affairs of people who are making quite substantial sums of money illegitimately. Those records are there and, through the Government's cash transactions legislation and the proceeds of crime legislation that is now starting to evolve in each of the States-I notice that the honourable member for Corio has strongly suggested that there be Commonwealth-State task forces established-these issues can be further examined and moved on.

I can advise the honourable member, through my experience on the parliamentary committee which oversees the National Crime Authority, that there are in fact-and the honourable member for Moore (Mr Filing) concurs with me-Commonwealth-State task forces being arranged in a number of areas. I have no doubt that they will reveal some quite strange techniques going on around the place to actually launder and dispose of the proceeds of crime. I think this issue is much more sophisticated than the honourable member for Ballarat might otherwise feel.

Having said that, I want to go to, though, what I think is at the root cause of all this. The honourable member for Ballarat gave his litany of problems in the region including not enough police numbers-and I do not deny that in Victoria that is a problem, as it probably is in most States. But here I think is where we come to the essential difference between ourselves and the Opposition. In one of my capacities in this Parliament I am a member of the Prime Minister's country task force. That task force moves around Australia talking to people in all different forums and, for at least the last two years, the message has been coming through very clearly to me that there is no more fat in the system and there is no more scope to cut the public sector and the provision of services.

So, when honourable members on the opposite side of the House come in here and call for an extra $3 billion or $4 billion to be cut from public sector expenditure, what they are really talking about is money for police services, for hospital services, and for schools. Any council we talk to will tell us it does not even have any money for roads. If honourable members opposite accept there is no more fat in the system and yet they come in here and bleat, as they have, about declining police numbers-although at the same time they come in here and say they will cut more money from the public sector-then we have to say: what about these services that honourable members opposite bleat about? Are they talking about transferring money from somewhere else for those services? There is the signal.

Yesterday, the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) in a question, I think it was, to the Minister for Community Services and Health (Mr Howe), representing the Minister for Social Security, Senator Richardson, described the Government as having a $30 billion welfare budget. I presume, because that is the biggest area of spending, that that welfare budget is where a lot of this money is going to come from. Obviously it is not going to come from police, and it is not going to come from schools and road funds and all these other things that honourable members opposite bleat about. What is the major component of the welfare budget? As they describe it, it is pension payments to retirees, to pensioners.

Ordinary age pensioners are now being described as welfare recipients. So when Opposition members tell the public that a coalition government would cut taxes and government sector expenditure, in a country that already is the third lowest tax paying nation in the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development, they will have to tell the public that some of the services that government provides will have to be dispensed with, and they will continually be asked which services will be cut.

This motion draws attention to the problem and recommends that further resources be given to the police and the law enforcement networks to do something about what appears to be an increasing trend in housebreaking and crime. I have no problems with that. However, I ask the House: if it is perceived that increasing police resources is the way to tackle crime, who will pay for it? Obviously it becomes a legitimate part of the tax mix of this country.

Opposition members are very keen to jump up in the debate and make a great play of law and order and the need for more police. That is fine, but they should tell the House where the money will come from. They are the ones who run the debate that too much money is spent in the public sector. They are the ones who want to see more expenditure on defence, more on police, more on this and that, so they should explain where the money will come from to increase these resources.

As to the claims of the broken promises of the State Labor Government in respect of police resources, in my home town we would love to have more police officers, but where will the money come from and who will pay for them? If Opposition members believe there is more fat in the system and that we can cull some of that fat and find the money to pay it that way, they should identify it. We do not hear too much of that any more.

I do not hear of Opposition members visiting country councils and telling them there will be no money for roads. I am sure that at least once a week the honourable member for Ballarat tells the councils in his electorate that they should be getting more money for roads, hospitals, police and school teachers but that they will not have to pay more taxes and in fact a Liberal government would cut more money out of the system. That is a nonsense position, a position of populist cant. I am sorry that the honourable member for Corio found himself moving this motion, which is a good one and has substance. He is prepared to say that of course there need to be resources and there needs to be a tax mix to pay for that.

In their opportunism in supporting the motion those opposite go on with this sort of cant. Let me ask whoever will follow me in the debate-perhaps the honourable member for Moore-to address himself to the question of where in the Opposition's proposal for big cuts in expenditure does the money come from to provide the resources that it says we need.

TALK.START.PARA: —I call the honourable member for Moore.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Filing Mr P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, in speaking to your motion I acknowledge your presence in the chair.

SPEECH.PARA: When constabulary duty's to be done--
To be done,
The policeman's lot is not a happy one--
Happy one.

Those who are fans of Gilbert and Sullivan will recall that particular segment from the sergeant's song in the Pirates of Penzance. In speaking to the motion-and I notice I have a very brief time in which to do so-I wish to say that I have no doubt as to the sincerity of the mover of the motion. I have no doubt that in moving the motion he was acting on behalf of many of his constituents who have been plagued by the terrible, rising increase in crime and criminal behaviour all around the country.

I must point out why, in relation to this motion, the Government is not sincere in the fight against crime. In the legislation before the House in the present session, the Government has introduced a substantial impediment to the objective of recovering stolen property through its Crimes (Investigation of Commonwealth Offences) Amendment Bill, to which I will refer again later. First let me have a quick look at the motion itself. Clause (1) states:
is concerned at the enormous growth in the amount of goods stolen from private homes and the apparent failure of police forces to uncover the disposal networks which clearly must exist;
If we consider this to be factual, and I have no reason to disbelieve the statement, we must ask ourselves, as one famous television professor used to say: why is this so?

First of all, let us look to the past, to past behaviour, in relation to the question of the disposal of stolen property. In the past, to a large extent stolen property was disposed of locally. In the past there was less sophistication in the level of criminal behaviour; there was less criminal intellect, let us say. There was less mobility of criminal offenders and, above all at that time, it was less lucrative because people had less valuable disposable property to steal in the first place.

There was less emphasis on the rights and the interests of the offender vis-a-vis the victim, and we can all see the sort of Marxian view of society where the criminal offender is seen as a victim rather than the perpetrator of evil or wrongdoing. In the past there was a greater fear of detection by police and a greater fear of the prospect for proper punishment.

Let us look at the present. There is no doubt today that offenders are more mobile in committing offences. They are often mobile in stolen vehicles-there has been an enormous increase in the theft of motor vehicles. I can give the House a personal example from my days as a police constable in the Western Australian Police Force. We arrested two juveniles for stealing a car, having chased them through a pine plantation in which they half wrecked the motor vehicle. One of them was on the floor operating the pedals, the other one was standing on the seat operating the steering wheel and the gears. When they went before the Perth Children's Court the next day they were let off with almost no punishment whatsoever. One of the two then proceeded to steal a car in the car park of the Perth Children's Court and went home. I believe that particular person was identified in a photograph in the West Australian newspaper during that time when a very observant photographer with a telephoto lens took a picture of him stealing a car in the car park of the West Australian newspaper or close by.

There is more sophistication in crime today. The high unemployment created by the present Government has resulted in high unemployment amongst young people, and young people are predominantly the higher level of criminal offenders. Of course, because of the high unemployment factor amongst young people-up to 25 per cent to 30 per cent in many communities-there is a higher standard of education amongst offenders, which stands to reason. There are more resources available to criminal offenders-things such as scanners to intercept police messages on their radio networks. It is much more lucrative these days to steal and dispose of stolen property. Things such as video recorders and electronic equipment are far more valuable these days and far easier to dispose of, having been stolen.

There is far more protection and cosseting of offenders these days. There is far more emphasis on the rights and the interests of the perpetrator rather than the rights of the community as a whole. Overwhelmingly, the most crucial reason is the greater workload being experienced by police forces throughout the country.

I want to dispel one myth that is contained in the first clause of the motion before us today-that is, the apparent failure of police to do their job properly, which is implied in that particular clause. In 1980 to 1981, when there were 845,923 offences reported to police throughout the country, there was a clean-up rate of 34.91 per cent. In 1988-89 there were 1,410,065 offences reported-an increase of 66 per cent on the previous figure-yet the clean-up rate was still around 30.07 per cent; in other words, a drop of only about 5 per cent in the clean-up rate.

During the 10 years between 1978 and 1988, police strength rose from 29,441 to 37,875, a rise of only 28.6 per cent. Thus, if we compare the clean-up rate to the rise in the offences reported to police throughout the country and we add the police strength as a factor, we find that there is little statistical evidence-despite the honourable member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe) trying to pretend that his speech contained it-of failure on the part of policing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time for the debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday. The honourable gentleman will have leave to continue his remarks.

DEBATE.TITLE: CHARTER OF RESIDENTS' RIGHTS AND RESPONSIBILITIES

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act

I move this motion-which is in conjunction with notice of motion No. 4, which I will deal with at a later time-to give this House an opportunity to debate a matter that concerns a most important sector of our community, that is, our senior citizens, our old aged, a sector which we believe has been badly neglected by this Government. Some might say, `Why debate these motions now if the charter has been placed into legislation?'. There is a need to do so, because nothing more clearly demonstrates this Government's attitude towards the elderly than this charter. It reflects poorly on this Government and its social justice policy that in the 2 1/2 years in which I have been the shadow Minister for community services and aged care, any legislation on aged care has been hastily drafted, poorly worded and then guillotined through this House with little opportunity for a full and open debate on what I consider to be a most important issue.

The subject of the motions is an excellent example of what I have just said. Taken together with the proposed agreements between the nursing home residents and proprietors, the legislation was drafted very hastily, some of it by consultants, I understand, some by departments, and some by a QC, but not, I understand, by the Attorney-General's Department or by the legislative draftsmen. As a consequence of all of this, in spite of the rush to complete the legislation before Christmas, the agreement and the charter still languish in the hands of the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services (Mr Staples) for a final check at this very late stage on their legality and their constitutionality.

The draft agreement originally circulated by the Department to peak bodies and interest groups was not the agreement tabled by the Minister. A last-minute change-apparently made by his office-had not been notified even to his own departmental head, which may highlight a problem of insufficient contact and dialogue between the Minister's office and the Department.

The amending legislation incorporating the Charter of Residents' Rights was actually guillotined through this House in the space of just 40 minutes to meet the Senate deadline for receiving legislation. If this is the commitment of the Minister or the Labor Government to social justice for the aged in Australia, the aged must find that commitment very shallow indeed. One has only to note the manner in which these original documents were drafted. With the permission of the Minister at the table, the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Crean), I would like to table the charter.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is necessary to put that on record to show what our complaints are and to see how sloppy the drafting was. My original notice of motion set out to make the charter worthy of the formerly high standard that has been set in this Parliament's legislation and to provide a clear path for interpretation and to reduce the amount of unnecessary litigation which may have resulted because of the current sloppy drafting-which is now, unfortunately, incorporated into legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not intend to go through the whole 23 clauses, in both this motion and the other one, to explain this sloppiness fully. I just want to take some particular examples of the cooperation we were offering in putting these resolutions forward. For instance, as to the third amendment, we were looking at the matter from several points of view. The main one was to omit from the preamble the words `freedom and' because in some cases every person within the Commonwealth does not have the complete freedom that was being offered in this case. The explanation we give of that relates to convicted criminals sentenced to imprisonment and insane persons legally committed to institutions who do not have the right of freedom. Right from the beginning the charter sets out a right that is not every Australian's right. We wanted that looked at more comprehensively so that it would reflect the proper situation.

Another amendment we are suggesting is amendment No. (4): that we should omit `A person's rights do not diminish when they move into' and substitute `People's legal and moral rights should not be diminished by reason only of moving into'. Again, the amendment is necessary to clarify the actual meaning. Some people in nursing home situations may, by reason of physical or mental deterioration, lose capacities that they previously had; as for example, the right or capacity to make or revoke a will or to enter into a contract. Unless carefully worded, the charter could mislead residents on issues of this nature.

I now come to what we believe would be a substantive amendment, amendment No. (8), in regard to the heading `Each Resident of a Nursing Home has the RIGHT'. We wanted to insert the following paragraph:

The rights conferred, and the responsibilities imposed, by this Charter are subject to such limits as are imposed by applicable laws and to such other limits as can be shown to be reasonably necessary to ensure that the nursing home operates as a just and supportive community and that harmony is promoted within the community without injustice to any individual.

The explanation of that is that there is a need to incorporate in the charter some provision that will permit the declared rights of and responsibilities towards residents to be abridged for demonstratively just cause.

The Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms declares that the rights and freedoms set out in it are subject only to such reasonable limits prescribed by law as can be demonstratively justified in a free and democratic society. Although it was recognised that the interpretation of that qualification would not be easy, it was universally accepted that some qualification on the general rights and freedoms granted to all Canadians was essential if order were to prevail. Some corresponding provision is necessary in the charter to enable the rights that it confers on all residents in unqualified terms to be enjoyed by all. There were other amendments but, as I said, that was the substantive one.

In amendment No. (12) we sought to incorporate the words `unjust discrimination or victimisation'. Our explanation of that is that at the moment it says, `to live without discrimination'. Discrimination perhaps of itself is not necessarily bad and in some instances is desirable. For instance, in employment, the Australian society discriminates on the basis of efficiency. In some matters we discriminate on the basis of first come, first served. Discrimination in itself is not objectionable. What is objectionable is the use of unjust criteria, such as race, colour or sex, to discriminate in certain situations. That is what we sought to amend in that regard, again just to seek clarification.

In that same clause, the dot point is a good example of sloppy wording. The whole section sets out to describe what a resident's right is and the point is `to live without discrimination or victimisation.'
It then goes on in a fresh sentence:
The resident is not obliged to feel grateful to those providing his or her care and accommodation.

That is not a right. That has nothing to do with the dot point and again demonstrates ungrammatical language when we are trying to set out something that will be clear to interpret later on. In exactly the same way, the seventh dot point, in amendment No. 15 is to read:
to be treated and accepted as an individual.
It then goes on:
Each resident's individual preferences are to be taken into account and treated with respect.
Is that is a right? It certainly does not really apply to the point in question.
As I said, I am not going to deal with all the amendments, but if we go to our eighteenth amendment again the same thing applies there. It reads:
to maintain his or her personal independence, which includes a recognition of personal responsibility for his or her own actions and choices.

Then there is another sentence that really adds nothing to the original right and in fact again could be quite contradictory in some respects. The final dot point, number 18, was changed for the same reason.

I do not have time to go into each one of those, but I wanted to demonstrate that when we came to this debate we came with good intentions and an eye to the future to avoid the type of situation that apparently is now facing the Government as to how it might deal with the suggested legality of the agreement.

These charters are an example of how the Labor Government has failed our senior citizens and of the fact that it takes the aged for granted. It also takes for granted those people who voluntarily and professionally give their time to our aged citizens. Volunteers, working together with paid staff, play an invaluable part in providing the best possible care for our frail elderly and disabled citizens in hostels, nursing homes and within the community. But this Government's initiatives and funding cutbacks during the last session of Parliament are putting intolerable pressures on this important and often unpaid sector of the work force. It has taken entirely for granted the efforts of the voluntary organisations and the capacity of the volunteers to extend themselves yet further.

This is demonstrated by the reduction in funding for nursing home residents; the introduction of geriatric assessment team assessments for residents in hostel care; the abolition of the hostel care subsidy for residents who are not financially disadvantaged; and the residents' rights legislation which introduced the agreement between residents and proprietors in nursing homes. All these measures-and they are certainly not all inclusive-are placing great stress on the voluntary sector and the private sector of aged care. I must caution that Australia cannot do without voluntary workers, yet this Labor Government continues to take them for granted.

During my time as coalition spokesman on aged care, I have tried to cooperate with all the Ministers involved, as I believe that care of the aged is too important to play politics with. But again I give just a few examples where the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services and this Government have played those politics. First, there was no consultation with the coalition in drawing up the draft legislation on residents' rights. Had we been allowed to participate, I believe that the charter and agreement would have been better worded and the threat of future litigation reduced. Again, I offered the Minister my cooperation in redrafting the charter and agreement to a better standard, but that offer was rejected.

Secondly, in the notification of dementia grants by the Minister in January, Government members and senators were given advance notice, whereas coalition members in whose electorates grants were made were notified many weeks later, even though the coalition member would have been closely involved in assisting organisations in getting those grants. Also, it appears to be a policy of this Government and the Minister that when a hostel or other aged care organisation is to be opened in a coalition member's electorate, the Minister demands the right to open the facility and then sends an apology and delegates a Government member to do the job for him, even though that member would have little empathy with the organisation, the community effort involved, or the residents concerned. I say to the Minister, as I did in my letter to him of 18 January-as yet unanswered-that care for the aged is too important for him and his Government to play politics with.

Let us look at the other occasions on which the Government has taken the aged care providers, both in the voluntary sector and in the private sector, for granted. At the time of the Budget last year, without consultation and pre-empting a review of the care aggregated module (CAM) of nursing home funding, the Minister reduced the hours of care in categories three and five effective from 1 September 1990. He also withdrew the hostel care subsidy for non-financially disadvantaged persons as from 7 January 1991.

These measures were estimated to reduce aged care expenditure by approximately $31m but, as I said, the first measure pre-empted the Government's own CAM review and the second retrospectively made a charge on residents and voluntary organisations. This is at a time when admission to hostels has been made subject to geriatric assessment team assessment, which in itself means a greater reliance on the personal care subsidy for all residents. One wonders whether in fact any of the $31m in savings from the withdrawal of the hostel care subsidy will be effected.

Let us also look at the greater pressure being put on staff and providers, both as a result of the reduction of funded nursing home hours and the need to basically treat only categories one to three in nursing homes and categories four to five in hostels, but without the CAM or standard aggregated module, or SAM, funding that normally goes with it, and with only a personal care subsidy, which is of a much lesser amount. Again, the charge of taking residents, staff, providers and volunteers for granted is only too true.

There is another point in the agreement on which I have sought a reply from the Minister, both in writing and in a question on notice. I have asked the Minister whether the Little Sisters of the Poor and other such Catholic nursing homes which do not sign the agreement between proprietor and residents will continue to receive funding. In reply to my question on notice the Minister hedged; he talked around the subject, but he still has not answered my question: will nursing homes which do not sign the agreement continue to receive funding?

I now understand that initial advice given to Catholic nursing homes is that proprietors are under no legal obligation to enter into agreements in the form adopted by the Government and that they should decline to enter into such agreements on the ground that they believe it is not open to them morally to sign agreements in that form. So again the Minister should be asked whether nursing homes which do not sign the agreement will continue to receive funding.

There is another area which has been left open to abuse and that is in respect of the part that the advocates will play, both with the amendments and in the role of aged care. I have given an example to the Minister in connection with the incorrect reporting and the disclosure to the press of the results of one advocate's inquiry into a nursing home. Again, I have asked the Minister about this and I have not yet received a reply as to what will happen in connection with this type of improper activity of disclosing to the press matters which should be properly addressed by the inquiry within the Department itself. There are some extreme examples but one fallen leaf does not make an autumn, as they say.

I want to place on record the good relations and communications I have enjoyed in the discussions on both the charter and the agreement with Mr John Barber, of the Australian Pensioners and Superannuants Federation, and Mr Dominic Gibson, of The Accommodation Rights Service. It has been really great.

It does appear to me that, for those involved in aged care, the Act is administered to distribute funds more for the benefit, the glory and the convenience of the Government and the Department than of the residents for whom the Acts were intended.

I would have liked to have dealt more fully with the current review being undertaken on Commonwealth-State relations in respect of delineation of roles and duplication of functions. If this is to succeed, both the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services and the Minister for Community Services and Health (Mr Howe) will have to take a different attitude from their entrenched position that health and, I assume, related health services, not be transferred. In those circumstances one wonders what point there is of going into something meaningful.

In matters of duplication, it is very important that costs are saved to allow more funds to flow to the aged sector and that those funds be used properly. This is absolutely essential. In that, the devolution question must be raised, not only in connection with funding-because that is only part of it-but also in service delivery, in the assessment, the monitoring and even the industrial awards under which each State functions. This causes a tremendous difference in the CAM application within the funding itself.

In this regard we believe the mid-term review of aged care will not address those matters properly. The consultancy which apparently has been appointed to assist the Government in these discussions between the States and the Commonwealth would need to have better practical experience of what is the reality than I believe it has. That same consultancy was involved in residents' rights, and there is a lot to be said about the manner in which its service was delivered. What I am saying is that if we are going to address the matter properly, we will need to have a more open approach.

It is interesting that from 3 March to 10 March Senior Citizens Week will be observed in New South Wales. Perhaps this is an opportunity for all of us in this chamber-the Government and the Opposition-the Department of Community Services and Health, and all those who play a part in delivering services to the aged, to make some observations.

We should all consider where the main emphasis for aged care should be put. Surely it commences with that senior citizen who has a need and with the necessity to deliver to that individual, that Australian, the appropriate care of the best quality in the most efficient and least costly way. That care must be available equally, and of the same quality, to all Australians, whether they live in Perth, Hobart or in country and rural areas right around the nation. That should be the point from which we commence to devise and develop our policies. That senior citizen himself or herself should be the first priority.

We cannot deliver that quality service if people within government frame sloppy and litigation-prone legislation where there is no certainty. We cannot give that care if local, State and Federal bureaucracies seek to preserve and entrench their positions. A stressed and overregulated proprietor and staff cannot give that professional service to residents. The service cannot be given if volunteers and professionals decide that it is not worth it and their efforts will be in vain.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion and reserve my right to speak later.
