TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that it will suit the convenience of the House for the debate on this and the previous Order of the Day to be conducted concurrently, and if there is no objection I will allow this course.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Melham Mr D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to oppose both motions before the House. The key question to be asked in responding to the offering of the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) is: why is he wasting the time of Private Members' Business by once again raising the Charter of Residents' Rights and Responsibilities and the agreement between nursing home proprietors and residents?

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation has already been debated in detail by both Houses of the Parliament. It certainly looks as though he is blatantly attempting, in a pathetic manner, to bucket the responsible Minister. It is a cheap political stunt designed to create further opposition and needlessly stir up controversy for his own ends.

All the issues raised by the amendments of the honourable member for Dawson have been previously dealt with by this Parliament, and he is well aware of this. Who is going to thank him for wasting the Parliament's time? Not the people living in nursing homes and hostels who have been waiting for the protection offered by the charter and the agreement for many years. Certainly not the industry-union and consumer groups-who have dedicated years of work. These groups, along with consumers, who are the ones directly affected by these reforms, are supportive of the legislation passed by the Parliament. They will not thank the honourable member for Dawson for trying to undermine their years of work and their commitment to improving the lot of nursing home and hostel residents.

The honourable member's position shows a blatant disregard for the basic principles of social justice which are widely recognised and, indeed, demanded by Australian society today. His action aims at denying the rights of residents and those who care for them. The only people who might appreciate the efforts of the honourable member for Dawson are those who would deny people living in nursing homes and hostels their basic rights, including the fundamental right to choose their own doctor.

In regard to the doctor of choice, this has been an enforceable standard in Commonwealth funded nursing homes for the past three years. If this has not been a problem for nursing home proprietors and their boards in the past, why is this now a problem for the honourable member for Dawson? I understand that the honourable member has interests in the nursing home industry. Does he afford his residents such a fundamental human right as doctor of choice?

The Charter of Residents' Rights and Responsibilities is a document which sets the standard for care provided in nursing homes and hostels. It makes the issue clear. Older people and residents of nursing homes and hostels must be treated with respect and dignity. That is the issue that we are debating here. It states that residents are individuals who must be able to continue to make their own choices about what is right for them. These principles are the usually unstated essence of a society which is free from prejudice and is caring, just and humane.

The philosophy behind the agreement is that it gives individual residents the private right to ensure that they receive care commensurate with their needs, and that this care is of the highest standard.

Honourable members will remember that before the Parliament considered the charter and the agreement, the Government undertook an extensive process of consulting all groups who had a vested interest in providing residential care to older people. The industry, relevant unions and of course consumer representatives were all extensively consulted. This was a national consultation process which spanned a period of several years. The protracted and exacting process undertaken by the Government to ensure that all points of view were taken into account has resulted in the worthwhile documents ultimately passed by Parliament.

What the honourable member for Dawson has given us now in these two motions is simply a re-run of those that he put forward to Parliament to consider last year. Of the 23 amendments relating to the Charter of Residents' Rights and Responsibilities, he has included four which the Parliament approved last year, and they are amendments 1, 9, 10 and 21. The Parliament rejected the other 19. What he is proposing, therefore, is a nonsense.

That aside, and more importantly, the majority of the amendments to the charter now put by the honourable member for Dawson would place unnecessary caveats and limitations on the rights of residents. These would weaken the position of residents. Signing of an agreement by both the resident and the proprietor will secure the rights of both parties and enable them to take action to enforce their rights on their own behalf.

It is also a condition of approval that the proprietor comply with the conditions of the agreement, once signed by both parties. If proprietors refuse to offer or sign such an agreement there is a range of options which the Government may pursue, including withdrawal of funding. That said, the decision to take action against a proprietor who refuses to offer or sign the agreement would be taken in the overall context of the level of care and accommodation provided by that nursing home.

The welfare of the resident is of paramount concern; that is what the charter is all about. That is what the honourable member for Dawson seeks to deny. Let us not underestimate what the charter is about and the detrimental effect that the honourable member for Dawson's proposition will have on the lives of 103,000 frail older people living in the relevant nursing homes and hostels.

Let me reiterate the basics of the issues at hand here: these documents espouse fundamental human rights as they relate to the provision of care for frail older Australians. They put into practical effect the Government's social justice principles. These principles are not ideals; they are the same rights which each and every one of us take for granted every day, such as the freedom to control one's own life and the right to privacy and dignity, to be treated with respect. That is what the Government is on about, not discriminating against frail older Australians. They are entitled to the same dignity and rights as other Australians. They are not second-class citizens, as the honourable member for Dawson and the Opposition would have them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gallus Mrs C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion, which seeks to amend the hastily conceived and poorly drafted legislation on residents' rights that was pushed through the House, under guillotine, on 20 December 1990. I must say that I have not heard quite as much nonsense in a long time as I have just heard from the honourable member for Banks (Mr Melham), who obviously has not read anything on the subject on which he has spoken.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Banks mentioned doctor of choice. I ask him to look at the proposed Opposition amendments, because he will see nothing at all about doctor of choice. The honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) and I believe very strongly that residents should have their doctor of choice. We have not mentioned, in any shape or form, that residents should not have their doctor of choice. We do not deny residents their rights. In fact, what we are about is giving residents rights. We wish to clarify residents' rights so that they know what they are. The Government's interest in this matter is evident when it puts forward an honourable member who does not even understand what it is that the Government is opposing. We respect the elderly, and we want their rights to be clear.

The honourable member for Banks said that this matter had been fully debated. I remind the honourable member that it was not fully debated because debate on the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Bill was guillotined. That is why the amendments proposed by the honourable member for Dawson were not considered. So much for the comments of the honourable member for Banks.

The honourable member for Banks also said that the elderly must be treated with respect and dignity. He will find no argument with that on this side of the House. We strongly agree that the elderly must be treated with respect and dignity. I would have liked the Charter of Residents' Rights and Responsibilities to have done the same thing for the elderly.

The amendments which my colleague has sought to make to the original charter indicate the lack of thought that went into drawing up the charter. They question not only the competence of those people drawing it up but also the sincerity of the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services (Mr Staples).

If the Minister really thoroughly understood the area of aged care, he would have had concerns about the preamble to the charter that specifies, `every person has the right to freedom'. I will ignore the obvious comment that every person does not have the right to freedom. If every person did have that right, we would not have gaols. I question how the Minister would see this actually applying to nursing homes where approximately 60 per cent of residents suffer from dementia. What would the Minister suggest the nursing homes do with residents with dementia-the resident who thinks it is 1960 and that she is still living on a farm? Would he suggest that she have total freedom to leave the building, to leave the grounds, to be run over by a truck on the road; for the nursing home to be sued by the resident's family for lack of care? It is nonsense. `Every person has the right to freedom.' That sounds good if one does not think about it. That is what the Government is all about-sounding good.

Have Government members-or the three who are in the House-actually read the Charter of Residents' Rights and Responsibilities and the agreement the Government has trumpeted as proof of its concern for the frail elderly? I will bet they have not. I would be surprised if the Minister had read it, too. If the Minister has not, it is a reflection of the importance that he gives to this document. On the other hand, if the Minister has read the document and approved it, I ask what he is doing as Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, because it is a hideously worded document. It reflects poorly on the Minister. It reflects poorly on his competence and on his knowledge of the frail elderly who reside in nursing homes.

I will read from the Charter of Residents' Rights and the agreement. However, before I do, let me tell the Government members who are in the House about the document. The charter and the agreement are to go to the residents of nursing homes when they are admitted. Altogether there are 16 pages. The resident is expected to read the document and sign it. Remember that we are not talking about someone in his or her prime, confident and fully in charge; we are talking about an extremely frail elderly person who has been judged by an assessment team to be frail enough to require permanent nursing care. This frail elderly resident, who will have a number of illnesses, is expected to read, understand and sign this document, despite possible failing eyesight, diminished faculties, trembling hands and the enormous fear that dislocation into a nursing home has caused. Let us look at what this resident faces. Paragraph 4.2 on page 3 states:

The proprietor shall provide to the resident such services, facilities and goods as are agreed from time to time in accordance with Clause 5 and the proprietor shall set out a list of the services, facilities and goods ordered by the resident in a document which shall then be attached to the Agreement and shall be amended from time to time to reflect the changing requirements of the resident.
My frail elderly will just love that one. Let us look at paragraph 15.1 on page 6. It states:
The resident may not be moved from the resident's bed location to another bed location in the nursing home except . . .
(b) on bona fide medical or other care grounds, as provided for in ``Clause 15.3; and/or
(c) Where the nursing home becomes an exempt nursing home in the circumstances set out in Clause 15.4.

We can just see a 76-year-old resident, who has just had a stroke, asking a nursing sister who wants to move him to another bed to prove that he falls under 15.3! I would read clause 15.3 to the House except that it contains 20 lines. I would not want to send Government members to sleep. The whole thing is a farce. It sounds good, but in reality it terrifies those people for whose benefit it is designed-the frail aged.

Of course, there is a provision for residents to have an advocate read the document and sign it for them; in the first instance, a family member. I can tell the Minister, because I have read the charter and the agreement, and I suspect he has not, that it is not only the residents who will have trouble with the convoluted document; so will the relatives. I would like the Minister to tell me how many relatives does he envisage reading 16 pages and checking up on clause 5, which is referred to in clause 17 (a) (i), clause 21.3, when it is referred to in clause 21.5, and clauses 21.3, 21.3 (f) and 21.4 (e), when they are referred to in clause 21.7?

Now, the final irony. What about those residents for whom English is not their native language? We have heard nothing from the Minister to suggest that those residents from non-English speaking backgrounds will receive the charter and agreement in their own languages. But perhaps the Minister realises that there is little point as it is incomprehensible in English and there is no need to make it incomprehensible in Italian, Greek or Vietnamese. At present we have 70,000 residents in nursing homes in Australia. This means 140,000 signed agreements-one for the resident and one for the home-and 140,000 times 16 equals 6,160,000. That is over six million sheets of paper that no-one will read. Pity the poor trees.

It is not just the form of the charter of rights and agreement that is such a mess; it is also how the Government intends to have it administered. From time to time nursing homes rearrange beds so that, for instance, Mr Smith who has arthritis but who is mentally alert is not roomed with three residents who have advanced dementia. The agreement requires that in order to be moved a resident needs to give assent, but people with dementia cannot give informed consent, so the client's advocate has to be contacted. When the advocate cannot be contacted the nursing home has to call in a Commonwealth medical officer to assess the propriety of the move. This has to be done for every single resident that is to be moved. I suspect that if this is needed in order to move three residents with dementia from a four-bed room to a three-bed room, it will not be done and poor Mr Smith will have to go where he is put because rearrangements are too much trouble.

There is no question that residents in nursing homes should have rights, but this Government does not understand individual rights. If it did, it would not have created such a piece of nonsense as the Charter of Residents' Rights and Responsibilities and the agreement. If it really understood its clientele it would have made the charter and agreement short, lucid and easy to understand. I suspect that this Government has no real concern for individuals. It likes them en masse; it likes to provide a philosophy for the frail elderly, but it does not actually get down there and find out what it is really like to be one of the frail elderly. This Government is great on rhetoric-the rights of the frail elderly, the rights of the disabled. Unfortunately, when one looks below the rhetoric the reality is somewhat different.

Let us look at what the Government is actually doing for the frail elderly in nursing homes, as opposed to what it is talking about. In South Australia it has cut nursing home hours from an average of 21.6 hours per resident per week to 19.5. At the same time, the frailty criteria for entry into nursing homes has been increased. We now have frailer residents getting a lower amount of care-that is the Government's social justice for you. This means that staff do not have time to actually talk to residents but, rather, spend their time cleaning, feeding and peeing residents. There is no longer time for personal contact. Nurses are quitting the industry because they are tired and because it is distressing to them no longer to be able to give the level of care they once gave.

If the Minister were really serious about improving the lot of the frail elderly he would not have cut back South Australia to bring it into line with other States; he would have raised other States to the level of South Australia. It is not only the Minister who makes fine, grand-sounding speeches about what he is doing for those under his charge. The Minister for Community Services and Health (Mr Howe) also tells us how much he cares for the disabled and how much he is doing for them, while the number of intellectually disabled people who are without activities and who cannot find accommodation increases day by day. Meanwhile, the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services introduces the per capita equalisation scheme so that South Australia is brought back into line with the other States. Some social justice policy.

The elderly do have rights; nursing homes have responsibilities. But this Government, with more thought for the appearance than for the substance, has chosen one of the most unwieldy ways possible to recognise this. I trust that these amendments moved by the honourable member for Dawson will go some way towards repairing the Government's suspect endeavours in this field.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dubois Mr S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —My colleague the honourable member for Banks (Mr Melham) condemned the Opposition's tactics on the grounds that they were designed to delay the implementation of the Charter of Residents' Rights and Responsibilities and the agreement, passed by Parliament in December last year. I feel compelled in the circumstances to remind the shadow Minister for community services and aged care, the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite), of the rationale behind the charter and the agreement. These documents put the Government's social justice principles into practical effect. They are part of the philosophy and the framework that should underpin the provision of services and care to older Australians in nursing homes and hostels. These people depend on others for care and support on a daily basis.

SPEECH.PARA: The charter also protects staff and proprietors by indicating that the resident has a responsibility to respect their right to work in an environment that is free from harassment. The agreement makes it clear that residents are to accord proprietors and staff the right to freedom from abuse and reprisal, the right to privacy, to individuality and to complain. The charter addresses both quality of care and quality of life issues, and in doing so emphasises that all nursing homes and hostels have two roles: to provide health care services; and to provide residents with their long term and only place of residence-their home. These documents affirm the fundamental rights of our older Australian citizens to be treated in the same way as any other members of our community.

What makes the position of the honourable member for Dawson even more untenable is that these initiatives do not confer any additional rights. The intent of the charter and the agreement is solely to ensure that these fundamental and basic rights-to be treated with dignity and respect as equal members of society-are not taken away from people when they enter a hostel or a nursing home. Specific clauses of the agreement call for proprietors to acknowledge and fulfil their commitment to the provision of quality care to older people in an environment which encourages feelings of personal well-being. The agreement between nursing home proprietors and residents will ensure that there can be no mistake, no misunderstanding and no margin for error when it comes to ensuring that the rights of a person living in a nursing home are protected.

When the Parliament approved the charter and agreement in the last session it provided a clear indication to the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services (Mr Staples) that it wished to have these implemented. Now the honourable member for Dawson is attempting to stymie the Parliament's intent. To top it all off, the honourable member has used a technically incorrect mechanism to retable the amendments to the charter which he tabled last year. No amendments to the charter can be achieved by the process the honourable member for Dawson has involved us in today-and he knows it.

We can only suppose, as my colleague the honourable member for Banks has said, that the honourable member for Dawson simply wants to go on wasting the time of this Parliament. He is also confounding the clear wish of the key industry and consumer representatives to have these initiatives introduced as quickly and effectively as possible. Again, the rationale for his action at this time-after the exhaustive and open process undertaken by the Government in developing and bringing these initiatives into law-is at the very least very suspicious and is in basic contravention of the will of the Parliament and the people. The responsible Minister has now embarked on the process of implementing the charter and agreement for the benefit of the residents of hostels and nursing homes and for the benefit of those concerned for, and involved in, their care and welfare.

The Government is planning to take a measured approach to the implementation in 1991 of the charter and the agreement. The principal components of the implementation strategy will include training, support for proprietors and staff, and information to residents and their relatives. With this widespread support and commitment to put the initiatives into effect and with industry and consumer groups continuing to be consulted at key stages of the implementation, what does the honourable member for Dawson really think he will achieve by rehashing old news?

With the Parliament two months ago recognising the need to protect and promote the rights of our older Australians, it is appalling that the honourable member for Dawson should attempt to reopen the debate on this issue in the manner that he has. Is it not time that the Opposition, and some in the community who provide care to our older Australians, realised that these people are adults, not children; that the care and services provided to older Australians should be in keeping with their adult status; and that certain members of this House stopped wasting the Parliament's valuable time?

It would be better if instead they turned their energy to assisting to implement the Parliament's will. If they did that, they would also be implementing the clear desires of our older citizens and those committed to giving them the quality of care they deserve. Let us get on with the job of caring for older Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House:
(1) deplores the brutality used against the citizens of Lithuania and the deaths of 14 persons arising from the use of force by Soviet troops on 13 January 1991;
(2) condemns the assault by Soviet troops on the Interior Ministry in Riga, Latvia, on 20 January 1991, in which at least four persons were killed and nine injured;
(3) is appalled by the additional threat of force against the democratically elected Parliaments of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania;
(4) demands that the Soviet Union, in accordance with universally accepted principles of human rights, desist from the use of military force and violence against the peoples of the Baltic states;
(5) calls upon the Australian Government, in conjunction with other democratic states, to protest such brutality to the Soviet authorities and in international human rights forums; and

(6) calls upon the Soviet Government to facilitate the peaceful transition to independence of those Republics which have expressed through democratically elected Parliaments, a desire for self-determination.

This motion gives the House another opportunity to place on record-I hope unanimously-its very grave concern about the continuing situation in the three Baltic states. The motion gives the House an opportunity to express its concern about the continuing refusal by the Soviet Union to grant independence, sovereignty and other internationally recognised rights to those three countries which, of course, now have elected parliaments. It gives the House an opportunity yet again to express its very great concern, and to express its concern on behalf of the people of Australia, about the continued suppression of civil and human rights in the three Baltic states by the Soviet Union. It gives the House an opportunity to call on the Australian Government to continue with those protests it has made and to encourage it to be more robust, more resolute and more persistent in making its protests against the abuse of both civil and human rights in the three Baltic states. The motion also gives the House an opportunity to encourage the Australian Government, with all the support and comfort that can be given by a resolution of this House, to continue its protests and leave no stone unturned to ensure that at the end of such protests full civil and political rights are restored to the people of the three Baltic states together with their true and full independence.

The motion that I have proposed is self-explanatory. It seeks to cover both the basic principles involved in this matter and some of the very unfortunate recent events which have occurred in the three Baltic states. Firstly, the motion deplores the brutality which has been committed against the citizens of Lithuania as recently as 13 January of this year when, as honourable members will recall, some 14 persons, and possibly more, were killed as a result of the brutality used by the Soviet authorities against the people of Lithuania.

Secondly, the motion condemns the assault by Soviet troops on the Interior Ministry in Riga, the capital of Latvia. Thirdly, it expresses the concern of the House not only against those acts of brutality which have already occurred, but also about the continued use of force, threats of brutality and the presence of the Soviet Union which hovers over the three Baltic states, with all the necessary implications that the Soviet authorities will use their regular and persistent brutality in those states to deny basic rights to the people of those three countries and to deny them their full independence. In that part of the motion we draw attention not simply to the brutality which has already occurred-as if that were not bad enough-but also to the continuing threat of further brutality and express our concern about that.

Fourthly, the motion turns to matters of very great principle, when it expresses the view of the House that the Soviet Union should stop the use of military force and stop the violence against the peoples of the Baltic states. It also then draws attention to the obligation of the Australian Government to protest about that brutality to the Soviet authorities. It was this clause of the motion which was amended in the Senate because the Government expressed its view there that we were already protesting. It is true to say that the Government has made protests; we give it credit for that. Nevertheless, there is a case for the motion saying, as it does, that there is now an obligation on the Government to go further.

We say that the Government should raise this matter in the United Nations and pursue it there. We also say, as the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) has said, that this matter should be raised in all of the human rights and international fora where the Government can raise it, because concrete results will only be achieved if we make it very plain to the Soviet Union that Western democracies will not let up until independence is granted once again to the Baltic states and until the Soviet Union stops both its demonstration of brutality and the threat of the exercise of continued brutality and force in the three Baltic states.

The other day I had some quite incontrovertible evidence given to me that the peaceful demonstrations and rallies concerning the events in Romania had some considerable effect on the way events unfolded in Romania. In other words, although we cannot claim that the demonstrations that some of us organised and held in Australia about events in Romania were the sole reason why the Ceausescu regime was overthrown, I have been given evidence recently that the actions of the Australian people and the Australian Parliament had a very considerable effect in forming world opinion and, indeed, leading to the changes which took place in Romania. If that can be done with respect to Romania, it can be done with respect to the Baltic states. But it will not be done unless we persist in presenting this case, not only in this Parliament but also in all of the international fora and all of the human rights bodies where we can promote this view.
As I said, the Opposition has made a very clear statement of its position on the whole matter. The Leader of the Opposition has said:
. . . the Soviet authorities must-
and I emphasise `must'-
be left in no doubt that Western support and aid for the Soviet Union can continue only if minimum standards of human rights, including the right of peaceful self-determination, are observed.
Our statement goes on to say-and this is our clear declaration of policy-that the Australian Government:

. . . should take a lead in strongly pressing the Soviet Union, both in its own right and in conjunction with other governments, as well as in the United Nations and other appropriate international forums, to end its illegal occupation of the Baltic states and restore their legitimate independence and sovereignty.

So what the Soviet Union must do, and what we must keep telling the Soviet Union it must do, is end its illegal occupation of the Baltic states and restore independence and sovereignty to those states. There is no point in mincing words about this matter. That should be the objective; that is what we are pursuing; and that is what we will continue to pursue on this issue of the Baltic states.

To return briefly to the motion that I have moved-the final part calls upon the Soviet Government to facilitate the peaceful transition to independence of those republics which have expressed through democratically elected parliaments a desire for self-determination.

This is a cause which has come a long way. It has had a lot of ups and downs in Australia. Although we give credit to the Australian Government today for what it has done, it should not be forgotten that there are some rainbow warriors on this issue. They come out after the storm, when the sun is shining and when the rainbow starts to show. There is a lot of keenness and enthusiasm when the tide has turned, as it were.

There was a time, of course, when this country recognised the incorporation de jure of the Baltic states within the Soviet Union. The parties that I am speaking for today, the Liberal and National parties, opposed that very strongly. It should be remembered that one of the very first acts of the incoming Fraser Government in 1975 was to undo and set aside for nought-and that is what it deserved-that recognition of the incorporation of the Baltic states in the Soviet Union.

It is very appropriate that today the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), who was then the Minister for Foreign Affairs, should be in the chamber while this motion is being debated. I say with all sincerity, and it is something that everyone could say objectively and agree with, that it is very greatly to the credit of the honourable member for Kooyong and the Government of which he was part that one of its very first acts was to remember three groups of very oppressed people.

Australia is a very prosperous country, although it has at the moment severe economic problems. What we as Australians forget far too often is that there are people who do not have the same good fortune as we have and who do not have not only the same economic prospects as we have but also those most elementary and basic rights that we have-those civil, political and human rights that we grow up with and assume as part of our second nature. Many people do not have those rights and continue to have them denied to them. We forget that far too often.

It is for that reason that I say that it is very much to the credit of the Fraser Government and the then Minister for Foreign Affairs, the honourable member for Kooyong, that a very early action of the Fraser Government was to set aside at nought and cancel that quite improper and disgraceful recognition of the incorporation of three independent countries within the Soviet Union. For our part, we never had any truck with that recognition and it is good that we can put it behind us.

It is good that the Labor Party has now seen the error of its ways-I do not want to trade on the political aspects of this at all-and can now join us in a bipartisan approach to this issue, because it concerns fundamental issues on which there should be no division between us and on which there should never have been division between us. That division should never have been there.

We are in favour of bipartisanship where it can acknowledge very basic principles to which we can all subscribe, and surely this is one-the interests, rights and liberties of the people of the Baltic states, and their right to conduct their own affairs and to run their own country. This motion seeks no more than that-the right of the people of the three Baltic states to have their own countries and to exercise sovereignty over those countries.

That is the reason why we move this motion once again; it is not the first time that such a motion has been moved in this Parliament. I hope that this motion will be passed by the Parliament, if not today, then as soon as possible and that it will be passed unanimously, because it seeks to pick up-and I think it does emphasise-all of those essential features of the three Baltic States of which we must keep reminding ourselves: first, they are still in a position of oppression; secondly, they are being denied their basic civil, political and human rights; thirdly, they are being denied that most elementary and basic right of all, the right of sovereignty, the right of people to conduct their own affairs and rule themselves. What we say to the Soviet Union is, `Wake up to yourselves; go back to your own country; leave the three Baltic states alone-they are not part of the Soviet Union; you have enough problems in the Soviet Union itself to occupy you for the rest of your likely life. Concentrate on those and leave the people of the three Baltic states to run their own affairs'. That is what we say to the Soviet Union. We hope that the Labor Party today will join with us in sending that message to the Soviet Union.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak later.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Catley Dr R.

TALK.START.PARA: — I am pleased to have the opportunity to support this private member's motion, which, I might say, was very eloquently moved. It is similar to one which I supported last year in this House, and it is in tune with the Lithuanian, Latvian and Estonian communities that live in my electorate and with whom I have been able to confer on these issues regularly, most recently on Friday of last week when I was privileged to share the celebrations held by the Lithuanian community on the seventy-third anniversary of their country's declaration of independence. Last month I was honoured to be invited by the Latvian community to address a rally on the steps of the South Australian Parliament House to protest recent Soviet repression in the Baltic republics in general, and Latvia in particular.

SPEECH.PARA: It needs to be noted that the views of these communities are very similar to those of the representatives of the Ukrainian Government and the Ukrainian Republican Party. Very recently, I had the honour to host a delegation from the Ukrainian Republican Party visiting Adelaide and my electorate office. I should also add that the motion contains some sentiments which are very similar to those that I expressed in a personal letter to Mikhail Gorbachev. Mr Deputy Speaker, you would be surprised to hear that I await a reply to that letter.

This motion has been moved at a most appropriate time, when many of us in the West are coming to see very clearly that the President of the Soviet Union-as the former Prime Minister of the United Kingdom said-is not a man with whom we can always do business. Recent events in the Baltic republics and also in the Ukraine, Moldavia, Georgia and the other minority nationalities in the Soviet Union have confirmed that Gorbachev's clean break with the past has not been so clean and that he is maintaining some old Soviet and Russian habits.

The threat and the actual use of force and violence in the Baltic Republics are all too reminiscent of past tsarist behaviour and more recently of Soviet repressive behaviour, as in the case of East Germany in 1953; Hungary in 1956; Czechoslovakia in 1968; then in 1980-81 with proxies used in Poland. This was not only true of the fact that this repression is very similar to those that I have just mentioned, but also that it has occurred at a time when the West has had its attention diverted elsewhere and has thereby not acted as decisively as it might otherwise have done.

This motion might also have called for the diplomatic recognition of the Baltic republics, particularly Lithuania, where I believe the case is very well made. It is clear that it very difficult to do that at a time when the West is engaged in peacekeeping operations in the Gulf and one of the legal bases for these operations has been produced by United Nations resolutions. In the event of our taking action in the Baltic area in a way that we might were moral considerations the only ones weighing with us, the Soviet Union could make life extremely difficult for us in the United Nations. No doubt this is one of the issues that has weighed heavily with Washington. In any case, I should add to my Lithuanian friends in Adelaide, Moscow has, all too clearly, retained effective control over the destiny of Lithuania and this makes recognition in a de facto or de jure sense very difficult to undertake.

We should not be fooled by the rationalisation that the Moscow Government has sought to give, that the repression that occurred in Lithuania was the result of deviant actions undertaken by local military forces. It is quite clear that the central government was responsible for the military build-up in the Baltic area, and it is, after all, President Gorbachev who is the Commander-in-Chief of the Soviet Armed Forces-and he gave his explicit approval for the build-up two days before the crack-down in Vilnius; and he expressed only regret, not condemnation, for the killings that occurred on 15 January.

TALK.START.PARA: —Disgraceful!

—As my colleague opposite says, absolutely disgraceful bully-boy tactics were used. Clearly, once again they are the go in the Soviet Union and are used by Russian dominated forces with respect to minority nationalities.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Government has already made plain its views on this most recent instance of Soviet repression in minority nationality areas. In media statements by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans), and by the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development (Dr Blewett), and most recently in the statement to which the mover of the motion referred, that by Senator Evans on 22 January. In that statement, Senator Evans made clear the Government's condemnation of the use of force by the Soviet Government, first in Lithuania and then in Latvia, and said that the Government's concerns had already been conveyed to Moscow.

But we should note that this motion urges that we continue with these protests-and I am wholly in agreement with the mover, the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. BROWN)-and that we should be prepared to put aside our previous faith in Mikhail Gorbachev as the great reformer of the Soviet Union. It is quite clear that he has lost his zest for reform and is now throwing in his lot with the old guard. We should take more note of Eduard Shevardnadze's resignation speech, in which he suggested that the Soviet Union was going back down the route to dictatorship. Of course, he has been credited by the old guard, who are coming back into control, with having lost eastern Europe.

The Soviet Union is reverting to a dictatorial regime, and it is quite clear that we need to send a message to Mikhail Gorbachev. When we have cleared up this unfortunate little mess created by another dictator, Saddam Hussein, in the Gulf area, our voice should become louder and louder, and the inhibitions caused by considerations of realpolitik become lessened. We have some methods by which we can exercise leverage on Gorbachev. The first lies in the fact that the forces that have been unleashed by the early glasnost and perestroika reform programs are still in place, notably in many of the republics. The strongest of these is, of course, Boris Yeltsin, who is leading a very strong program of political opposition to Gorbachev, and among other things has called on Russian ethnic soldiers in the Baltic republics not to be part of the use of force.

The second kind of leverage we have is as a result of the breadbasket case condition that the Soviet economy now faces, which had led it to agree to East Germany joining West Germany, and both of them remaining in the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation (NATO) alliance, in exchange for a pot of West German gold. We should use any aid programs adopted with respect to the Soviet Union as a mechanism for applying leverage on it to reduce its repression and to assist in the development of independent and democratic republics, particularly in the Baltic area, but also in other areas of the Soviet Union.

We are not here just to condemn Soviet activities, but also-as the motion quite rightly says-to support this movement towards democratic and independent Baltic republics. These were incorporated in the Soviet Union as part of a deal with Hitler at the onset of the Second World War. Stalin never consulted the Baltic peoples on this. Now that they are being asked what their opinion is on this matter, they are giving it the overwhelming thumbs down. Even the Soviet Union's Congress of People's Deputies last year declared the Nazi-Soviet pact to be both illegal and immoral.

From March of last year, democratically elected governments in all three states declared their independence from the Soviet Union, amidst overwhelming displays of public support for these actions. Lithuania recently conducted an independent plebiscite on the issue, which produced a 90 per cent positive vote in support of independence. Such acts, I might point out, for what it is worth, are entirely consistent with the Soviet constitution, the seventy-second article of which declares every state's right to secession. I note that on 3 March Estonia and Latvia will also be holding their own plebiscites. These are consistent also with the final acts of the 1975 Helsinki Conference on European Security and Cooperation, which declared the right of all participating nations, including the Soviet Union, to self-determination.

The central Moscow government knows it cannot win this argument with the Baltic peoples by persuasion, and it has banned all plebiscites in the Soviet Union not conducted under its own auspices. It will be conducting a ballot later this year on 17 March on a new Soviet Union treaty, which it is clearly going to rort very heavily, in the hope of being able to use it as a legitimacy for its continued occupation of the minority nationality republics.

The Baltic, Georgian and Ukrainian republics have refused to participate in the plebiscite. I note from today's paper that Moldavia has also said that it is not going to be party to this fraudulent plebiscite.

The Soviet Union is the last great European colonial system and I am sure that its continued existence meets with the disapproval of my colleagues on this side of the House. Some may even concur with the description used by a former American President, who was not always popular with all of us, that it constitutes an `evil empire'. It is clinging, much as did the British, the French, the Belgians, the Portuguese and other European colonial powers in the early post-war years, to its empire. Most of them had the good sense to realise that eventually they would have to get out. The British and, to a lesser extent, the French, the Belgians and the Portuguese, did get out, often retaining good connections and good relations with their former colonial territories. The Soviets seem determined to have the last great European colonial empire and to ensure that their relations with their former subjugated colonial peoples will not be good, will not be harmonious and the break will be as nasty as possible.

I hope that the message of this House, which we are about to convey, and its firm and clear condemnation of that kind of behaviour by the Soviets will play its part in persuading the Soviet Union to behave otherwise. The message to the Soviet Union is: `Get out now, while the going is still relatively good, and cut your losses.' There is not much to be gained by staying and that which is to be gained will be quickly evaporated by the struggle involved in the repression of maintaining those gains.

If, as Boris Yeltsin claimed yesterday, Gorbachev's aim is to preserve the system, is to maintain the system, and no longer to reform it, the time has come also for him to go and we should be doing nothing to delay his departure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aldred Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I fully support this motion put to the House so incisively by my colleague the shadow Minister for communications, the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. BROWN). Inasmuch as the Soviets have effectively controlled the Baltic states of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania since 1940 during World War II, this will give honourable members some indication of how fiercely the fire of independence burns in the hearts of people in those still captive nations. Now the Soviet empire, crumbling under the weight of secessionist movements and economic disaster, has lashed out in a desperate effort to retain control of the Baltic states.

SPEECH.PARA: Although the President of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR), Mr Mikhail Gorbachev, stated as recently as 23 January this year-as reported in the Sydney Morning Herald by Robert Haupt-that `the gains of perestroika, democratisation and glasnost were, and still remain, lasting values guarded by presidential power', nevertheless, while the Western democracies were pre-occupied with events in the Gulf, the USSR cynically used its troops to restore Soviet control in the Baltic states of Latvia and Lithuania in the belief that no-one would take action or take notice.

However, as the Gulf crisis moves to a resolution, the Soviet position regarding the Baltic states appears to be increasingly untenable, especially given growing world concern about the brutally repressive measures used by the Soviet Union, particularly in Lithuania.

International measures taken so far appear not to have had a great deal of effect upon the Soviet Government. There have been protests from many countries, including Australia. The European Community, in protest against Soviet violence, deliberately postponed a meeting on economic cooperation with that country and it was recently no doubt a factor in the postponement of the US-USSR summit. Stronger action certainly seems to be required to ensure that President Gorbachev fully realises that the use of military force against the small but fiercely independent nations cannot be tolerated.

The Lithuanian people have clearly demonstrated their current and continuing determination to again have full and proper independent status. This was clearly shown in a recent plebiscite when, despite the duress applied by the occupying power, 84 per cent of those eligible to vote turned out defiantly to cast their ballots in what resulted in over 90 per cent of the voters favouring independence.

Since then, Iceland, on 12 February, became the first nation since the current crisis to recognise Lithuania as an independent state. This is a courageous precedent and a fine example to be followed, hopefully by the rest of the world. I call upon the Australian Government to move to the same position as soon as possible in accordance with the motion now before the House.
