That grievances be noted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Dr D.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Over the last four days we have witnessed what can only be described as a shameful attack by the Government and the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) on the Opposition and on the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson). Why do I say shameful? Because what we have witnessed is an attempt to distort and, indeed, stifle debate through wholesale misrepresentation of what those who disagree with the Minister have said. The Minister has tried this tactic before and has failed, and he will fail again.

SPEECH.PARA: Before discussing the impact of this sordid tactic, let me first demonstrate the hypocrisy of the Minister for Employment, Education and Training on this matter of public debate. In a speech in November last year, the Minister made the following extraordinary statement:
In Australia today there is an urgent need for robust discussion on education.
Did honourable members hear that? The Minister wants robust discussion. He then said:
. . . I cannot help asking myself, where are the other views?
So the Minister wants to hear other views. He then had this to say-and this takes the cake:
. . . why is it that any such comment from the other side is nearly always reactive . . .

So the Minister wants those opposed to his policies not to be reactive but to initiate debate. Let me say that there is an army of people opposed to his policies. Then, with breathtaking innocence, he asked:
What are the causes of this comparative silence?

Well, Minister, I rise today to say that the education debate in this country has been damaged by the shameless misrepresentation of views and bully boy tactics which have characterised the Government's approach. I have no doubt that some have been intimidated. I recall the vicious attack on Professor Caro last year when he questioned the amalgamations process. I recall the Minister's description of those who gave critical testimony to the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training as `malcontents'. The Minister's tactics failed then, and they will fail now.

The Leader of the Opposition was doing exactly what the Minister called for. He was initiating debate. The Leader of the Opposition made it abundantly clear that he was not announcing policy but simply drawing attention to alternatives which have been suggested in public debate. His comments on vouchers were couched explicitly as a reference to radical proposals suggested by others-specifically, the Institute of Public Affairs and the Centre for Independent Studies. In his speech he warned:
Some in the media will undoubtedly be tempted to run away and say he is making policy on the run. I'm not.
The Leader of the Opposition went on to say:
It is essential that political leaders be able to raise issues and stimulate effective debate in this country.

Let there be no doubt that after eight years of the Hawke Labor Government such a debate is long overdue. Last year the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training had this to say about higher education after eight years of Labor Government:

. . . the central consideration in reforming higher education must be the quality of the education which students receive . . . The preoccupation with the way the system operates, rather than what is intended to achieve, has excluded these issues from the agenda of debate.

A committee headed by a Labor senator blew the whistle on a Minister more interested in bright ideas and grand plans than in their impact on quality. Who can forget the Minister's gross over-reaction, or Senator Aulich's timely response? Senator Aulich said:
I will not be bludgeoned into silence . . . The Minister ought to come out of the bunker and participate in an exchange of ideas.
That is what someone on his own side thinks of the Minister's love of public debate.

Let us turn to schools. In the wake of November's Special Premiers Conference, the Labor Premier of Queensland, Mr Wayne Goss, used three words to describe the Minister's performance: `Incompetent and arrogant'. What more can be said? From the Minister I offer his own statement to the November conference to which I have already referred. I quote the Minister's own words:
Our schools are in crisis . . . there has never been a greater questioning by parents, teachers and employers of where our schools are going.

Last week in a media release he repeated this claim and added, `The morale of teachers has never been lower'. If this is the legacy that the Minister and his Labor predecessors have left us after eight years in government, then he would do well indeed to heed the calls of Senator Aulich and come out of his bunker.

The Opposition has long recognised the worsening crisis of confidence in our schools. There are solutions to this crisis. The Government has failed to adopt them. Indeed, it has opposed them at every turn. There are two alternative strategies to address this crisis. One is the Government's. It is a strategy based on strengthening centralised regulation of schools-government and non-government schools. It is a strategy based on centralisation of industrial relations and the creation of mega-unions in education, as elsewhere. There is another strategy which could be adopted, a strategy of genuine micro-reform in education, a strategy to enlist the motivations, the interests, of those whom the schools are there to serve-the parents of Australia and their children.

Australia's parents are clearly not satisfied. Many have sought to exercise their right to choose a school by moving their children from government schools to the non-government sector. The Government has, frankly, tried to make this exercise of choice as difficult as possible, as difficult as it has dared. But as for the parents of government schoolchildren, they also have a right to choose. They have a right to be able to choose their child's school. They have a right to proper comparative information about the standards of educational achievement of their children, for they care about the quality of their children's education more than anyone else. Under the Government's strategy they are shut out. They are told, `Stand aside; the bureaucrats and the unions will take care of the schools; you stay out'.

For two days running in this House, the Minister has derided the right of parents to choose their school. Ultimately, the parents of this country will demand a proper say in the schools that their children attend. It is the children of the most disadvantaged parts of this country who will benefit from this change. The teachers will benefit, for instead of relying on the union muscle which has failed them, they will have the support of an involved and caring community of parents behind them.

This is the debate on schooling that Australia needs, and out of this debate community confidence in schools can be restored, the morale of teachers can be lifted, and opportunities can be opened for all Australian children to have the quality of education to which they are entitled.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Neil Mr L.R.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to draw to the attention of the House the need for urgent changes to be made to the legislation concerning the 12-week suspension incurred by people on unemployment benefit when they move to areas of low employment. As all members present would be aware, most rural and country areas of Australia would be classed as areas where prospects of employment are low. My electorate of Grey in South Australia is such an area. I am being inundated with calls from people who have been advised to move to country areas where accommodation is more readily available, there are shorter waiting lists and where, in most cases, the accommodation is less costly.

SPEECH.PARA: Accommodation is at a premium in metropolitan areas. For example, I have been advised that there is a minimum waiting period of six years for State government housing in metropolitan Adelaide. Private rental accommodation is at extremely high levels. The money diverted from the family budget for private rental could be better utilised for everyday essentials, especially where there are small children involved. Consequently, when a person on unemployment benefit is advised that there is cheap government housing available in country regions, that person will automatically seize the chance to better his or her family's living standards by moving house.

Any person living on a tight budget is continually looking for ways to stretch his or her limited income. These people are not indulging in life's luxuries but are battling on a daily basis to make ends meet. This is not the first time I have voiced my concern on this issue. I previously brought this matter to the attention of the Department of Social Security and as a result of my inquiries a small note was placed in the right hand corner of the unemployment benefit form lodged by applicants. This note is inserted just prior to question 6. Question 6 asked: did you change your home address? The note appearing in small print states:
Moving to an area with lower employment prospects could mean no payment for 12 weeks. If you are thinking of moving, check with the CES first.

The addition of this note has not reduced the high incidence of people approaching me for assistance when they are subsequently cut off from the unemployment benefit. The majority have moved to the country after being advised by the State government authorities that housing is readily available for themselves and their families. The note is not readily notice- able and can be easily missed, especially by the long term unemployed who fill out this form on a regular basis and who would tend to skip over the addition of a small note.

This situation is not unique to my electorate as discussions with my colleagues indicate that it is a widespread and thoroughly terrible situation throughout all country regions. I have had a number of cases brought to my attention where the suspension of unemployment benefit has been applied. One such instance was that of a young couple, both in their late teens, who were residing in the metropolitan area, sharing private accommodation with other young couples. The people with whom they were sharing were taking part in nightly alcoholic and drug abuse sessions. As they did not want to join in or be involved in any part of these activities, they needed to extricate themselves from this high risk situation at the earliest opportunity.

Upon application for State government accommodation, authorities advised the young couple that immediate housing was available to them in Whyalla. After travelling to Whyalla and preparing to move into their new home, they were then advised by the Department of Social Security that their benefits had been suspended. This placed them in severe financial difficulty. Their only other alternative was to move back to the metropolitan area, with the prospect of obtaining accommodation virtually nil, or moving back into the potentially dangerous situation from which they had removed themselves.

A further instance, and one very similar to an appeal won last year, was that of a married couple. The couple's decision to move to another area was based on the husband having been in trouble with the law. The man and the woman were unable to cope with the stress of their situation and the woman was placed under medical care for a nervous condition which was a direct result of her husband's circumstances. The couple were advised by their medical practitioner and a specialist to move away from the area. A request for a transfer through State housing was made. The couple were advised that there was no vacant alternative accommodation in the metropolitan area but immediate State housing was available in the country regions of the State.

Bearing in mind the medical advice received and with medical certificates to back up the advice, upon applying for unemployment benefit an immediate 12-week suspension was applied to the couple's unemployment benefit. Their only alternative was to move back to the metropolitan area or to wait for 12 weeks for recommencement of benefits. No State government accommodation would be available to the couple in the metro- politan vicinity. The cost to relocate to the country had exhausted the family's limited budget and private rental in the metropolitan region was costly. The suspension of benefits for a 12-week period could very well have seen this man reoffending in an attempt to provide essentials for his family.

These are only two instances of the numerous complaints that I have encountered regarding this legislation. I can fully appreciate the need for control regarding the payment of social security benefits to genuine job seekers. However, I feel that a person's individual circumstances when moving to another area must be taken into account. Many are not even aware that by moving they risk the loss of their benefits.

Many people find themselves unable to obtain employment in the competitive job market, yet are continually seeking work. The plight of the homeless is one we as a government are addressing, yet we penalise a person who, by finding accommodation, reduces his job prospects. It is interesting to note that a significant number of appeals are being overturned. The main reason the tribunal is overturning the suspension of benefits is that individual circumstances are not taken into account from the first instance. I firmly believe we must ascertain the reasons behind a person moving to an area before making harsh decisions regarding that person's social security benefits.

It must also be borne in mind that not everyone understands that the right to appeal exists under the Social Security Act. Many families accept the first decision as final. I am aware that the recent amendments to existing legislation will alleviate some of the problem areas. However, the real issue, the real crux of the problem, has not been addressed.

This legislation is causing hardship to a great number of unemployed people who, for numerous reasons, are moving to new areas. Many families who are affected by the rule are already significantly disadvantaged. The need to assess each case on its individual merit is vital if we as a government are genuine about helping those people in real need. It seems to me quite ironic that, when we have in today's society this huge drift of people from country and regional Australia to the metropolitan area, we are not addressing this huge problem.

If there is housing available in country and regional areas and people can utilise that housing, surely we have a responsibility to assist people to acquire adequate housing and take into consideration the housing needs of people. I am pleased to see that the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security (Mr Sciacca) is at the table. I hope that he takes on board some of the things that I have raised here today. It is a genuine problem; it is a genuine concern. I think this House has a responsibility to house properly and adequately those people that are in genuine need of housing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid The Hon N.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —A plague has been visited upon this country. It stretches from east to west over 2,000 miles or more from the east coast of this country through Victoria and South Australia, right across to Western Australia. It affects the lives and well-being of more than five million people. It is presided over by a line of Labor State governments. The plague that I am talking about is a level of financial incompetence and mismanagement unparalleled in Australia's history. It is large even by world standards. All of this on top of the failed economic policies of the Hawke-Keating Labor Federal Government.

SPEECH.PARA: We have seen the demoralisation of the people in Victoria by the Cain-Kirner Australian Labor Party (ALP) Government with the collapse of the Victorian Economic Development Corporation, the Victorian Division of the National Safety Council, Victorian Equity Trustees, Workcare, the Pyramid-Farrow Group and the Tricontinental royal commission. The State Bank of Victoria-the fifth largest bank in Australia, with over four million cheque and savings accounts, 12,500 employees and with net assets of $1.8 billion-ended up being sold to the Commonwealth Bank for $1.6 billion. There is a State debt at last count in excess of $34,000m and growing.

In Western Australia, of course, we have seen a long progression of financial mismanagement by the Burke, Dowding and Lawrence Labor governments. We now have a royal commission into Western Australia Inc. Under the terms of reference the royal commission will inquire whether there has been corruption, illegal conduct or improper conduct into a number of financial debacles in that State. I could run through those terms of reference but they are widely known to the public and the public is aware of the financial mismanagement of that State.

We now have in South Australia mismanagement by the Australian Labor Party President, Premier Bannon. A royal commission has been set up to inquire into the workings and operations of the State Bank of South Australia, which has non-performing loans of $2.5 billion.
I want to address a couple of comments that were made in the Australian Financial Review of Monday, 18 February 1991 about this debacle in South Australia. I quote:

. . . SA Treasury officials have confirmed that as far back as three years ago, after investigations in late 1988, they alerted Premier John Bannon to potential problems within the State Bank of South Australia.
I now quote the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin)-`the outspoken Stephen Martin', as he is described in the Australian Financial Review:
. . . despite being a politician of the same colour-
and I presume that that is a faction-
as the SA Labor Premier-believes that Bannon has to accept the blame for the downfall of his $15.4 billion State bank.
I quote the honourable member for Macarthur again:
Bannon has already said the problem was he wanted the bank to be at arm's length from the Government. But you should never be at arm's length when you are dealing with the people's money.
This gives a clear indication of where the blame for those non-performing loans should rest.

Why raise these points at this time? The Federal Parliament should have a record of the lack of competence of the Hawke ALP Government and the State governments of Victoria, South Australia and Western Australia, particularly in the financial area, so that future generations will understand what went wrong in Australia during the Labor Party's reign in the 1980s.

One might say that the Hawke-ALP Government has no role to play in this issue; but it does. I want to read to the House the words of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) when he made his second reading speech on the Commonwealth Banks Restructuring Bill 1990. He was referring, of course, to the Commonwealth Bank's purchase of the State Bank of Victoria. He said:
It is Australia's fifth largest bank with extensive liabilities overseas, and a loss of confidence in it would have threatened the very stability of Australia's financial system.
I want honourable members to note carefully the following words of the Treasurer:
This was a situation which the Commonwealth Government could not allow to occur.

In other words, the Commonwealth has accepted the responsibility and could not allow a State bank to get into a situation where people lost confidence. It is an acceptance by the Federal Treasurer that he does have a role in the State banking institutions of this country.

People will ask, and will continue to ask, `Why must I suffer because of the incompetence and financial stupidity of various ALP governments throughout this country?'. It has had a dramatic effect throughout the length and breadth of this country, particularly in those three States that I have mentioned-Victoria, South Australia and Western Australia-with unemployment figures increasing on a daily basis, industries and businesses closing, and higher bankruptcies than we have seen for many, many years in this country.

I think what we need to do is to look at what has happened. What has happened is that the economic policies of this Government have created only one growth industry in this country. The growth industry that I am referring to is in the insolvency and legal professions. There is quite strong growth in those areas, as people try to attend to the problems of an economy which has been severely damaged by the economic policies of the Hawke-Keating Government.

The royal commissions are in full flight in each State that I have mentioned: in Victoria, there is a royal commission into Tricontinental; there is now one in South Australia, a royal commission into the State Bank; and, of course, in Western Australia there is a royal commission into WA Inc. The legal fees, particularly for a Queen's Counsel at those royal commissions-and there will be plenty of them-can reach as high as $1,100 per day. The second ranking legal advice to those royal commissions could run to at least $1,000 a day. Honourable members can see the additional expense that is being caused by the Labor governments in those three States and the impost on those States and the people who reside there.

The receivers and liquidators throughout the length and breadth of this country are thriving at the moment because of the difficulties in which people are finding themselves as a result of the failed policies not only of the three State governments but also of the Federal Government. The bottom line in this plague, in all of these financial debacles, is that Labor governments cannot manage people's money.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —For some years the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation has been afflicted with a series of bungles which have not only seriously embarrassed the ministerial head of the CSIRO, but also had the effect of causing a dramatic loss of morale amongst employees of Australia's premier research organisation, the CSIRO.

SPEECH.PARA: The latest bungle concerns the imminent decision by the CSIRO to relocate the 15-member staff of the Division of Tropical Animal Production at the CSIRO's Davies Laboratory at Townsville out of the tropics to Brisbane. The particular reason given by the CSIRO for this proposal is lack of resources. Put simply, the CSIRO claims that it does not have the money to operate its Division of Tropical Animal Production in the tropics. Not only is this claim false, but it illustrates an almost total lack of leadership on the part of the CSIRO at its highest levels.

The disadvantages of the proposed decision by the CSIRO to abolish the Division of Tropical Animal Production at Townsville are many. The loss of contact with industry in tropical regions in turn leads to reduced understanding of the severity of the problems in tropical regions. Future contact with advisory services would be reduced. This, in turn, would lead to reduced application of results of research.

At a time when Australia's primary industries are reeling against the onslaught of unprecedented economic adversity, the decision to abandon a permanent tropical animal research facility in the tropics is incomprehensible and unforgivable. More than half of the national cattle herd is located from Rockhampton north. The cattle industry of northern Australia constitutes one of the nation's best economic assets. The maintenance of this asset, with support from research and development, and the application of that research, is of paramount national importance.

Townsville has been the centre of tropical animal research since the CSIRO established the Davies Laboratory in 1962. Its early pioneering work covered a variety of research, including the effect of animal production through improved pastures in a tropical environment. Shortly after it was established, one of the leading research scientists, Mr Les Edye, and other scientists at the laboratory, were responsible for the development of new legumes, many from South America, which, through pastoral improvement, have dramatically increased cattle production in the tropics. I believe that they have added hundreds of millions of dollars to the value of the cattle industry in northern Australia. In addition, the scientists at the CSIRO laboratory in Townsville have conducted extensive research into improving calving and growth rates of cattle, mineral nutrition and the use of tropical legumes as feed supplements.

The success of the research work of the Division of Tropical Animal Production at Townsville has brought international renown to its research scientists, particularly Dr Jim Hogan. Their expertise is unmatched elsewhere in Australia. CSIRO research staff at Townsville have a highly productive record of collaborative research with the Graduate School of Tropical Veterinary Science and Agriculture at James Cook University in relation to beef cattle production. The skills and facilities of both organisations have complemented each other and have led to the efficient use of research funds and resources. This link will now be severed. In addition, staff at James Cook University and the CSIRO have been involved in the presentation of scientific lectures-in their fields of research expertise-to graduate students undertaking master of science programs in tropical veterinary science and tropical agriculture.

Research carried out at the Davies Laboratory in Townsville has been used to advantage by Australia's near neighbours who reside in countries with climates and conditions identical to that found in tropical Australia. CSIRO staff also assist with the supervision of research projects undertaken by graduate students, and a number of them hold honorary positions within the university. If this policy decision to disband the division at Townsville is pursued, then this expertise would be lost.

The loss of the Division of Tropical Animal Production from the tropics would also reduce the number of research workers in northern Australia with expertise in animal production. Good research work evolves from the opportunities of researchers to talk with each other and to discuss ideas. Once the scientists from the Division of Tropical Animal Production leave north Queensland-outside of James Cook University, and there will be fewer than 10 scientists involved in tropical animal research who live and work in north Queensland, and probably none elsewhere in northern Australia.

If CSIRO pursues this bone-headed decision to close down the Division of Tropical Animal Production in Townsville, it will earn the contempt and disgust of the grazing, scientific and academic communities of north Queensland, and it will be conclusive proof that this Government cannot sincerely claim to be genuinely interested in the promotion of research into primary industries in northern Australia.

I make this further point regarding the collaborative research effort at the Townsville laboratories. The CSIRO Davies Laboratory, James Cook University and the Queensland Department of Primary Industries work together in a way which is internationally unique. No other developed country has a similar set of research institutes in the tropics.

For some years now the Division of Tropical Animal Production at the CSIRO laboratory at Townsville has been starved of funds by CSIRO head office. It has been suggested that this change of policy was introduced because of an emphasis on funding divisions concerned with manufacturing to the detriment of divisions concerned with primary industries. As a consequence, primary industry divisions were required to make good their shortfall from external funds.

To exacerbate matters for the division in Townsville, Federal Government policy in the late 1980s encouraged all CSIRO divisions to try to obtain 30 per cent of funds from external sources. In plain English, they were required to scrounge around the community, begging for funds to carry out vital research work demanded of them by government, by the CSIRO and by the cattle industry. This situation has now deteriorated to the level where many CSIRO divisions concerned with primary industries cannot fulfil their charter to conduct basic and applied research into major problems affecting Australia's primary industry.

If honourable members are disgusted by the proposed decision to abandon tropical animal production facilities in the tropics, then they would be furious to learn that the Liberal-National parties propose even greater destruction to CSIRO than the public realise. On 30 August 1990, an article appeared in the Canberra Times with the shock headline, `Coalition considers disbanding CSIRO'. The article went on to say:
The Federal Opposition will consider disbanding the nation's premier scientific research body, the CSIRO, under a new policy review.

The Opposition spokesman on science and technology, Peter McGauran, told the National Science Forum in Canberra yesterday that the Coalition was embarking on a reassessment of the appropriateness of the `current institutional structure' in which scientific and technological research was undertaken.
The article went on:
A spokesman for Mr McGauran later said the direction of the review might lead to the disbanding of the CSIRO.

What a contemptible, irresponsible attitude to primary industry research in Australia. No wonder the people of northern Australia, particularly in the rural communities, academics, and research and technical workers, have lost faith in the Liberal and National parties.

Australia is the only developed country which can carry out tropical research in its own territory. The proposed decision to move the Tropical Animal Production Division to Brisbane goes contrary to every sound principle of academic research management. Australia cannot afford to let this happen. I despair of the lack of imagination and vision evident behind this decision.
The former head of the School of Tropical Veterinary Science, Professor Rod Campbell, has written to Dr Alan Donald, the Director of the Institute of Animal Production, CSIRO, Canberra, saying:

It is distressing to learn again that scientists actually working in the tropics, with tropical production systems, are in danger of transfer to Brisbane. Senior administrators seem able to think in one direction only. The Brisbane line mentality is alive and well.

Madam Deputy Speaker, you are right in what I have heard you say before: the Brisbane line mentality is alive and well. Closing the Townsville site of the Division of Tropical Animal Production and moving it to Brisbane will be explained by those who want it to happen as having the advantage of concentrating resources in one place. But what it loses for Australia is having in situ, on site, a tropical research facility that is unique in the world.

Everything that needs to be done should be done to secure the continued existence of the CSIRO's Division of Tropical Animal Production at Davies Laboratory. These facilities must remain in the tropics where they belong.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Dr H.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I grieve today for the pain, the tragedy and the loss caused by the recession in this country-the recession we had to have, according to the present Treasurer (Mr Keating); the recession engineered by the Treasurer and the Government-as is acknowledged on all sides by informed commentators, not just this Opposition-with the main factor being the 18 months of sustained very high interest rates to January 1990.

SPEECH.PARA: I grieve too for the other dreadful legacy of the Hawke Government's economic failure-the vast overseas debt. At last count, this was $156.3 billion in gross terms compared to about $30 billion when this Government came to power-more than a five-fold increase. This debt undermines the living standards of this country and will undermine those of our children too, unless we really come to terms with it. This debt constrains the future development of the country because of the mounting interest bill for servicing the debt-in the order of $50m a day. We have to borrow that to pay the interest. This debt also makes Australia very vulnerable to external shocks like the emerging world recession and falls in commodity prices.

One measure of the loss caused by the recession is the loss of output. The recorded fall in total national production to the end of last September was already a cumulative 2 per cent. Even if there is a beginning to a recovery in the second half of the 1991 calendar year, that loss of output would amount, over a year, to $8 billion-about the same as a year's spending on defence or what is annually spent on aged pensions. That is the measure of the potential production lost forever because of the ineptitude of the Government's policy.

The pain and the tragedy of the recession is, firstly, in the destruction of the life's work of many a small business person, with the number of companies going into receivership having doubled over the past year. As a Monash study released in the new year, put it, `The corporate damage attributable to the current recession is devastating', inflicting `a horrendous social cost'. That cost, pain and tragedy is especially in the growth of unemployment, and I want to focus on that. Jobs have been lost over the past six to seven months at a rate of upwards of 1,000 a day. Let the Parliament and the people out there listening to this broadcast really take that on board. Jobs have been-are being-lost at the rate of 1,000 a day. Since the first part of last year more than 250,000 jobs have been lost, contributing to a total unemployment figure of the order of 750,000. The increase in unemployment from December to January, the latest figures, seasonally adjusted, was 26,800. Honourable members can see from that figure that more than 1,000 jobs are lost per working day.

That is the effect of this recession that the Government has created. Only yesterday, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer, under continual Opposition questioning, expressed their concern and sympathy. They have stood there day after day, continually harping on the theme that since they came to office there has been, until about a year ago, an increase of 1 1/2 million jobs. That is a very good thing, and we all acknowledge that. But now, unhappily, the process is very much in reverse.

As I expressed in a previous grievance debate as far back as May 1989, and as the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) and the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) have stressed in recent days, there has been a heavy price to pay for that job growth. In particular, the five-fold burgeoning of the overseas debt, to which I have just referred, was directly associated with the forcing of the pace of economic growth to provide those jobs.

While I have been over this ground before, there are other aspects of that point that is continually made by the Prime Minister and the Treasurer that need to be emphasised. The first point is that employment growth has always been relatively rapid in Australia-much higher than the average for the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) countries. For example, in the 20 years from 1968, employment growth in Australia averaged 2.5 per cent per annum, compared to just one per cent for the total OECD-which is, among other things, associated with the very rapid growth in population.

The second point is that it has not just been confined to the period of office of this Government. Strong employment growth has been evident over the whole period since World War II-in the 1950s, 1960s and the early 1970s. I would like to stress that this was also so under the oft-criticised Fraser Government, with the honourable member for Bennelong as Treasurer. Under that Government it is true that growth in employment was slow at first as the economy was bent back into shape after the destructive Whitlam years. But from 1979 there was strong growth, generating some 530,000 jobs over the period of the Government, to the cyclical peak of September 1981.

That was robust growth-comparable to that of recent years under this Hawke Government but, of course, never acknowledged by it. It was cut short by the severe 1981-82 drought, the onset of world recession and the wages mayhem led by the metal unions, with plenty of support from the whole gang-the present Prime Minister, then only recently translated from the Australian Council of Trade Unions, Messrs Dolan, Crean, Kelty, Carmichael and the lot.

Until this current recession, since the coming to power of the Hawke Government there was no such major interruption to growth. That could not be said to be due to the ministrations of that Government. The situation was the same in the United States, the United Kingdom and the world generally: continuing employment growth with a prolonged worldwide upswing in business activity until about a year ago. Since 1983 it has not been peculiar to Australia; it has been worldwide.

What I think also needs to be recognised is that, whereas job growth under the Fraser Government was soundly based on resource development as its motor force, under the Hawke Government growth benefited in the early stages from the bounce back from the recession, the breaking of the drought and the Fraser wages pause, and then we had this growth on `tick' so to speak. That is, there was a large degree of force-feeding of demand by the Budget deficit. Subsequently, in 1987-88 we had excessively loose monetary policy-admittedly, combined with a strong upswing in the terms of trade-which led to the subsequent dramatic overheating of the economy.

The third point relates to unemployment. The facts are that on average the level of unemployment, despite the job growth, has been higher under this Government than under the previous Government and now is burgeoning at the tragic rate of 1,000 a day, on course to 9 to 10 per cent of the work force.

Meanwhile, notwithstanding all the pain of the recession, the other legacy of failure-the overseas debt-continues to climb. That is because, as the latest balance of payments figures, which were so lauded complacently but falsely by the Treasurer, make clear, the current account deficit is clearly stalled at the still-too-high level of around 4 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP), despite the recession. There is no doubt there was an improvement on the levels of 1989 of about $2 billion per month to an average of about $1.3 billion per month, but it is stalled there. In fact, the latest figure was $1.7 billion. But it is stalled at a level of about 4 per cent. At that level the foreign debt will continue to climb and the country will continue to borrow heavily, going further into hock, at a rate of about $50m a day, just to pay the interest on the existing debt.

What I would stress is that the ill-judged, sustained high interest rates not only reduced consumer demand, but also affected investment in new and replacement productive capacity, particularly in export and import replacing industries. That means that any significant recovery of the economy will soon run into the same capacity and balance of payments roadblocks as before, repeating the cycle.

What is required is a consistent, sound monetary and fiscal policy-beginning with a mini-Budget as soon as possible-for lower inflation and interest rates and a competitive exchange rate, along with fundamental reform of the industrial relations system to permit and encourage enterprise bargaining, major and urgent micro-economic reforms especially in transport and the waterfront, and tax reform, particularly the implementing of a goods and services tax.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crawford Ms M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I grieve today for the people of Logan City, whom I know Madam Deputy Speaker also knows, and the fact that here we have one of the largest growing cities in Australia, 130,000 people, with no public transport.

SPEECH.PARA: Surely any council that had any concern for its citizens would, in fact, investigate the matter and look to the provision of such services. Certainly it is true that there is a State suburban train running through the middle of the city, which in fact helps to perpetuate a situation of division. But what that provision means is that unless people live within walking distance of those train stations, or have jobs on industrial estates that are close to those railway stations, their access to a whole range of services is, indeed, very limited.

One would have to ask about the implications for a city of 130,000 people who have no public transport-of course, the implications are enormous. It means that, at the very first level, the implications for access to work and access to employment are severely limited. People need to walk, bicycle, hitch rides with people, or buy however many cars are needed in the family to facilitate gaining access to their work. One way in which people sometimes manage is that they get a taxi to a nearby railway station and then go on to work. However, this, of course, meets with a huge outcry from a whole range of citizens who believe that people living in our poorer and less well-served areas should not enjoy the aspects of a taxi service. They fail to consider that, if there is no other means of transport, the use of such a taxi service is vital and essential.

It also creates barriers in terms of recreation, so that recreation facilities are not always available to the whole range of people within the city. It means that unless one lives close to some of the services that are available, they become virtually inaccessible to one. So we have a proliferation of a number of services. For example, in an attempt to overcome the transport barrier, we have a range of soccer clubs, community groups and other things, all of which provide smaller services for people and which are extremely local.

But more importantly, Logan City as a whole, because it is also cut in half by the Pacific Highway on the main route from Brisbane to the Gold Coast, is a very divided city. It is not only physically divided-that city has now become socially and psychologically divided. In fact, we have one part of the highway where services seem to have been provided at a much higher rate by the local city council. On one side of the highway we have much better servicing in terms of kerbing, guttering, roads and, indeed, even gardens and gardening, all of which I agree with, and which go to make a much better environment for people to live in. But in the older part of the city we are still waiting for many streets to be curbed and guttered after 20 to 25 years, which seems an extraordinary situation when one side of the city is so well serviced that money can be found for gardens.

As well as those sorts of factors, transport, of course, also impinges on a whole range of other activities, some of which relate to schooling, training and education. Eighteen months ago we greeted the opening of the Logan College of Technical and Further Education, which was an excellent provision and which was welcomed by everybody within the city. Fortunately, it was placed next-door to a railway station, which was a very worthwhile thing to do. But, unfortunately, yet again, access to the college is limited for very many people in the Logan City area-particularly sole parents, of whom there are 4,000-who want to take advantage of the college and the kind of courses which it offers.

If they are not car drivers or do not live close to a railway station, then access to the college becomes virtually impossible. So, while the college certainly has no shortage of takers, we would like to see the kind of barriers which lack of transport creates broken down to ensure that the college is open to everybody and that everybody has an opportunity to go there.

One may ask, `What then does this city council do if, in fact, it provides no public transport for people within the confines of its city and the provision of services such as kerbing, guttering and general road maintenance is somewhat limited and often a scattergun approach is adopted?'. I think there are very many people who, in the lead-up to the elections which are to be held on 23 March, are also asking themselves that question. What we do know is that the Logan City Council has a great propensity for publishing very beautiful and very glossy pamphlets and leaflets about itself. We have lots of large pictures about the Council and about its various committees, but we have never actually been able to quite ascertain what some of them do.

We saw a pamphlet in relation to a great tree planting project-very worth while, very commendable and very essential. But most of that has not quite come to fruition. In fact, it is quite extraordinary to think that two or three years ago the very same city council rejected a Federal Government grant for the provision of 5,000 trees to the city simply because it came from the Federal Government. It was quite an extraordinary situation. Indeed, Logan City's record on the environment is somewhat to be questioned. As many people may know, there was a toxic waste situation in Diamond Street in part of the city.

It was only by applying constant pressure to the Goss State Government that eventually action was taken. We did, in fact, see one of the leaders of the demonstrations against a range of State and local government factors to get something done and to get recognition that toxic waste was in fact in Logan City ultimately placed under a medical health Act. Fortuitously, she has now been released, her home has been purchased, she has moved elsewhere and we have seen some realisation of the toxic waste.

Throughout that very early campaign, and throughout the work to acknowledge that there actually was toxic waste, we had the Council actually fighting against the demonstrators and saying it was a nonsense, they would bring discredit upon the city and that what they were saying was actual lies. So we did not actually see any movements there.

Unfortunately, Logan City, historically being a large housing commission and cheap housing area, has also in fact had quite a high level of unemployment. One of the areas people would think the Council would be very active in is the area of job creation. When the Federal Government suggested that Logan City might like to have the only information technology centre in Australia out of the central business district, the Council rejected a three-quarters of a million dollar grant. The mind just boggles. In the same sort of way it was also instrumental in ensuring that the local SkillShare project was moved from the premises where it was because it thought it lowered the tone of the area or some other such thing. It had no recognition of the kind of work which was actually being done by the SkillShare project in pursuing job opportunities and job training for a whole range of people in that area.

So we can see its record in terms of job creation which would benefit the city in the long term because, of course, if people are working, they are more able to participate fully in the community, they have a larger disposable income and they are more able to pay their rates-which, I might add, are very high in Logan City for what one may question are very, very limited social services.

We also saw opposition from this particular City Council to a new government building which would provide better services to citizens through the Department of Social Security and the Commonwealth Employment Service. But no; it was opposed to that as well. So I grieve for the people of Logan City, but I also hope that they will recognise the kind of very poor services-in transport, in people services, in a whole range of areas-which have failed to be delivered to them by the current members of Logan City Council and that they will take the appropriate action to ensure for themselves and for the city as a whole that a better deal is had for everybody. I know they can take that action on 23 March.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cowan Mr D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the opportunity in this debate to raise a matter that has come to my notice in recent times, that is, what many people are beginning to believe is a duplication in the operation of SkillShare, technical and further education (TAFE) and adult community education generally. This is a matter that has been brought to my attention by a number of my constituents-I think principally by those who, as taxpayers, feel that their money should be spent in a way that would give the best results so far as our unemployed people are concerned. I refer not only to the unemployed or the employed, but also to the employer who seeks to get employees with a rather sound knowledge of the work that they are going to do, particularly in manufacturing industry.

SPEECH.PARA: I appreciate, of course, that the Government has fronted the employment situation, particularly so far as the younger group in the community are concerned, by the encouragement of SkillShare and by looking at the problem from a short term point of view. Therefore, I recognise the work that is being done by the organisation. The Commonwealth Employment Service suggests to people that they should avail themselves of the opportunity to go to SkillShare and receive a certain type of education.

It does seem that there is beginning to be a duplication with regard to the programs of SkillShare, TAFE and adult education generally. It has also come to my notice that even in the case of, say, Sydney University, the private institutions and Sydney TAFE, there is a duplication, even in that higher field, of many of the programs that have been set down by the education departments.

I appreciate the fact that we are dealing with education in a field that is sponsored not only by the Commonwealth, but also by the State to a very great degree. So far as SkillShare is concerned, it is complemented by the local community business houses, we trust, and by other groups within the community. There are also local committees. In fact, I would like to see many more business houses and other professional people become involved in education schemes for the unemployed.

The matter has been brought to my notice because in recent times I have had approaches from SkillShare committees within my electorate which are very short of accommodation. Keeping in mind the fact that the active employment strategy program is to take place from 1 July, which means that it is anticipated that even over one year there will be at least 75,000 people who may avail themselves of the opportunity to participate in SkillShare programs, it is clear that extra accommodation will be needed.

I have written to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) asking whether it is the intention of the Government to purchase and provide actual accommodation for the operation of SkillShare programs. I am anxious to know this because places like Nelson Bay, within my electorate-and there is no large TAFE college there-are most anxious to obtain accommodation.

The same problem has been witnessed at Taree, where we have had a somewhat very heated discussion between SkillShare and the greater Taree City Council over the accommodation aspect there. This is because SkillShare is located within a residential area and it needs to expand. If SkillShare is to expand, as intended under the program of active employment strategy, it is necessary for the Commonwealth to realise that the matter of accommodation faces these particular people.

I say that there is a duplication because, from what I can see, there is a duplication and I believe that there should be a thorough review, perhaps conducted by someone outside the area, but incorporating the local communities that are active-the principals of the colleges, the chairmen of SkillShare, and other people within the community who should be in a position to advise the authorities as to the better way to prevent the duplication.

We see a certain fragmentation there now, one that will develop more in the future. So I appeal to the Minister to have a look at the situation. First of all, he must realise that it is developing and will continue to develop. Governments should try to find out, by consultation with local people and industry, the direction that the planning should take, from both a Commonwealth and a State point of view.

I find that the State of New South Wales is now making grants available for some forms of education outside its field. So it is that there is a duplication not only from the programmers, but from both the governments concerned. They have to confer properly, realise the position, and come up with a more satisfactory answer. The whole financial responsibility for this comes back upon the taxpayer. The taxpayer is the person who requires value for the money that is being spent. We see a duplication in many fields of Commonwealth, State and local government.

I believe this duplication is taking place within the educational field. It is important that these young unemployed-or any unemployed persons-who are undertaking the program not be lead astray in the long term. They should be assisted by way of technical advice and learning different fields, whether it be bartendering, typing, reception work, or anything of that nature.

Whatever changes are made must be in both the short and long term interests of these particular people within the community. SkillShare issues to participants in its program a certificate similar to the one issued by the local TAFE to those who complete a course. The SkillShare program may offer only a smattering of a subject-that is apparently all it is meant to cover. It may advise the student to attend the TAFE after that.

Some claim that 60 per cent of their people find jobs, but that actually encompasses the people who go on to TAFE, or people who may find only small, part-time jobs within the community. I think that might be a little misleading, having regard to the advice that is given to the public.

I do not have time to go into this matter in detail, but bearing in mind the economy of this country and our desire to train our young people properly, I appeal to the Government to consider this matter, and interlock this short training period of SkillShare with TAFE, or incorporate them. That is another suggestion-that SkillShare should be located and controlled by TAFE. If there are short term courses available to the public there now, why cannot these programs be incorporated into TAFE itself, on the premises, if the premises are available? This must result in cost savings and be much more successful than what we see at the present time, having regard to the fragmentation and multiplicity of what I believe is actually occurring.

That is why I say that if Australia is to increase its productivity, if we are to process the natural resources that we have got in Australia, including wool, we must create the programs that will train these people properly and which will ensure that they acquire technical knowledge.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bevis Mr A.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last September, I informed the House of problems existing within the Brisbane City Council area for part pensioners, and the costs they incurred when paying their rates. I would like to remind the House of the information that I presented at that time, which is still current. Full pensioners within the Brisbane City Council receive a 40 per cent rebate on their rates bill. Part pensioners, no matter to what extent they may receive a pension, receive no rebate whatsoever from the Brisbane City Council.

SPEECH.PARA: Last September, I took the opportunity to point out to the House the increased problem that this policy of the Brisbane City Council administration would create, following the introduction of deeming in March this year. Those calls went unheeded by the Brisbane City Council. Yesterday, the Lord Mayor of Brisbane, Alderman Atkinson, had the effrontery in the wake of that to attack the Federal Government, claiming that we had somehow introduced new laws that were going to tax Brisbane ratepayers. Yesterday's Daily Sun had this headline: `Mayor Blasts Feds on New Tax'. The article went on to state that the outraged Lord Mayor would lock horns with the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in Canberra today over the tax which she claimed would send the elderly broke.

That occurred yesterday. It would have been interesting to have been involved in that discussion, but I followed the course of that discussion today in the Courier-Mail. I noticed that the Courier-Mail reported that the Lord Mayor and the Minister for Social Security, Senator Richardson, were working on a compromise to prevent pensioners losing rate discounts.

I am quite sure that the Lord Mayor had a few of the facts of life explained to her yesterday during that discussion, and had pointed out to her the situation that does exist in the Brisbane City Council, because it is absolutely absurd to suggest that the Federal Government is in any way responsible for what is happening to part pensioners in the area covered by the Brisbane City Council. The Lord Mayor and her Liberal administration have determined that part pensioners will receive no rebate whatsoever.

The proof of that matter is not to wait until after 1 March; the proof is to see what the Council is doing now, before deeming is even introduced. One of my constituents has recently suffered at the hands of the Liberal administration's policy in Brisbane. Mr Lettice, a retired pensioner who is 78 years of age, is now in a position where he will have to pay $397.12 more for his rates every year because his pension is reduced by 64c. Because of a 64c reduction in his pension because of other income, he will pay $400 a year more to the Brisbane City Council, and the Lord Mayor of Brisbane has got the hide to come out, only a week or two after that information was presented to her, and claim that the Federal Government is imposing some new tax.

Mr Lettice, along with hundreds of other pensioners within my electorate, has suffered that additional cost, not because of deeming-because, as everyone in this place knows, deeming has not commenced-but because of the policy adopted by the Liberal administration in the Brisbane City Council. It has nothing at all to do with the Federal Government and certainly nothing to do with the deeming arrangements.

The situation is worse than that because the Brisbane City Council has, in fact, budgeted this year to continue to provide a pension rebate to every one of those full pensioners. So it is planning to give a 40 per cent rebate to all the people who are now on full pensions, some of whom, after deeming commences, will have a lower pension rate but, in fact, a higher personal disposable income because of their savings. The Brisbane City Council is content not only to take money from the part pensioners from whom it currently takes money, but also to make a windfall gain out of pensioners who, in a month's time, are likely to have part of their pension adjusted. To continue to provide the rebate to existing full-rate pensioners would cost the Brisbane City Council not one cent more than they budgeted-not a cent. Yet the Lord Mayor of Brisbane says that the Federal Government is responsible and it is an impost on the pensioner taxpayers and the pensioner ratepayers that has got nothing to do with her. It is squarely in her court.

The Federal Government has guaranteed to those people in this situation a continuation of the fringe benefits to those current holders of the pharmaceutical and health benefits card. I strongly urge the Brisbane City Council to adopt the same position and provide that guarantee to the pensioners of Brisbane who are currently full-rate pensioners. It will cost the Brisbane City Council not one cent more out of its budget. To fail to do that amounts to the Brisbane City Council's putting its hands into the purses of pensioners and taking money which it never intended to take, which it did not budget to take and which it has no right to take.

The Brisbane City Council, under a Liberal administration, is trying to make a profit at the pensioners' expense, to have a windfall gain not budgeted for. It then has the hide to turn around and blame the Federal Government. It stands as one of the most brazen political stings we have seen in recent times. It is a real confidence trick. These are the actions of a concerned Lord Mayor in the lead-up to a Brisbane City Council election and why would she not be concerned? She has had a party room revolt over a new dump at Rochedale, massive public discontent about the Council's failure to properly address waste disposal, and now, of course, there are angry pensioners who know she is the one trying to take more money from them.

Regrettably, the Courier Mail at the end of the story to which I referred continues with the myth that has been perpetuated by the Lord Mayor and by some others, that a group of pensioners are actually going to be worse off by virtue of deeming. Let me put the record straight-the only pensioners who will be worse off after deeming are those unfortunate enough to suffer at the hands of the Liberal Party's policy in the Brisbane City Council area. As has been made abundantly clear by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) and others, pensioners who invest their savings and as a result earn income from those savings and reduce their pension, will have a higher personal disposable income and will continue to receive the fringe benefits guaranteed by the Federal Government.

Those pensioners in Queensland are fortunate enough also to receive the benefit of the senior pensioner card recently introduced by the Goss Labor Government-and an important initiative that was. I might add, in the context of this debate, that the initiative provides for all senior citizens a rebate on their local government rates. The Brisbane City Council, of course, being the largest--

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: UN Convention of the Rights of the Child

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Taylor Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier today my Opposition colleagues the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) and the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Peter Fisher) led a debate in this House on the shortcomings of the Hawke Government's ratification of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child. I reject as simplistic the views of the honourable member for Brisbane (Mr Bevis) that this was, to use his own words, `mischievous debate'. On the contrary, it was an objective attempt by my colleagues to highlight two major points: firstly, that the Government has moved with unreasonable unilateral haste in the ratification process, without the opportunity for a single word of parliamentary debate.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, it highlights the fact that while we should not throw out the baby with the bath water by rejecting the convention outright, and while its underlying principles are sound, a number of its articles need amendment. They need amendment to ensure that they are not misconstrued in any quarter as flying in the face of the very real responsibilities of individual parents for what their children do or do not do. Such unfortunate perceptions have been conveyed to this House by nearly 5,000 petitioners. Once again, the Government's irresponsible action has dismissed as irrelevant a large body of public opinion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on behalf of retired people whom not all but some Opposition members have been trying to mislead regarding the Government's policy to ease the financial burden on taxpayers by requiring banks to give full value to pensioners with savings over $2,000. People with a lifetime of experience do not lose their marbles just because they are growing older. They are quite capable of appreciating the benefits to the taxpayer-their children and their grandchildren-when they move savings from a savings account with minimal interest to a savings investment account which pays interest of 10 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: This is not to belittle the discomfort someone can experience when a change is introduced, particularly when the person wishes to enjoy a reprieve from filling in forms after a lifetime of abiding by the laws. Some, too, have more complex investment arrangements.

Given the advantages to all Australians of a government at last tackling the imbalance which will occur as the number of pensioners peaks at the turn of the century while the number of taxpayers funding the pension declines, it is our duty as representatives to ensure that the change causes as little disruption as possible. Opposition members should not make political attacks. They should distribute pensioner information kits; explain the reasons for, and the processes of, deeming; and refer cases of potential hardship to the Minister. They will find that many pensioners wonder why they have never been told that they can keep their savings in an equally accessible account in the same bank but which pays much higher interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Filing Mr P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the House's attention to some statistics relating to unemployment in my area of metropolitan Perth- the north metropolitan statistical division-which contains sections of the city of Stirling and all of the area of the city of Wanneroo. I raise the fact that the unemployment rate is most strongly affecting those in the age group of 15 to 19 years. In this region there was an increase in the unemployment rate from 2,000 in December 1989 to 3,500 in 1990. This was an increase in unemployment of 111.24 per cent. That gives an unemployment rate for that particular age group of 35.7 per cent which is a national disgrace. It happens to be way above the Western Australian average of 12.02 per cent and way above the national average of 9.3 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: That indicates quite clearly that young people are being asked to carry the burden of the Government's economic incompetence. The conspiracy between the trade union movement and the Government's policies is causing youth unemployment to rise in a totally unacceptable way. I am giving the message to young people in Australia that the Government is virtually consigning a substantial proportion of them to unemployment for a great deal of their working lives. It has to be changed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There must not be ground war in Kuwait. There must be peace based upon Iraqi withdrawal, which then addresses postwar regional problems: the Palestinian-Israeli dispute, regional security arrangements, and secure borders for Middle East nations. Saddam Hussein and President Bush should accept the Soviet Union's initiative, with any agreed modifications. If this initiative provides for Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait, and then provides scope for addressing critical regional issues, it is virtually identical to the formula agreed between the United States and Soviet Foreign Ministers on 30 January last.

SPEECH.PARA: If the United States presses ground war after an Iraqi agreement to immediately withdraw, it would be because of expanded war aims beyond the liberation of Kuwait to the destruction of the Iraqi regime. How would this be achieved? Does the US push all the way to Baghdad? If so, tensions would increase between the super-powers and postwar regional problems would become more difficult to solve as Iraq is destroyed. Now is the time for the Australian Government, as a participating nation, to urge President Bush that war aims must not be expanded beyond Resolution 678.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sullivan Mrs K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Many serious issues are addressed in this chamber but from time to time some of us have the pleasure of raising slightly more pleasant subjects. I rise briefly to pay tribute to a fine group of athletes who are presently on the Gold Coast contesting one of the latest introductions to professional sport in Australia. I refer to the National Baseball Championship which will be contested at Palm Meadows tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: I notice the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards) nodding his head. He will be aware that the Gold Coast team, the Dolphins, is playing the Perth Heat for the championship. The Gold Coast Dolphins, of course, have the support of all of my constituents and many other people throughout south-east Queensland. We are looking forward to those fine young men winning the championship for the Gold Coast tonight.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the honourable member for Stirling want equal time?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: — I am happy with the comments of the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan); the result might be different. I am concerned about a situation were a young man can work 62 hours for a week and be paid $220. This is the amount being paid to a trolley boy who works for an organisation in Perth called VIP Cleaning Services. Its business address is in Bayswater and its home address is in Inglewood.

SPEECH.PARA: It is currently in the process, in my view, of exploiting young people. One young man recently told me that he was told that his wage was being reduced from $7.20 an hour to $5.20 an hour. When he complained about that he was told the he could work for $1 an hour or $4 an hour. This organisation refuses to discuss the matter with any of the parents; it refuses to discuss the matter reasonably with any of the young men; and it refuses to discuss the matter with anyone else. In fact, it is interesting that the trolley boys are not covered by an award or a union, which is a great shame.

I am concerned that young men are often being taken from one shopping centre to another, at great inconvenience to them, and being paid a very small amount of money. It is clearly a case of exploitation of young people. Incidentally, I point out that it makes the case for having unions and awards very strong. It is a particular concern of mine that we have young people being very grossly exploited. As I point out, for a young man to earn $220 for working 62 hours seems to me to be a very, very ordinary work practice indeed. VIP Cleaning Services certainly needs to lift its game.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cowan Mr D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I thought that you might be disappointed if I did not rise to speak about Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport. I speak on behalf of millions of frustrated people throughout Australia who, for the last eight years, have been waiting for the Commonwealth to do something about the third runway. The environmental impact study has been carried out; the report is to hand. Why will it be delayed for another year or so, or for forever, affecting those people who travel within the State of New South Wales, interstate and overseas.

SPEECH.PARA: Tourism is Australia's biggest industry now, because wool has gone down. If the economy is to come around, we have to do something about Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport where over 50 per cent of travellers coming into Australia arrive to circulate around the country. I appeal to the Government to do something about it. Badgerys Creek will cost the Government $6 billion to $8 billion with infrastructure and transport. We have to have something immediately to overcome the great need that exists at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McHugh Ms J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to remind the House and the Australian public, and I will again and again and again, of the forgotten case of Cyprus, which almost exactly parallels what happened when Iraq invaded Kuwait. Seventeen years ago Turkey, a country of 50 million people, with the largest army in the region, attacked and invaded a defenceless tiny neighbour, Cyprus-a small independent state, a member of the United Nations, a member of the Council of Europe and a member of our Commonwealth.

SPEECH.PARA: The aggressor bombed civilian targets, used napalm, left 5,000 dead, took hostages, murdered and raped civilians, as documented by the United Nations (UN) Human Rights Commission and the Council of Europe. It expelled one-third of the total population, creating refugees in its own land; it colonised the occupied territory so as to change the demographic character; installed a puppet regime in the occupied territory, supported by its occupation troops; looted the cultural heritage built up over 3,000 years; and continued contemptuously to ignore over 50 United Nations resolutions to withdraw.

Mr Speaker, I call for the implementation of the UN resolutions in Cyprus-nothing more, nothing less. That does not mean I am calling for war; I oppose war. I oppose the use of the military option. But there will be no good new world order if the world community is going to be selective in the application of the rule of law and universal principles regarding the conduct of nations. That will lead to allegations of hypocrisy and moral bankruptcy in the world community. Double standards cannot be maintained.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Riggall Mr J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to advise the House of a company in my electorate called Gippsland Aeronautics. This company has developed an agricultural aircraft due to get type certification in March of this year. The aircraft has been nicknamed the fatman and it is the first aircraft of a commercial nature to be developed in this country since the Nomad some 10 years ago.

SPEECH.PARA: Tragically, yesterday in the Senate Senator Cook, in answering a question in his capacity as the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin), gave an inconcise and sloppy answer. This has brought public speculation about whether aerial crop spraying is to be phased out.
I call upon the Minister responsible for prime industries to make a public statement which will terminate this speculation so tragically damaging to this fledging aircraft industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr L.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to bring to the attention of the House an important event taking place in my electorate this weekend to commemorate national scout week. True to the character of people in the Ipswich and West Moreton area, the local scout association has decided to go one step further than the rest of the country and adopt an international theme for the celebrations, something very appropriate for the scouting movement.

SPEECH.PARA: As reflected in the breadth of the countries that will be represented, through their consuls, at the opening of scout week on Friday, the scouting movement has developed and come a long way since being formed by Lord Baden-Powell in Great Britain 84 years ago. It was established in Australia one year later. Though many things have changed since the time of that first scout group, the spirit of camaraderie evident in scouting across the globe remains as strong as ever today. Here in Australia there are numerous scouting groups with more than 140,000 uniformed members amongst their ranks and with in excess of another 30,000 lay members assisting the movement.

In the Ipswich-Moreton area we have 25 uniformed groups with a total membership of about 1,000, plus approximately 500 lay personnel. With so many Australians involved in the scouting movement it is no surprise that most of us either have someone in scouts or have at some time been involved in the scouting move ourselves.

As the Federal member for the Ipswich area, it gives me great pleasure to be a part of the local celebrations, especially given the reliance of regional communities on the qualities and values that make the scouting movement. I take this opportunity to wish the Ipswich and Moreton scout region well in the celebrations for next week and throughout 1991.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support my colleague the honourable member for McMillan (Mr Riggall) in the comments he just made in the House and to express my concern that Senator Cook should consider anything as unbelievably emotional as a ban on aerial spraying.

SPEECH.PARA: Everyone in this House recognises the care that is needed when using agricultural chemicals but as one who has been inadvertently exposed to agricultural chemicals from time to time, I can only plead for a more realistic view of the essential role of agricultural chemicals in agricultural production in Australia. We only need to appreciate that the production of food is being very much influenced by the availability of agricultural chemicals and that in fact aerial application of these chemicals has in many instances been much safer than hand application would have been in precisely the same circumstances. I recognise that there is frequently far more exposure for human beings from hand application than there is from aerial application and I call on the House to recognise the relatively low risk to human beings that applies to the aerial application of chemicals.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 2 p.m., in accordance with sessional order 106A, the time for members' statements has concluded.

—As a matter of courtesy, I inform the House that I have appointed the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Hon. Robert Tickner, MP, as Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Aboriginal Reconciliation.

—I direct my question to the current Treasurer. In Question Time yesterday, the Treasurer was asked how many people in his electorate have been retrenched since the recession he engineered took hold. — Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. The point of order is that the Standing Orders in relation to Question Time are quite clear-questions shall not draw inferences and shall not contain information.
