—I have already asked the Deputy Leader of the Opposition to get to his question rather than continue with the preamble, so he might ask the question now.
—I ask the Treasurer: can he do any better today; and why does he not have the decency to resign?
—I have nothing to say.
—Mr Speaker, will you call on the Treasurer to answer that question?
—I called the Treasurer, and the Treasurer gave a response. I take it that is the only response.
—What was that response?
—What did you say?
—I ignored you. That is the response.
—Order! The Treasurer was called. The Treasurer made a response. I will now call the next questioner, the honourable member for Parramatta.
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. Is it permissible for the Treasurer to respond to a question without coming to the dispatch box?
—I call the honourable member for Parramatta.
— I ask the Prime Minister: can he inform the House of the latest developments in the Uruguay Round trade negotiations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure all members of the House will be pleased to know that negotiations overnight in Geneva appear to have paved the way for a restart of the Uruguay Round negotiations. There does appear to have been a long awaited breakthrough to the deadlock on reform of world agricultural trade. Of course, I must say that experience does suggest that we must be cautious in interpreting developments in agricultural negotiations. But, on the basis of the apparent breakthrough last night, there are grounds for optimism that the United States Congress will agree to an extension of the fast track legislation, allowing more time for negotiations to be completed. It seems that all participants are now willing to start negotiating on specific binding commitments to reduce farm subsidies, export subsidies and import barriers.

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable members will recall that it was the refusal of the European Community to make such an unqualified undertaking, particularly in relation to export subsidies, which led to the breakdown of the Brussels talks and the stalling of the Round. Clearly, if they do in the words of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade Director-General, Mr Arthur Dunkel, overcome the biggest hurdle to restarting the Round, then these developments are very welcome. Such genuine movement would, again to quote Mr Dunkel, `demonstrate a collective will to protect the international trading system and put the Uruguay Round back on track'.

The restart of the Uruguay Round negotiations on this basis also, of course, vindicates the position taken by Australia and the Cairns Group all along and specifically at Brussels. May I interpolate there to say that I think we are all indebted to the work done by the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development in this regard and the very competent group of officials that have supported him.

The position we have taken in these negotiations under the leadership of the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development is, firstly, that there can be no future reform of world trade that excludes agriculture and that reform of world trade in agriculture must include movement in those three areas of export subsidies, internal support and market access. Of course, success in the agricultural negotiations is absolutely vital to this country and to our farming community.

Earlier this week the Minister spoke about the increasing damage being caused to Australian farmers caught in this cross-fire of the export subsidy war between Europe and the United States. The Uruguay Round, in the agricultural negotiations, offers the best chance of ending that iniquitous trade war. As I said at the beginning, I am sure that all honourable members will welcome this development and hope that it will be the beginning of the end of this iniquitous trade war.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Treasurer: is it a fact that in the 1986 Budget Speech the Treasurer told the Australian people that we would trade out of our difficulties and that in the 1987 Budget the Treasurer said that `we have turned the corner and the big gaps in our trade account have begun to close'? Is it a further fact that in the 1988 Budget, the socalled `bring home the bacon' Budget, the Treasurer said that Australia had the best Budget numbers and that our current account deficit was close to a solution? In the 1989 Budget, whilst overseas debt skyrocketed--
—Order! The honourable member might get to his question.

—The Treasurer boasted that he was making a massive deposit in savings. I ask the Treasurer: in view of the fact that his statements do not equate with the reality and the economic agony, when will he have the decency to resign?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Budget surpluses are an unambiguous large deposit in the savings account of the nation. If the Leader of the National Party does not understand that he may as well not be here. As to Australia trading its way out of its troubles, of course we will trade our way out of our troubles. The fact of the matter is that the troubles, of course, sprang from the indolence of those opposite in the late 1960s and 1970s, that is, relying wholly on commodities. Talk about asleep at the wheel. When the weight really came on, when our competitiveness was falling to pieces and our secondary industries were being shut down and we were losing capacity hand over fist, we had the then industries Minister putting out lists of investment in mining. The great mineral boom was going to save everything. In fact, what they left us with was a place with an uncompetitive exchange rate, a $10 billion Budget deficit--
—But you had it fixed when we were bringing home the bacon.
—Order! The honourable member for Isaacs!

—Manufacturing just about shut down, and a massive level of unemployment. That is what they left us with. What we have done is internationalise the economy so we can trade out of our troubles, which we have done in two ways: by adding to investment, reducing the current account deficit, and building a stock of assets offshore --

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Reith interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition will cease interjecting.

—which sit in countervailance to the stock of debt onshore. We have about $90 billion of private debt onshore, and since we removed exchange control there is now $60 billion of assets offshore. That is at book value, and if one looks at those assets in terms of current market values, that $60 billion is more likely to be about the size of our private debt onshore. Over the 1990s there will be a higher dividend stream coming from those investments, which will reduce the net income deficit. That is what we call trading out of our troubles-not putting our head in the sand believing some lazy view that a blind faith in commodities will get us out of our troubles.

ANSWER.PARA: A lot of the problems of this country are visited on the exchange rate policies of the former Government, which were exacerbated by the mindlessness of the National Party. They left the Australian dollar wildly overvalued and robbed Australian farmers of income all through the 1970s and into the early 1980s. That whole tariff structure-that industrial protection from which we are now trying to extricate Australia, putting the breath of life back into industries that were deadened by the former Government in terms of international competition-was built by the honourable member's predecessor, Sir John McEwen, and the influence of the National Party on coalition governments through the Menzies and Fraser years.

We notice today that the Opposition's industry spokesman is talking about low tariffs. It is always about endorsing our policies. It is always about following us down the track. But where did the sclerosis come from? It came from mediocrities like the questioner, people who have tried to pass themselves off as national politicians whereas, in fact, they are basically hayseeds and Country Party hacks.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Community Services and Health. I refer to the newly released national health strategy background paper by John Deeble. What factors in this report indicate the need to finetune Medicare when the Australian Government has kept the cost of health care down to a considerably lower proportion of gross domestic product (GDP) than most other Western countries since the introduction of Medicare?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Dr Deeble's paper is the second in a series, and the first background paper coming out of the national health strategy. I would like to put on record my thanks to the Leader of the Opposition for a press release that he issued to the Press Gallery this morning which, frankly, I could not have bettered. He has taken the quotation. I want to confirm that it is absolutely accurate. It certainly makes me sound somewhat statesmanlike in the sense that those who read it will see that I am arguing for political debate on Medicare based on facts, not prejudice. The health care strategy document is totally consistent with what I had to say, and the Leader of the Opposition was good enough to circulate it verbatim to the Press Gallery.

ANSWER.PARA: Dr Deeble's paper shows that the fundamentals of Medicare are sound; however, that the medical service demand and supply sides need close attention by the national health strategy. It points to the fact that the number of doctors billing under Medicare increased by 25 per cent. The largest rises were in general practitioners, consultant physicians, psychiatrists and radiologists. The lowest increases were in surgeons, obstetricians and gynaecologists. There has been a very substantial increase in the 1980s in the number of doctors registered to practice and, therefore, billing for Medicare.

On average, total fees per doctor rose at about the rate of average weekly earnings (AWE) for general practitioners but significantly more specialists. Medical service use per person increased by 23 per cent in the five years to 1989-90, the largest increases being in pathology and other diagnostic services. On the other hand, the average fee for service has fallen by about 11 per cent in real terms since 1984-85, having risen by less than the rates of increase for either the consumer price index or AWE. Therefore, while usage of medical services continues to rise, its effect has been significantly offset by the decreased value of average fees in relative terms. The overall cost of private medical services remained a stable proportion of GDP, 1.24 per cent, over the past six years.

The paper documents a continuing underlying growth in the number of doctors and the use of medical services, particularly diagnostic services. The doctors numbers problem is the result of training decisions made in the 1970s.

With the exception of the United States of America, all western European countries have national insurance systems which ultimately have one payer, either the state or employer funded schemes. In other words, while members of the Opposition seem to delight in making something of bulkbilling, the fact is that the principles of bulkbilling are provided for in almost every Western country, with the exception of the United States.

TALK.START.PARA: —How does that follow?
—I will explain. The honourable member for O'Connor was not one of the more intelligent of my predecessors and he may need to listen rather more carefully than other members of the Opposition.
—It is a load of rubbish.
—The honourable member for O'Connor will cease interjecting.

—In the United States the larger number of private health insurers has led to higher costs in both service delivery and administration. The amount spent on health in the United States is 11.2 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP) while in Australia it is much less-8.1 per cent of GDP. In elaboration of that point, the trend in Australia throughout the 1980s was stable; the trend in the United States was for expenditure to move upward as a percentage of gross domestic product, which is why former Governor Dukakis is in Australia looking at the Australian health system as an alternative to the American model.

ANSWER.PARA: If we look at the amount spent on health per person, the difference between our two countries is even more pronounced. In the United States in 1987, $2,769 was spent on health costs per person compared with $1,294 per person in Australia. In other words, the United States spent more than double the amount on providing health care to each person compared with Australia. Unlike other national schemes, the Australian system puts very little restriction on delivery of health services. Medicare has not altered the basic structure of private practice and that, in many ways, is perhaps the most surprising thing-that we have preserved private practice but at the same time we have retained a stability in terms of health costs which is very unusual for other countries.

In the United Kingdom, France and Germany, the total level of funding available for medical services is closely controlled. In Canada, doctors' fees are tightly regulated and in some provinces, quantity and price are traded off. Australia is unusual because it does not cap either the supply of services or the demand for them. It is extraordinary in the light of that that Australia has managed to keep its share of health costs down for so long.

In conclusion, let me say that this is not to suggest that there are no issues in the Australian health system that need to be addressed. In this paper, Dr Deeble identifies some of the specific concerns. The paper refers to medical services. In the area of services, both on the supply side and on the demand side, there are certain issues that need to be addressed.

The Opposition raised this issue apparently for ideological reasons, and was unable to give the question of vouchers any policy content whatever. The Leader of the Opposition has remained absolutely silent because he is making an ideological point to the right wing of his own Party. As opposed to that, we are concerned with trends. I believe we have one of the best and more stable health systems in the world. We intend to go through the 1990s with that system leading the world, not wrecked by the ideological prejudices of a rather ignorant Leader of the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question without notice is to the Treasurer. In 1949, Ben Chifley said, `I try to think of our Labor movement not as making somebody Prime Minister or Premier, but as a movement bringing something better to the people'. In view of the fact that the Treasurer sees the Labor Party simply as a vehicle for his ambition, and as he is the engineer of the recession which has inflicted misery on most Australians, I ask the Treasurer: when will he have the decency to resign?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —All I can say is that the Leader of the Opposition is very worried about me! We hear that publicly from him at Question Time and we hear it privately from him through the organs of the Liberal Party. I can only say: and well he might be worried. Talk about an empty, monodimensional person who does not seem to understand what is required! The Leader of the Opposition put out a statement yesterday saying how extraordinary it was that the Prime Minister should try to berate him for simply being willing to look at a full range of ideas in the midst of a recession. He asked:

ANSWER.PARA: What does he think politics is about?

Politics is about working out what to do, and doing it. It is about finding solutions-not about being a visiting professor dropping issues, wafting into issues and wafting out the other side-which is the specialisation of the Leader of the Opposition. On anything of substance he is rolled in a second. He was rolled on the assets test. Even Senator Newman rolled him on something like a fee for the War Memorial. So on any matter of substance he cannot even get his own way in his party room.
A few minutes ago I had a question from the Leader of the National Party about the Budget surplus. The coalition parties never produced a surplus in the 30-odd years that they were in office.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is just not true.

—It is absolutely true. It is a matter of record; it is a matter of fact in the Budget documents. We have sat here and cut 7 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP) out of outlays, the equivalent of $28,000m a year. Yet on a thing like a fee up here at the War Memorial he is rolled. On a thing like the assets test on the family allowance-a perfectly sensible, equitable measure-he cannot get it through his party room, he gets rolled. This guy gets rolled on everything.

ANSWER.PARA: The Leader of the Opposition comes in with matters which are not substantial. He has all the ideas; they are ideas, he says. Then he attacks the Prime Minister for suggesting that his ideas do not have any flesh, just as my colleague suggested very adequately in relation to health. We have a fee for service system in health care in this country. We do not have a salaried system like Great Britain's with all of its problems. We have kept the national health cost below that of comparable countries.

In spite of that, the Leader of the Opposition walks in here with a voucher system which would let doctors charge what they like, which would see the private hospital sector blow its brains out and we would see people up for thousands of dollars a day to hospitalise themselves. He has not put one detail to it, and then he attacks the Government for daring to have the temerity to attack him.

The Leader of the Opposition talks about the light on the hill. As if anyone who has sold out his own people and gone across to represent the people of Vaucluse should be talking about the light on the hill. He is a fraud. He is a disgusting fraud.
Opposition members interjecting-

—Most of these characters behind the Leader of the Opposition have not got either two zacks to rub together or the intelligence to go with it, and ought to be supporting us.

ANSWER.PARA: I will tell honourable members what we are doing on this side of the House. We are trying-just as Ben Chifley did in his day-to re-establish the basis of Australian wealth, which was lost in the coalition's years of government. When Chifley left to the coalition the governing of Australia, the country had the second highest income per capita in the world. Yet it was down to eighteenth when we took over. So in the 30-odd years of coalition government Australia was taken from second place to eighteenth place. The proper basis of our wealth, the whole postwar trade in goods and services, just passed us by. The whole postwar trade in goods and services, adding value, passed us by when the coalition parties believed we could ride on the sheep's back, and then at a pinch dig up another mound of rocks and flog them to somebody.

That was the whole basis of the coalition government's policy. It let the whole basis of Australian wealth fall apart. What this Government has had to do is painstakingly put it back together, get the profit share up, fix the exchange rate, free up the financial markets, cut the Budget deficit, and deal with a surge of income which came off the large terms of trade rise and the boom it gave us. We had to try to come out the other side with lower inflation, which we did for the first time and which in 20 years the coalition government was incapable of giving us. Opposition members are supposedly people of business; they are the people who supposedly knew better-until inflation came along with the first oil shock.

TALK.START.PARA: —De-spiv the economy!
—The Deputy Leader of the Opposition will cease interjecting.
—Members opposite sat with double digit inflation and were absolutely useless. Now, after two decades, it again falls to Labor to break the back of inflation. That is what this recession is about.
—Tell us why we had to have a recession.

—To get the current account under control, to face up to issues and not be basically, as the Leader of the Opposition is, a visiting professor wafting in and out of issues without giving any specificity to any policies.

—I ask the Treasurer whether he is aware of recent comments by the Governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia, Mr Bernie Fraser, suggesting that there is scope for bank lending rates to come down? Is there scope for bank lending rates to be further reduced?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Governor of the Reserve Bank had this to say the other day:

ANSWER.PARA: In our view there is scope for banking lending rates to come down a little further yet in the wake of the December easing in official interest rates.

What we do know happens in the banking industry is that it takes a while, after an official easing of rates, for the cost of deposits to migrate down, as some of the deposits are month, 3-month or 6-month deposits, and find their place in a lower rate structure. Gradually those easings have come through. I certainly endorse what the Governor has said. It is also worth recording that every rate reduction has been opposed by the Leader of the Opposition-the professor. He has opposed them all. In February 1990, he said:
Why the sudden urgency? Australians will know that policy is again being manipulated for political ends.
He said also:
It begs the question really as to whether it is a political decision.
On 23 January, he said:
Today's move to begin lowering them is a pre-election ploy. It begs the question of just how much Mr Keating is pushing the pace of interest rate reductions simply to suit his electoral timetable.
On 1 February, he said:
Everybody knows that this crowd would put interest rates up again if they were to get back into office.
They have only fallen by five percentage points since. He continued:
In this sense the Treasurer is still forcing the pace.
He said in March last year:

The public would be justifiably cynical, particularly in regard to the statement that was made yesterday by the Prime Minister and the Treasurer that after the election they were going to instruct the Reserve Bank to lower interest rates.

That is what we did. Interest rates were lowered. The Leader of the Opposition's comments go on and on all through 1990 into 1991. This is the person who is complaining about the recession and about the costs Australians have had to bear but who for shabby political reasons, shabby political motives, has opposed every rate reduction that the Government has put into place. The Leader of the Opposition said in a press release yesterday:
The starting point is honesty.
Professor Hewson is dead right. What about starting with him?

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations aware of calls for increased labour market flexibility, particularly at the enterprise level, so as to improve productivity and competitiveness? Can the Minister inform the House what progress has been made in this area?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can inform the House that certainly in recent years there has been much concern on the part of all parties involved in the industrial relations process-employers, unions, governments and the industrial tribunals, Federal and State-to achieve a system that had much more flexibility in the labour market at the enterprise level. I can say to the House that developments in that regard over the last two or three years have been very encouraging indeed. We now have a framework for the implementation of a considerable degree of labour market flexibility at the enterprise level, the like of which could not have been envisaged a few years ago.

ANSWER.PARA: The means by which that has come together is basically through the introduction of the structural efficiency principle, which has enabled enterprise level flexibility to be put in place by such means as the award restructuring process, which provides for multiskilling; broad-banding of classifications in awards-in the metals award 300 classifications came down to 14; and skill-related career paths. That gives great scope for management at the enterprise level to utilise the work force flexibly and productively in a way that simply was not possible under the previous arrangements.

There have also been other award variations to allow flexibility at the enterprise level in regard to a whole host of working arrangements such as the spread of ordinary hours, rostered days off, meal breaks, job sharing, shift work rosters, reductions in penalty rates, provisions for part time and casual work, and things of that nature. There is also provision in awards for enterprise flexibility agreements. These agreements are exceedingly important in that they provide the means by which, at the enterprise level, the award variations can be implemented in a way that suits the enterprise's own arrangements. That is a major development.

This has enabled enterprise agreements to be reached in a vast number of industries. We see that such clauses apply at the present time in timber, clerical, storing and packing, transport, journalism, metals, building, food, entertainment, paint, local government, brewing, gas, and textile, clothing and footwear. All these agreements require endorsement by the Industrial Relations Commission, but there are some other types of agreements that do not require that Commission endorsement; they are called facilitative clauses.

So the structural efficiency principle has, in a variety of ways, enabled enterprise level flexibility to be introduced in a way that very much increases the capacity for us to get increased productivity and efficiency. That has been supplemented by two other factors. One is the provision for certified agreements, introduced in the Industrial Relations Act 1988. There are 45 such agreements that can go outside award conditions. The other is the wages system, which is now moving to focus much more on the enterprise level. In the current national wage case virtually all parties-employers, unions and governments-are supporting the development of a wages system that allows for wage increases to be negotiated at the enterprise level but within a framework of general guidelines to be determined by the Commission. Assuming that the national wage decision endorses this approach, we will have made a major change in wage determination in this country in a way that further extends labour market flexibility.

With all of this happening, one would think, listening to the Opposition, that it would be accepting that this is a major change. What we have is continual prattling about the need for enterprise agreements as though nothing was happening. In fact, a whole edifice has been erected through the structural efficiency principle and other changes I have mentioned. With the endorsement of the national wage case completing that process, a whole edifice has been erected which is enabling enterprise level negotiations to take place in a way that has never been the case in industrial relations in this country before.

We have from the Opposition its spokesman prattling on this morning about how he is going to erect a tent pole for economic policy through the bringing in of voluntary enterprise agreements. While he is erecting a tent, we have erected a massive edifice which is certainly going to do a lot more for enterprise level agreements, flexibility at the workplace and productivity than the Opposition's voluntary agreements ever would do.

Two other factors should be mentioned about the Opposition's policy. Firstly, with the Opposition's voluntary agreements not having the involvement of the Commission, with therefore no guidelines applying to wages policy, it would have no idea about the wages outcome and no means of controlling that. Secondly, and most importantly, the Opposition's policies would also open the door to severe exploitation of workers who were poorly organised and had poor bargaining power. That, of course, fits with the general approach that we have seen from the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, on a point of order: I want to take the same point of order that I took yesterday, namely, that Ministers are taking far too long to answer questions. I ask you to rule that they make ministerial statements. There is less and less time available for questions to be asked by a very large House of Representatives. I ask you to rule accordingly.

—As I was saying, the fact is that the possibility of severe exploitation is opened up by the Opposition's policy of non-involvement of the Commission in voluntary agreements which could break award conditions, meaning that the employees could simply have employers impose on them the loss of things like annual leave, meal breaks, sick leave entitlements or whatever in a way in which there would be no control.

ANSWER.PARA: This breaching of the plank which has existed in industrial relations throughout this century, where there has been this basic protection for those who are the least capable of defending themselves, would be a major sea change in industrial relations. But it fits absolutely with the approach of the Opposition which we have seen in a whole host of other areas this week in relation to health, education and social security where the Opposition does not really care about the weak and the disadvantaged. The Opposition's policies have no concern for those sorts of people.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

The ruling on his point of order is that I do not know why he might have drawn the inference that I was suggesting it was Opposition members. INTERJECT.PARA: I also remind the Opposition that the House seems to have adopted a position lately that Question Time runs for longer than three-quarters of an hour so that members get the chance to ask more questions. The Prime Minister seems to have had a deliberate policy of allowing that to occur, for which I commend him. The Minister for Finance was answering a question. We will have his answer. I am sure the member for Bennelong, as the Opposition spokesman, is interested in what he has to say.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I was saying, I can understand the sensitivity of the Opposition, but the fact remains-and the Opposition spokesman knows this-that his policy opens the door to exploitation by taking away the award plank which has always existed, thus enabling workers to be exploited. — I refer the Minister for Community Services and Health to comments he made at his press conference this morning on the extent of overservicing by doctors uncovered by the Deeble report. Will the Minister please explain his proposal for `a budget for doctors', which would impose some `pain on them' in order to contain costs? In particular, can the Minister explain what criteria doctors would be required to use to ration services under this proposal?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Lowe for his question. As I said in the previous answer I gave, I was referring this morning to the pattern outlined in the Deeble report in terms of servicing and the growth in the number of services. I made the point that the average rate of growth prior to Medicare was about 3.4 per cent and that the average growth in a number of services after the introduction of Medicare was about 3.7 per cent. Effectively the overall rate of servicing varied little prior to Medicare and after the introduction of Medicare. That is an extremely important point.

ANSWER.PARA: The difficulty with averages is that they mask differences. Particular problems vary on different bases. One of the points that I made, and perhaps could have emphasised more, was that the pattern of servicing will vary across Australia. For example, a member with an electorate in, say, Sydney where there is an oversupply or a very significant number of doctors is likely to find a pattern of overservicing as doctors seek to carry out more services effectively to lift their incomes. I made the point that perhaps to some extent that is understandable in the sense that the position of supply leads people to a situation in which they want to achieve more.

At the same time, those same doctors have accepted and make use of bulkbilling, but one ought not draw the conclusion that members of the Opposition seem to draw, that is, that somehow the insurance system is related to the rate of servicing. The insurance system is not found to be particularly significant.

However, there are particular areas where overservicing occurs. The value of the Deeble report is that it illustrates and points out patterns of servicing that are much more serious perhaps than in terms of general visits to the doctor or general consultations. Overservicing occurs particularly in the area of pathology. As I indicated, the figures for general pathology services show a rate of increase not of 3.7 per cent or 3.4 per cent but of 7.3 per cent per annum. For radiology, the increase is 4.8 per cent. The particular area of overservicing that we are concerned about and that Deeble points our attention to is not the whole area of Medicare but the area of diagnostic services. For me that point was important enough to warrant putting some facts in front of the Parliament and the people. In that sense, that was all that was requested of the author of the paper.

At a press conference it is not unusual for one to be questioned about what one's response will be to the problem of overservicing. In one press conference I simply referred to the situation in other countries. The former Minister for Health pointed out to me as I was approaching the dispatch box that I could have mentioned British Columbia, but in fact I was thinking of Great Britain, which does not have a fee for service system as we do in Australia. It operates a system which at the moment it is experimenting with and which would set a budget for general practitioners so that they have some sense of the financial impact of the services they order.

As I indicated at the same press conference-I noticed a member of the staff of the Leader of the Opposition there, so he should have had the following reported to him-because the United Kingdom system is not based on fees for services but on a very different system, I did not see that approach as necessarily relevant to Australia. Rather, I saw as being more relevant an approach that emphasised the need for the education of general practitioners and for a greater understanding on the part of the medical profession of the concept of accountability. The fact of the matter is that when one orders a test, one is ordering up, in effect, dollar costs. There is a cost which needs to be recognised.

In a real sense, in Australia we need to find a way of putting greater emphasis on this point. It might be asked, `How do I draw the conclusion that education might be a significant approach?'. I draw that conclusion from the very clear suggestion in the Deeble report that there is enormous variation between pathologists and other diagnostic groups. General practitioners vary enormously in terms of the number of tests that they order. Perhaps that is putting it more clearly.

So, in a sense, there are different approaches and in terms of training and in terms of discussion within the medical profession, within the colleges, it seems to me we ought to be able, together, to find a solution to a problem which simply we cannot live with. In conclusion, I would not want to have my remarks this morning or the Deeble report interpreted as in any sense flagging a particular attack on pathologists or any one group. The reality is that all this report is doing is factually saying there is a problem that we need to face up to. Part of the problem is to do with diagnostic testing. There is a number of issues and elements that are behind that situation. We ought to address them sensibly. That is the contrast. We work on the basis of the facts. We precisely attempt to address the problem. We do not throw up ideology clothed as policy. It is not policy; it is nonsense; and, if we go down that route, we do the Australian people no service.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Transport and Communications. It refers to proposals for the privatisation of Telecom Australia and OTC Ltd. Is the Minister aware of proposals urging the Government to privatise telecommunications by offering Telecom and OTC for sale to the private sector; is this proposition feasible; and what are the Government's intentions in this matter?

—Mr Speaker, I wish to raise a point of order. Again I draw your attention to standing order 144 which, in paragraph (b), clearly indicates that the Minister does not have the right to proceed down a policy announcement path as is indicated by the last part of that question. As such, I would ask that you rule that question out of order.
—The honourable member for Burke specifically asked the Minister a question about his portfolio, and nothing about the announcing of policy.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. I think the honourable member for Burke would be well aware that the approximate value of Telecom and OTC combined is something like $21 billion. About the largest raising on the Australian share market in recent times has been some $700m. So if anyone-and this includes the Opposition-sought in government to privatise Telecom or were this Government to proceed down that course, we would obviously throttle the Australian share market for years if we were to reach anything like the true value of Telecom-OTC in the price the taxpayers received for their asset being dispensed with.

ANSWER.PARA: Of course, if the Opposition's policy in that regard were pursued, it would not be achieved. In other words, Telecom would be sold for a great deal less than its worth-and something like that was the experience of the British when they went down that same course. In the process of the attempt being made, two things would happen. Firstly, those elements of the service which are important to the public, particularly the disadvantaged sections of the public--

TALK.START.PARA: —The sky has fallen in. The Labor Party has done everything terrible.
—Order! The honourable member for Mayo will cease interjecting.

—They would very rapidly disappear as the new owners sought to recoup their investment. That is the first thing that would obviously happen with it. Secondly, the Government of the day would lose interest in capping the charges. Indeed, where these sorts of things have occurred, the Government of the day has lost interest in capping the charges.

ANSWER.PARA: So what the public could be convinced about in this particular proposition is that the price of the telephone service would rise. Whatever happened to the business community, the price of telephones to the ordinary members of the public would rise. Add to that the Opposition's proposal to impose a 15 per cent tax on goods and services, and not only would it rise in accordance with the lifting of shackles related to privatisation, but it would also rise with an additional 15 per cent-15 per cent on this, just like there would be 15 per cent on food, 15 per cent on clothing, 15 per cent on medicines, 15 per cent on wreaths for Anzac Day, 15 per cent on every element which is a necessity of life in this community.

The ordinary taxpayer would carry the burden-and this from an Opposition that says time and time again here in Question Time that it is seriously concerned about what is happening to ordinary people in this country. The propositions of the Opposition on the privatisation of Telecom are of a piece with all the other positions that they adopt. What they are about is making a massive imposition on ordinary Australians in defence of ideology, not of sensible policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, could I add to an answer I gave earlier? In a question I was asked earlier, the Leader of the National Party suggested that there were surpluses under the coalition government. I table an extract from Budget Paper No. 1 from the 1990-91 Budget, page 513, which shows that as far back as 1953-54-that is, three years after the coalition came into office-there was never a Budget surplus. The only surpluses were the surpluses created by this Government-the first one in 1987-88.
