DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Lowe (Dr Bob Woods) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of Medicare to deliver high quality and accessible health care to all Australians.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woods Dr R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: — I want to start this discussion by congratulating the Minister for Community Services and Health (Mr Howe) because at last he has come to the conclusion that there are indeed some problems with Medicare. He has been able to bring himself to say this publicly for the first time in his release of the paper by Dr John Deeble that we discussed earlier in Question Time.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a whole range of issues. However, I want to say to the Minister, in the best bipartisan spirit: I am glad the light has come into his life, and we will actually help him recognise these problems. We want to be generous about this. We will give the Minister some advice in discussions about how to fix them. We will do our best to solve them in a constructive way. Our aim is not to be partisan just for the sake of it. Our aim is to be bipartisan, wherever possible, for the benefit of Australia. We want to work together to get a health system that is good for all Australians-not just those who can afford it, not just those whom the Government covers, but for Australia.

This morning the Minister released a document which indicated very clearly that there were a number of problems with the Medicare system. The first problem is the question of overusage. We have to ask ourselves whether there is overservicing and overusage of this system. We have been saying for years, from the time of the introduction of Medicare onwards, that there was overservicing. Were we right? Clearly, we sure were! Who tells us? No less a person than the Minister for Community Services and Health. How bad is it? The answer is that it is very bad. The figures show that the services used in Australia between 1984 and 1989 went from 114 million to 153 million-up almost a third. Why was this? It was not because of an increase in population. It was not because of any change to the schedule. The Minister himself says that he does not really know why.

I guess it is a bit difficult to get all the neurons working at once, so let us give the Minister a bit of a prod. The figures have increased because of a range of things, but mainly because of bulkbilling. The largest increase was in bulkbilled items. The Minister has pointed out in this place many times, with glee, that bulkbilling is increasing rapidly. Around Australia the level stands at about 55 per cent. The State with most bulkbilling is New South Wales, where 75 per cent of general practitioner services are bulkbilled. Where does the most overusage occur? It occurs in New South Wales. Of course, it could just be a coincidence. It could be a chance finding.

I want to point out an inconsistency between this and the Government's approach to pharmaceuticals. There is a major inconsistency. In August the Minister said that there is a gross overuse of pharmaceutical benefits items. The solution to that, which we agreed with, was to introduce a price signal. That included the $2.50 charge for pensioners. The Minister's press release stated:
The introduction of a charge on prescriptions for pensioners is part of a program which will make the PBS more efficient and encourage more responsible use of medication.
The Treasurer (Mr Keating) himself said that if we do not charge for a service it will get overused. Amazingly, for the first time in most of our careers, we would agree with the Treasurer.

I find myself also agreeing with Minister Howe and with the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services (Mr Staples). They got it right for pharmaceuticals and a price signal is important, even if it is fully rebatable. The Government should introduce price signals and we would support that perception. Minister Howe keeps on pushing this perception that the levy pays for everything and the whole service is free. That is absolute nonsense. The levy pays for about one-fifth of Commonwealth outlays in this respect. There is an enormous misunderstanding in the community because of that perception he peddles around.

The Minister claims that Medicare costs have been kept down, and I have to say that we are always in favour of keeping costs down. Let us see whether this is true, and, if it is true, how it has been achieved. There is some truth in it. It is a relatively cheap system-cheap in every sense of the word. It has not led to enormous blow-outs, but how has the Government done that? The answer is very simple. To keep costs down it has kept the quality down and kept the access down. It has rationed services. The headline of the Minister's press release says `Howe: Health resources must be rationed'. Further down it says:
Resources are limited and rationing is unavoidable.
It is the Minister's press release; they are his words. This is what he believes-that rationing is needed. It is what he has said. If that is what he has said, he should stand up and support it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Look up, Brian. Don't hang your head in shame.

—I agree entirely. The reason people are on waiting lists in this country-they are enormous waiting lists-is due to this Minister and his predecessor, because they have rationed health services and rationed drugs. How serious is the rationing? Is it a real problem? If someone in his own State of Victoria wants to have ear, nose and throat surgery at, say, the Monash Hospital-it is one of the leading centres in Australia-the only problem with having such surgery there is that one waits 23 months, almost two years, for very painful and uncomfortable conditions. There are a whole range of other problems. If one goes to some other hospitals one might be lucky enough to get it done within a year. It is all around Australia; it is not just confined to one State. The problems of this system are all across the whole country. This matter is very interesting to me because I have a quote which is of some relevance to it. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: I think sometimes the patient is at the bottom of the pile rather than our greatest priority.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?
— Honourable members can ask where that came from. They might think it was Bruce Shepherd, John Logan or somebody like that. No, it was our beloved Minister. Let me read it again:

SPEECH.PARA: I think sometimes the patient is at the bottom of the pile rather than our greatest priority.

The Minister should indeed hang his head in shame when he says a thing like that. He is admitting what a lousy system he has constructed. It is an abject failure, both in terms of the system and what he has done to it in so many regards.

Let me touch upon our position. As I said yesterday in this House, we on this side have no bias against Medicare as such. We realise that Medicare has a number of problems and we are happy to do our best to fix them with the Government, if need be. There is nobody here who is ideologically committed to destroying Medicare. We will look at a whole range of options and see if Medicare can be fixed, and if it can, we will fix it. We are looking at a whole range of options and one of those options is the voucher system. It has some advantages; it has some disadvantages. It is just one of a whole range of options which we are considering. The situation is not as the Government would paint it-that this option is the be all and end all of our philosophy.

I will also make a few points about my quote that if anybody is worse off, then it is better if they choose to be worse off. The Government seems to be trying to avoid a few basic points. Forty-six per cent of the population at present chooses, on top of paying their Medicare levy, to take out private health insurance. Forty-six per cent of the population chooses to be worse off so that they can have access to private health insurance, and that is how it should be. Somehow the Minister thinks that it is amazing. I must say it is a bit surprising that 46 per cent of the population do still take out private insurance after the way the Minister has squeezed health insurance and the private hospitals.

The private health system is groaning under the strain. The Minister took out the bed day subsidies and the reinsurance contributions and changed the gap contributions. He took $430m from the private health system and he wonders why the system is groaning under the strain.

It transpires that the Minister has some rather strange concepts about how our health system works. On the one hand he splutters and spouts over there with the rhetoric that everybody in this country has access to good quality medical care.

TALK.START.PARA: —And spits.
— Yes, it is a bit like that. I seem to remember the honourable member for Kooyong needed an umbrella at one stage.
—There is no need for the honourable member for Lowe to include those sorts of remarks in his speech.

— All right, but the Minister does make some very strange comments. I will point out one of the problems he has in understanding this matter. I quote him from an interview on the Walsh Report on 17 June 1990. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Public hospitals are primarily centres for teaching, for research, for treating people who are very sick and who may have obscure and difficult complaints.

So if one does not have a obscure, difficult complaint, is not going to be researched on, and does not have private insurance, what exactly is one supposed to do? That means that if one has a touch of mild pneumonia or a hip that needs replacing or a need for cataract surgery, one should not expect such mainstream problems to be dealt with in a public hospital; they should be dealt with in a private hospital. Surely even the Minister cannot mean that. That means that 55 per cent of the population cannot have those diseases treated because they do not have access to a private hospital. The Minister has squeezed the private industry so much, and put up the premiums so much that people cannot afford private insurance and they cannot have access to private beds. Those patients just have to grin and bear it. I presume this is a mistake. Even the Minister could not really be espousing that sort of nonsense. I hope that the Minister will take the opportunity to recant on that. I would be delighted to say that even the Minister with his socialist ideology actually would not want that situation.

Let me look at the ideology. I believe that one of the things that both the Government and the Opposition should be doing is looking at the whole system, free of bias and preconceived ideas, in order to see what gives the best position in terms of quality of care, access to that care and efficient delivery of that care. I think that we would actually agree on those basic principles.

As I said, the voucher system is one option and it is one on which the Minister seems very keen for some reason. I can understand that with all the problems the Minister is facing, he would try to grasp at anything. It seems that the Minister is trying to grasp this alternative and palm it off onto us. But this is one option in a whole range of options.

The Minister should be getting away from his blinkered, ideological, socialist approach to Medicare. We should not beat around the bush. One of the Minister's aims is to push the socialist agenda. There is no doubt about his credentials. Let me remind the Minister of a few speeches which he made-a few years ago now but in this Parliament-and which he has never retracted or argued against. He said that the Government could raise $700m per year on death duties and that not taxing deceased estates was `inequitable'. Does the Minister still espouse death duties? Does he still espouse taxing deceased estates? The Minister is trying to push our medical system into a socialist agenda.

There is an enormous problem with access to services. One of the things that Minister has always claimed is that there is good access because Medicare is a quality service and everybody has access to it. We have looked at the quality of the service. What about the access to the service? It is not just access to hospitals, it is access to a whole range of other areas. In particular, what about Medicare offices? Most people would think that part of the Government's philosophy would be to make Medicare offices accessible so that people do not have to travel very far to get their rebates.

Over the last few months the Minister has actually closed 13 offices-one would think he would be opening them. A large number of these offices are in the country. He has closed the offices in Leeton and Narrandera, for example. He has closed offices in the electorate of the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith). He has closed offices in Perth. In the case of the people in Leeton and Narrandera who want to make claims, they would have to travel 51 kilometres and 95 kilometres respectively to Griffith to get a rebate or else wait weeks for it to come through the post.

Of course, on top of that, in this time of unemployment, the medical office staff in those areas will either lose their jobs or be forced to relocate, taking their buying capacity out of an already depressed rural area. The Minister claims that he is saving money-about $1m. It is not good enough to save money and to put an extra burden such as this on patients. Closing these offices will be remembered by the electorate, as will the Government's callousness to a whole range of other issues, including kids with holes in the heart.

Let me cite a case in point. This morning I was speaking with Roger Mee from the Royal Children's Hospital in Melbourne. I think the Minister is probably aware of the problem here. He may well look a bit embarrassed, because it is embarrassing for the Government. Roger Mee is the head of the cardiac surgery unit at this hospital. It treats 700 kids a year, and we are talking about kids with congenital heart disease-hole in the heart patients and similar patients. Most of those disabilities are life threatening. That unit has the reputation for being one of the best units in the world.

The Victorian Labor Government-and I remind honourable members that it is a Labor government-says it cannot afford to fund the unit properly because it does not get appropriate funds from the Commonwealth. Fortunately for kids, there is a private foundation which has contributed a quarter of a million dollars for an operating theatre. It is an operating theatre, not extras, that we are looking at. These are basic things here. Let the Minister try operating without an operating theatre-or try operating at all! Costs include $80,000 for sterilisers, $100,000 for monitoring equipment, $100,000 for heart-lung machines-I could go on. It would be impossible to run that unit without that sort of private foundation support. There is a 24-bed intensive care unit, but 10 of those beds are closed because there are no funds to run them. I could go on and on about the hospital.

This Minister has actually evaluated the situation-he is aware of it. The Minister's Department was supposedly, in October this year, going to announce whether in fact it would fund a grant to this centre as a centre of excellence. There is no question that it should get it. But while the Minister is dithering and delaying and trying to put off the evil day of spending a bit more of our money, those kids are suffering. I call upon the Minister, in the best spirit possible, to announce that grant for those people as soon as it is possible.

What about Danny Young? I mentioned Danny yesterday. He has troubles because he cannot get an appropriate suit. He has scars as a result of a firecracker accident-scars all over his leg. The treatment is to wear a pressure suit, rather like a wet suit. It stops the scars from being deforming and it stops him from being immobilised later on. The total cost over 18 months is about $4,000. This Minister's Department has said that it cannot afford $4,000 to ensure Danny has a reasonable quality of life. There are hundreds of cases like Danny. It is passing it off. What this Minister says is, `We will pass that on to the States. We will not give the States any money; we will just pass responsibility on to the States'. So either Danny's parents have to raise that money or, sadly, Danny may be immobilised.

Just a few minutes away from here there is a pensioner, Mr Adam Milanczuk, who has oesophageal ulcers. They have haemorrhaged repeatedly, and it is dangerous, because haemorrhaging in the oesophagus-which is the gullet, in case the Minister does not know-is really a major problem. Every other treatment that he has had has failed. He had a drug called Losec six months ago. It is a new drug. It worked dramatically well. Unfortunately, the ulcers recurred and the Minister's associate Department was actually asked-under Minister Staples in fact-whether in fact he could have another course of the drug. And what was the answer? `No-you can have one course of this drug in your whole lifetime'. Once only, once ever. If the patient haemorrhages, that is just tough. If he haemorrhages and bleeds and dies, what will the Minister do? What will the Minister and Minister Staples do if in fact this pensioner does have another haemorrhage and does die?

I think one of the things the Minister has to decide is whether he can hold his head up here with the quality of service that he is offering to the community of Australia. We will work together with him constructively to reconstruct a Medicare system, a health system, which gives quality care to everybody, which gives access to everybody, which delivers that health care efficiently, which is understandable and which is not a major imposition upon the pockets of individuals or the pocket of our community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HOWE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Community Services and Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Lowe (Dr Bob Woods) referred to the fact that the Government seemed to have discovered that there may be some problems associated with Medicare or associated with the national health system. Of course, he forgets-as apparently the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) had forgotten-that the national health strategy or the review of health care in Australia was announced last November. At the time of that announcement we in fact defined the series of issues that would be dealt with as part of the national health strategy. So, rather than putting our heads in the sand and failing to recognise that there were some issues, we in fact defined what the issues were, and as a responsible Government, we are setting about systematically seeking to deal with those issues.

SPEECH.PARA: Interestingly enough, the opportunity was not taken by the Opposition spokesperson, the honourable member for Lowe, to do any serious analysis of the Deeble report. Rather than spending time on the question of overservicing, which he seemed to think was an important issue, and dealing with the information included in the report, he skipped off into a range of other issues. Of course, the Deeble report is not unimportant, because it systematically looks at the trends in relation to both the supply side and the demand side in terms of medical services fitting into Medicare. He makes the point that there has been an increase in the average use of service of about 23 per cent over the six years of Medicare. After the first two years, the average annual increase equalled 3.7 per cent, compared with the pre-Medicare rate of 3.3 per cent. So rather than being dramatic, as the aggregate figures would suggest, that increase in the trend is not really very dramatic at all. It is a significant trend, and we take account of it, but it is not dramatic.

More seriously, the honourable member points to the trend in relation to diagnostic services. There the trend not only is more serious but obviously also requires the Government to develop measures that will deal with a much more significant increase. For example, in pathology there was a rate of growth of 7.3 per cent per person per annum, and for radiology there was a rate of growth of 4.8 per cent per annum. Therefore, it is the diagnostic areas that are the growth areas.

Of course, the honourable member's attempt to link all this somehow to Medicare and bulkbilling falls because, essentially, diagnostic services-the main growth areas-are effectively generated not by the general practitioners (GPs) or by the population; in fact, they are generated by the doctors themselves. As Deeble points out, even there we see quite a wide range of practice. That figure represents an average. In terms of the actual referring of people to diagnostic services, something which occurs in an extraordinarily high proportion of GP visits-I think something like 50 per cent of GP visits lead to an ordering up of tests-we see that that varies a great deal from general practitioner to general practitioner. There is something happening here that we need to know more about. Of course, part of the method of the national health strategy will be to pursue these questions given rise to in the various reports in order to understand them more and to understand what we can do about them.

The interesting thing is that during that period in which there has been some growth of services with all the attendant pressures on Medicare, Medicare has stood up very well. In terms of doctors' fees, the average fee for service has risen 32.8 per cent-less than the consumer price index, and a little less than average weekly earnings. Doctors have had to share some of the restraint worn by the general community. The honourable member for Lowe should understand that because, after all, his political party has opposed every national wage rise that I can remember during our period in government.

There is an issue, it is an issue about services, and it is an issue which we will have to deal with. The honourable member draws an analogy between Medicare and the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. I suppose that there are some parallels. The fact of the matter is that essentially we finance Medicare through the levy. Australian taxpayers make a contribution to the levy according to their income. On the other hand, the pharmaceutical benefits scheme is funded by taxation. We are talking, therefore, about quite different issues. The real problem, as I suggested before, in the diagnostic area-at which we have to look rather critically-is that it is not particularly related to the clients at all. It is related more to general practitioners who order up these tests in increasing numbers, perhaps without being fully aware of the fiscal impact.

In what turned out to be a very general speech, the honourable member for Lowe did a number of things. He sought to attack Medicare again. Frankly, I do not understand why the Opposition thinks it is good politics to attack Medicare. I drew the attention of the House to the fact that seven out of every 10 Australians are currently in favour of Medicare. Support for Medicare has been steadily increasing and in 1990 had stabilised at 71 per cent-the same level as it was in 1989. Opposition to Medicare, to which the honourable member for Lowe referred, has reduced to an all time low of 22 per cent. Essentially, only half of Liberal voters oppose Medicare. Only two in every 10 Australians oppose Medicare.

As to the honourable member's reflections on the health system, the same research indicates, in some quite telling ways, a degree of satisfaction with the health system that I think would also be of considerable concern to him. The most telling of all the statistics in the survey, given all the criticism of the public hospital system by the Opposition, is that 66 per cent of those people who have been in a public hospital in the last two years were satisfied with their experience because of the good standard of care, service, treatment and cost. In other words, satisfaction with Medicare arrangements is highest among those people with recent experience of the public health system. That may be a very surprising conclusion, but it is one that is supported by the evidence.

Only 14 per cent of people express dissatisfaction in terms of waiting periods. Of course, the honourable member for Lowe, like his predecessors, wants to make much of waiting lists. I am surprised about that. When I said to Peter Collins, the New South Wales Minister for Health, that one of the things he might have to worry about was waiting lists, he replied, `Well, you don't have to wait more than three weeks in New South Wales'.

TALK.START.PARA: —How about the figures in Victoria?

—I do not think the figures are very different in Victoria. The fact is that for critical surgery it does not matter where people live in Australia-whether they are in New South Wales or Victoria-if they have an acute need for treatment in a public hospital there is no question at all of a waiting period. Again, a lot of this so-called concern on the part of the Opposition is very much a case of crocodile tears-tears it feels it can exploit for political advantage rather than for any serious purpose. There is no evidence that treatment for serious or traumatic conditions is being delayed. Much of the waiting list time reflects convenience considerations for doctors or patients rather than the unavailability of resources.

SPEECH.PARA: The particular case of ear, nose and throat surgery that was mentioned by the honourable member reflects the obvious fact that in some areas of specialty there are more significant waiting periods for discretionary surgery than in others. Of course, orthopaedic surgery is another example of the supply being controlled effectively by the college, and the effect of that control on the supply, as the honourable member knows, is to induce delays and some stacking, if you like, of patients so that very profitable use is made by surgeons of the opportunities available to them.

Various reflections were made again on the state of the Australian health system. I think that is unfortunate, coming from the Opposition, and I think one ought to correct some of the false impressions that have been created for base political motives. What is really impressive about the health system is that at a time when there has been a great deal of debate about waiting lists and so-called delays-and of course one has to have a concern about those kinds of issues-at a time when that concern is at its height, we have seen public hospital separations rise from 2.5 million to over 2.7 million for the period 1982-83 to 1988-89. There has been a massive increase in the number of people being treated in public hospitals.

The efficiency of public hospitals is extraordinarily impressive in terms of the improvement in productivity that has been achieved. At the same time as hospitals are becoming more efficient, people are expressing a greater level of satisfaction with the treatment that they are receiving within our public hospital system. I made reference to some of the things for which our public hospital system is renowned. I make no apology for describing our public hospital system as one of the best in the world. I make no apology for drawing attention to the extraordinarily important role that is played by our great teaching hospitals and the standard of excellence, notwithstanding that we are a country which spends only 8 per cent of gross domestic product and maintains very tight controls, which means that we are able to boast one of the finest health systems in the world.

We are able to find $100m a year for research through the National Health and Medical Research Council so that we remain at the cutting edge. We are able to provide the kind of support for our health system that means that we are competitive in terms of standards. But, most importantly, people that go into the Australian health system, particularly in the public hospital system, will get the very best treatment. It does not matter who one is in Australia, what one's background is, how poor one is or how wealthy one is, one gets the very best treatment out of that system. Indeed, that is something to be very proud of, because we know that the best in Australia is amongst the best in the world.

That is reflected in the progress that we make in some of the areas of research for which we are renowned. In the area of heart disease, we are able to see an impact from the effort that we have made. In the rate of mortality, we have seen a decline in the number of deaths from 34.6 per cent in 1983 to 32.4 per cent in 1988. One can cite a number of cases. In my own experience, our response to the treatment of HIV has placed us in the strongest ranks in the way we have responded, particularly in being able to link people into our health system and to build a partnership.

I conclude by simply saying that the honourable member for Lowe has said that he is not interested in ideology. That is a very important point, and I ask honourable members to mark it. If he is not interested in ideology, why did he say, `What we'd like to do is, if people are worse off, they're worse off by choice'? The honourable member was asked, `Well, in terms of allowing people to look after their own future . . .'; he was asked about going back to the 1950s. That is his model-the Earle Page model. It is a model of ideology; it is not about people. It is about private health, private insurance and private sectional interests. It is not about a response in the interests of the Australian people. The honourable member for Lowe will talk about efficiency and equality, but he will not talk or pursue a path which leads to greater equity.

Medicare has provided-indeed, it has guaranteed-access to one of the finest health systems in the world. It is popular with three-quarters of the Australian population. Those who in the last 12 months have been in the public health system are extraordinarily satisfied with the treatment that they received. That is good policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable Minister's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gallus Mrs C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to stand in this debate today because I believe that it is time that the Minister for Community Services and Health (Mr Howe) faced up to the disastrous state of the health system he presides over. The Minister is one for effect. He is adept at the grand statement. The words `social justice' are attached to everything he says as if, by saying them, he gives his programs a legitimacy they do not otherwise have.

SPEECH.PARA: The medical system in Australia today, the medical system this Minister presides over, is confused, inefficient, unfair and socially unjust. The Bulletin of 14 August last year described Medicare as a `bizarre and irrational' system.

TALK.START.PARA: —Bizarre!
—Those were the words in the Bulletin of 14 August last year, and that is exactly what the system is-bizarre and irrational.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at what has happened to our medical system since this Government came to office in 1983. There has been a drop in private health insurance from 65.1 per cent in March 1983 to 44.6 per cent in March 1990; a consequent decrease in the use of private hospitals, leaving private hospitals with empty beds; and a consequent increase in the use of public hospitals so that there are now long waiting lists for admittance to public hospitals. While private hospital theatres sit empty, there are queues for operations in public hospitals.

Before the introduction of Medicare, the breakdown in emergency versus elective surgery was approximately 65 per cent to 35 per cent. It is now approximately 95 per cent to 5 per cent. It is bad luck if one wants a hip replacement or a prostate operation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unless you are the Prime Minister!

—Yes, except for the Prime Minister. Let us look at what this actually means to people. Let us look at the case of a gentlemen in his seventies whom we will call Mr Smith. I assure honourable members this man exists, but his name is not Smith. Mr Smith was suffering from disabling nocturnal angina. In case honourable members do not know what this is, it means extremely bad pains in the chest; people with disabling nocturnal angina cannot sleep at night. In this case, not only could Mr Smith not sleep; the pain was such that his 65-year-old wife sat up all night with him.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Smith's doctor told him he was desperately in need of a coronary bypass. Unfortunately, because of the waiting list in public hospitals, Mr Smith could not get that coronary bypass. He was told that he would eventually get one, but Mr Smith eventually could not wait, so he had to go to the private system. Despite the fact that Mr Smith was paying more than $1,000 a year for private health insurance, he ended up with a bill exceeding $2,000 which he had to pay himself. Do honourable members think Mr Smith was a rich man? Both Mr and Mrs Smith were elderly pensioners.

This is the equity the Minister talks about. This is his sort of social justice. The Government has given us a system where the public pays four times for medical services. We pay through our taxation, we pay through that farce called the Medicare levy, we pay through health insurance and we also pay the gap. No wonder the Bulletin called it a bizarre and irrational system. The Minister must have a strange idea of social justice.

The situation would be laughable if it were not so serious. It is serious for families with young children who are fighting to make ends meet under a Government which, through its economic policies, has lowered living standards and made life a daily struggle. The Minister talks about equity. Families with chronically ill young children know what he means; there is no equity for them. A large proportion of their budget goes on providing medical services for those children.

Medical care is a major issue for the elderly. The elderly today are terrified that they will not be able to get the medical care they require and because of this are forced to take out private insurance they can ill afford. The system is in a shambles. It is not even as if costs were being contained. In a press release of 14 February 1991, last Thursday, the Consumers Health Forum of Australia Inc. told us that, for the December 1990 quarter, health costs for the ordinary consumer shot up 6.6 per cent. For the year to 31 December 1990, the Consumers Health Forum tells us that health costs rose by 12.2 per cent. Hospitals are in a state of confusion. Let me read a report from the Canberra Times of 16 October 1990. It said:
SYDNEY: Sick patients often have to wait days for admission to Australia's major public hospitals and waiting lists for elective procedures also are growing, according to a senior medical academic.
These problems had arisen because teaching hospitals were facing unreasonable and progressive funding restrictions, said Professor Richard Larkins, professor of medicine at Melbourne University.

The great strain under which the system is struggling is evident in the emergency departments of teaching hospitals in several capital cities where sick patients often cannot be admitted for hours or even for a day or two because of lack of available beds, while whole wards lie closed because of budget problems.
Have honourable members heard what happens to people who live in the country? An article from the Australian dated 5 November 1990 reads as follows:
For many country people a two-week wait to see their local doctor is common, for others a two-hour drive is standard.

This is equity-we are all equal; it is just that some people are less equal than others. An article from the Age on 18 February 1991, Monday this week, says the following of waiting lists in public hospitals:
There are now two people waiting for each available hospital bed in Victoria, according to the State Opposition.

The Opposition spokeswoman on health, Mrs Tehan . . . said January figures obtained under Freedom of Information legislation showed that 26,985 Victorians were waiting for 13,500 beds. In NSW, there were only 21,155 people waiting for 21,000.

How lucky can one be! Only 1,155 people in New South Wales need hospital treatment and cannot get it. In the public hospital system there is a financial crisis with the majority of hospitals being unable to stay within their budgets. Most public hospitals are coming in $1m to $2m over budget, and nobody knows where the money is coming from. There is a fear that the hospitals will have to absorb the debt and cut costs accordingly next year.

On the ground, this means that doctors are performing sleight of hand, pushing costs from one section to the other. Victorian hospitals are billing South Australian hospitals for drugs given to South Australian patients who have their operations in Victoria because the procedures they needed were not available in South Australia. South Australian hospitals are refusing to pick up the drug costs. These are the petty actions that occur when a system falls apart.

Hospitals are desperate for more money. The States say that the Commonwealth is squeezing them. Short cuts are being taken. There is a suspicion that some patients are being pushed into day surgery who should not be. And the reason? The Commonwealth has direct financial input into day surgery-patients go where the money is. The people who suffer are those who are forced to go home when they need post-operative care in a hospital.

The Minister said that only 14 per cent of people expressed dissatisfaction with hospital waiting lists; he can do a lot with statistics. I ask the Minister: what percentage of people who are actually on the waiting lists for hospitals express dissatisfaction? I suggest to him that it would be 100 per cent. The Minister also said that there was a massive increase in the number of people treated by public hospitals. He used this as a very good statistic. I ask him: is it good for a pensioner to be sent home at 3 a.m. because there is no bed for him? Turnover rate does not necessarily equate with good care.
In a report of the Journal of the American Medical Association in May 1988 Dr Peter Arnold explained what quality means in the context of the Australian health system, and I quote:

Medicare was introduced to cure inequalities in health services. We now have equality of a sort-equality of access to the queues at state hospitals, with waiting lists exceeding, on a per capita basis, those of Britain's National Health Service; where patients have no choice of physician--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gear Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is another typical debate here in the House. We are up debating the Government's policy, in the absence of one from the Opposition. The Opposition speakers so far have spoken a lot about waiting lists. If we want to have a look at how well our hospitals are working in this country, what we should really focus on is the amount of people going through them. We have the highest hospitalisation rate in the world: 21.8 per cent of our population will pass through our hospitals this year. No other country comes close. If honourable members opposite want to get stuck into the hospitals of this country, they should just compare their statistics with the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development average of 15.3 per cent. The 3 1/2 million Australians who will go through our hospital system this year would be reduced by a million if we could achieve the OECD rate.

SPEECH.PARA: Who puts people in hospitals? People do not put themselves in-it is the medical profession. We on this side of the House and honourable members opposite have talked about over-servicing coming about from bulk billing. One thing I think the national health strategy should look at is the amount of people going through our hospitals. It is a very efficient system. We talk about hospital waiting lists for public hospitals. I pointed out to the House yesterday that there is no medical reason why public patients cannot be treated in private hospitals.

We cannot blame Medicare for that, because the Medicare agreement specifically allows, in clause 4.4, for States to put public patients in private hospitals. But why does it not happen? There are two reasons: firstly, the States by and large have not taken up the offer, apart from South Australia; but, secondly, the mates in the medical profession of honourable members opposite will not operate on them. We all know why-because the doctor-dollar relationship is in question if they do.

Honourable members opposite also talked about the resources that were needed in our hospitals. Liberal Party spokesmen on anything talk about resources and particularly about resources in terms of health care. What are they going to do with their $3 billion cut to the Budget? Are they somehow going to give the Australian people all the resources they say are needed in the medical system and still cut $3 billion off expenditure, or are they going to have a magic pudding somewhere from which all of this money somehow materialises?

Honourable members opposite have no credibility when talking about fiscal responsibility, so they should not talk to this Government about resources. The simple fact is that we know from their rhetoric that they could not supply that money. The honourable member for Hawker (Mrs Gallus), who is leaving the chamber now, also talked about doctors in the country, and I know that is a problem. But the fact is that the Government does not tell doctors where to go in this country; the doctors decide for themselves. That really is a problem that the medical profession itself should have a look at. Why is it that our cities are overstaffed with doctors and we have long waiting lists in the country? That has nothing to do with the Government-it has everything to do with the medical profession.

Honourable members opposite always have goes at Medicare, but there are a few principles worth preserving in Medicare. The first one is ability to pay. On this side of the House, we seem to think that health care is a right. We should not have to be rich to have good health care. So in our proposal on Medicare, the ability to pay is tantamount. It is one of the pillars of Medicare. In actual fact, we go further. A married couple, with two kids, earning $21,560 does not pay anything. What is that family going to do under the Opposition's system? Will it get a voucher? What happens when the voucher runs out? We just do not know.

The second principle we talk about is equality of access-and it is in the Opposition's matter of public importance today. Let me tell honourable members about equality of access. It is the charging practices of medical specialists in this country that is the greatest threat to equality of access. There is nothing in Medicare that stops patients going to a doctor. But in many cases medical specialists in this country will not see patients if they are not privately insured-`If you don't have private insurance so we can send you the Bill direct, don't worry about coming to us'.

We hear a lot of tales about people who are in need of medical attention and who cannot get it. Let us put it on the public record. Who makes the decision in this country as to who gets access to medical treatment? Is it the politicians; is it the bureaucrats; or is it the doctors who decide who gets access to medical care and when they get it? If people are waiting on waiting lists, it is because the medical profession says that they can wait and that the people in the system already are more in need.

I notice that Andrew was able to get his eyelids fixed up quite easily; and there are plenty of cases where we can point to the fact that in hospitals around Australia today there are people receiving medical treatment who on an objective basis are receiving it prior to people receiving it on need. The case mentioned by the honourable member for Lowe (Dr Bob Woods), and the case brought to our attention by the honourable member for Hawker, concerning a Mr Smith, may be two cases in point. Why can they not get medical treatment? It is a medical decision-not a political or bureaucratic one.

I ask the honourable member for Hawker not to shake her head; she knows it is true. She had the audacity to start talking about the American Medicare. It bears absolutely no comparison with Medicare in this country.

Let me tell honourable members about the American system. The highest cause of bankruptcy in America is medical bills. People die over there if they cannot afford medical treatment. That is the sort of system we would experience if we wanted to go to a market system. There are 37 million American people who are uninsured. The honourable member opposite sits there shrugging her shoulders, throwing her hands out.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not mention it.

—Of course she mentioned it. She and the honourable member for Lowe did not make any sense in anything either of them said. We never heard anything about what they would do-only a little bit of a whinge about what they perceive as the shortcomings of Medicare. Each of those shortcomings they mentioned can be treated on their own and the argument which was put up can be shot down-and, indeed, the Minister for Community Services and Health (Mr Howe) did that.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us have a look at private health insurance in this country. There are a couple of things about private health insurance in this country which honourable members opposite should answer questions on, the first of which is the community rating principle. Are they going to keep that or are they going to a real market force? Are they going to be hairy-chested about this free enterprise and get rid of the community rating principle? Are they going to make those funds profit organisations? Currently, the major health insurers in this country are non-profit organisations. Yes, that might surprise those opposite, but it is true and it always has been true. If we look at the efficiency of Medicare when compared with the private health systems, out of every dollar that goes into Medicare, 96c goes to paying medical bills. In private insurance, out of every dollar that goes into private insurance, 86c goes to paying medical bills. That is the measure of efficiency.

All the people of Australia want in a health insurance system is, in general terms, to pool all our risks. We all have different medical risks. Some of us are quite healthy; others need constant medical attention. But Australians want to pool their risks and pool their resources. The health strategy announced by the Minister I think is timely. Medicare has been there for seven years and it is about time we had a look at it again. But not with a view to getting rid of it-with a view to strengthening it; a view to making Medicare work better. The consultation process that the Minister is going through contrasts quite remarkably with the Opposition's.

I read in the paper the other day about the Opposition's little get-together I think on 20 or 21 March. I had a look at the list of the people who were invited to attend-Bruce was there, the Australian Medical Association was there; the private hospitals were there; the private doctors were there-and there was not a word about consumers. It did not worry about them-let us construct ourselves a health insurance system for the providers. That is what the Opposition is about. There was nothing about the Australian Federation of Consumer Organisations, nothing about anything to do with the people who pay for the system, the consumers. Honourable members opposite never said anything about that. There was no mention of them in the paper the other day; and the Opposition gave the list out. The Opposition should have a look at the process of the Minister who is putting up position papers for community input-the people who use the system. That is who it should be designed for-not for the providers as the Opposition is going to do. We know the Opposition's system. (Quorum formed)

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. In a matter of public importance, when there is a fixed time for the debate, is it within the Standing Orders for the Opposition to call quorums? On two occasions as a mechanism for preventing the Government--

—Order! The Minister has made his point. It is the responsibility of members of the House to be present in the House at all times. If there is not a quorum present and the Chair's attention is drawn to that, then the Chair must make sure that a quorum is formed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gallus Mrs C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—I claim to have been misrepresented.
—The honourable member may proceed.
—The honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear) said that in my speech on the matter of public importance I was holding up the American system as an example-
—American Medicare, I said.
—Order! There will be no exchanges on this matter.
—The American Medicare system as an example we should follow in Australia. If the honourable member for Canning had been listening, he would know that I said absolutely no such thing. I said:

SPEECH.PARA: In a report to the Journal of the American Medical Association in May 1988 Dr Peter Arnold explained . . .
I went on to quote from a report in that magazine, which in no way held up the American system as an example.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Robert Brown, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to give effect to the Government's decision in the last Budget to recover the costs of marine safety and regulation from the industry that benefits from this regulation. Maritime and safety regulatory functions include ship control and ship safety-related activities, bulk cargo and dangerous goods inspections and the administration of the Marine Council. These functions were transferred to the new Australian Maritime Safety Authority on 1 January 1991.

The levy will be imposed on all seagoing ships except those exempted by regulation. The ships that will be exempt are those that are exempt from payment of the existing navigation levy and include commercial ships under 24 metres, fishing vessels, pleasure craft and ships in ballast. The levy will be phased in over three years with full cost recovery in the 1993-94 financial year.

The present cost of providing these services is currently estimated at $7.1m dollars per year. The formula for calculating the levy is similar to the existing marine navigation levy and is based on a sliding scale which ranges from 2c to 4c per net registered ton, with the rate per net ton being reduced as the ship's tonnage increases. The maritime industry was invited to propose alternatives to this method but no practical alternative was put forward.

The Bill also allows the rate of levy to be varied by regulation. However, after the phasing in period has been completed, the annual rate of increase in the levy which may be effected by regulation will be limited to an absolute maximum of 15 per cent. Any actual increase in the levy effected in this way will be related to reasonable cost increases.

To summarise, this Bill and the associated Marine Navigation (Regulatory Functions) Levy Collection Bill will provide funding to ensure that ship safety standards and the protection of the marine environment will continue to be maintained. I commend the Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum for the Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Sinclair) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: MARINE NAVIGATION (REGULATORY FUNCTIONS) LEVY COLLECTION BILL 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Robert Brown, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill sets out the necessary procedures for the collection of the proposed regulatory functions levy and provides minor amendments to other legislation. It provides for the levy to be paid to a collector of customs or an authorised person. The levy will not be payable merely because a ship calls at an Australian port for shelter, repairs or refitting, to take on provisions, to change crew or to land a crew member for medical treatment.

The levy will not be required to be paid for a ship more than four times a year. Ships exempted by regulation under the Marine Navigation Levy Collection Act 1989 will also be exempted from paying this levy, and I gave some examples of those when introducing the levy Bill. The Bill also allows payment of the levy to be made in person or by post or by a prescribed method.

The Bill amends the Australian Maritime Safety Authority Act 1990 to provide for payments of the levy to be appropriated to the Authority, which provides these services to the shipping industry. The Bill also amends the Marine Navigation Levy Collection Act 1989 to ensure that the procedures involved in paying that levy and the proposed levy are consistent.
In summary, this Bill provides the administrative detail to give effect to the levy. I commend the Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum for the Bill.
