SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a small contribution to the debate on the Family Law Amendment Bill, which was before the House last night. The provisions within the legislation are matters to which I would like to address some particular remarks. Before I do I would like to say a few things in general. Firstly, there is no doubt that the family law field is extraordinarily difficult. It was interesting to read in the summer edition of the Bar News, the journal of the New South Wales Bar Association, a little while ago some remarks attributed to Scott Turow, who many honourable members will recall is the author of two fairly well-known books, The Burden of Proof and Presumed Innocent. He is a person whom Time magazine has described as `the bard of the litigious age'. It is of interest that Turow has stated:

SPEECH.PARA: I do regard the law as a noble calling, but I can't shake the notion that the law is coming up short in its inability to deal with intimate human situations.

It is a problem, as far as the law is concerned, to try to relate the processes of the law and justice to family situations in any way at all. In particular, it is difficult to deal with cases of child abuse and of matters pertaining to guilt and innocence thereon.

I am concerned that in the process of our manifestations within the family law, most of which I endorse, there are still problems which seem to me to be quite fundamentally difficult. For that reason I was delighted to read that the Senate is about to constitute another inquiry into the family law legislation. I say to the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy), however, that it is a pity that the members of the House are not participating in that review. It is a field where on past occasions there has been a free vote open to members of the Parliament. I think it is a field which does need to be seriously considered, in so far as there are a number of aspects of the legislation which at this time need consideration.

The first is in the structure and nature of the court itself. I was one of those who felt very sad at the time the legislation went through that it was not possible for us to be able to persuade each of the States to accept their role within it. As a result, we now have a proliferation of judges, far more than in the days when, long since, I practised law. Then the legislation was administered by relatively few. The old matrimonial causes legislation that was in place in those days did not seem to have anywhere near the involvement of as many members of the judiciary as there are today. In my day in New South Wales there were only three judges, I think, and an acting judge. It seems to me that it perhaps worked more effectively than it does with a multiplicity of family law judges and all their staff in place at this stage.

It could be said that the number of divorces has increased and as a result so too has the workload of the family law jurisdiction, but it still seems to me that there is an enormous cost burden on the community in this jurisdiction. I am not too sure whether it is necessarily the only way in which it can best be regulated.

Secondly, I have often felt sad that there is a necessity to have this jurisdiction completely isolated from the mainstream of law. I would have preferred that in family law there were a capacity to give those who are justices in this jurisdiction a wider responsibility. At the moment numbers of them sit in bankruptcy hearings, but for those who are in what is an extraordinarily personal field it is a pity that they cannot get into a wider area and perhaps get some balance.

Apart from all that, we know of the risks and hazards to which these judges individually are subjected. I have often felt that if it were possible for them to get out of that informal environment and back to the formal process of the law occasionally, it might help both them and their administration of these intimate matters that are before their jurisdiction if they could perhaps sit back and view personal issues a little more dispassionately. I say that having full mind of the extraordinary complexity and difficulty of administering law in that jurisdiction.

The third thing I wanted to say is that there are a number of fields in family law that worry me. One that has come to my attention is the problem of custody of children. While this particular legislation deals per se with child abuse, there is a far wider field that needs to be dealt with: that is the general way in which the custody of children is considered. I have felt that it might well be appropriate that before the process under the family law legislation which allows divorce to be achieved after 12 months separation, before any decree is issued by the court, the custody of children should be resolved. If that were allowed, the interests of the children would be seen in a higher frame than they are at the moment. Too often divorce is granted and whatever the realities of the breakdown of marriage, the circumstance of the custody of children remains. I have always felt that in a marriage the responsibility of both parents for the child is such that they should not receive a divorce until such stage as the custodial responsibilities and access to children have been determined.

In that respect I confess also, as a member of parliament, that there have been many occasions when I have felt that the distribution of matrimonial property has not been equitably considered. It is extraordinarily hard when, as a Federal member, one is approached on this matter by a constituent. I have had any number of cases where I have felt the court has given inadequate consideration to the rights of the man within the relationship. Of course, as a man, it is inevitable that one applies a subjective judgment. But in circumstances where there are assets to which that particular husband will gain access at some future time, assets that come through his family or through an association that is quite outside the marital relationship, assets which have never formed part of that marriage relationship, I have felt that they should not be part of the distribution of matrimonial property. Yet under the way the court functions now, they often are. Once again, the question of the distribution of matrimonial property might also be a factor which should come before the court before divorce itself is granted.

Those two matters, the custody of children and the distribution of matrimonial property, are extraordinarily controversial. There is no doubt that if the guilt of either party were brought into account, it might have some bearing. It is very difficult, as a member of parliament, to know how and in what way one can correct what in some instances seem to be inequities and injustices to constituents. For that reason I would have hoped that perhaps the House of Representatives would be able to participate in that family law review so that those issues, and other issues which I know are quite difficult in this jurisdiction, could be addressed.

With respect to the particularity of this legislation, I want to say several things. The first is that we are all aware of the regrettable increasing incidence of child abuse. Indeed, for some years my wife has had a particularly active role in this field as national president of the National Association for the Prevention of Child Abuse and Neglect, a body called NAPCAN. She has been trying to assist in determining ways by which child abuse can be prevented. In other words, the organisation with which she is associated is not so much there to look at the post hoc situation but to see whether there are ways by which more can be done to create a climate within which child abuse will not happen.

In that respect, I think it is also worth remembering that more than 90 per cent-in fact it is said to be even as much as 99 per cent-of those people in gaols around Australia have been abused in some way as children. Whatever the percentage, I certainly know that it is a significant majority. Not all the abuse is sexual abuse, although much of it is. But there has been a very large incidence of abuse of those who are today's criminals-in a physical sense, in a sexual sense and, of course, an emotional sense-which has contributed to their appearance before and conviction in the criminal courts.

In many instances the abuse is perhaps a result of economic pressures on parents. While parents may have excuses, I think that they are difficult to rationalise as children are at least as important as their parents. In the distribution of family property and the custody of children, children are so important that those issues need to be before the courts before a divorce is granted. In instances of child abuse, we need to ensure the maximum consideration of the degree to which a family relationship has broken down so that we might be able to do something to help the children. In the several contributions by the Attorney-General and the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), I know they have expressed that concern.

The worry I have in regard to the amendments that have been moved, both by the Attorney-General and by the honourable member for Kooyong, is that I think they are perhaps going too far to allay the concerns of the legal profession without worrying about the children of a marriage. I do not think partial mandatory reporting goes far enough. I feel it is important that when any cases of child abuse come to the notice of the court or court personnel, they should be reported to the child welfare authorities in the respective States. Having said that, I am concerned that in the States there is often very little capacity to deal with those reports.

I commend to the Minister the suggestion by the honourable member for Kooyong that once a report has been made by the officers of the court to the child welfare authorities, the court, in turn, seeks a report back from the child welfare authorities as to the nature of the suspected child abuse. Equally, it is important that at the State level there are adequate resources to deal with child abuse cases, not just to find out whether abuse occurred and indeed not just to punish those who are guilty, but rather to help the children by trying to ensure that they are brought out of that extraordinarily traumatic experience which inevitably is a product of child abuse.

To me, one of the saddest aspects in this area of social concern is the number of occasions on which my wife Rosemary has spoken in meetings around Australia only to find that people in the audience have approached her afterwards and explained how they were abused as children. In other words, this abuse has been happening for years, but society has done little about it. I am suggesting that child abuse is not just a matter for the courts but for society to try to do something about, as it does have a traumatic impact on the victim which often lingers long after the event.

Rosemary became involved in this matter because a person with whom she had had an association lost a sister. It transpired that the sister had been abused as a child. The suicide of this girl was the result of the fact that she had never been able to get over the impact of that abuse as a child. That happens in so many instances. So it is not sufficient for us to look just at the legalities involved in this matter; it is necessary for us to try to ensure that there are adequate resources within the State welfare system to help those victims and to provide some psychological assistance to them.

It is because of my concern that there should be adequate consideration that I strongly commend the process which the Chief Magistrate in the ACT, Ron Cahill, uses. He allows video taping of evidence outside the courtroom in order to ensure that adequate evidence can be taken from children away from all the trappings of the law, in a climate where it might be possible for the children to feel more relaxed. Because I approve of that process, I therefore support clause 15 in the Bill-that is, the degree to which there is to be some modification of the rule against hearsay evidence so that in child sexual abuse cases there can be some lightening of the restraints in the normal evidentiary procedures to allow evidence to be received on the basis that the Government permits in its amendment. I do not accept that that particular clause should be deleted.

Although I know that the honourable member for Kooyong is reflecting the view of the Law Council and others in that field, it is my own view that it is important that we try to allow the maximum evidence from children so that we can try to determine the truth in such cases. Certainly, trying to establish the sort of evidence that is adequate is extraordinarily difficult, as the Cleveland cases in Britain demonstrated. I stress that in this jurisdiction people are giving evidence to a judge-not to a jury-and a judge should be sufficiently and properly qualified to be able to assess even hearsay evidence given by a child in a case of this kind.

It is my view that clause 15 in the amendment that the Government proposes to submit should be retained. I believe that these changes should be welcomed. I know that the gestation period of the amendments has been long. I know that inevitably clauses within this Bill will be seen as inadequate by many. They will not be seen as addressing the total problem. It is for that reason that I believe it is necessary to have a wider inquiry and I commend to the Attorney-General that the inquiry that the Senate is about to undertake should not just be for the Senate, but for both Houses. This is a matter of tremendous importance to our society and if we are able to overcome some of the products of child abuse, there will be a beneficial effect far beyond the area of family law and into the area of lessening the number of criminals and reducing some of those psychological pressures which regrettably linger for those who have been abused in any way during their childhood.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-Before going to some of the matters of substance raised by the shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), which I will respond to in summing up, I must say that this probably has been one of the best debates-if not the best-that I have heard on an issue in my 10 years in this House. It is unusual to be able to say that in this place. I would like to thank all those members who have participated in this debate-the honourable member for Kooyong, the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Lavarch), the honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Webster), the honourable member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio), the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), the honourable member for Petrie (Mr Johns) and the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair).

SPEECH.PARA: I will touch briefly on the matters raised by the right honourable member for New England because they are fresh in my mind at the moment. On the question of the family law committee to which he referred at the end of his speech-the idea for which originated in the Senate-I can tell the House that it has been agreed that that will be a joint committee. No doubt the right honourable member for New England may well desire to make a contribution to that committee.

The fact that the Family Law Amendment Bill was introduced in May last year gave people an opportunity to give a lot of thought to this matter. That was probably partly why we have heard a very reasoned debate. I am not saying that one could agree with all that has been said. Some speakers dealt with the Bill very specifically and others covered the matter in a far broader sense, expressing philosophical views about the Family Law Act and families generally, and particularly the breakdown of marriages. Whether one agreed or disagreed with all that was said, there were many genuine contributions made in this debate.

There has been an enormous amount of consultation on this Bill-first, with the various societies in the legal profession, secondly, with the Opposition and thirdly, within the Government. Whilst there is some disagreement and there are amendments which will be moved by the Opposition in committee, at the end of the day I think that whilst we are not in total agreement, we have probably gone about as close as we could in this difficult area, as was outlined by the right honourable member for New England a few moments ago.

I would like to express my thanks to the Attorney-General's Department for the amount of work its staff has done, particularly in consultation which took place just before this debate when there were still some matters about which people were expressing concern. I thank members of my own staff, particularly Keith Holland who had the carriage of this matter in the office. I also thank Sturt Glacken who is on the staff of the shadow Attorney-General. I understand that he is moving on in the near future, but he did work extremely hard on this Bill. There was a lot of correspondence between those two people and I thank them for the effort that they put in.

The shadow Attorney-General raised many of these issues immediately this Bill came into being back in May last year in order that they could be properly addressed. I must say that the performance of the Opposition was a very satisfactory one in attempting to be extremely constructive. I think it must be noted that that is the case, because it is very rare that one has the opportunity to say that. I am not saying that is always the Opposition's fault. Nevertheless, a little more constructive debate in this place would not do any of us any harm.

During his remarks the shadow Attorney-General sought my response specifically on some issues. Some of them could be dealt with in the committee stage, but I think I will deal with them now. He indicated that the Opposition would be moving five amendments to the Bill, and these have been circulated.

I can indicate at this stage that the Government will be accepting one amendment to be moved by the Opposition, and that is the amendment requiring an alleged abuser of a child to be served with notice that the allegation has been made in family law proceedings. That is the amendment to clause 12 on page 5, line 19, which is the first amendment on the list of amendments circulated on behalf of the shadow Attorney-General. That amendment will be accepted.

The other issues raised by the shadow Attorney-General include clause 12, which is of course the one I think every speaker has touched on. That is the question of mandatory reporting of child abuse. The Opposition has proposed amendments to clause 12 to replace the mandatory reporting provisions in the Bill with voluntary reporting provisions.

This is the matter which caused an enormous amount of discussion on both sides of the House. I can assure the House that within the Government it was discussed at committee meeting after committee meeting. It was not an easy matter to deal with. In our view the Government's proposed amendments to the Bill substantially narrow the mandatory reporting provisions of the Bill as far as is consistent with the protection of children. I think that has made that issue more acceptable to the Opposition, although today-very late in the debate-the right honourable member for New England expressed some doubts about that. That is an indication, I think, that people who have looked at this matter closely find it very difficult to be too sure which way to go.

Following the efforts that have been put into it, and on the studies that we have done, we say that that mandatory reporting-to be limited to the most serious categories of abuse-does meet the concerns of people in this area as can best be done. There will, of course, now be no criminal penalty for failure to report. I think that was certainly necessary. Reporting will be limited to abuse coming to the attention of court staff during the course of their duties. So it is true it has narrowed considerably.

The object of mandatory reporting provisions is to increase the chance that an abused child will be protected in future by having the abuse reported to the authorities who have the necessary statutory powers and responsibilities for investigating abuse, and of course there I refer to the State and Territory child welfare authorities.

Family Court staff do not have the expertise or the statutory powers to investigate allegations or to determine whether they are to be believed. State child welfare authorities have the powers and the responsibilities for such investigations. Family Court counsellors have been consulted on the amended reporting provisions of the Bill and now generally support the provisions. I must say that the responses from the Family Court counsellors was prompt, and I should also express our appreciation for the way they responded to the need for us to know what their view was. It was extremely helpful in reaching a determination as to which way the Government should go.

The shadow Attorney-General in the second reading debate referred to a Family Law Council suggestion that judges of the Family Court should vet allegations of abuse before they are sent to child welfare authorities. It is the Government's view that the investigation and determination of suspected child abuse is a matter for State and Territory child welfare authorities and not the Family Court. In any event, the Chief Justice of the Family Court has rejected the Law Council's suggestion as being too cumbersome, and the Government cannot support a procedure which would potentially, in our view-and there is a lot of support for this opinion-delay an investigation where there is a risk of abuse.

The shadow Attorney-General asked why the proposed subsection 70bb (5) was necessary. The purpose of that section is to ensure that court counsellors may disclose information to child welfare authorities in case conferences with those authorities following the initial notification of abuse. Family Court staff sought the protection of the reporting provisions for those conferences, and the Government believes the provision is a sensible measure. There was a lot of concern on the part of Family Court staff in relation to this matter. I think that that protection should have been given, and that is the reason for that section.

Clause 14 was another matter where the shadow Attorney-General raised some concerns. That is the question of intervention in proceedings. The Opposition has circulated, as one of the amendments that it will be moving in committee, an amendment that will alter section 92A in clause 14 of the Bill in two ways. Firstly, it would make intervention a matter of judicial discretion rather than a matter of right, and it would add to the categories of persons who may intervene-a person, for example, with access rights or any person with an interest in the welfare of the child. The amendment to clause 14, however, is not acceptable to the Government. Section 92 of the Family Law Act already allows for any person to apply to the Family Court for leave to intervene. Thus a person with access rights or an interest in the child's welfare can apply at any time for leave to intervene, the distinction being, of course, that the Opposition wanted that intervention in limited circumstances to be as a matter of right.

The new section 92a will allow certain categories of people to intervene as of right in child abuse proceedings, and the list of people in that new section 92a has been limited to those who clearly have a legitimate interest in the proceedings. A multitude of parties would make the proceedings longer, more complex, and in our view it is not something that should be done. Of course, it would add considerably to cost.

People with access rights or with an interest in the child's welfare-and two groups specifically referred to were grandparents and neighbours-should intervene only if they can persuade the court that they can usefully contribute to the proceedings. It is not a matter of the Government and people we have consulted on this issue wishing to exclude them, but it is a matter of importance that they should at least be able to indicate to the court that they can usefully contribute to the proceedings, rather than have the right of intervention automatically.

The other matter raised by the shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for Kooyong, related to hearsay evidence. The Opposition has circulated an amendment proposing the omission of clause 15 of the Bill which provides that hearsay evidence of a statement made by a child about matters relating to the child's welfare is admissible in Family Court proceedings. In the family law area something that a child has to say about his or her welfare should not be excluded from consideration by the court. It is the established practice of the Family Court to admit hearsay statements of children regarding their welfare so that children will not be drawn into court proceedings by being called as a witness for either partner in a custody or access dispute.

Whilst the Opposition has proposed that amendment, I do not think there is an enormous amount of difference at the end of the day. I do not think that amendment is proposed with any great fervour although, clearly, there is a difference between the Opposition and us on this matter. I think it is worth noting that clause 15 does not extend but simply states in legislation the Family Court's existing practice in relation to hearsay evidence because, in fact, that is the position that has been adopted for some time. The statement of this practice in legislation was recommended by the Family Law Council to clear up doubts about the legal basis for what had been a long-standing practice within the Family Court.

The Government's decision to accept the recommendation has been shown to be correct by some recent events in the United Kingdom where the necessity arose for urgent legislation to be passed in order to overcome a recent decision by the court of appeal that there was no legal basis for admitting hearsay evidence of children in family law proceedings. We may well have found ourselves in the position where, although such hearsay evidence has been a practice in this country, because there was no statement of that practice in legislation it may well not have survived.

The Government's amendment to clause 15 will ensure that the judge in each case retains a discretion to determine whether to admit the evidence and to determine the weight to be given to such evidence when it is admitted. I think that gives the necessary protection, without removing the flexibility which I think is necessary in relation to the evidence of children in family law proceedings.

In closing the debate before we move into the committee stage, I again express appreciation on behalf of the Government for the constructive attitude adopted by the Opposition to this Bill. Although we brought the legislation in last May, I think the delay in allowing people the opportunity to consider it has been well worth while.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Costello Mr P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 12, page 5, line 19, at the end of proposed subsection 70ba (2) add ``, and serve a true copy of the notice upon the person who is alleged to have abused the child or from whom the child is alleged to be at risk of abuse''.

The first Opposition amendment to the Family Law Amendment Bill relates to provisions concerning what should be done after an allegation is made that abuse of a child has occurred. Let me make it clear, as it has been throughout the conduct of this debate, that the abuse of children is an evil. It is an evil that we in a civilised society must do as much as we can to prevent and prohibit. It is something that can damage a child for life. All of those who are touched by child abuse are diminished by it. As has been made clear, I believe by speakers on both sides of the House, child abuse is something that Parliament must do its utmost to bring to an end and to protect those who cannot protect themselves.

Child abuse is a primary evil. Unfortunately there are other evils that can be built upon that. It has been known-I am not suggesting that it is common-for allegations of abuse to be falsely made by parties who are in the midst of family law proceedings. That is regrettable because if that practice should go on, to a degree it undermines the seriousness of allegations of child abuse. That is a secondary evil that we must determine to set our faces against as well.

The Opposition amendment proposes that where an allegation is made in a Family Court proceedings that a child to whom the proceedings relate has been abused or is at risk of being abused, notice of that allegation be served on the person who is alleged to have abused the child. The person against whom the allegation is made will, therefore, be notified that the allegation has been made. Of course, that is a matter of natural justice in itself, but it is also, if you like, a protection so that if the allegation is falsely made, the person against whom it is falsely made has notice and has the opportunity to come into the proceedings and, presumably, to contest that matter.

The proposed clause as presently drawn sets out a procedure whereby court registrars must notify child welfare authorities of any allegations made by a party to the proceedings that abuse has taken place. The reporting obligation imposed on registrars becomes triggered upon the filing of a prescribed notice by the party making such an allegation. The amendment I am moving is simple: it requires the party making the allegation to serve a copy of the prescribed notice upon the alleged abuser.

The amendment endeavours to give effect to the fundamental premise of the rules of natural justice; that is, people should be in a position to answer any allegations made against them. The form of the notice will be prescribed by rules of the court. It is for the judges to determine the exact content of such a form. For my part, I would hope that such a notice will require the alleging party to give particulars of the material facts relied upon and that it will contain a statement setting out the entitlement of persons under proposed new section 92a to intervene in proceedings. I welcome the indication from the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) that the Government will accept this amendment.
Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Costello Mr P.H.

I should also explain that it is not proposed to formally move Opposition amendment No. (5) relating to rules allowing hearsay evidence from children whose interests are affected under the Family Law Act. The shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for Kooyong, put the case for the Opposition in relation to that amendment. It has been commented on already by the Attorney-General. Although the proposed amendment stands, we will not be formally moving it because it has been well and truly canvassed already.

The second amendment the Opposition moves seeks to delete the new section 70bb, which is yet to be moved in its entirety by the Government, and to substitute an alternative section. The alternative section would provide that there be discretionary reporting in all cases that have to be reported pursuant to the section. Those would be cases where abuse has occurred, or is alleged to have occurred. `Abuse' is defined to include assault, sexual assault, involvement of the child in improper sexual activity, or ill treatment. It is a narrower definition of `abuse' and will have less reach than section 70bb will have after the Government moves its amendments because, in addition to that definition, the amendment the Government proposes to move will bring in some element of psychological abuse in relation to notification under that section.

We propose that in all cases of abuse, as defined, there be a discretion, as opposed to an obligation, to report suspected cases of child abuse. We should make it clear that those who will be receiving notice of abuse are trained persons-persons who will have experience and persons who will be capable of exercising that discretion. For our part, we hope that in every case where the prosecution authorities ought to be brought in or where a child is at risk that discretion is exercised. However, we do not believe that one can arbitrarily draw distinctions between levels of abuse and have different standards of reporting. We believe that those people who are interested, those who have the details, those who have the training, will have the ability to exercise that discretion in relation to reporting.

The third amendment is an amendment moved to clause 12 and follows on from the change to section 70bb if it is accepted according to our amendment. It is a consequential amendment and stands as part of the package. The fourth amendment relates to clause 14, which seeks to insert a new section 92a allowing for the intervention of interested persons in proceedings which concern allegations of child abuse. Under our proposed amendment, intervention will take place only if the court grants leave. I listened to what the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) said in relation to our proposed amendment in summing up the debate.

If our proposed amendment were accepted it would not lead to numbers of persons coming into the court and delaying proceedings because a discretion would be reposed in the court whether or not to grant permission in relation to all persons who sought to intervene. The court would be in a position to decide who did and who did not have a particular interest in that matter and the court could, if necessary, exercise its discretion in order to prevent persons with a frivolous or minor interest in the matter from coming in.

Our proposed section 9a also sets out with some greater width those who would be able to apply for rights of intervention in those circumstances. This would include persons who have been granted access and other persons with an interest in the welfare of the child, as determined by the court. The purpose of this is to avoid hardship in cases which may not fall within the list of categories put forward in the Government's Bill. Under the amendment, it will be up to the court, in deciding whether to grant leave, to determine whether it is appropriate for such persons to intervene.

The court will be in a position to weigh up the nature of the interest claimed. The court will retain control over proceedings. The court will have the opportunity to hear from all interested parties. The court will have the opportunity to inform itself as best it can and the court will have the opportunity, in the final analysis, to protect the child-which is the object of this whole Act-as is its duty, and to ensure that the best interests of the child are taken into account. I urge the Government to accept the amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: The proposed amendment to clause 12, the mandatory reporting of child abuse, has been very fully canvassed in the debate. I wish to say only that the object of the mandatory reporting provisions is to increase the chance that an abused child will be protected in future by having the abuse reported to authorities who have the necessary statutory powers and responsibility for investigation. As I indicated earlier, that is the State and Territory child welfare authorities. I do not intend to take up the time of the Committee by going into that matter in any more detail because it has been canvassed very fully by all speakers in the second reading debate.

The honourable member for Higgins touched on the matter of intervention in proceedings, clause 14, to which the Opposition moved an amendment. As I have indicated, that is not acceptable. Hearsay evidence, which is dealt with in clause 15, was not pursued, but I would like to make a couple of points on it. It should be clearly understood that clause 15 does not extend, but simply states in legislation, the Family Court's existing practice, as I indicated earlier. The statement in legislation was recommended by the Family Law Council to clear up any doubts about the legal basis for the Court's practice. The Government amendment provides for the judge's discretion to remain as to whether to allow the evidence and the weight given to such evidence. Therefore, with the exception of that one amendment which is accepted, the Government is unable to accept the Opposition's amendments.
Amendments negatived.

In introducing the Family Law Amendment Bill, I said that I welcomed public comments on it. These amendments come as a result of wide consultation with a number of people individually and with a number of groups, including such organisations as the Family Law Council, the Family Court of Australia, the Law Council of Australia, the Law Institute of Victoria and Family Court counsellors. The first amendment, which is an amendment to the marriage counselling provisions of the Family Law Act, is necessary as the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) has taken over responsibility for the approval of marriage counselling organisations.

The amendment to clause 4 inserts new definitions of `abuse' and `member of the Court personnel' into the Bill. The new definition of `member of the Court personnel' includes welfare officers and Family Court registrars as the Family Court advises that these officers may also become aware of suspected child abuse in the course of their duties. Of course, the new definition of `abuse' spells out what is meant by assault and child sexual abuse and, once again, the definitions are based on the advice received from the Family Law Council on how those terms should be defined.

Clause 3 is amended to make the Bill clearer in its operation in relation to step-parent adoptions. The amendment makes it clear that a step-parent adoption does not put an end to custody access rights under the Family Law Act unless the Family Court has given leave for the step-parent adoption to proceed. Under amendment 4, clause 7 is amended to make the Bill clearer in its operation in relation to step-parent adoptions. The amendment makes it clear that the step-parent adoption does not end the access rights unless the Family Court has given leave for the step-parent adoption to proceed.

Amendment No. 5-that is, to clause 8-makes it clear that in any custody access proceedings the courts are to have regard to the need to protect children from ill treatment and psychological abuse. This was a matter touched on by many of the speakers in this debate. This amendment makes consequential amendments to the welfare of the child principle to be inserted in section 64 of the Family Law Act.

Amendment No. (6), which is to clause 9, ensures that where a court grants leave for the disclosure of information on the whereabouts of an abducted child the lawyer representing the party looking for the child may also have the information. Amendment No. (7), which is to clause 5, is a minor technical amendment to require a notice filed by a party alleging child abuse to file the notice in a form prescribed by the rules. Amendment No. (8)-that is, to clause 12-provides for the notification of abuse to child welfare authorities by court counsellors. Clause 12 will be changed to narrow the scope of mandatory reporting, which has been discussed in some considerable detail.

Amendment No. (9) clarifies the legal protection given to court staff who report abuse. Legal protection will be limited to bona fide abuse reports. Amendment No. (10) is necessary to make it clear that hearsay evidence of statements made by children may be admitted; the court retains a discretion to exclude the evidence. Amendment No. (11) clarifies the drafting of clause 17 of the Bill in relation to the protection of children from repeated medical and psychological testing. The provision will now only apply to proceedings involving allegations of child abuse.

Amendment No. (12) clarifies the drafting of clause 17 of the Bill in relation to the protection of children from repeated medical and psychological testing. The schedule to these amendments is mainly to make technical changes to clarify the consequential amendments in the schedule to the Bill and will include provisions to increase penalties for offences. The Government amendments increase the penalties in line with the current position set by the Crimes Act.
