TALK.START.PARA: —The Companies (Insolvency Assistance) Amendment Bill 1990 proposes to amend the Companies Act 1981. That Act is in the sunset of its life. By virtue of the Corporations Legislation Amendment Act 1990, cooperative scheme Acts, of which the Companies Act is one, continue to operate only in relation to matters arising before the national scheme laws commenced. The national scheme laws, which were passed through this Parliament last year, contain provisions which are virtually identical to those proposed by this particular Bill. By virtue of the amendments set out in schedule 3 of the Corporations Legislation Amendment Act, the corporations law in section 411 now incorporates provisions which this Bill seeks to put into the Companies Act 1981. We are to a degree, therefore, harmonising the past law in transitional phase to the current law which will operate in future. For that reason, the Opposition supports this particular Bill as a sensible change in relation to insolvency which will be conducted under the old laws to speed up and facilitate in practical terms schemes of arrangement.

SPEECH.PARA: Where a scheme of arrangement is proposed between 30 or more subsidiaries of a particular holding company and between the holding company and its creditors, the court will have the power to order that meetings be consolidated between the holding company and the subsidiaries. Where there are fewer than 30 subsidiaries and there is a holding company and schemes of arrangement are proposed in relation to subsidiaries and the holding company, where the court considers it desirable to do so, it can order consolidation.

The effect of that is that where a group gets into financial trouble and it is proposed that a scheme of arrangement be put into place so that the group as a whole can continue trading in the interests of the creditors, the mechanism to be gone through to implement that particular scheme of arrangement can be achieved through joint meetings rather than by multiplicitous meetings between various creditors in relation to various subsidiaries. Of course, all this came about when the Hooker group of companies proposed to enter schemes of arrangement and it was estimated that some hundreds of meetings would be required in order to bring that scheme of arrangement into effect.

This is a sensible amendment which will facilitate in large company restructurings the holding of meetings to vote on schemes of arrangement in relation to the whole of the group. For that reason, it deserves the Opposition's support, and the Opposition will support this particular Bill.

In preparation for looking at this particular legislation, I attempted to obtain statistics on the number of company liquidations that have occurred over the previous years-and these figures are not very easy to come by. It may be, of course, that the Department of the Attorney-General has not kept records of them because company liquidations have gone through in State courts and the Attorney-General's Department has not been able to collate all those figures. But I recommend to the Attorney-General's Department that it collates figures on company liquidations and that it releases them in such a way that they are easily ascertainable and become public in much the same way as bankruptcy statistics become public.

The Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) is quite forthcoming in releasing statistics on bankruptcy, as part of the administration of the Bankruptcy Act. Now that the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) is predominantly responsible for the operation of company laws in Australia, this is something that I would recommend to him; presumably he, like Senator Tate, can take some sort of responsibility for the number of company liquidations which are proceeding through the courts.

The figures on bankruptcy-and they may give us some estimation of what is happening in relation to company liquidations-are quite horrific. The figures on bankruptcy to June 1990 showed that in the year since June 1989 there was an increase in the number of personal bankruptcies of about 10 per cent. The number of bankruptcies up to June 1990 increased 10 per cent on the number of bankruptcies to June 1989.

But figures which have been released since June 1990 show a disturbing picture. The figures for the September 1990 quarter showed that there was an increase of 32 per cent over September 1989 quarter. We were coming off a high starting base anyway, but there was a 32 per cent increase in the number of bankruptcies in the September 1990 quarter compared with the September 1989 quarter. Worst of all was the State of Victoria, where bankruptcies increased by 70 per cent in that quarter.

That will give honourable members some indication of the way in which the Victorian economy has been doubly jeopardised-not only jeopardised by the incompetence of the Federal Labor Government but also having the double whammy of the State Labor Government, which has given rise to a 70 per cent increase in bankruptcies in the September 1990 quarter.

Overall in Australia, the figures for December 1990 looked even worse. The increase in the number of bankruptcies in the December 1990 quarter compared with the December 1989 quarter was 56 per cent. Fifty-six per cent more people went bankrupt between September and December 1990 than between September and December 1989. As I said before, that increase of 56 per cent was already coming off a high base. This seemed to be more evenly distributed right throughout the States, and it is testament to the way in which the Federal Government's economic policies began biting in the latter part of this year.

A bankruptcy is not just a statistic. A bankruptcy involves an individual person and an individual tale of woe and destruction. When bankruptcies occur, it means that people who are unable to pay their debts lose control of their financial position, turn over their assets to administrators and have administrators distribute those assets to creditors. For people who become bankrupt, that ends effectively their opportunity to engage in independent business on their own account; they lose the ability to generate credit and they lose whatever savings they may have been able to put together over the years. The family-and many bankruptcies affect families-loses the financial security of the bread earner in the house. On many occasions houses and cars are sold and it becomes a tale of tragedy and woe.

To talk about the increases in bankruptcy that I have mentioned is to tell in a very shorthand way what is going on out there in the Australian community at the moment. A wave of bankruptcy is surging through the Australian community as the Government's economic policies begin to take effect. I believe that if we had company liquidation figures they would show a similar tale. Honourable members should not think that just because we say a certain number of people went bankrupt in a particular year, that means they were the only people who were affected by the economic recession brought on by this Government; it means that they were the only people who had no opportunity other than bankruptcy to deal with their particular economic problems. Bankruptcy is only the extreme case of what is surging through the Australian community at present.

When the Treasurer (Mr Keating) says, `This is the recession we had to have', he is effectively saying, `This is the bankruptcy I had to give you', `This company liquidation was my work', `This was my work to give you this liquidation' or `This was my policy to drive the Australian economy into recession'. `This is my policy, and it works,' is what the Treasurer says, `for I am the one who brought this about through my economic policy'.

I feel sorry for the poor Attorney-General; by changing insolvency laws, he has to pick up the results of the Treasurer's good work in relation to the economy. I must say that the Attorney-General is doing a reasonably good job in trying to pick up, through changes to insolvency laws, what is becoming an all too frequent problem in the Australian economy.

I do not believe I would go as far as the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell), who nominated the Attorney-General as an alternative Prime Minister. I sometimes wonder whether the honourable member for Kalgoorlie has the best interests of the Australian Labor Party at heart; when he nominated the Attorney-General as a potential Prime Minister, I could not decide on which side of the House he was coming down. But in the near future the Attorney-General probably will have his chance, as the aspiring candidates to take over from Prime Minister Hawke begin to fall one by one.

Of course, the honourable member for Kalgoorlie only nominated the Attorney-General as part of a quinella, with the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin), but that Minister seems to have taken a very bad fall recently over the failure of the reserve wool price scheme, and I would think that, as far as the honourable member for Kalgoorlie is concerned, the Attorney-General is the only horse still in the race, with a good opportunity to pick up where the Prime Minister and the Treasurer are beginning to fall.

As I said before, since national scheme laws have been put in place-with, I might say, coalition support-so that we now have one corporate regulator, the Australian Securities Commission, which has responsibility for the administration of company laws, the Commonwealth Attorney-General, as the Minister responsible for the Australian Securities Commission, has the responsibility for the operation of corporate and company laws in this country. I suggest that the Attorney-General should be doing whatever he can to ensure that the service which is being offered by the Australian Securities Commission is one which is helpful to corporate operation here in Australia.

From time to time I get letters from constituents who are concerned about operation of the Australian Securities Commission. There is, indeed, a lot for the Attorney-General to investigate. For example, recently a letter was passed to me from some accountants who had been paying fees to the Australian Securities Commission as their annual return fees for the 1989-90 year. Although they posted off the cheque for their return on 10 January 1991, that cheque had not been banked by 7 February 1991.

They followed it up. They rang the particular office-and this was the Hobart office-and found that it had received the annual return and sent it across to Morwell. The cheque presumably was sitting in Morwell in Victoria. Morwell was rung and the accountants were told that the return had been received and was sitting in a tray with many others, but that the staff at Morwell were too busy to attend to it yet. Attached to the return was the cheque which had not been banked. One can accept that in the setting up phase of the Australian Securities Commission, the staff at Morwell is busy; one can accept that it may take them some time to key annual returns into the computer system. But one finds it hard to believe that they cannot remove the cheques from those returns and bank them in the interim.

I would think that this is something the Government ought to follow up, because that money, standing for 30 days in somebody's tray, has, of course, lost interest; it has lost money for the Government. If the Government wants to ensure that it operates a tight financial system and maximises the returns that it has, it should not leave cheques which have been paid to it sitting in people's baskets. The Government's organisations should be banking cheques as soon as they are received and putting that money to work. That is something that the Attorney-General might be able to investigate to see whether in fact the Australian Securities Commission is doing whatever it can to ensure that it runs an efficient system in relation to financial operations.

I hope that when the Australian Securities Commission settles down and is fully operational, and when it has all of its teething problems out of the way, it can give Australia an efficient, clean and competent regulation of all of Australia's companies laws.

There is a lot to be done. Certainly over recent years there has been concern in the Australian community that compliance with corporate laws has been optional for some companies. There has been a justifiable concern that Australia's corporate regulators perhaps have not done all that they could have done to protect those who have invested in companies and those creditors who have dealt with companies. I know that the Australian Securities Commission is turning its attention to that, and it needs the support of government in the area of enforcement.

But enforcement, which is a subject for another time, is not the be-all and end-all of companies regulation. Enforcement no doubt is very important and it is a very substantial part of the work which must be done, but an awful lot of simple regulatory work has to be done in relation to operating a proper corporate system. It is a question of getting returns in; of putting them on records; of creditors and lenders being able to access all those things; of keeping company charges down; and of banking the charges when they come in. All of those things must be attended to for the sake of running a clean and efficient system.

The Attorney-General, having had the support of the Opposition in introducing that national scheme, now stands before the Australian people as the person responsible. The buck stops on his desk in relation to the operation of that corporate system. I appeal to him to watch very carefully the Australian Securities Commission in its infancy and to make sure that every effort is made to iron out any of those defects which may occur.

As I said before, this Bill is but a very small part of that whole system-indeed, a part of that system which looks backwards rather than forwards. But, in so far as it looks backwards to harmonise laws and to bring in what should be a more efficient and more effective procedure for introducing schemes of arrangement in relation to holding companies and subsidiaries, it is a step forward, it is a measure that is worthy of support, and it will be supported by the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Companies (Insolvency Assistance) Amendment Bill has as its objective the creation of a new power for a court to order meetings of creditors of a group of companies on a consolidated basis with a scheme of arrangement that will have the effect of transferring assets, property and liabilities to the holding company. This consolidation will reduce the total number of meetings to a manageable size.

SPEECH.PARA: I read with interest the second reading speech of the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy). He pointed out that the need for this legislative change was bought about some time back in relation to the Hooker companies. They faced a difficulty in that they had to convene some 500 separate meetings of creditors right across the nation because of the complex connection or, one might say, the interrelationship between the 90-odd companies that made up the Hooker group. I welcome the legislation, and I believe it is another example of this Government acting responsibly to address problems in the corporate area.

I noted the concerns expressed by the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello) about bankruptcies, and I can understand anyone being concerned about the blow-out in their number. But I would like to bring to the House's attention another aspect that confronts those who do get into difficulty in business, and in doing so I refer also to the creditors, the shareholders and ultimately the employees of those businesses. I draw to the attention of the House the present procedures that exist for the appointment of receiver-managers and ultimately the activities of liquidators.

I argue strongly that we need to restructure the present system, to have a hard look at the existing law, to take up some of the recommendations that appear in the Harmer report of 1988 and to change radically the present procedures used for the appointment of receiver-managers and ultimately liquidators by the courts.

As most people appreciate, if a creditor believes that a company is in real difficulty it will go to the court and petition that court to have a receiver-manager appointed. Most times the appointee is recommended by that major creditor. I believe the system in principle is a good one in that, if a firm is in trouble because its directors face difficulty or the economic circumstances are such that they cannot handle the problems before them, there is value in bringing in an expert. That is the key to my contribution: the bringing in of an expert. But the information brought to me and the number of cases brought to my attention demonstrate over and over again that the people appointed as receiver-managers have no competency, no expertise whatsoever, in the management of the firm to which they have been appointed.

I do not cast aspersions at all on accountants in their profession. I know hundred of accountants in my own area and throughout Queensland through my years in politics and in business, and I believe they are good at their job. They are good at the job of accountancy. But I do not believe that they can automatically hold up some sort of badge and say, `I am a great restaurateur. I can be a hotelier. I can look after some processing firm'. And that is the task that is given to them.

I argue strongly that the objective of receiver-managers is to maximise the recovery of moneys owed to creditors and to maximise the outcome for shareholders. Also they have a moral responsibility to employees. That responsibility also flows to the liquidators. Yet in thousands of cases-and I suspect across the nation tens of thousands of cases-there is evidence that the system is not working and that there is a real need for this issue to be taken up at the level of the ministerial council for the Attorneys-General and to be placed on the agenda so that the relevant corporation law can be amended. The law needs to be amended in the first instance to ensure that the person appointed to be a receiver-manager has the ability, the competency and the expertise to do that job.

Business brokers, people whose firms have gone broke, hoteliers who have gone into bankruptcy and all sorts of directors have come to me and raised the issue that, whilst in principle they are allowed to stay involved, they never get the chance, particularly where some banks are involved. The banks appoint receiver-managers and those people are given all power. They often have no training whatsoever in business management; they have no understanding of whatever that industry is; and in most instances they tend to simply work out who owes what and what the assets are worth, and then they go all out to recover the moneys owed to the major creditor who was instrumental in having their appointment made before the court.

In most instances, they act like a liquidator in the interim period. From what I am told they carry out what we could call a scorched earth policy. They go out to sell up everything they can, sometimes at any price. This issue is an important one because it affects shareholders and employees. If the business goes bust, the employees lose their jobs.

The alternative is that, given people in place who are competent, who have those skills, that business could continue, creditors could recover a large amount of the moneys owed to them and shareholders could ultimately get a return from their investment. Instead, what do we find? We find receiver-managers charging up to $160 an hour. Another case I have here is of a receiver-manager charging $1,000 a day-for what? To wind down, in effect, that company-not to carry out his job. If we look at some of the disbursements at the end of the period when the liquidator has finally come in, we see fees of $130,000. I have two cases here: firstly, of fees of $135,000; and, secondly, of a construction company in North Queensland where the liquidator's fees were over $100,000.

The costs have to be relative to the results received and I would suggest that is not the situation. Instead, what these individuals do is simply sell off assets. In one instance I have here, there was the needless selling off of assets. They sold assets far in excess of the moneys required to recover, in this instance, a bank's debt-and that same person is still refusing, after six months, to substantiate the fees charged. The losers are always the other creditors. The losers are always those people who are left behind-and very rarely do we find a prime creditor suffering in any way.

The solution is to ensure that receiver-managers who are appointed have that experience and that there is a requirement for them to convince the court that they have that experience-the experience to maximise the recovery of moneys for the creditor; to maximise the capacity of the business to be ongoing, which ultimately protects the employees. If a liquidator comes in after a receiver-manager, again there ought to be a requirement that that person maximise, again, the return for all concerned. But that simply does not occur in many cases.

I have been told of sweetheart deals-of liquidators who have in fact a class of friends in business who are there to buy up the businesses in trouble. There ought to be a requirement that all businesses in difficulties such as this ought to go to tender; that equipment, fixtures and fittings all ought to go to some form of auction. There ought to be real tests made when companies are sold up.

A case was given to me where a liquidator sold a business to two directors of that company for about a third of its worth-a price tested by its real asset backing, tests having been done on land, improvements, pieces of plant, fixtures and fittings, stock, and work that was in progress. It even went into goodwill areas such as the brand name and, in this instance, some drawings. We could add in other companies where we have patents and trademarks that are of real value, but these things do not seem to be taken into consideration by the liquidators who carry out what is really a fire sale to their mates-a fire sale to the boys.

All businesses and all properties should be put to public tender when liquidation is reached or, when a receiver-manager is involved, he should be bound to do his utmost by way of public tender, by way of every action possible, to recover the debts not only of the petitioning creditor but also of all other creditors. He should be forced to call a meeting of all creditors. This sometimes happens and sometimes it does not. Very often a person knows nothing about it as a creditor until there is a piece in the newspaper or the word gets out-and that person is the last one left. There ought to be a requirement that every creditor is notified in writing and that letter ought to be sent at a reasonable time-not well down the track.

I know this is difficult. I know that when we start advertising a situation where a receiver-manager has been appointed, suppliers are going to hesitate and many will simply have no part of the business in difficulty. This can still be done taking that point into consideration. For instance, it can be achieved by having that full meeting of creditors.

I would suggest also that we need to have a hard look at the US chapter 11 system where an individual can stay the action of a creditor. One has a given period of time-it is a short period, admittedly-when one can bring in a manager with great skill on an interim basis to try to overcome the problems and see where the difficulties really are.

The situation we have instead in this nation-and I go to cases in Queensland of restaurants, hotels, construction firms, engineering companies, processing companies, and it goes on and on and on-is that receiver-managers have been appointed and the only result was the winding up; that is all that happened. There is the case of a particular restaurant in Brisbane where immediately the plant, the fixtures and the fittings were sold; of a hotel in central Queensland where they went automatically to auction; of a construction firm in Queensland that they did nothing to help-the fees were enormous, but they did nothing to recover the stability and viability of that firm; and with an engineering firm they did not even bother to try to sell the business as a going concern, but instead sold off bits and pieces at depressed prices.

In another instance, they actually sold the key machinery of the business, which made it impossible for the business to continue anyway. At a processing company in Brisbane the receiver-manager had no understanding of the business whatsoever, and all he did was to wind it up and sell all the equipment on a piecemeal basis.

I give due credit to the accountants, who have a very difficult job to do. At the same time, they ought not take on these tasks that they are not competent to a carry out. What we could and I believe should do is take advantage of the many people out there in the community who come within that retired category. I give this as an example because, in the case of a newsagency in Brisbane, the Kendals accountancy firm decided to appoint, employ, a retired newsagency proprietor. He and his wife were working on a strictly salary basis, and within a period of time ended up turning what was a newsagency in great difficulty into a business that was going quite well. It was ultimately sold at a fair price. The major creditor in this instance, the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, had a total recovery of its money and all other creditors gained significantly because of the action taken by Kendals.

That is not true of other accountancy firms, and I do not want to go into naming some of them. Some of them are very well known. Some have great reputations in the accountancy profession. But what they do is appoint accountants; they do not appoint people with skill and expertise. I know that there is a list of liquidators in Queensland, but again there is no measure of their skills; they are simply on the list. From what I am told of people who are close to this in the legal profession, these people virtually take their turn. They are on a register of liquidators, their turn comes up and they eventually get a job-a job that they have no skill for, have had no involvement, experience or past performance in, and for which they have no expertise-but they get the job, and who suffers? Again, the creditors, the shareholders and the employees.

There is another good example of Horwath and Horwath, accountants, in Brisbane. A major reception centre was in great difficulty. But instead of putting an accountant in, they put in a competent management couple. They are now making solid profits. I suggest that we could add to that the Australian Business Industry Council. The ABIC linked up with Benfield Constructions, identified the most viable part of the company, and got it running well. Why, again? Because they used competent people who knew that specialist industry; who found the profit source and did something with it; who understood how to turn what was then a very bad dollar in debt terms into good dollars in profitability terms. In this instance, with this building construction firm, the jobs have been kept, a lot of creditors have already been paid, and there is a maximising of the returns.

I believe we can go further. I believe that we have the opportunity to go further, now that corporate law has become uniform at a national level and we do have this ministerial council structure. I believe we can actually come down to a procedure, for instance, where a receiver-manager who is appointed by the court ought to be required to go away and come back to the court with what we might call a business plan that sets out the options available.

I think also there is room for the appointment of some type of board of review or panel of experts to assist the judges, so that when the receiver-manager comes back and says, `Look, these are the options; these are the things we can or cannot do', people with that specific expertise can say, `That's the way to go'. Instead, what happens? Their turn comes up as the liquidators, they get it and who cares? As long as they wind it up and at the end of the day they, the liquidators, get paid. It is a receiver-manager situation. The only ones who are really concerned are those petitioning creditors who appoint in most instances or highly recommend the receiver-manager. That person gets his $160 an hour or $1,000 a day and the major creditors recover their money. The others are the losers.

I argue that, as we take up this issue- and it is an important one; as I said, it was raised in the 1988 Harmer report-there ought to be some type of investigatory stage. I mentioned before the American system where they have an interim manager arrangement. It seems to me that we do not have to just copy what the Americans do, but we can take the advantages from what they have experienced and what they have been able to achieve. There ought to be some type of investigatory arrangement as stage one, where the receiver-manager goes in-and he can be the accountant, the money person-and checks through the whole business; then he can come back with a prepared plan, a plan that goes to the judge; and the third stage would be the implementation of that plan, with the appointment of competent people.

The issue is serious. I take note of what the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello) said. I also have concerns about the growth in the number of bankruptcies. I have seen it in my own area. I have seen people whose life savings have gone. I have seen people who have retired from Commonwealth jobs and from the Army and who have gone into a business of one sort or another. They are now bankrupt and face a very miserable existence. I also ask the House to take up the issue of those other people linked to businesses-the creditors, the shareholders and the employees. I believe that we really need to come to grips with this problem because no-one else appears to have done so.

I give full credit to my own Government for what we have done in the area of the rights of shareholders. I refer to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, chaired by the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Lavarch), which is doing some excellent work in this area. As a member of that Committee, along with the honourable member for Higgins, I am impressed with the sorts of recommendations coming forward. But as yet no-one has taken up this matter and understood the imperatives that exist in trying to solve the problem. It is a major problem and its consequences are measured in hundreds of millions of dollars and in ruined lives. This Parliament has a special responsibility to try to solve those problems. The suggestions I have put forward may not be the total solution but I believe they are at least a solution in part and ought to be considered carefully.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had not really intended to join the debate on the Companies (Insolvency Assistance) Amendment Bill because it appeared to be a fairly straightforward amendment under the new Companies Act. However, when I read the second reading speech by the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy), I found that a good deal of it was put along the lines of the debacle involving the Hooker Corporation Ltd. I therefore thought I would correct the record because there is an attempt in this somehow or another to dump on me in particular and the Opposition in general for what was, without any doubt at all in my mind, a rushed, ill considered and certainly self-interested push by the professional advisers to Hooker.

SPEECH.PARA: I even went back to my office and got my diary. I have found that in politics it is a very good idea to keep a diary. It has all sorts of interesting things in it. In fact it is the first time I have opened it since 1989, and I will refer to that later. It shows that the first time the matter was drawn to my attention was on Saturday morning, 16 December. The House was sitting on 21 and 22 December-one of these new fangled ideas of having sittings of Parliament the day before Christmas for the maximum convenience of members.

As a result of that Saturday morning, three people, Brazil, Cadell and Grellman, travelled to Brisbane to outline their proposals to have a specially designed Bill for the liquidation of the Hooker companies introduced into the House and passed instantly. As all honourable members would know, Hooker got into some financial difficulties. As a consequence of this intervention, I asked them why the rush. I have always been of the view that corporate matters should be given time to mature. There is no point in suddenly rushing in to change company law or some Act.

The cooperative scheme-I was the Minister responsible for getting it through the House, and a few other things-took nearly 3 1/2 years to get together, getting the States to agree and so on. The hallmark of its success was the fact that all the various draft agreements and parts of that companies code were circulated to all the interested communities. Every law society, the Institute of Chartered Accountants of Australia, the public accountants, got the papers. They all had three to six months to read them and everybody agreed. There was no disagreement at the end of the process. It took time, there is no doubt about that, but at the end we had the best we could muster on that occasion.

This is one of the areas that I took issue with in relation to the last event. That was not circulated and the Government did not have community agreement behind it. It just pushed it through: no consultation, shove it through. Company law is not about shoving things through, it is about a technical matter in which one must carry the lawyers, the solicitors and all the participating people.

I indicated that I thought that, firstly, a special pleading really was not the thing for Federal Parliament and, secondly, that these things do not really need to be rushed. I wanted to know what the rush was. It appeared that there were some 90-odd companies in difficulties, some of which were solvent and some insolvent. There were a range of credit preferences. They were proposing to merge the assets and liabilities, pay out the lesser ones to an amount I think of the order of $200,000, maybe $250,000, somewhere in that area, and manage it out.

When I inquired who was the person who stood behind most of this, I found that that unfortunate bank, the Westpac Banking Corporation, was there and that it had largely lent on negative pledges to the tune of $800m. So suddenly the urge for action was readily seen. We left that meeting on the basis that I said we would not support a particular Bill, that they ought to think about a general Bill, and that I still saw no reason to rush.

Time then passes and we get to Canberra on Wednesday, 20 December, when there was a party room meeting and shadow Cabinet meeting. That Bill was not on the list and it did not reach my room in the new form until Wednesday night. It was then produced in the general form of amendments to the insolvency Act. This is Wednesday, 20 December, with the House called back for 21 and 22 December to pass amendments from the Senate. They were tight timetables. I shall read from my diary for Thursday, 21 December, and I will leave out some personal observations.

TALK.START.PARA: —When is the book coming out?

—It will be very interesting. There was a late meeting with Brazil, Cadell and Grellman in an attempt to get some agreement to some minor changes to the Bill they wanted introduced in the Senate and passed in five minutes, with our full support guaranteed in the future. An officer from Bowen's office then requested that I sign a form indicating that debate would be limited to five minutes in the Senate and that we would give it full support. I said, `There are a couple of things I cannot do. First of all, I cannot guarantee that the Senate will agree with that, and I still do not understand the rush'.

SPEECH.PARA: I informed these gentlemen that the best I could recommend would be that it be introduced into the Senate, let lie on the table over Christmas, and come back on the agenda in the new year. One gentleman had some problems with his position with the New South Wales court, to which he had to return his views by 10 February or something like that. But I took the view that that was not a bad position.

Because I found the behaviour of the staffer from Bowen's office irregular, I sought out Lionel Bowen. I met him in the parliamentary dining room and I told him that I thought what was going on was unusual. It says in my diary, `Later Bowen agreed with me to introduce it in the Senate and leave it there if he could get it on the timetable'. That was at about 7 p.m. that night. I subsequently learnt that the Government dropped the Bill. From 21 December 1989 we rushed all the way through to 20 February 1991 before it came into the House.

I rest my case. I do not know what the rush was at that time. One of those gentlemen involved in this then went out and gave me a bucket. There is nothing unusual in that. The professional behaviour of those involved in all this was rather extraordinary. I do not blame the current Attorney-General; he had nothing to do with it. I am quite sure, on talking to Lionel Bowen, that Lionel was not fully up to it either.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The long and detailed contribution by the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) is a very difficult act to follow in respect of the Companies (Insolvency Assistance) Amendment Bill before the House. It is always good to keep diary entries because they can often be used to prove a point. I think he has done that tonight. I also think it is quite refreshing to hear the honourable member for Ryan, from the Opposition benches, suggest that it is important for consultation to take place and that draft Bills be allowed to lie on the table of the House and warnings be given to the broad constituency which may be affected by pieces of legislation so that they may respond to it.

SPEECH.PARA: In respect of many pieces of taxation legislation, that is certainly not the attitude that has been displayed by the Opposition. It quite often suggests that exposure drafts of legislation, the so-called legislation by press release that it claims the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has been famous for in the past, has often meant that there is too long a delay in getting Bills into the place before debate occurs. It is refreshing. It goes hand in glove with the attitude displayed by the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) yesterday in his contribution to the debate on the matter of public importance. It is a much more reasoned and a softer approach.

A couple of points made by the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright) and the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello) in this debate were interrelated to some degree. I am referring particularly to the issue of bankruptcies. Sadly, bankruptcies do occur in the Australian economy, an economy which after all is reasonably diverse, and the opportunity is provided for people--

TALK.START.PARA: —Well into recession.

—In a recession, as the honourable member for Wannon suggests, there is an increase in those bankruptcies. But it is also important to look a little beyond and say to the obvious culprits that might be there, like the government of the day, that their policies have put the economy into recession and therefore they are to blame entirely. Then when people have finished with the government they go to the banks and say that it is the banks' fault. The point I was going to make to the honourable member for Higgins was that in a submission that has come to the parliamentary inquiry into the Australian banking industry it was clearly demonstrated that about 5,000 bankruptcies occur annually within this country-not at this particular time because of economic circumstances, but mainly as a matter of course. The reason that this is the case lies in the very point that the honourable member for Capricornia made about people who perhaps were in the armed forces and had taken a severance pay, or people in the Commonwealth bureaucracy or a State bureaucracy who had taken a severance pay, or coalminers who had decided it was time to get out of that industry. They take a considerable sum of money with them, and the next thing they decide is that they are small business people. They set themselves up in some business where they think that their investment will be multiplied and that they have the necessary level of expertise.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a sad commentary. Again, I think the honourable member for Capricornia was absolutely right in his reference to experts needing to be put into positions where perhaps bankruptcies or the winding down of companies are taking place. The same thing can apply to people who intend to become small businessmen and women in this country, and that is a level of training. It is a difficult and very competitive environment in which they seek to become involved. It is simply not a matter of finding a shop location somewhere and paying rent every week to ensure that one has one's shopfront location, putting in some stock and expecting to sell it. That is not what it is all about.

There are a myriad of legal complexities involved in establishing a small business. On top of that there are the taxation requirements of Federal and State governments and a range of issues which people must address. Whilst we in this place might be debating the rights and wrongs and the problems that have been caused by the present economic circumstances, it is important that we should not lose sight of the fact that certainly while those circumstances may contribute to some of those problem bankruptcies, nevertheless, it is important to look a bit beyond that.

I appreciate, Madam Deputy Speaker, the opportunity to range a little widely in this debate after the latitude that you have displayed to other speakers. I come particularly to the Bill before us. I suggest that the purpose of the Companies (Insolvency Assistance) Amendment Bill is to simplify the use of schemes of arrangement in complex corporate structures. The Bill will enable the court to order meetings of creditors of a group of companies on a consolidated basis where the scheme of arrangement will have the effect of transferring assets, property and liabilities to the holding company. This consolidation will reduce the total number of meetings to a manageable number. I will refer to that classic case of the Hooker Corporation Ltd shortly to illustrate that point.

The power given to the courts is in addition to the powers the court already enjoys under the Companies Act-a point that was made by the honourable member for Higgins. The power is to be used in conjunction with the discretions the court has in determining the classes of creditors and in protecting the interests of creditors. That is a point that needs stating again and again. The interests of creditors must be protected. I do not think there is any disagreement by members on both sides of the House in respect of that.

Section 315 of the Companies Act 1981 allows a company in financial difficulty to reach a compromise or arrangement with its creditors or members as a means of avoiding a possible winding up of that company. I again would suggest that we would all be in agreement with that procedure. Schemes of arrangement provide significant benefits to both the creditors and shareholders of companies experiencing financial difficulties. But the great value of schemes of arrangement lies in their simplicity, their flexibility and, probably more importantly, their reversibility.

Quite often all creditors agree to a compromise of their claims. In this particular circumstance not even the court's approval needs be obtained and all that may be necessary is informal consultation with creditors and their consent to the scheme itself. As well, any combination of rights may be decided upon so as to suit the needs and the circumstances of the company, its shareholders and, of course, its creditors. Indeed, the only real disadvantage of such schemes lies in their initial cost. The preparation of documents for the court and legal representation may result in substantial costs.

Surprisingly, at the moment the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs is examining this matter. It is looking at this whole question of costs of legal actions. I think it is probably appropriate, in the light of issues such as this and generally in terms of the extent to which actions are being launched in difficult economic times by people to recover debts.

The current Bill aims to enhance the advantages of schemes of arrangement in the case of complex corporate structures by reducing such costs where necessary. As was indicated, and as I indicated a little earlier, the legislation has its genesis in the winding up of the Hooker group. The honourable member for Ryan went to some length to explain the Opposition's involvement in the preparation of this legislation. I have no need to comment further on the contribution that he made. In December 1989--

TALK.START.PARA: —Where's your diary?
—I am keeping a very accurate diary at the moment, for the benefit of the honourable member for Higgins.
—What were you doing on 21 December 1989?

—I would not tell the honourable member even if I could remember. In December 1989 the Government was approached by legal advisers to the provisional liquidators of the Hooker group of companies, seeking an amendment to the Companies Act because of the considerable practical difficulties which the provisional liquidators were facing. As was indicated by the honourable member for Capricornia, the fundamental problem facing the liquidators was the need to organise some 500 separate meetings of various creditors across the whole of Australia because of the interrelationship of approximately 90 holding and subsidiary companies which made up the Hooker conglomerate. I think that says something about the structure of some Australian companies, what has happened in the 1980s and why perhaps now there is such a call within corporate Australia for them to re-examine themselves and to look at the interrelationships that they have within their corporate structures.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course we are talking about perhaps improving the ethics of business. I think that is appropriate for the 1990s. Sadly, of course, it is a reflection of some extravagances in the 1980s, which occasioned that for a variety of reasons that I will not go into at this time.

In the circumstances of the Hooker wind up, there was a real risk that it would not be possible to reach agreement on an appropriate scheme of arrangements which would enable the affairs of the companies to be wound up in a way which provided the optimum protection for creditors. There is that particular phrase again. The then Attorney-General accepted that there was a need to facilitate schemes of arrangement for complex company structures and the Government agreed that legislation should be developed which would provide a general solution to problems of this kind.

At present, schemes of arrangement require separate meetings of classes of creditors of each subsidiary. In a case such as the Hooker Corporation, one can see the obvious difficulties there. This can result not only in the enormous task of getting people together, but also in the arranging of hundreds of meetings in a country the size of Australia, which can be a very costly exercise and should be avoided at every opportunity. The Bill therefore allows the court additional flexibility in making orders under section 315 in order to circumvent this particular problem.

It is interesting to note that the Chairman of the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities advocated his support for such change on 29 June 1990. In the Australian Financial Review of the same date, he was reported as saying:

. . . liquidations such as that of the Hooker Group often involved many creditors meetings, each of which had to agree separately to arrangements to wind up affairs of the parent company. By consolidating all assets and liabilities of individual companies the number of creditors meetings could be reduced and the liquidation could be accelerated.

I suppose the idea of accelerating liquidation is not a pleasant thought, but nevertheless the arrangements for doing so when a company of this size was in a great deal of difficulty provided an appropriate process for facilitating that.

In drafting this legislation, the Government was concerned that the fundamental protections already in existence for such schemes were maintained. One essential element of such schemes was that a court should decide whether a consolidated meeting of creditors should be held. This would enable the interests of shareholders to be protected as they could ensure that the court was aware of considerations applicable to the circumstances of each specific case.

As I think was indicated, the process and the pattern of having legislation introduced at that time necessitated a rather rapid passage of legislation but, for a var- iety of reasons which the honourable member for Ryan elaborated upon, that did not happen and the legislation is now with the Parliament for consideration.

The original exposure draft which was put together in 1989 is different from the Bill presently before us. There have been one or two particular changes, not the least of which is that the power to order a consolidation should arise only where the number of subsidiaries of a group is at least 30. As a result of the consideration by the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities, this Bill allows consolidation orders to be made where the court considers that circumstances exist which would justify making such an order where there are fewer than 30 subsidiaries involved.
It is interesting that legal opinion on this matter has indicated general support for it. In fact, Associate Professor Leigh Ffrench has offered the opinion that:

Applications to the Court for a scheme maybe made in respect of a group of related companies. However it may be difficult to ensure in these circumstances that proper separate meetings of members and creditors of the individual companies are held. Often the respective meetings are combined together.

This Bill will go a long way towards overcoming the problems which arise as a result of the necessity to hold separate meetings for all subsidiaries. Quite obviously that is the major intention of the legislation.

The legislation is in keeping with the spirit of the current case law and aims to expedite the administration of such schemes by overcoming the strict formality of complex company structures. As was indicated by His Honour Justice Street in Re Jax Marine Pty Ltd (1967) as reported in the New South Wales Law Reports at page 145, persons should be dissected into separate classes-

. . . by reason of some particular matter so affecting the rights of some as to render impossible for them to pursue their own interests concurrently with their participating in the pursuit of the interests of the class of which they appear to be members.

This Bill will vest in the court a capacity to facilitate schemes of arrangement in the case of labyrinthine and convoluted corporate structures where emphasis can be more readily placed upon the real interests of creditors rather than upon the formal organisation of the corporate group.

As I said, it is the creditors who must be protected. This legislation will do that. It is appropriate and it is timely. Again, I am pleased that the Opposition is supporting this legislation unamended in its passage through this place and to the Senate. I wish it speedy passage and I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a sad day for Australia when the Government brings in legislation to make it easier for people to go bankrupt and that is what this Companies (Insolvency Assistance) Amendment Bill does. The second reading speech of the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) makes it very clear that, whilst the original beneficiaries of the amendments will not be able to take advantage of them, they `will, however, be available for other administrations of complex groups'. That was the Attorney-General's comment when he introduced these amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, one of the greatest assistants to insolvency in Australia today must be the Treasurer (Mr Keating). He is assisting more people to become insolvent than any other known factor in the history of this country. So this Bill follows the phil- osophy of the Treasurer and makes it easier for people to go broke or to wind up their cases when they find they are in difficulties. That is a sad commentary on the way in which this Government feels that it needs to deal with its economic problems.

This Government has broad economic problems and one of its fix-it-quick processes is to allow large corporations to fold up easily. It allows all those people who are creditors to forgather, sometimes in numbers exceeding 500, in subsidiary groups and complex arrangements to be represented at a grand meeting. One could almost describe this as a funeral or a wake as another great Australian corporation bites the dust. So these creditors can assemble in proper solemnity and see how much of the remnants of that company they can attribute to themselves or to those for whom they act.

Bankruptcy law in Australia has been a problem, as has the administration of that law. In some instances it has been so rigid it has not been possible for creditors to rightfully gain access to their funds. In other instances bankruptcy law has been relaxed, where agents and other individuals have been appointed to act on behalf of the Commonwealth to wind up companies and to see that funds and assets are distributed, but there is little left at the end of the day.

A number of cases come to mind, cases which I have raised in this House. One that is still proceeding is the Latona case, which is a fascinating study of a bankrupt being wound up by a bankrupt agent but the Attorney-General refusing to remove that bankrupt agent-who was also an accountant-from the completion of his task until late in the day. Then the Government personality representing the Attorney-General eventually concluded the bankruptcy proceedings. It is fascinating to study how a bankrupt can be wound up by somebody who subsequently, during the process of those proceedings, proves to be bankrupt himself.

The Attorney-General assured me at the time that changes would be made to resolve that. I have not noticed them come before the Parliament, but today before the Parliament we have this wonderful piece of legislation to allow people to become bankrupt more easily.

Of course, within the last few weeks we have had the total bankruptcy figures for Australia, and it will not surprise the hordes of people in the gallery tonight to know that every year and every month records are being broken in Australia. It is a record breaking government! It is smashing records like you would not believe. But the records that it is smashing each successive month are its own records in the number of people who are going broke in Australia.

That record of the Government is something that today in the House the Treasurer appeared to be proud of-the economy is steady on course, and we are about to come into some sort of legislation-led recovery. The legislation that is going to bring about the recovery is legislation of the type we are debating in the House at present-that is, legislation to assist people to become insolvent.

If one looks at the statistics it is pretty easy to understand why indeed people are going broke. If one looks at the commentaries of major business groups around Australia, one can easily see that the stern advice being offered to the Government is not being heeded-and it is desperate advice in most instances. I have never seen such uniformity of proposals coming to the Government to assist it to rectify the problems that it has in bankruptcy and rising unemployment. It does not matter whether it is the Confederation of Australian Industry, the Business Council of Australia or any of the myriad of smaller groups representing employers-those who supply the wherewithal for the Australian economy to function- the propositions that they are putting to the Government are consistent.

I think the position is best summarised by the comments of the Business Council of Australia, which says in part that to be effective and credible, the statement that we are to face on 12 March-which will cover issues such as bankruptcy, unemployment and trade-must convince business that the Government is committed to all elements of the Australian economy, not just traded goods and services, to become internationally competitive. It is not saying that legislation to make bankruptcy hard is going to solve the problem. It is saying there must be consistent attention given to the internal needs of Australia as well as to our export effort. I guess that is the key to Australia's recovery.

When one considers that Australia, in a period of just over 20 years, has slipped from about the fourth country in terms of living standards down to about twelfth, thirteenth or fourteenth, and in trading countries down to twenty-seventh, one can see it does not matter what measure is used. Whether it is trading ability or living standards, Australians are suffering.

Right at the moment we have seen the insolvency processes of very large Australian corporations, one of which would have benefited from this legislation. Not only have we seen the friends of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer-former friends, those magnates of large corporations, who have become people whom they do not associate with any longer-disappear from the corporate scene over the last 12 or 18 months, but also we have seen many very efficient and effective businesses come to a stop and cease business. The effect of that, of course, is the massive and quickly rising level of unemployment in Australia and the fall in the levels of job vacancies.

The average Australian, through the processes and policies of this Government, has in fact really suffered from the bankruptcies that have occurred over the last 18 months. It does not matter whether it is somebody some Australians now like to poke the finger at, such as a Bond or a Holmes a'Court-and we tend to be a bit like that, which is regrettable in some ways-or little subcontractors, many of whom live in my electorate, who employ two or three people and who now find they only have one or two days work a week. If they go bankrupt the effect on the Australian economy and our future is exactly the same.

It does not matter whether a little subcontractor is dragged before the bankruptcy court and the house and his wife's assets are gone, and the funds of his children are dissipated, gone-`lost the lot' is the term-or whether it is the large corporation, multi-million or billion dollar corporation that has also suffered, the impact on the Australian community is exactly the same. The nation has become less effective. It spends more on welfare. People cannot manage their family budget from week to week. We find rising unemployment and hardship. It is a tragedy that the Minister, in introducing this legislation, did not give some acknowledgment to the greater dependence that there is now on bankruptcy law in Australia and to the difficulties that people have in meeting their commitments.

The so-called Hooker's amendment-the Companies (Insolvency Assistance) Amendment Bill 1990-that we are debating today deals with one particular case, but I would have thought the Minister could have used the opportunity to announce, firstly, a major review of bankruptcy law and bankruptcy processes in Australia. It is not as clean and easy as it could be, and to solve one particular case by one specific piece of legislation such as this really does not resolve the problem. That could have been the other area that the Attorney-General, in his typical free and easy style, could have alluded to-that is, the problems of the economy-and proposed some alternatives for the Treasurer. Maybe he did not feel disposed to, but at least in his second reading speech, instead of a castigation of the Australian Democrats and the Opposition, there could have been some acknowledgment of the problems most Australians find themselves in today.
I have looked through the statistics concerning our foreign debt ratio. Most people know that we are in debt. Few realise it has taken about 20 per cent of our exports to meet that debt--

TALK.START.PARA: —More than that.

—It is more than that, my colleague now says. It continues to rise. The profitability of organisations in Australia is falling dramatically. Something the Treasurer used to pride himself in was the profitability of Australian enterprises, and that is falling dramatically, particularly if one is to remove from the profitability factors the interest charges and the tax charges from corporations. If one removes the high interest rates, or removes interest rate factors and takes that into account over a period of years, and if one also removes the burgeoning tax on Australians and Australian employers, and runs that back over a period of years, one comes to the point of view that never before-or in the past 20 years-has profitability been lower. Therefore the pressure on solvency is greater and the prospect of or need for bankruptcy or liquidation is even greater than it has been in the past. That can be followed over the last 20 years.

SPEECH.PARA: Today the Treasurer went back to the time of Menzies in order to draw some parallels. He need not have gone that far back; he could look back over the Fraser Administration as well as his own to realise that profitability is extremely low, which means employment is going to wane and the prospect of employment for school leavers is going to wane. It means that those people providing productive effort in Australia-the small businessmen, the small employers, the self-employed persons-are not going to be able to offer jobs or prospects of expansion. One only needs to look at the last 20 years to realise what a parlous state Australia is in.

We can use all sorts of measures to look at, for example, pre-tax profits and sales of corporations, at how much people want to buy-domestic demand-and where that has got to. We can look at the unemployment rate and the way it is rapidly screaming up, and at business investment. All of those things are just measures of how people in the community feel. Most of the information that comes to government is probably dated by six months by the time it passes through the Australian Bureau of Statistics and then becomes available. The figures that we look at here are dated in regard to what is happening now in the community.

The situation in rural areas is desperate. In city areas there is rising desperation, with many bankruptcies and homes for sale. Therefore, I have taken the opportunity of this debate on the Companies Amendment Bill to draw broad attention to the fact that the way ahead for Australia is not one of producing legislation which allows people to become bankrupt more easily or of assisting them in the process of selling up their assets and dissipating the goods and savings of companies, but lies in other avenues. It does not matter whether those avenues of reform lie in reform of the Australian work force, the Government's own behaviour and expenditure, or just performing better in what are loosely termed the micro-economic areas such as transportation systems, with improvement of our capacity to get goods on vessels and sell them overseas on time and at the right price. All of these factors must come together as a package.

Unfortunately for the Hooker organisation, for which this legislation was drafted, the single blunt instrument of the Treasurer's single-minded high interest rate policy was the cause of its problems. One can analyse company after company that is going bankrupt. The real cause of their problems is high interest rates. We can look at companies' profitability tables, market share and employment rates, and sheet the whole lot home to high interest rates. The Government has had alternative policies offered to it for two years now. It has fiddled with the hard parts and used the easy part. The Government could have done the hard things but it chose the easy way, which was to stick with a rigid, gut-busting, company life-destroying high interest rate policy.

The 12 March statement is approaching. I will guarantee to the Minister at the table, the Minister for Local Government (Ms Fatin), that the expectation created in the community in regard to this statement will not be met. The community knows that the Government talks big and acts little. The process of the gradualisation of change will be continued on 12 March. All of the high-sounding statements and the polemic will be there, but there will be no firm proposals. It will be something similar to the Premiers Conference-a constructive idea broken down into a series of committees, the results of which we are yet to see. So 12 March will result in a continuation of the same policies of high interest rates, failure to grapple with increasing bankruptcy and the continuing and increasing need for the Government to use prop-up measures such as this measure before the House today-a measure which seeks to make it easier for people to become insolvent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: —In May 1988, the Federal Government offered rural industry finance on a dollar for dollar basis up to $750,000 a year to finance an Exotic Animal Diseases Preparedness Consultative Council to assess the adequacy of existing exotic disease control procedures and the human and capital resources associated with those control procedures. The council was also to inquire into the social and economic implications of exotic diseases and compensation principles. It was to advise on how to monitor the efficiency of veterinary emergency plans.

SPEECH.PARA: The National Farmers Federation (NFF) agreed to take up the Government's offer because it believed there should be an independent body to look at those matters rather than interdepartmental committees. At that time I was critical of the Government off-loading some of what I believed should have been a national responsibility for exotic disease preparedness and quarantine services in Australia. It is to the credit of the National Farmers Federation that it accepted that responsibility.

The purpose of the Meat Chicken Levy Amendment Bill is to correct a drafting mistake in the 1989 amendment to the 1969 Act which accidentally set the maximum at 0.005 instead of 0.05. I suppose that one can say it was a drunken drafting error, with regard to the 0.05. It has also taken some time to correct that error because the Bill went through in 1989. I do not know what has happened to the level of contributions from the industry in between times. It is my understanding that the operative levy rates will continue to be set by regulation-presumably that is the answer, as the rates had not gone up to the maximum-on the recommendation of the relevant industry committee of the NFF in accordance with the Exotic Animal Disease Control Act 1989. The funds raised through the setting of the correct levy rate for this coming year are estimated to total $27,000. I understand that that is about 6 per cent of the total contribution to the rural dollar for dollar part of the fund. The other industries involved are wool, sheep meat, beef, dairy, pigs, poultry, buffalo and goats.

The Exotic Animal Disease Control Bill 1989 established the consultative council. One of the major reasons the legislation was introduced and the council established at that time was the continuing problem of disease risk for our livestock and plant industries. It has been the relative freedom from these exotic diseases which has been a great strength of those industries in the past.

Unfortunately, more diseases are being discovered in Australia and there is considerable risk from a number of other diseases. The latest disease to be recognised is the nematode disease affecting some potatoes in Victoria. That is an unfortunate important problem for the potato industry in this country, which previously has been free of that disease. We face also the great risks of screw-worm fly, rabies and bluetongue.

In addition, there is the risk of inadvertent, but to some extent deliberate, introduction of disease through a minimum risk quarantine policy. One can think of transmissible gastroenteritis with the importation of pig meat, fire blight with apples, and diseases of bananas, strawberries, deer, nursery products and nashi fruit. There are probably quite a few others as well.

This is of great concern to those domestic industries because so far they have been free of disease and they do not see why they should be exposed to those disease risks through a quarantine policy that allows imports into this country which they consider to be less than adequate. They also point out that there is a double standard being applied in relation to the importation of horticultural products in particular into Australia compared with the quarantine requirements imposed on our horticultural products when they are exported to other countries.

I am thinking in particular of the citrus industry. We have been allowing the importation of oranges from California. Australia has the same disease affecting citrus as does California and although we allow the importation of Californian fruit they will not allow our fruit into California-even though they now admit, reluctantly, but admit nevertheless, that it is the same disease. When one challenges the United States representatives on why this is so they say, `It's only a matter of a short period before this is sorted out. It's only one more review or one more set of documents to fix'. But they keep finding a problem each time. One has to question the sincerity of the United States in this matter.

I also challenge the sincerity of Japan. When one compares the standards Japan requires under area freedom-the policy of area freedom of minimal risk for the importation of product from another country-its definition of area freedom for product from Australia is dramatically different from product from Japan. I think particularly of nashi fruit, but I know there is a range of other horticultural products that are equally disadvantaged by the double standard of the Japanese.

I believe that since this consultative council was introduced and other improvements have taken place with the Australian Quarantine Inspection Service there is better communication between the industry and the responsible Department, and I include in that a monthly magazine. The original legislation also mentioned the Austvet plan-the emergency veterinary plan to combat any of these exotic disease outbreaks.

The Australian Animal Health Laboratory (AAHL) at Geelong plays an important part in this overall plan. It is part of a worldwide network of maximum security laboratories. Purbright in the United Kingdom is a similar laboratory which I have visited and which is well-known for its foot and mouth and blue-tongue work. I think also of Oondespooret in South Africa, which I have visited twice-the last time last July-which is the world's leading centre for blue-tongue.

That one facility in South Africa-the South Africa that is reviled in relation to the rest of Africa-has done more than any other operation to prevent and cure animal diseases throughout the rest of Africa. We should remember that those African countries rely more on animal products to feed their people than on the grain products of other countries. The work by Oondespooret has done more to help people in the rest of Africa live and eat properly than all of the Western aid and Western lectures put together. I think we should realise that. I am disappointed that we have not been able to maintain the relations, communications and cooperation between Oondespooret and Australia-AAHL, in particular-which are essential if we are to combat exotic diseases around the world.

I look forward to a normalisation of relations between our two countries, which I believe should take place again, so that that cooperation between those two very important animal health facilities can once again return to what it was for the benefit not only of our two countries but also of many other countries. On behalf of the Opposition I support the Meat Chicken Levy Amendment Bill 1991.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Courtice Mr B.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Meat Chicken Levy Amendment Bill 1991 is to amend the Meat Chicken Levy Act 1969. The Act was to increase the maximum rate of levy for exotic disease, as the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) has commented. We have been fortunate in Australia, as an island continent, in being free from many of the diseases that have ravaged Europe, Africa and the Americas. It is important that we ensure, through the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) and every other means possible, that we maintain that high standard-and I must say that AQIS does a great job.

SPEECH.PARA: The Act was amended in 1989, together with other livestock industry levy Acts, as the honourable member for Murray has said, in order to raise funds for exotic disease preparedness. There is always a risk that, no matter how many precautions we take, inadvertently-for example, through fishermen in the north-some disease will come into Australia. I share his concern with regard to screw-worm, which is prevalent in New Guinea; rabies; and foot and mouth disease, which is present in some of the South East Asian countries. If those diseases got into our herds in the north, the cost and the means of eradication would be monumental. I believe it is important that we impose levies for preparedness measures to eradicate exotic diseases.

Due to an error, the maximum rate of levy was set at .005c per head instead of the correct rate of .05c per head. I guess the original amendment, like a chicken on Thanksgiving Day, has to get the chop so that we can bring in the correct levy of .05c per head. The matter has been discussed, as the honourable member for Murray said, with the relevant producer organisation and, of course, the National Farmers Federation has (NFF) has formally indicated its support for the amendment.

Passage of the Bill will enable the correct rate of levy to apply from 1 July 1991, on the recommendation of the relevant industry committee of the NFF, in accordance with the Exotic Animal Disease Control Act 1989. The funds raised via this levy are matched on a dollar for dollar basis by the Commonwealth, and it is estimated that the additional funds raised by the setting of the correct levy rate will total some $27,000 in 1991-92. This is in accordance with many of the other levies that are matched dollar for dollar by the Government-whether it be in regard to research and development, which is equally vital for our rural industries, or in regard to exotic disease.

The honourable member for Murray raised some interesting issues in regard to quarantine standards in other countries. Australia has the highest quarantine standards in the world. It is important both to prevent disease coming in and to make sure that when we fight for freer trade we are able to show that our quality product is the best and the cleanest in the world. We faced some problems when dieldrin was found in our beef, and I have always believed that this was used for some time as an excuse to keep our beef out, even though there were errors in the first instance. We have to ensure that we have the highest standards so that other nations are not able to use excuses such as health or disease risks to keep our products out.

One of the other difficulties we have had-and we are getting breakthroughs in this area-is with regard to protocols between countries. We have set up a protocol with New Zealand in horticultural products. It is often hard for us to get the recommended and desirable standards because New Zealand has a hang-up about fruit fly because it does not have the problem in that country. There are several other less harmful problems we have that have kept zucchinis in particular, which are produced in very large quantities in my area, out of the New Zealand market. Although they are heavily tested and sprayed, if even one egg is found the whole consignment is in trouble.

There is a lot more work to do to ensure that we get the best protocol possible. Time and time again quarantine measures have been used against our nation to refuse us access into other markets. That is why it is so important for us to show that we have the best standards in the world in order to protect our industries here and to gain access to other markets.

The Prime Minister's country task force, of which I am a member, met with some egg producers this week and we discussed many issues-in particular, intensive farming. Pressures are often put on primary producers by animal liberationists in relation to intensive farming. I have always been of the view that farmers are, in the main, most humane and concerned people in regard to livestock because that is how they make their living. I believe they are doing a great job in the research and development that is going on now into producing quality breeding stock that can live better in that sort of environment.

It is unfortunate that often these sorts of issues are blown up in the media for sensationalism, because were it not for intensive farming we would not be able to feed the world. I remember when I was attending primary school that teachers used to tell me that the world would be starving by the year 2000. Of course, that will not be the case: food production is outstripping consumption. It is ironic that as we approach the next century we still have mountains of food stockpiled all over the world as a consequence of new technology and better farming methods and practices. It is intended to maintain the best standards here so that we can access the markets that are flooded as a consequence of the technological breakthroughs that have existed, particularly in countries in Europe.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
