DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN HORTICULTURAL CORPORATION AMENDMENT BILL 1990[COGNATE BILL:DRIED VINE FRUITS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1990]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 4 December 1990, on motion by Mr Kerin:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Horticultural Corporation Amendment Bill and the Dried Vine Fruits Legislation Amendment Bill will restructure the Australian Dried Fruits Corporation into the Australian Dried Fruits Board and place it under the wing of the Australian Horticultural Corporation (AHC). The Bills will deregulate the domestic market by removing the domestic component of the sultana equalisation scheme, but continue export underwriting for another three years to minimise the impact of the changes.

SPEECH.PARA: The Industry Commission, formerly the Industries Assistance Commission, is required at least every five years to investigate and report on any primary industry receiving what is called government assistance. The definition of assistance basically is that there is some sort of delegated power or authority from the Government. Thus these Bills follow a report and investigation by the then Industries Assistance Commission in 1989 and recommendations for the future marketing of dried vine fruit.

The legislation we have before us is in many ways similar to that for the wheat industry in that the domestic market is to be deregulated, but export controls will continue. The Government will continue its current-not currant-underwriting scheme for another three years. The two pieces of legislation, as I said, will change the Australian Dried Fruits Corporation into a board and place it under the broad oversight of the Australian Horticultural Corporation.

Quite frankly, the dried fruits industry does not want it; the industry has been forced or blackmailed by the Government, by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin), to agree to those changes to preserve the export power. I acknowledge that that was a sensible decision for the industry, because the export power is particularly important in these uncertain exporting times. The dried fruits industry cannot see any benefits at all in being tied to the AHC. All it will have is an additional cost of $60,000 a year for the next three years while there is some government subsidy to the overall costs of the AHC, and then the price could double.

The export power is an important one for the industry, and I believe it has utilised that power with great skill. The industry has a long history of competing successfully in export markets. Australian fruit, competing against that from a number of other countries, including the United States, Turkey and Greece, attracts the highest price on world markets; it attracts a quality premium and there is obviously good marketing. But the Government has claimed that its decision to force the industry into the AHC is justified by saying:
When monopoly export control powers are exercised, government needs to be assured that sufficient checks and balances are in place to ensure that the national interest is taken into account.
In reality, the AHC is the creation of the Minister, but so far has been of very doubtful value; in government we will certainly review whether it has any worthwhile future.

I turn to some of the details of the legislation. The sultana underwriting scheme was introduced in 1982, when the world was oversupplied with sultanas and prices were disastrously low. The scheme paid out $1.3m or $16 a tonne in its first year, but has not been triggered since-and I emphasise that. In 1986 the scheme was changed to reduce the level at which the Government could underwrite. The level was set at 80 per cent of the free on board export return for the past three years and a sunset clause inserted so that the scheme finished at the end of December 1990. This legislation will continue the underwriting for another three years to help the industry to adjust to the deregulation of the domestic market.

The sultana equalisation scheme was introduced many years ago to equalise the domestic and export markets so that farmers would be paid the same price for their product irrespective of where the product was sold. Legislation in 1986 set a cap on the equalisation payments that could be made over and above the average export return, and those payments are now limited to 15 per cent above export returns, or equivalent to import parity. Because the domestic price in most years was above the export price the Government and the Industry Commission believe this has been a consumer transfer. However, it should be pointed out that neither the Dried Fruits Corporation nor the Australian Dried Fruits Association actually has ever marketed fruit on the domestic market.

Because of this perceived transfer, the Government is removing the domestic component from equalisation but, as I indicated earlier, it will continue it on exports. This means that equalisation will be a reconciliation of export returns at the end of each season. There will be no levies and no government financial involvement.

The industry, as I said earlier also, is not happy with losing domestic equalisation. It points out that it is already competing on the domestic market against heavily subsidised product from Greece and very much cheaper and poorer quality fruit from Turkey, and is now subject to a decreasing tariff so that by July 1992 it will be 15 per cent on a normal basis and 10 per cent on a developing country basis.

I want to refer in more detail to this point of protection, because the dried vine fruits industry was one of five agricultural industries in 1988 to have a regime of tariff reductions so that by 1 July 1992 they would be all on the 15 per cent normal and 10 per cent developing country preference. The speed of that tariff reduction is far greater than that which has been applied or is likely to be applied to any of the high tariff protected manufacturing industries, if one looks in particular at textiles, clothing, footwear and the motor vehicle industry. In addition, if the Government accepts the latest recommendation from the Industry Commission about the motor vehicle industry, that industry will have an extremely generous export subsidy. No agricultural industry has any export subsidy whatsoever.

There is also talk in the Government that, while this slower reduction of tariff is taking place with those highly protected manufacturing industries, there will be further reduction in the already low level of tariff for agricultural industries that are on this very low level of tariff at present. I believe that is wrong and unfair. What is known as the `tops down' approach is, I believe, far fairer-that is, all tariffs come down to 15 per cent and 10 per cent before there is any further reduction. I believe that is a far more equitable way of handling what we all believe is necessary-and that is reduced tariff protection-than what appears to be sold or talked about at the present time.

I also want to challenge the calculations used by the Industry Commission in relation to what is the effective level of assistance. I know the effective rate or level of assistance is more than tariff; it can be a range of marketing procedures, export subsidies and so forth. I commend the National Farmers Federation for the independent work that has been done on the way in which the Industry Commission calculates protection or assistance. In a news release of the National Farmers Federation of 20 December last year, it said that the Industry Commission had miscalculated levels of assistance between agriculture and other industries throughout the economy. I quote:

``In essence, the Commission has failed to recognise that agricultural industries are being penalised by inefficiencies in other sectors in the economy, particularly in the transport, irrigation, financial services and electricity industries . . . The rate of assistance, or the aggregate effect of Government intervention in industries such as sugar, rice, dairy and dried fruits, is much lower than is indicated by the Commission's current methodology.
``Inefficiencies in key support service industries have resulted in major cost burdens on our efficient export industries, yet the Commission has ignored their impact.
``NFF is calling on the Industry Commission to change the methodology it uses when calculating effective rates of industry assistance so that all industries are treated equally''.

The Commission's assistance rate calculations include the cost of tariffs, subsidies and other Government intervention on goods which are internationally traded, but excludes Government interference in services and non-traded inputs to production.

The Commission's reasons for including some interventions in the calculation and leaving others out are weak and very flimsy . . . An assistance calculation that ignores services and non-traded inputs is half baked and an unreliable policy guide.
``If the Commission ignores the need to improve the accuracy and comprehensiveness of their calculations, it risks a serious loss of credibility.''
I understand that there has been some contact between the Industry Commission and the National Farmers Federation on this matter since then.

I now want to indicate the difference between the calculations of the Industry Commission of effective rates of assistance and those of PDP Australia Pty Ltd, which was the consulting body used by the National Farmers Federation, by reading the following table into the record:

The figure for sugar would be considerably less since 1988. The figure for citrus is an interesting reverse. The figure for dried vine fruit is the key figure for this debate.
I hope that the Industry Commission adopts a methodology that is fair and equal and on the same basis between primary industry and all the other sectors that it is comparing.

I also want to talk about a problem confronting the dried vine fruits industry. It also relates to what I would call fair trade. If we look at the problems in that and many other industries which are either import competing or a combination of import competing and exporting, there is no fair trade at the present time. For fair trade to occur, first of all, those countries that are not genuinely developing countries should no longer continue to receive the 5 per cent tariff advantage.

It is interesting that the criteria or definitions used certainly by the United States and New Zealand are considerably different from that used by Australia. These countries belong to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade and conform to the GATT rules as much as Australia does. For example, the Asian Tigers-that is, Singapore, Hong Kong, Taiwan, the Philippines, et cetera-all still have their developing country preference with Australia. I am told that all of them have now lost it with the United States because of the calculation it uses on ratios of gross domestic product.

There are also other requirements used by both the United States and New Zealand which limit developing country preference to particular commodities when they have reached a certain percentage of the market or some other basis. I am told that, for example, citrus concentrate from Brazil is no longer allowed into either of those countries on a developing country basis. I believe we have to review the reality of many countries and commodities still receiving that assistance in Australia and not recognised, in reality anyway, as such by other countries.

The second point in relation to fair trade is food standards. The very high food standards applied in Australia-and correctly so-should be equally applied to all imported goods. There has been progress in this area. It has been slow and painful and it has been very much bipartisan at the Federal level over the years, but it is still not adequate because there is still only a very minor percentage of imported foods being tested.

I give an example of the dramatic contrast in our standards of food testing. I have been advised that some dried apricots were imported from Turkey, but because the quality was so poor they could not be sold. So, when we attempted to re-export them because they could not be sold here, they could not be re-exported as they could not receive the health certificate necessary to export them from Australia because they were not considered to be on the same basis as an Australian product.

The next point in fair trade is dumping. When the coalition Government lost office in 1983, we had, at least for certain types of horticultural commodities, an arrangement called `fast track', particularly with New Zealand. At the 60-day point, it allowed cash securities to be applied if a prima facie case had been established. Then those cash securities were either confirmed as dumping or countervailing duty or repaid at the final determination.

In this country at the present time there is a 55-day initial investigation and then two periods of 120 days each, which makes it 295 days generally before any dumping or countervailing duty is applied. I believe that is too slow and unfair on that industry. Where there is prima facie evidence, it should be possible to apply cash securities after the 55-day period. I am told that in the United States there is a 30-day period.

We also have the requirement for material injury, which in practice means that 20 to 25 per cent of the market has to be lost before a complaint can be lodged. That in itself means that quite a period of time will have been lost. I am aware of cases over the years in the United States involving some of the products from Goulburn Valley. Those involved do not bother about material injury. They belong to GATT. The moment dumping is proven or the prima facie case has been established, the duty or penalty is applied.

I believe that a particularly difficult and unfair addition of this Government in relation to dumping is the sunset arrangement-that is, if dumping or countervailing duty is applied, after three years basically it has to be proven again. But because material injury or significant loss of market share has to be proven before one can actually apply for the dumping action to begin, basically the whole rigmarole and nightmare of losing market to what may be a dumped product has to be gone through again before action can be taken.

I think that both the dried vine fruit industry and the citrus industry are examples of industries in which potential complications could arise. Surely it should be possible to have some investigation ahead of that three-year sunset arrangement to establish whether or not the reasons why the duties were applied in the first case are still in place before the duty expires.

We are moving to lower protection levels in Australia. I believe that is necessary provided in particular, as I said, that everybody shares equitably in that. Therefore, I think it does increase the importance of ensuring that products are being imported fairly. That is the reason why I mention those four or five key points which I believe are essential for the establishment of a fair trade policy. The dried vine fruit industry, as I said earlier, reluctantly has agreed to this legislation, and the Opposition supports the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Courtice Mr B.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Dried Vine Fruits Legislation Amendment Bill, which is being debated cognately tonight with the Australian Horticultural Corporation Amendment Bill, is to continue the sultana underwriting scheme for three years and to remove the domestic component of the dried vine fruits equalisation arrangements. In September 1989, the Industries Assistance Commission reported on the dried vine fruit industry and recommended reforms to equalisation and underwriting arrangements. The Government has since then been liaising closely with the industry on these recommendations.

SPEECH.PARA: The extension of the sultana underwriting scheme for three years to 31 December 1993 is to assist the dried vine fruit industry during the period of change in the level of Government involvement in other areas of the industry. The Government considers this appropriate, given the concentrated regional nature of the dried vine fruit industry and the impact that change may otherwise have on such regions.

I concede that I do not have any dried vine fruit in my electorate. In my electorate of Hinkler I probably have the most equable climate in the world and, consequently, I do not have the climate that allows one to grow dried vine fruits. But I do acknowledge the interest of several honourable members here who do have dried vine fruits in their electorates. Dried vine fruits are a great product and just because they are not a massive industry does not mean that they are not important. They are equally as important as any other industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —The largest horticultural industry in Australia.

—And I do enjoy consuming some of the products from the electorate of the honourable member for Mallee, who has just interjected, because those products are top quality. The Bill also provides for domestic returns to be removed from the statutory equalisation arrangements. Once removed, the provision for a levy on domestic sales will no longer be necessary and the Bill therefore provides for the levy arrangements to cease to apply to fruit produced after 1 January, 1991.

SPEECH.PARA: Under the existing equalisation legislation, a levy is imposed on domestic sales of dried vine fruit and the proceeds are then equalised across all sales, both domestic and export. A domestic consumer transfers results in seasons when domestic returns are higher than export returns. Domestic returns have been higher than export returns in some 26 of the past 30 years. The proposed amendments thus leave in place provision for the equalisation only of dried vine fruit export returns, and provide for this to take place as a reconciliation after the end of each season.

The continuation of the sultana underwriting scheme continues the Commonwealth's liability to make payment in the event that the scheme is triggered. The Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics has estimated that export prices would have to slump in excess of 30 per cent over the three-year period of the scheme's extension for it to be triggered and for a pay-out to be made. With the removal of the domestic component of the equalisation arrangements, a levy on domestic sales will no longer be necessary. The Commonwealth's involvement in these levy arrangements, other than to complete arrangements for previous years, will therefore cease as a result of the proposed amendments. Continuation of the equalisation of export returns has no financial implications for the Commonwealth.

The other Bill being debated is the Australian Horticultural Corporation Amendment Bill 1990. The purpose of this Bill is to provide a mechanism for the establishment of an Australian Dried Fruits Board within the Australian Horticultural Corporation, the AHC. In September 1989, the Industries Assistance Commission report on the dried vine fruits industry recommended that the Australian Dried Fruits Corporation be brought under the umbrella of the Australian Horticultural Corporation, and this Bill provides the mechanism necessary to achieve this.

The Bill provides for the establishment of product boards within the Australian Horticultural Corporation. Product boards are to be corporate entities and are to operate with substantial autonomy, but under the broad oversight of the AHC. The Australian dried fruits industry is currently assisted by the Commonwealth in the area of marketing only for exports. Participation in the Australian Horticultural Corporation is not intended to change this.

Provision has therefore been made for the functions of boards to be tailored to cover particular products in particular ways. The Minister will have the final say on which products will be covered by a product board since product boards will be established by regulations. They are to have functions and powers that largely mirror those of the Corporation: to promote those Australian horticultural products covered by a board, both in Australia and overseas; and to improve the industry's competitiveness by improving the quality, handling, storing, processing and marketing of board products.

I would like to add that only recently the Queensland Banana Association has become involved with the greatest rugby league team in Australia-the Broncos. The Broncos are supporting the banana industry of Queensland. That shows the sort of innovation that is starting to come into our agricultural industries. That is what we need. Just imagine how much more we could sell if Elle MacPherson perhaps promoted some Australian horticultural products.

The Australian Dried Fruits Board is to be established through provision in the Bill, as this is the most efficient way of providing for the transition from the Australian Dried Fruits Corporation. We can expect that, at this stage, only the dried vine fruits industry will join the AHC under the product board arrangement, although the honey industry may well take advantage of this structure. Product boards are to be corporate entities and are to operate with substantial autonomy, but under the broad oversight of the AHC. They are to have powers and functions which largely mirror those of the AHC and are to be funded in the same way through industry levies. Such funds are to be paid direct to the relevant board from Consolidated Revenue net of an amount to be paid to the AHC to cover a share of the overheads of that body.

This Bill then provides for the establishment of the Australian Dried Fruits Board and for the repeal of the Australian Dried Fruits Corporation Act of 1978. Essentially, the Dried Fruits Board will take on the activities of the ADFC, including the export control arrangements and the ADFC staff, assets and liabilities. The Bill provides for a product board to be funded by industry levies which are to be paid to a product board directly from Consolidated Revenue. Product boards are to be responsible for their own finances and are to have their financial dealings separately audited and reported. Payments to boards from Consolidated Revenue are to be net of payments made to the AHC for the product boards' contribution to the AHC's overheads. The formula or amount of this contribution is to be determined by regulations. I believe that the dried fruits industry is currently finalising this matter with the AHC.

When monopoly export control powers are exercised, the Government needs to be ensured that sufficient checks and balances are in place to ensure that national interest is taken into account. This will be provided for the Australian Dried Fruits Board through the oversight and monitoring by the AHC. As well as this, the Government has before it two independent reports both recommending that the dried vine fruits industry be brought within the AHC, namely, the Industries Assistance Commission report into the dried vine fruits industry; and the review by Professor Jeremy Davis of primary industry statutory marketing authorities. The Government has agreed with this approach and the provisions of the Bill reflect this.

The Commonwealth currently collects and then disburses industry export charges imposed on dried vine fruits to fund the operations of the Australian Dried Fruits Corporation. The Commonwealth recovers the costs of these charge collections from the dried vine fruits industry. This involvement by the Commonwealth is set to continue with the establishment of the Australian Dried Fruits Board since that body will be funded in the same way, through industry export charges and levies. Costs associated with the establishment of other boards will be met in the same way from levies on products covered by these boards as other industries come into the system. There are, therefore, no implications in this Bill for additional costs to the public sector.

I would like to comment briefly on the horticultural industry in total, because I am very fortunate to have the largest and I believe most important horticultural industry in my electorate, in Bundaberg, which now produces more tomatoes than any other area in Australia and some $135m worth of horticulture in any year. It has played a massive part in employment and in the operations of the many service industries and small manufacturing and engineering works that have been associated with horticulture.

There are some interesting contrasts in views in regard to aerial spraying, and the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) mentioned the concerns that had been raised and supported them. In the Bundaberg region we lose $2m worth of horticultural crops a year because of the indiscriminate and inaccurate use of chemical sprays, particularly 2,4-D and 2,4,5-T, which are used in other enterprises. I have consistently called on the Queensland Minister to tighten up the relevant Act because individual farmers cannot afford to lose $2m worth of crops a year through the indiscriminate use of chemical sprays.

Until the election of the Goss Government there was no Act in Queensland covering the health and safety of workers in the horticultural industry, and indeed the farming industries. That matter is now being addressed by the Queensland Minister for Employment, Training and Industrial Relations, Mr Neville Warburton. Unfortunately there has been massive indiscriminate use of chemicals throughout the horticultural industry over years. We all know what happened when dieldrin was used with gay abandon in Queensland, and the resultant effects on our beef industry and on our exports markets will be felt for many years.

Horticulture has a massive export potential. Earlier in the debate on a previous Bill, I said that protocol was one of the problems that has to be addressed. Many of the protocols that have been in effect for several years with different countries-New Zealand in particular-will run out. New Zealand does not have fruit-fly and its horticultural industries are sensitive not only to fruit-fly but also to other problems we have that are similar to or associated with fruit-fly.

If we can demonstrate through research and development that products such as zucchinis, which are grown in my area, are clean and cannot cause any contamination we have a massive market potential. Last month during a brief visit to Japan I went to a supermarket in Yokohama to find that rockmelons cost $25 each. We sell our rockmelons locally and in the markets in Brisbane, Sydney and Melbourne for $1 plus each. While transport charges are very high, with protocol and a little technology I believe we have a massive market potential in Japan, particularly as that country starts to lower its tariff barriers, which it is doing.

When the beef liberalisation comes through in April, I believe Japan will discover that the consumer is the beneficiary. Once that consumer pressure builds up, it will diminish the pressure from the Japanese farm lobby as a consequence and we will get better access for our products into the Japanese market-a market that, along with Taiwan and Korea, poses the greatest potential at the present time for Australia, given the behaviour of the European Community.

Earlier the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) spoke about dumping. Australia has very good anti-dumping measures in place, but it is like any other problem. We need to be able to prove dumping, as we need to prove that someone has broken the law before that person can be charged. It is not easy. The honourable member for Murray mentioned New Zealand as a case in point. Since that example he gave, which was several years ago, we have moved into closer economic relations (CER) with New Zealand. I am positive that CER will be a benefit to both countries because both agricultural nations have access to markets on which each can piggyback.

Collectively, Australia and New Zealand have a population of 20 million and, collectively, an expertise in marketing our export products. We can utilise the markets New Zealand has that we may not have access to in Australia and vice versa. We should be neither intimidated by nor fear our brothers and sisters in New Zealand, which has only 3 million people and a very small area of land.

There is one other concern I have which I should like to mention, given that it was mentioned several times today during Question Time and would have a massive effect on the horticultural industry. I refer to the imposition of a goods and services tax. It would impose a 15 per cent tax on food in this country and reduce the ability of people, especially pensioners and working people, to buy food and it would impact on farmers. A goods and services tax would have a devastating effect on the horticultural industry and particularly on the agricultural industry right across the country. The Opposition would do well to abolish any plans to implement such a tax if it really cares about horticulture.

Protection is another issue that we grapple with. I am criticised in my electorate for consistently supporting freer and fairer trade. I was pleased to note that recently the Leader of the National Party (Mr Tim Fischer) said that he would not ban imported food products because he recognised that 80 to 85 per cent of our agricultural products need overseas markets. I am pleased that the Leader of the National Party understands that if Australia erects barriers against imported products it cuts off its nose to spite its face.

Unfortunately in my electorate in Queensland two of the three stooges in the National Party, Senator Boswell and Senator O'Chee, have continually run around frightening farmers in support of protection. It is beneficial neither to their Party nor to the industry. I wish they would desist from spreading that proposition. All it has done is frighten the farmers and put a proposition that may well in the short term be beneficial to their own political stand but will be of no benefit at all in the long term to either agriculture or to them.

In regard to imported food products, I should like to see every product that is sold in supermarkets being Australian, but Australia has to trade bilaterally. We have introduced an initiative that has not yet been acclaimed or cheered by people such as Senator Boswell, who has been critical of us. I refer to the compulsory labelling with country of origin of all fruit juices and blended fruit juices.

The Government has taken an initiative through Senator Tate, who deserves to be complimented on the way in which he has attacked this issue, in asking all State health Ministers to support our lead in the compulsory labelling with country of origin of all food products in Australia. Once that is enacted it will give Australian consumers a choice. We are all proud of being Aussies. The Brisbane Broncos have lined up with the banana industry. This will give other horticultural industries an opportunity to promote their products and will halve the number of imported food products sold on our shelves simply through promotion and the loyalty of the Australian consumer.

Unfortunately, Senator Boswell, who is one of the critics of our free trade proposition, cannot even come to terms with his own Party's decision on wool. He continually supports protection for his own short term political ends at the expense of our large export industries such as beef, wheat, wool and sugar and is even at odds with his own Leader.

These Bills deserve the support of the House. They are not dramatic Bills that will attract the attention of the Press Gallery, but they are part of the agricultural industries that ensure the employment of thousands of Australians and thousands of Australian farmers. I believe these Bills provide us with a great opportunity to expand our horticultural industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can understand Australian farmers being concerned if they heard the comments of the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice). The fact is that this Government has only a single-item policy on horticultural industries, and that is to reduce tariffs. March 12 will produce more of that process and will bite more on the farmers and manufacturers of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Unlike the Government, the Opposition has a multi-strand approach to these problems. We are determined to reduce tariffs but we are not prepared to send more and more businesses broke, as the Government is doing, by relying on high interest rates and reduced tariffs. A more rational and thoughtful approach must be brought to bear on these industries.

Our approach is to reduce tariffs and at the same time to instigate reforms in industrial relations, to establish more competitive and efficient government enterprises, to ensure that our transportation systems are working, to make sure that, unlike the Government, there is actual reform on the waterfront so that our export industries gain the maximum markets. We have a multiplicity of strategies to deal with Australia's current economic problems. Unlike the Government, we have ideas. Unlike the Government, we do not rely upon one policy, which is to reduce tariffs.

In the last few days the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has made a continuing commitment to further reduce tariffs without giving any consideration to all the other cost factors that impinge upon the cost of production and the effectiveness of our horticultural and manufacturing industries. Sure, we have to be in the world reducing tariffs. Sure, we have to be internationally competitive. But we cannot meet that target by reducing tariffs. That is the bluntest instrument a government can use against employment and against those who provide employment. We cannot get results in Australia in that way. That is a punitive approach which is just a prescription to send more and more people bankrupt and create more and more unemployment. The Government needs a range of strategies.

A lot of hype has been generated by the Prime Minister, Senator Button-the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce-the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and a whole bunch of people. Even the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Crean) wants to jump on the bandwagon. A whole raft of them now want to get involved in this. I wonder whether the Minister at the table, the Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown), is involved in the drafting of the 12 March statement.

In this speech I am not going to blame the Australian Labor Party for creating the wrinkles on sultanas, but I do blame the Labor Party for the way it has dealt with all of these complex problems with such simplicity and such obvious failure. One only has to read the bankruptcy lists to recognise the failure of the large companies and look at the increasing unemployment list, the queues on the dole and the job vacancies that are not there to understand that cutting tariffs and high interest rates is not a policy that will get results for a government of Australia. The Government has to be more sophisticated, more thoughtful and more intelligent. The Minister is intelligent; he needs to increase his intelligence by listening to some of the wisdom that comes from this side of the chamber in order to deal with the problems that confront Australia.

It is no good saying, `The ACTU is really difficult and they're our mates and we can't fix up the transport industries because we've got TNT and we've got this one and we've got that one'. It is really too hard for the Government. It has to be firm. It has to be able to take a stand on these issues. That is what we are prepared to do. There has to be a range of strategies to solve the problems that confront Australia today. Nowhere more can it be seen than in Australia's dried fruit industries. Those are industries in which we are extremely competitive. We are competitive by world standards. But it also happens to be an area of production that most of southern Europe is involved in. It is an area that can be dramatically affected by the low cost of labour. It is an area within the European Community where there are untold problems of trying to cope with the surplus of dried fruits. Despite its efficiencies, Australia has an international problem in trading where there are subsidies and mechanisms of support and protection that are so much more sophisticated and devious than ours, which tend to be up-front and transparent, and we tend to use the tariff mechanism.

The growers of Australia understand that it is our intention to reduce tariffs, but I want to reiterate, in perhaps a more serious vein, that it is our intention to deal with a range of policies that will dramatically reduce costs of production. Dealing effectively with matters such as transportation-road, rail and sea-the reform of industrial relations, privatising and making more competitive Australia's great organisations and corporations that are currently controlled by the Government, will add to our gross domestic product 3.7 per cent. That is the gain that Australia will see from taking those matters under control. If the Government pursues its current course of just reducing tariffs, there is a gain to national product: 1.5 per cent. It is less than half of what can be gained by taking a harder course but a more productive course in the management of Australia's economy.

I challenge the Government with these issues. It should just not chuck stuff off as it has with the dried fruit industry and the Industry Commission and hope to get a report that is rationally dry which it will endorse, while the Prime Minister is baring his chest saying, `We are going to cut tariffs'-wonderful stuff-and then walk away from the hard issues of being more productive in terms of economic outturn and benefit to the average Australian. I challenge the Government in that area to not concentrate on a single strand policy as far as Australia's horticultural industries, our smaller industries and our manufacturing industries are concerned.

The honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) raised an issue that we also need to deal with. As we reduce the protection in Australia we shall be more and more challenged by the cheats of international trade. As they have in the past, they will test our market and endeavour to undercut an Australian industry in order to weaken it to an extent that production falls and the number of people involved is reduced and ultimately it is exposed to imports. A fair way of tackling that problem is to insist that the standards that apply to production in Australia, standards which are brought onto the table of this House in the form of regulation or into State parliaments in the form of ordinances or regulations, must be observed by importers if they apply to Australian manufacturers or Australian producers. That is not the case at the moment.

Where a discrepancy is noticed in quality or standard by an Australian producer, then a notification process is required and through our Customs system we can require imports to comply with those standards. But it is only on notice and by the quasi-legalistic approach that we can achieve a fairness of quality demanded by governments of Australian manufacturers that is equivalent and is matched by goods being brought into the country.

I believe that this is a wrong approach. I endorse the view that where there is a legislative requirement for standards to be met in matters of manufacture and matters of processing or further development of foodstuffs, it should be mandatory that those standards apply to goods coming into Australia. It is easy to understand when considering the simple example of the dried apricots that we have just been presented with by the honourable member for Murray. Dried apricots were allowed to come into Australia which were of such poor quality that they could not be sold here and yet again of such poor quality that they could not be exported because they did not meet Australian standards.

How stupid of us to force Australian growers to meet standards that are required for the safety, the health and the expectation of the Australian consumer to be undermined by anybody who wants to ship a load of apricots or anything else in here. That is incredibly poor. It is really bad management and really undermines the competitive edge that Australian industries may have. That ought to be a change that this Government is prepared to instigate to prevent the international cheats in trade who would destroy the benefits of cutting tariffs and who will create great resentment and concern within those communities that will bear the tariff cuts. The Ministers of this Government will have knocking on their doors groups of people who will say that they have been dumped on and cheated against by overseas producers because on a quality basis they do not have to observe Australian standards.

I bring that important issue to the attention of the Government. It is further clarified when one looks at the requirements of the National Health and Medical Research Council, which looks at the standards required for human medicines and for cosmetics. Something that comes into contact with a human being must have very strict controls, and we apply those controls. Some would say that we apply those controls to an extraordinary degree, that the process of testing and the time it takes to examine products is overdoing it because what we do is to reinvent the wheel and conduct the same tests as the Americans, the British and the whole of Europe and we duplicate that process. That is wise and should be a requirement.

On the other hand, however, we have an attitude about manufactured goods and some processed foodstuffs that there is not a requirement to meet Australian standards. That is wrong and there should be blanket legislation to stop that going on. That would stop the cheats.

Another area in which the Government is moving painfully slowly-and I know it is a hard area; I have examined this matter myself-is that of labelling and product identification. Why does the Government not pick up Nick Greiner's suggestion-I think it is excellent; it is a way to make a start-and say that what applies in Western Australia will apply nationally and what applies in New South Wales will apply nationally? Everybody will accept everyone else's codes and we will have blanket legislation that is composed of all the current standards required around Australia. We could make that the starting point.

As time passes and the impracticality of some of the standards becomes obvious, we can gradually carve away at the edges. That is the only way in which we will have the States of Australia agreeing to a common marketing code, a common labelling code and a common description code that can be legislated across the country. We will do that if we follow the Greiner formula. I believe that he presented an argument and a way through this traditional problem of the competing interests of the States of Australia. So that would be a start.

Until Australians can be assured-not just on orange juice; on everything they jolly well buy-that something is made in, is a product of and is packaged in a certain place, until they can read that information, then they are not being provided with proper information to make judicial judgment on what they should be purchasing. Then there is the contents factor which is another argument that I will not go into here.

Another area that I will touch on briefly is that of dumping and the need for Australia to have effective anti-dumping procedures. I believe that these procedures are too protracted, too lengthy and too expensive. It takes 210 days to get a dumping case up and running. How much do we pay to the lawyers? How can a small manufacturing industry possibly cope with that? Anti-dumping procedures must not be made a protective mechanism. I think we can do it quickly and effectively and I think we can remove some of the factors that are currently there without creating a false barrier. That is what I would like to see instigated, also for the purpose of preventing the international cheats.

The proof of injury to an Australian industry is almost impossible. The honourable member for Mallee (Mr Peter Fisher) may remember that some years ago the cheese industry in Australia was under attack. Certain types of cheeses were not manufactured in Australia and Europe poured tonnes of cheese into this country. The cheddar industry and other healthy industries were wiped out when huge quantities of cheeses of different types were dumped on to the Australian market. The equivalent quality or the equivalent product argument in our legislation knocked out the dumping case against those cheeses.

Unless we are a bit smarter and a bit more inventive, then those who want to abuse Australia-those who want to kill an Australian industry and then take advantage of that death to promote their own product-will continue to do so. That has gone on a lot during the term of office of this Government to too great a degree. I thought that Ministers would have been more perceptive than they have been in detecting where Australian manufacturers and producers have been knocked off because of a lost leader in the market for a while.

There is the cumulative effect of one country putting a bid in, then bids from other countries flowing through until we have a huge amount of one product on the Australian market. It is worthwhile looking at the battery industry in that regard. Very quickly the orders roll from one country to the next, from one subsidiary or family company to the next and before we know where we are, across a range of countries-not from one source-we have the Australian battery manufacturers under attack. These are the areas to which the Government has to pay greater attention.

I started off my speech talking about the sultana industry. I have not blamed the Government for putting wrinkles on sultanas, but I do blame it for being far too simplistic, not thoughtful enough and not dedicated to fixing the hard things in Australia, the critical things that will produce the gross increase and provide a greater gross national product in which every Australian will share. High interest rates and cutting tariffs is not the answer to Australia's problems.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newell Mr N.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Horticultural Corporation Amendment Bill and the Dried Vine Fruits Legislation Amendment Bill that are before the House tonight form a part of the changes that have been seen as necessary if the horticultural industries in Australia are to expand in importance and provide a role for the national economy in the future. As these industries are finding new domestic markets and continuously entering overseas markets, they are certainly entering a new era for agricultural production in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: As the potential of these industries is realised, they will emerge as very significant earners of export dollars, as has been alluded to by honourable members opposite. The horticultural industries will produce significant and sustainable levels of production which will make Australia the major supplier to countries such as those on the Pacific rim.

The Australian Horticultural Corporation, set up some three or four years ago, has already witnessed and addressed a number of industry issues in its role as an industry driven organisation. Growers, processors and exporters have found the past year a difficult one, to say the least. With sophisticated overseas competition, dynamic market demands and shifting economic tastes, Australian participants have had to take a hard look at ways to improve their performance in the horticultural marketplace.

As the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) mentioned earlier, the coalition policies on the horticultural industry involve a number of things. One point on which they do agree with us is the reduction of tariffs. That would go ahead, even under a coalition government. The honourable member for Mitchell mentioned the basis for industrial relations and transport reforms. Perhaps if he had been listening to some of the answers that were given at Question Time, he might have been satisfied with the progress the Government is making in that area. If not, perhaps we could ask another question at the next sitting.

One of the Corporation's primary tasks is to assist in maximising the net return from horticulture in Australia. It has vigorously pursued the issues of shipping freights, access to export markets and domestic consumption. By working alongside industry, it has emerged with a full understanding of the horticultural environment and its demands.

The Australian Horticultural Corporation already has a number of achievements and they include an increased commitment to domestic promotion in advertising, market research into new and potentially lucrative markets and the establishment of the various bodies to better coordinate and address issues before the industry. Jointly with other boards it has been involved in negotiations which led to considerable savings on shipping rates in the 1990 season. It has also undertaken an extensive review and simplification of export licensing arrangements.

One of the previous speakers mentioned some of the problems that are facing the industry. I think the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) expressed some reservations about the Australian Horticultural Corporation and its future. Perhaps he could look just at that last aspect-the simplification of the export licensing arrangements and where that could lead us-and take it on board.

This aspect of the Corporation having the power to license exporters through whom all exports go is to be commended. Too often we see a number of small producers attempting to export into the same market. As a result buyers play them off, one against another, to the detriment of the final income earned. Probably one of the successes of the Australian Wheat Board has been to remove that sort of anomaly.

Product boards that are being set up under the Australian Horticultural Corporation have the function and powers that largely mirror those of the Corporation itself and the boards thus far set up will go a long way to ensuring that those industries reach some stability and maximise returns to growers.

Like the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice), I do not have any dried fruit vines in my electorate. Sometimes I wish that I did, but nevertheless, the interest that I have in this legislation is the success of the Australian Horticultural Corporation, because some of the subtropical industries in my electorate- banana, macadamia and others-need a degree of assistance with marketing, both domestic and export.

I will certainly be doing my best to encourage those horticultural industries that I have just mentioned, including the avocado industry, to come under the umbrella of the Australian Horticultural Corporation by forming their own marketing board. The gains that they can make in terms of extending domestic markets, researching and establishing standards which encourage domestic production, and researching and funding overseas marketing arrangements, will certainly ensure that surplus production can find a niche market and not be dumped onto the market, thereby depressing prices.

I feel there is an endless potential in the Northern Hemisphere for producers of subtropical fruits, such as we have here in Australia and especially in the area of the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice) and my own seat of Richmond, where there is a tremendous climate in which to produce a large range of subtropical fruits. We certainly could exploit the market during the off-season in the Northern Hemisphere. Consequently, there is no need to have the large surplus production depressing the prices, as I have just mentioned.

I would like to see, through the Australian Horticultural Corporation, these product boards researching a little more to find particular niche markets in that area. To simply produce a surplus here and then to put it onto a market when it is here leads to unreliability of supply and certainly a bad reputation. It is something we have done in the past, and something we have to address in the future if we are going to lift our game, so to speak.

What we do need to do, and I am sure this will occur under the Australian Horticultural Corporation and the boards that are being set up, is find niche markets, especially within the Pacific Rim, and take advantage of the fact that there are few other Southern Hemisphere companies that produce the subtropical fruits and vegetables that we produce here. Our only other competitors of any real significance would be countries such as Chile, South Africa, New Zealand and perhaps Argentina, which have the same potential as we have. But we must address the fact that we are on the doorstep of the Pacific and the Asian markets and we must take advantage of them.

We must establish these marketing boards, and the Australian Horticultural Corporation recognises this. As I said, I will certainly be doing as much as I can to encourage industries in my region, and in any other region for that matter, to come under the umbrella of the Australian Horticultural Corporation, and to seek to establish not just one-off markets but products which are produced for particular markets, so that instead of just getting in there when we have a surplus, we can get in there and stay there, and become a recognised and reliable producer.

Much has already been said of the problems of overseas competition being allowed into Australia, but what we must do here-and it is happening under the Australian Horticultural Corporation-is increase quality standards, as mentioned by previous speakers from the other side of the House, as well as food safety. These are aspects which Australia can address. Certainly one aspect which we can address is quality. It has long been recognised throughout Asia and the Pacific Rim countries that Australia can provide quality and safe produce, which is what they demand-produce which is free from any pollutants or any chemicals which would see it being downgraded.

It is certainly clear that consumers around the world are becoming increasingly concerned about what is in their food. From research in the major Asian markets we know that Australia has an image of supplying fresh quality produce grown in an unpolluted environment. Monitoring of fresh produce in the home market has also shown that it is rated alongside the best in the world. The challenge is certainly there for the Horticultural Corporation, for producers and producers' boards to build on the wholesome and nutritious image of Australian fruit and vegetables.

A further aspect would be to show the consumer, through educational programs, that fruit and vegetables are even better value for money in times of financial restraint. As production expands-as our agricultural industries are quite capable of doing-we will become better and smarter marketers. That is one aspect of the Australian Horticultural Corporation's charter.

Australian grown produce is more likely to gain increased access to Pacific Rim countries as a result of the stronger image of quality and reliability, and it is hoped that the efforts of both industry and government alike will assist in the entry to markets currently closed to Australian product. If we take up this challenge, niche markets will also develop and have a significant impact on the total market mix.

A further aspect which is not directly related to this Bill but which has been mentioned by two previous speakers-and it is certainly related to the performance of Australian horticultural products on the domestic market-is the country of origin labelling which has been initiated by the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate). I commend his efforts in coordinating the difficult task that it is with the States and Territories to draft the legislation which will permit that function. Certainly the labelling of products with their country of origin will have a decided advantage for Australian producers. One thing that has been expressed to me is the frustration that people feel in not being able to determine accurately whether products are Australian made or have undergone some small degree of processing in Australia. Certainly the food regulation process is part way down the track. It is frustratingly slow, but it has to be done, and has to be done well. We will all be very pleased when that finally comes to fruition. I certainly call upon the State health Ministers who are involved in this part of the process to try to speed up the process over the packaging of food so the labelling of the country of origin can become a reality.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are mainly Labor members, so you should be able to speed them up.
—The difficulty is New South Wales.
—Could I suggest that we have one debate at a time?

—The difficulty is, as the Minister has interjected, that New South Wales has tended to drag its feet there. I would ask the New South Wales Government to speed up the process of negotiation as there are a number of industries within the State that are suffering because that State is dragging its feet on this particular aspect.

SPEECH.PARA: The other aspect of this is that unpackaged food-not just packaged food but unpackaged food also-has been imported, and certainly we need some legislation in place quickly so that food which is imported will carry a label of some sort so that buyers, when they go to purchase, can be assured that what they are buying is Australian grown and that they are in fact supporting Australian farmers and not, as has been mentioned before, the cheats in the international trade of produce.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I would like to finish on that note. I support the legislation. Certainly the issue of the dried vine fruits board is one which, as part of the Australian Horticultural Corporation, will go towards supporting that industry. Honourable members have mentioned how significant the dried fruits industry is. It is a large horticultural industry in Australia; it exports a large proportion of its production-some two-thirds of its production-and consequently it does play an important role in our balance of trade. With the advice and the guidance of the Australian Horticultural Corporation, other fruits and other vegetables can also play a similar role.

One of the previous speakers mentioned the cost of production but did not quite mention the nature of the industries. Most of these industries are based on family farms involving family labour, and with the impetus of the Australian Horticultural Corporation, it is one way of ensuring that the family farm remains to the forefront of sustainable agricultural production. That is just one more reason why I support this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fisher Mr P.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —For 100 years the dried fruit industry has been a very successful part of the region I represent in the Sunraysia. It is the area where virtually all Australian dried fruit is now grown-90 per cent in the electorate of Mallee and approximately 10 per cent across the border in New South Wales in the electorate of my Leader, the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer). It makes an enormous contribution to the local economy, and it is extremely important for the whole aspect of regional development. Dried fruit is the single largest horticultural crop in Australia, producing $160m worth of produce annually on average, with about a $500m flow-on effect throughout the local community.

SPEECH.PARA: In many ways the Australian dried fruit industry is a miracle industry in terms of the Australian economy. Dried fruit is a high cost horticultural crop. It is highly intensive. Generally, it is competing against low cost, low labour countries. Yet, it has managed to survive and remain extremely viable over this long period. In fact, just at this moment I guess there are thousands of people out in the fields picking under the lights or in heat that is probably very close to 40 degrees celsius-not like it is for those of us here, in an air-conditioned chamber.

I think it should be asked why this industry, with all its impediments, has been so successful. Basically, there are three major reasons which make the industry an example to every other horticultural crop growing industry, in fact every other industry, in this country. First, the industry has an obsession with high quality product. Second, for years the industry has had a very disciplined marketing scheme. Third, I think it has also had a very effective level of industry leadership.

I am sad to say that this legislation, despite a lot of the patronising rhetoric we have heard tonight, challenges both the history of enterprise and the stability that has existed in this industry for so long because of the very radical changes that it proposes. As has been pointed out, the proposed changes are a result of an Industry Commission report. I have no difficulties with the IC's reporting and recommendations on industry assistance. However, I have a problem with two aspects. First of all, the Government seems always to act upon recommendations to reduce the level of protection and tariff assistance to agricultural industries, but it is very reluctant, in fact it seldom takes action, on IC reports when those reports relate to manufacturing industry in this country.

The IC does have a role, but as my colleague and Deputy Leader, the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), said, it is time the IC changed its methodology and gave away some of the subjective guessing that it undertakes. In fact, there is a joke going around my electorate that the best way to get a downturn in the dried fruit or citrus industries if they are performing well is to have an IC report and the best way to get an upturn, if the industries are performing poorly, is to have an IC report.

TALK.START.PARA: —It happens time and time again.

—As the honourable member for Wakefield said, we can produce IC reports on, for example, the dried fruit industry in times of a downturn which would recommend that people restructure into the citrus industry. Four or five years later, the cycle turns, and the IC recommends that people in the citrus industry restructure into the dried fruit industry. In fact, it is such a joke that four or five years ago in the main street of Mildura the second last IC report on the dried fruit industry was formally buried.

SPEECH.PARA: I will now refer very briefly to a couple of comments made by the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice), particularly as they relate to Senator Boswell. We know that our senator wears his heart on his sleeve, but one thing he does do is work his guts out to protect the well-being of the people he represents.

If it were not for Senator Boswell and if it were not for the fact that so many people came up to this Parliament last year from the horticultural regions of Australia to protest on the streets of Canberra, we would not have had changes to the labelling laws. Make no mistake about it, that was the initiative that started that process off. If it were not for Senator Boswell we would not have the anti-dumping inquiry presently being undertaken by a Senate committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —A major breakthrough.
—A major breakthrough. Let us be honest about these things. Let us not condemn people for their activities on behalf of the people they represent.

SPEECH.PARA: These Bills will restructure and significantly change the administration, operation and marketing functions of the Australian dried fruit industry. They propose to make three basic changes. Firstly, the Australian Dried Fruits Corporation will be renamed the Australian Dried Fruits Board. It will become part of the Australian Horticultural Corporation (AHC). Secondly, the domestic component of the sultana equalisation scheme is to be removed, effectively deregulating the domestic market. Thirdly, underwriting will continue for three years to minimise the impact that even the Government acknowledges these changes will make as the industry adjusts to the deregulation of the domestic market.

I support this legislation, against my better judgment and my experience of the impact of similar legislation, particularly in the wheat industry. The dried fruit industry has worked very hard and has cooperated with the Government. However, in order to maintain its most significant marketing power-its export power-the industry has been forced to accept two measures that are not in its best interests.

I wish to go through very briefly the sultana underwriting scheme and the sultana equalisation scheme. The sultana underwriting scheme was introduced in 1982 when the world was oversupplied with sultanas and prices were disastrously low. In that year the scheme paid out $1.3m, or $16 a tonne, to dried fruit growers. That scheme has not been triggered since. In 1986 the scheme was again changed to reduce the level at which the Government would underwrite. The level was set at 80 per cent of the free on board export return for the past three years, and a sunset clause was inserted so that the scheme finished at the end of December 1990. As I said, this legislation will continue the underwriting for another three years to help the industry adjust to the new arrangements. The House should be aware that this scheme, while providing a notional level of security, in practice at 80 per cent, will provide no benefits at all to the industry as it did in 1982.

Of course, legislation was introduced many years ago to equalise the domestic and export markets in the dried fruit industry. It was done with the single purpose of ensuring that farmers would be paid the same price for the same product; in other words, a policy of equity and stability. Legislation introduced by this Government in 1986 set a cap on those equalisation payments that could be made over and above the average export return. Payments are now limited to 15 per cent above those export returns.

Because the domestic price of this product in most years was above the export price, the Government and the Industries Assistance Commission believe that this was a consumer transfer, even though the Australian dried fruit industry is not itself involved in the sale of its product on the domestic market. However, it should be pointed out that because of this perceived transfer the Government is removing the domestic component from equalisation, but will continue it on exports. This means that equalisation will be a reconciliation of export returns at the end of each season. There will be no levies and no Government financial involvement.

To this industry's credit, to counter this move and because of this industry's forward thinking, it is in fact putting in place a voluntary equalisation scheme. Although it is a voluntary scheme it will be legally binding and will use a system of contractual arrangements between the industry, the growers, their packers and processors. The industry should be commended for this.

The industry has the right to object to losing this equalisation of the domestic market. It already competes on its own market with heavily subsidised fruit from Greece and cheap and poor quality fruit from Turkey, which has been discussed already tonight. The dried fruit industry does this only with the aid of a low and decreasing tariff of developing country status.

I turn now to the worst feature of this legislation-the industry becoming part of the Australian Horticultural Corporation. As has been pointed out, the Bill provides for the establishment of an Australian Dried Fruits Board to be structured within the Australian Horticultural Corporation. It will be done by changes to the structure of the AHC to provide for product boards. This is necessary because the Government will concede that the dried fruit industry needs more autonomy than that which the other industries connected with the AHC presently enjoy. This is in recognition of the excellent export marketing operations of the current Australian Dried Fruits Corporation.

It should be noted that to date, the AHC has done nothing of note in the way of marketing for the industries which are currently participating under its control-the apple, pear, citrus and nursery industries. I know and I respect the people within the AHC. I believe that the new chairman will bring a new professionalism to this AHC that was lacking in the previous structure. However, why place a specialised industry such as the Australian dried fruit industry, an industry that has been successful and which has probably one of the most outstanding marketing records of any horticultural industry in Australia, within a bureaucratic structure and charge the industry $60,000 a year, with very dubious results- and recognising that, of course, as the years go by the cost will be doubled? I find this a most extraordinary thing to do in regard to an industry such as this.

The second part of the Bill sets out how the product laws will operate. The Dried Fruits Board will be the only product board but the framework means that other industries can, in the future, be accommodated. The product board will be a body corporate that will assist in longstanding arrangements the dried fruit industry already has with a number of overseas agencies and groups. The Government says that the Board will not interfere with the active private industry marketing program which the dried fruit industry runs in Australia because it will operate only on export markets.

The product board will have an independent chairperson, selected by the AHC in consultation with the relevant producer organisation, and five other members selected by the relevant industry body. Three of the five must have expertise in the industry, while the other two can be drawn from general areas. While the industry does not like being forced into the AHC, it recognises that in order to hold its export control it must agree to this legislation, and it is reasonably happy with the final structure of the board and the degree of autonomy it has been given.

I conclude with some general comments. Today in this House we listened to the Treasurer (Mr Keating) telling us how successful the long term nature of his high interest rate policies will prove to be in encouraging value added industries. This industry we are speaking about tonight already fulfils that role and function, as does the citrus industry. The Treasurer has lambasted us and has obviously convinced the media that the National Party policies of the 1950s and 1960s were bad for primary industry. I am tired of this misrepresentation. In my electorate of Mallee the 1950s and 1960s were a time of great consolidation, with the development of strong communities and towns and of profitability.

We had value added industries in those times. In fact, in Victoria we had 49 flour mills throughout the State and small and flourishing abattoirs in almost every town. Where have they gone? They have been gradually destroyed by the activities of unions and the Australian Council of Trade Unions, outmoded work practices, high domestic costs and high government charges.

This week some honourable members may have watched the Four Corners program focusing on the rural recession. This program was filmed in my electorate of Mallee. It showed not the brilliance of this Treasurer's stewardship but a string of bankruptcies and human disasters that will never be repaired. We are now told by economists working in a regulated wage system-I emphasise that-that the answer is off-farm work for the women. The economists say, `What a wonderful social reform, making them full time partners in the family economy'. This is a symptom of economic desperation and, for most, a time of great unhappiness. Pure economic theory counts not the value of the woman's contribution to the farm, to family life or to the farm's economy. Government policies are replacing the fundamental value of household life and the community. They have replaced farm people with chemicals and machines and imposed awful pressures on the land itself.

The ability to safeguard Australian industries from injury through the legitimate use of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade has been undermined by changes this Government has made to anti-dumping legislation. Unfair trading practices acknowledged by other nations are now acceptable in Australia. I really do not understand why this Government penalises Australia's primary industries to this level. We have become the laughing stock of the world; we have become the dumping ground for other nations' highly subsidised and, in many cases, low cost products. There can be no doubt that some day Australia will be posthumously awarded a medal for the self-sacrifice of its industries in the interests of minor pain relief for the great trading nations of the world. The surviving country people will be seen trapping a few rabbits, and I am sure they will feel patriotic and proud.

I pray that this legislation does not do to this industry what the wheat legislation has done to the wheat industry. In one year the Government's wheat legislation has reduced the domestic cost price of wheat to growers on its own market by 39 per cent. I am fearful that the same pressures of world export trade on our dried fruits industry will do the same thing. It is alleged that last week nine semitrailer loads of Brazilian orange juice flowed into the converters and processors of citrus juice in this country. It is an absolute disgrace.

I believe governments have to be much stronger in relation to quality, labelling and anti-dumping. More importantly, they also have to remove some of the taxation burdens from these industries. I give but one example and it relates to the grape industry. A bottle of brandy in a shop would today cost about $16.60. Of that $16.60, the growers, producers and retailers receive $4.60; the other $12 is government tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —A scandal.

—It is a scandal, and we have seen a government destroy the Australian brandy industry not just through taxation but through the six-monthly indexation of that taxation. I conclude by saying that Australia's agricultural industries, of which the Australian dried fruits industry is a very important part, have over the years funded our standard of living; but they can take no more. I believe the party is over.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to address the Australian Horticultural Corporation Amendment Bill 1990. The purpose of the Bill before the House is effectively to amend the Australian Horticultural Corporation (AHC) so that it can accommodate the dried fruits industry. Effectively, what has been the ADFA, the Australian Dried Fruits Association, will lose its control of the dried fruits industry and the ADFS, Australian Dried Fruits Sales, which has been the marketer for the ADFA, under this legislation now loses control of the domestic market for Australian dried fruits. As the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Peter Fisher) has said, the dried fruits industry is somewhat reluctant to accept this move, but it has agreed to it because, under the Government's legislation, the Australian dried fruits industry in fact retains control over the export part of the industry and it retains a level of autonomy-not the amount of autonomy it would like but a level of autonomy that it earlier feared it might lose.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Horticultural Corporation has indicated to the Australian Dried Fruits Association that the Corporation will assist in market development. If we are to look at the second reading speech of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin), it would seem that this legislation is the first step in the establishment of the proposed product boards that the Minister wants as part of the AHC. As I have said in my contribution and as the honourable member for Mallee said very eloquently indeed, the industry is reluctant to make this move. This is partly because the move will cost the Australian dried fruits industry $60,000 per annum for the next three years and could cost it even more beyond that date, depending on the success of the move and whether the Government agrees to further subsidise funding for the AHC.

On 26 occasions in the past, the Australian dried fruits industry has used its domestic sales to assist with its export sales. These equalised payments, which have facilitated export sales, will now be lost. However, the sultana underwriting scheme, which has guaranteed some sort of stability to sultana producers around Australia, will continue. This underwriting scheme has been triggered only once since its inception, and that was in 1982 when the triggering of the underwriting scheme provided $16 per tonne for the producers of dried sultanas.

I can tell the House that $16 is not much on a tonne of sultanas because it takes an awful lot of tiny golden balls that were once large sultanas to produce a tonne. However, the mechanism was triggered and produced $16 per tonne and effectively cost $1.3m in 1982. The Industry Commission has calculated that it will take a 30 per cent slump in profitability for sultana producers for this mechanism to be triggered again, so it sees no reason for the underwriting scheme to continue.

I point out to the House that, while the underwriting scheme has given stability to the industry through difficult times and while a 30 per cent slump is seen as unlikely from the point of view of the Industry Commission, from my own experience in the industry-and I am sure the honourable member for Mallee would echo these sentiments-it is not beyond the realms of possibility for the income of dried fruits growers to slump by at least 30 per cent.

The other point that needs to be borne in mind when we look at the Australian dried fruits industry, particularly the sultana segment of that industry, is that it enjoys relatively little protection. As the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) said, its protection level will be only 15 per cent in 1992 or 10 per cent where there is a developing country preference.

I am not one to stand here advocating additional protection for either this or any other industry, but I do think that the House in considering this legislation has to bear in mind what a remarkable industry the Australian dried fruits industry has been and is. The honourable member for Mallee has made the point, and I can only restate it, that for almost 2,000 years the dried fruits industry around the world scarcely changed. The technique was developed by the early Egyptians of taking fruit, cutting it, finding an appropriate climate in which it would be reasonably preserved-or some other way of preserving it-leaving it in the sun until it was dried down and then discovering that they had a product that they could carry around with them for 12 months and still use as a food. This invaluable resource for the early Egyptians has, in its production technique, scarcely changed over 2,000 years.

Even at this time of the year in Sunraysia or Riverland, people will be found simply placing fruit in the sun in order to dry it and producing a product called `naturals', which is a dried fruit product, without any chemical exposure at all.
