The task is simply to take the product, keep the dew and rain off it, expose it to the sun, trust that the weather is kind enough to allow it to dry down without any fungal development and then market it as a product known as `naturals', which effectively lasts the year round.

The most remarkable thing about this industry is that in 1991 we have legislation dealing with an industry that is labour intensive and yet has survived in Australia. As an interesting aside, I point out to the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Crean) and the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories (Mr Simmons), who are at the table, that in 1991 when we are facing high levels of unemployment, when unemployment is clearly a major problem around Australia, in those areas of my electorate responsible for dried fruit production, there has been relatively little inflow of outside labour to harvest fruit. Because, remarkably, unemployment levels in the country are so high, much of the fruit is being picked without the Commonwealth Employment Service having to send labour in.

Given that that is the case, the two Ministers at the table might care to consider what will happen in country Australia, particularly in the electorates of Mallee, Farrer, Wakefield, Riverina-Darling and Barker, when the fruit season ceases and these people currently employed are then unemployed. We will then see unemployment levels of unprecedented proportions-thanks, I am sorry to say, to the policies of the Government.

In spite of the high labour content of the Australian dried fruits industry, it has continued to be a success. I think relatively few people are familiar with what was once the labour intensive technique of taking a bunch of grapes; placing it in a bucket that is perforated; dipping that bucket in a dip made up principally of caustic soda, potash and oils which then clung to the grape and allowed the skin of the grape to be broken down; placing that then damp bunch of grapes onto a rack of horizontal wire netting; leaving it for two or three weeks until it broke down into the product with which honourable members are familiar; shaking it manually off that rack onto hessians under the rack; pulling the hessians out from underneath; running them out in the sun; exposing that dried fruit in the sun during the day and closing the hessians at night to protect it from the dew; opening out and raking it out during the day-this process being repeated for a week or a fortnight, depending on the weather at the time-and then producing dried fruit, particularly sultanas, as we know them today.

If that were not labour intensive enough, let me remind the House that those who are producing raisins from gordo grapes, and not sultanas from sultana grapes, dip those gordo grapes in boiling caustic, oils and potash. If one considers the reality of being in 40-degree heat and keeping a dip of 200 gallons of boiling caustic on the boil all day, one can get an impression of how far removed from the comfort of Parliament House these people, even of my generation, I have to say as one who has done it, really were.

Today, the most remarkable changes in drying fruit have occurred. While there are still people today who go ahead with the task of picking grapes, dipping them and placing them on racks, they are normally picked, placed on racks and sprayed. But as a result of the work of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation the dried fruits industry has seen a dramatic change. Techniques are now being developed and used in, particularly, the Mildura area in the electorate of the honourable member for Mallee at this time where growers, instead of going through the labour intensive process I have just outlined, cut the canes on the grapes, spray the grapevine, still with the bunches on it, with recently cut canes-a cold spray that includes caustic, potash and oils; all relatively harmless chemicals-allow the grapes, the canes having been cut, to hang and dry on the vine and then harvest them off the canes with precisely the same machinery as is used to harvest wine grapes. So a real change has occurred in the dried fruits industry and some of the labour in the industry looks like disappearing as a result of the capacity now to harvest dried fruit on the vine.

Whatever technique is used, whether the grapes are dried on the vine or on the rack, the remarkable thing is that what is produced in Australia is a grape in the raisin, sultana and currant area that is unrivalled around the world for quality. Our capacity, in spite of our high labour cost, to sell in export markets reflects the quality of Australian produce. I do not want in any way to sensationalise the debate, but I often have in my pocket, and therefore I have in the chamber now, some of those sultana grapes produced in my electorate and in the electorate of the honourable member for Mallee.

TALK.START.PARA: —Table them.

—As much as I would like to respond to the interjection and table them, I fear that they would not get past the Clerks or Madam Deputy Speaker or, dare I say it, even Hansard, given their irresistible quality.

SPEECH.PARA: I keep these sultana grapes in my office. As those honourable members on this side of the House know, one can always come and sample dried sultana grapes in my office, because they are a product without equal. No-one else in the world can produce sultana grapes as cleanly as can Australian producers. The great problem that the Spaniards and the Greeks face, and a difficulty that even the Californians have more acutely than ourselves, is the intrusion of dust into their dried fruit product. Because of the way in which Australian producers are so particular about drying greens and maintaining a good environment for drying grapes, and because they have properties that allow them with irrigation to keep some sort of ground cover, Australia as a sultana, currant, raisin, dried apricot, peach and pear producer is unrivalled in the rest of the world.

I make a comment or two about the complexity of the industry. One may well say that if the industry is as good as those speakers this evening have indicated, everyone in a Mediterranean climate where it is dry and irrigation is available should be growing dried fruit. This has been a very difficult product to market, for just one reason: sultanas and gordo grapes-or, in the dried form, sultanas and raisins-are not only used in the dried fruit industry but also in the wine grape industry. Given the complications I have painted of being a dried fruit grower and facing all the labour intensive drying techniques that are part of the dried fruit industry, there is a real temptation for growers not to supply the dried fruit industry but to supply the wine grape industry.

Those who market Australia's dried fruit, particularly Australia's sultanas and raisins, face this constant fluctuation of supply-not dictated solely by frosts, droughts or hail, but by the fact that growers will determine to take their product wherever the short term demand is. If there is a short term demand in the wine grape industry, as there certainly was when cask sales were popular, suddenly we will find a scarcity of supply in the dried fruit industry, and export markets that have been cultivated and developed by that industry will be unable to be supplied.

I digress for a moment. This does not only apply to dried grapes. It also applies to dried apricots, peaches and pears, because there is a demand in the apricot, peach and pear industry for product for juice. If there is a demand for apricot juice, pear juice or peach juice, suddenly we will find product moving from the labour intensive and difficult dried industry into the less labour intensive processed industry. There is a constant move. Those who market our dried fruit face a constant challenge not only from the vagaries of nature but also from the unpredictability of the people who produce the fruit.

I want to make a comment or two about the environmental sensitivity of the dried fruit product and then about its market- ability. Australians, increasingly bothered about what they consume and about the impact of their lifestyle and their consumption on the environment, ought to recognise that dried fruit provides a great opportunity to consume something that is pollution free and environmentally sensitive. It is no idle boast to call this sun dried, because sun dried it is. We did not have to fire up oil furnaces to produce this dried product; the sun was used. This is a solar product; it has not been dipped in poisons or pesticides. It may have had the odd fungicide, but that would have been sulphur or copper based and therefore what I might loosely call a basic chemical and not a toxic chemical. But, apart from its exposure to the odd fungicide, it will have been well washed by the packaging and processing houses. It is sun dried and therefore environmentally sensitive. It is in itself non-toxic and, furthermore, is relatively non-perishable and, because the water has been taken out of it, provides a very concentrated form of energy that is easily transported around the world.

As I said earlier in my speech, there have been real changes in the way in which this labour intensive industry goes about producing its product, minimising its labour cost. What is needed for this product is not now on-farm efficiency, but off-farm efficiency. Changes in the transport area and changes to the waterfront are desperately needed by Australia's dried fruit producers. I do not find the dried fruit producers of my electorate demanding protection; they simply want to work in an environment where, if they are to be deregulated, so also should the wage market be deregulated. They do not expect people to work for them for Asian wages, but they say they want eight hours work for eight hours pay. That is not an unreasonable demand. But they have an even more acute need: they are saying that when the product leaves them and goes into the packing house or leaves the packing house and heads to the wharf they want to see that the people who are being paid to handle it are handling it in an efficient way.

I think I ought to restate a couple of points were made by previous speakers. The industry is entitled to rapid track anti-dumping legislation. This Government owes the industry at least some form of rapid track anti-dumping legislation-just as this Opposition has committed itself, through the honourable member for Murray and the honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan), to producing such legislation.

In my concluding remarks, I must take issue with the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice). He made a perfectly reasonable contribution to the debate until, at the end of his expose this evening, he could not resist getting stuck into the Opposition in a quite unsubstantiated way. He said that the goods and services tax, if you please, would be a major burden to Australia's horticultural producers. He wanted us to apologise for the very tax designed to assist exporters! I would remind him that this tax is designed to make exports more saleable and exporters more profitable. That is the Opposition's motive in entertaining it.

Furthermore, the honourable member for Hinkler went on and applauded the actions of the Queensland Government in proposing additional controls over chemicals. I do not know any horticulturalists or primary producers who are casual users of chemicals, because they have to pay for them and they have to expose themselves to those chemicals. So horticulturalists are among the most particular people about the way in which chemicals are applied.

As if that were not enough, the honourable member for Hinkler went on to say that a major problem faced in developing a horticultural export market is Queensland fruit fly. How, I ask, does he propose to control fruit fly in the chemical free utopia he was painting for the House tonight?

Horticulture is an industry with great export potential, but its capacity to realise that potential will depend entirely on the cost of production beyond the farm gate being addressed, and we have seen little of that from the Government of the day.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN BROADCASTING TRIBUNAL REPORT ON TV VIOLENCE IN AUSTRALIA

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Filing Mr P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In my 5 1/2 minutes to conclude my contribution to this particular debate, I repeat how I started out. That was to try to approach this issue from the viewpoint of a parent of young children who obviously are very impressionable on the question of television violence, from the viewpoint of a former policeman who has seen the effects of television violence on young people, or perhaps, as I mentioned earlier, as a member of the baby boom generation, the generation which has been exposed at some great length to the effects of television over the years since it was introduced into Australia in 1956.

SPEECH.PARA: I mention this purely and simply as a means of reducing some of the tension present in the House at the moment. I would like to look at an extract from an article in the Canberra Times which probably summarises the experiences of a lot of parents around the country on a Saturday morning. Certainly, it would be very familiar to many constituents in my electorate. It reads:
Weekends are different.

I am still amazed by the fact that children who have to be dragged, protesting out of a warm bed at 8am on school days have an inbuilt alarm which triggers off a jack-in-the-box effect around 6am on Saturdays and Sundays. Having soaked up all the early cartoons they are bored and ready for action around 8.30am just as we are turning over for a cuddle.

I mention that quotation because, as I said, it has a ring of familiarity for many people around the country. It is necessary to consider the effects of some of these cartoons on the impressionable minds of young people.

I now refer to an extract from the report entitled TV Violence in Australia Volume I: Decisions and Reasons which looks at the function of the `G' classification and at some of the cartoons that appear on Saturday mornings in front of impressionable young children. The report says:
. . . Ms Boekenstein of the FCB noted that the `new breed' of cartoon, such as TRANSFORMERS and GI JOE, contained violence which:

. . . throw away the rule book on kids' cartoon violence, (and) are causing us constant grief. The very last episode of GI JOE we saw, we actually put a PG on . . . We decided that the ongoing violence . . . was sufficient to warrant PG, which is a bit of a watershed for us in terms of that style of cartoon.
In other submissions it was noted that Channel 10 had withdrawn Transformers, The New Three Stooges, and Hulk Hogan's Rock 'n' Roll Wrestling from its program line-up.

Another important issue to my constituents about which I spoke earlier today is the question of rising unemployment in my own electorate, particularly amongst young people between the ages of 15 and 19. I think it is important that we consider the ramifications of this particular report in the context that in my electorate, at least, a far greater number of young people are going to be spending a lot more time sitting around watching television thanks to this Government's horrendous economic policies which have forced them onto the unemployment scrap heap. I pointed out to the House earlier today that in my area, the northern suburbs of Perth-which I would say is fairly typical of suburban metropolitan Australia-has seen a youth unemployment rate rise from 2,000 in December 1989 to 3,500 in 1990.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. I question the relevance of these statistics to a debate on a report on television violence.

—I wish to speak to that point of order. I have been present throughout this debate and it has been wideranging. The report under discussion at present concerns acts of violence in the community that are replayed on television in news reports. Consequently the honourable member for Moore is well within the terms of this debate to range widely over this whole aspect of crime and violence.

—I raise a further point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. I think that even from the vastness of the Speaker's chair, you would not be immune to the knowledge that the Australian population watches quite extraordinary amounts of television. During these trying times it is more likely than not that that will be exacerbated. Given the subjective nature of many of the judgments which have to be made in this difficult area, to attempt to restrict debate in the way that the honourable member opposite has is quite wrong. I would respectfully suggest that the point of order should be ruled out of order.

—If the honourable member for Gippsland and the honourable member for Pearce had waited for me to respond to the point of order by the honourable member for Chifley, they may have been able to save the House time and perhaps the honourable member for Moore would have had more time to speak because I do believe that the points that he was making were relevant to the debate and I was going to rule that way. However, the honourable member's time has now expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price Mr L.R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I see that contributions to this debate this evening are required to be wide-ranging and I am more than happy to comply with that. This matter is very important. I would like to start off by talking about violence in a much broader context. The Government's response to the serial killing in Melbourne and the community reaction to that launched a wide-ranging committee of inquiry called the National Committee on Violence. The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal already had its reference as far as the media was concerned. I really think that the Committee is an important starting point. It did an excellent job. It put out a number of publications, all of which were very good. One which really impressed me was on domestic violence.

SPEECH.PARA: I should also say that this National Committee on Violence introduced me to the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child. This occurred many months before I was inundated by many constituents' letters. The report on domestic violence was very good. (Quo-rum formed) I think it should be pointed out that the honourable member for Moore (Mr Filing) called for a quorum when I was talking about domestic violence. He has so little concern for domestic violence that he wants to pull the little stunt of calling a quorum. I hope he can stand up to the women of his electorate and say, `I think so little of domestic violence that I called a quorum.' In fact, it was the honourable member's profession-the police-that was singled out in the document on domestic violence as being singularly unsympathetic and uninformed about the needs of victims. Shame on the honourable member and shame on him for calling a quorum. I hope his electorate condemns him.
The honourable member wants to talk about the poor in his electorate. Why does he not read the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal's report TV Violence in Australia, which had this to say:

Poverty is one of the most important causes of violence and notes that most violent offenders and victims of violence are drawn from the disadvantaged strata of Australian society. The image which many people who earn low incomes have of themselves is one of worthlessness, expendability or, at best, irrelevance.
That is something that the honourable member reinforces daily in this House. The report went on to say:

This self image is reinforced if the person of economic disadvantage belongs to a minority group. Respectable paths to status or prestige are seen as barred or are often expressed in self-destructive or outwardly aggressive behaviour.
It went on to say:
The Committee considers that governments and oppositions should avoid the kind of political point scoring which labels poor people as worthless bludgers.
And who was doing that in this Parliament? The report continued:

The Committee considers it is a responsibility of the Federal Government to continue to provide adequate income support for the most disadvantaged members of society. Evidence for the importance of adequate income support comes from countries which lack income support programs, and where the level of violence is much higher.

I say to the honourable member for Moore that the real tragedy that we have had meted out this week is that Opposition members propose economic measures that are ideas from America. America has a much more violent record than we have in Australia.

The report of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal is a very good one, but I think it is really flawed in one respect. It calls for voluntary enforcement of codes, which I support. But it also calls on the parents of Australia to exercise responsibility in relation to the television material that their children see. Quite frankly, we need to encourage all parents to fully exercise that responsibility.

The other point that I would make is this: it is up to television viewers, if they are dissatisfied with this voluntary approach to these standards that have been adopted by commercial stations, to protest, and they will be heard. If they wish to know how to protest, they should in the first instance ring the television channel and voice their concern. If they wish more vigorously to follow up their complaint, they should write to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. If that is something they do not wish to do, they could write to their member of parliament. Certainly in the electorate of Chifley I would be encouraging them to write to me, because I can assure them that each and every complaint I receive I would be more than willing to pass on to the television station and to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal.

This is not just something for the eastern suburbs or the north shore in Sydney. It is a responsibility that we have right throughout New South Wales and right throughout Australia. I wish to repeat that the success of this voluntary code will depend on parents and television viewers accepting their responsibilities in relation to their own children, and also passionately believing that they have a right to be heard and that their standards are important. If television stations are not capable of exercising this voluntary restraint, or if they are producing material which offends the viewer, then the viewers should, and must, in our democracy make sure that their voices are heard.

Sometimes members of parliament are accused of getting carried away with certain issues. Does violence on television have an impact on children or adults? The weight of evidence is fairly consistent: that preferring violent television viewing leads to aggressive behaviour and aggressive values.

For example, there was a study undertaken in the United States that monitored soap operas, and in particular suicides within those soap operas. The researcher found, by going through the record, that every time there was a suicide in one of those shows the number of women suiciding went up quite dramatically. Why should it be women? I presume it may have something to do with the hours during which the programs were shown.

I believe this ought to be a matter of concern to us in this Parliament, and more especially of concern to us out in the community. We can cite an Australian example where there was a film shown, I think it was called Doomsday Flight, which portrayed a ransom being extracted from an airline. Of course, it was not too long after the screening of that film that Qantas paid out $500,000 in what appeared to be very much a mirror image of that film.

I would say that there is much more evidence than I have quoted here tonight to suggest that violence on television has an impact on children, who I am most particularly concerned about, naturally, and also on adults. I wish to reiterate that we cannot be passive about this. As a community, as fathers and mothers, as ordinary mums and dads, we have the right to determine what those standards are and whether the voluntary standards in fact are infringing.

Intrusive behaviour can also be very offensive. There are shows which are well known for intruding into people's privacy. This is outlawed also-where the interviewer extracts the last tear from the subject being interviewed. I have to say frankly that I find those types of interviews most offensive. In my own electorate I well recall a current affairs program interviewing one of my constituents, who was not able to cope with the aggressive tactics of the interviewer. That might not have been too bad, but the consequences were that it created quite some difficulty within his local community. He was not really well equipped to deal with that, and had to go around and apologise. So the television stations have responsibility.

I do not wish to go into the precise nature of the codes, except to say that of course they cover news, drama and current affairs. The key point is that in our society so many people feel that they are powerless, that if things are meted out there is no way in which they can fight back, there is no way in which they can make their voices heard.
I just wish to say to my own constituents in Chifley-who are very proud people by the way, and very good parents-that they do not have to cop it.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are proud of their member too, no doubt.

—I do not know about that, but I am privileged to serve them. I wish to say to them that if they have concerns about what is being shown, they should complain to the television station, they should complain to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, and if they do not wish to do those things, they should by all means write to me or ring my office. We are only too happy to take it up on their behalf, each and every one. One never knows, if they are objecting to particular footage of film or drama or whatever it is, they may be surprised to know that many other Australians are objecting as well. It is only by gleaning this information that the television stations and, more importantly, the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal can judge the success of this community standard.

SPEECH.PARA: I would also commend anyone interested in the subject to read the report on violence entitled Directions for Australia and the Government's response. I reiterate that all too often violence is a product of social disadvantage and something that I think all Australians would wish to avoid.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Webster Mr A.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was very concerned to see that the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price) was quite perturbed when the honourable member for Moore (Mr Filing) called a quorum during his speech. I point out that when the honourable member for Moore was making quite a telling point in his speech-a significant point which was important for people to hear-the honourable member for Chifley called a point of order which took up the last three or four minutes of the speech of the honourable member for Moore, thus preventing him from making those quite significant points. Therefore, whilst I agree with the honourable member for Chifley's comments tonight in regard to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal Report on TV Violence in Australia, I feel I had to make that little point.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not perhaps completely at one with him when he says that he totally agrees with the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal's recommendation that television stations should be voluntarily fulfilling the requirements of the Tribunal in regard to what they televise at certain times. The honourable member said that many people who complained about television violence would be surprised to know that there would be many other people complaining as well. This means that the voluntary system is very likely to break down and that we will need some pretty strong regulation of the programming of television channels when vulnerable audiences are watching.

As the honourable member for Chifley and other honourable members have pointed out, the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal's report is very interesting with regard to television violence in Australia. The honourable member for Chifley made a very strong point of the fact that most of the submissions to the Tribunal referred to the effects of television violence on children. Of course, as honourable members would know, that is a topic that has concerned me for many years. As a consequence I am very glad to have the opportunity to speak for a short period in this debate.

One of the major concerns of the Tribunal was the possibility of copycat or imitative behaviour. This is indeed the case. As I mentioned when making a point in the social security debate yesterday, prior to my coming into Parliament and following my career as a teacher I was involved in criminology and dealt with juveniles in varying age groups in New South Wales. It became patently obvious to me that the violence that was depicted on TV, in comics, in videos and so on certainly had a very dramatic effect on people's behaviour. Certainly, it had an effect on vulnerable people. Of course, such things do not affect all people but there are a substantial number of people in the community, particularly the young, who respond in dramatic ways to what they view on television. Very often they are young people who in other respects have all sorts of good influences on them. A wide debate can be undertaken with regard to that point.

I well remember one particular offender who had quite serious behavioural problems in the various institutions in which he was placed. On one occasion when he came into the area over which I had control, I made a deal with him in regard to his aggressive behaviour that if he did the right thing and toed the line and did the best he could I, as the chief superintendent, would actually take him home on discharge and meet his parents. That was our agreement. He fulfilled the agreement. When I took him home I went into the lounge room where the father told me over a cup of coffee that they were going to celebrate that night. He said, `I have all his favourite videos here'. I looked on the TV set and saw six or seven of the most violent movies that one could ever set one's eyes on. It soon became patently obvious to me why we were having a lot of trouble with that person.

We do not really have to think very hard to come to the conclusion that the viewing of violence on TV by young minds, very often of varying degrees of emotional maturity, has a harmful effect. We say that five-year-olds should not watch certain things. Some five-year-olds are quite resilient and maybe would not be affected. Other five-year-olds have not reached the necessary emotional maturity to enable them to watch varying kinds of violent behaviour on TV and not be affected very deeply by it. Therefore, we have to take into account a tremendous number of factors in regard to what we show on our television sets and how it can affect anybody's behaviour.

I make the point that it is far better to err on the side of overtightening the regulations rather than being too lax, because no-one has ever suffered as a result of having a fairly restrictive regulation of television content. Many years ago when we used to visit the cinema-perhaps the honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee) would not remember this because he is still quite youthful-we would not have had any concerns about what was screened or, in fact, what was shown on television because the programs were very strictly controlled. It was very rare for anything violent to come on to cause us or our parents any concern. However, we cannot argue that today.

We have seen a gradual sinking of our standards. The programs on TV in this day and age really need to be looked at very carefully, perhaps with a view to tightening the regulations a little more. This is bearing in mind, as I said before, that we will not suffer as a result of that extra regulation. I think that the nonsense people go on with about civil liberties being interfered with is just so much bunkum. People who take that view have rocks in their heads. We ought not to be swayed in the legislation and recommendations we make in this place by those people who are usually very vocal on these matters.

The honourable member for Chifley and other honourable members have mentioned the need for parental responsibility. Of course, in this day and age when so much violence is allowed on our TV sets, at times when the viewing should be Granted, even when the news is on, parental responsibility is an absolute must. Parents who do not monitor the programs that their children watch are really not being very responsible. I know it is not possible to scrutinise and watch every minute of television viewed by the child, but parents ought to be extremely mindful of the need to be aware of the kinds of things that their children have access to on television.

I remember, not so many years ago, that when quite violent scenes appeared on the news it was very distressing to my wife and me, and more often than not we had to turn off the news when our children were watching. That was not any special kind of supervision on our part; we believed it was normal for us as parents to do that. That is the kind of normality I would like to see other parents in this country adopt with regard to the things their children are watching on television.

This report is quite extensive in the areas it covers. A great number of submissions came in and many witnesses came forward to give assistance to the Tribunal. I notice that one submission came from the South Australian Council for Children's Films and Television. Mr Glenn Cupit, the affiliate vice-president of that organisation, carried out a study which found that a consistent theme appeared. He said:
If you expose children to a diet of violent material they will be more likely to resort to violence themselves, they become less concerned about injury done to other people.

Mr Cupit's survey showed that television violence involving humans stuck more in the minds of children. These are facts and, as I said before, we as legislators should be able to see from a purely commonsense point of view that we need to do something more constructive and more practical about the censorship this country currently has in place. If we do not see the dangers we are creating and leaving in place for the young people of today, for older people and for future generations, I say again that we have rocks in our heads.

We need to be aware of that. It is not something that we can argue away with obscure studies that minimise the effects of such things. The effects that violence has on young people are very serious, and I can talk from vast experience in that regard through my dealings with thousands of young offenders in New South Wales.

Finally, I mention that somebody who participated in the debate, although not in this House, said that he could excuse and justify violence and that he was opposed to the general tenor running through the debate in this House. He argued that there is much violence in the Bible, and he quoted that. There is a major difference between the violence in the Bible and the violence shown on television today. The violence in the Bible illustrates the conflict between good and evil, between righteousness and wickedness. Much of the violence shown on television today is between evil and greater evil-we have to admit that when we see the deterioration in the quality of films.

In the Bible there are godly heroes with whom the reader can identify. On today's television programs the heroes to whom young people and others relate are usually people with no respect for God. Viewers, including children, are usually forced to choose between people who have no respect for godly things and evil people, so they really do not have a great deal of choice. Quite frequently on some of these television programs the person who at first seems to be the best of the group turns out to be the worst of the bunch. Young people watching programs such as that can be quite devastated.
I conclude by quoting the last verse of a poem entitled The Bad Example. It says:
All in vain is splendid preaching,
And the noble things we say,
All our talk is wasted teaching,
If we do not lead the way.
We can never, by reviewing
All the sermons on the shelves,
Keep the younger hands from doing
What we often do ourselves.
I suggest that we take that on board.

TALK.START.PARA: — Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lee Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On several occasions the honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Webster) has reflected-always in a charitable manner-on the fact that I am a young person. I shall relay to him one comment told to me by a priest, Father Tom Isaac, when I was first elected to this House. It was a quote from St Paul with which I am sure the honourable member would be familiar. It was the very wise dictum: `Despise not your youth'. While I appreciate the honourable member reminding me on many occasions of my youth, I would be grateful if on every occasion I also had my contribution to the debate treated on its merits. I once again thank the honourable member for drawing my attention to my age.

SPEECH.PARA: The debate tonight on the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal report on TV Violence in Australia is a very important one for the community. The evidence of the level of community interest is demonstrated by the number of honourable members who have asked to speak in the debate tonight. It shows the level of concern not only in the community but also in this House that people wish to comment on the amount of violence on Australian television.

I suppose one of the television programs that has generated the greatest amount of comment concerning violence on television is the very famous children's cartoon called Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles. I know that a large number of parents have expressed concern that these cartoons depict characters who carry knives and all sorts of weapons. While it is certainly true that the characters, who are held up in an idealistic manner, use these weapons for the forces of good, it is also of great concern that it is often reported that children seek to imitate the behaviour of these Mutant Ninja Turtles.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some schools have had to ban them.

—The honourable member for Chifley reminds me that some schools have had to ban children from wearing Ninja Turtle outfits and, in some cases, carrying imitation weapons when mimicking the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtle program. Whilst I suppose any adult watching the program would see the humour in it, we have to think what impact that program and others will have on a child of an impressionable age, and that is what this debate is all about.

SPEECH.PARA: Several years ago-in fact before the former Minister for Transport and Communications, now the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Evans, asked the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal to carry out this investigation into television violence in Australia-I made one or two speeches in the House of Representatives expressing my concern about violence in the news coverage on Australian television. The program that triggered my concern was a report on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) of some of the violent deaths that had taken place in black townships in South Africa. This program sought to explain the fact that many of the Western news services censored out a lot of the worst violence that was on occasion filmed in South Africa. This ABC program went on to show the most horrific murder that I have ever seen on television. Whilst it is true that it was shown at about 9.00 at night, I am sure that a large number of young people would still have been watching at that time of the evening.

What worries me most about the news coverage rather than cartoons, films about the Mafia or some other violent fictional event is that people know that it is the real world, it is real life. It is of great concern if news reports show graphic violence early in the evening. I am sure that most young children watch some of the news services between six and 7.30 at night. I am sure that the commercial broadcasters, the ABC and the Special Broadcasting Service (SBS) realise that they have a great responsibility to make sure that they do not broadcast vision which can frighten and perhaps scare and make, for an extended period, a severe impression on young children.

I know that some honourable members in the House will remember a debate that took place in the television industry when one of the commercial television networks decided to show an American public official committing suicide with a pistol at a press conference. Although most of the networks did not broadcast vision, most of them broadcast the audio tape of the event taking place. One of the commercial networks actually broadcast the vision at about six o'clock at night. There was such an outrage from the community that I understand action was taken against the news director concerned for allowing that incident to go to air.

That is one example where a response from the public resulted in a broadcaster realising that a mistake had occurred. I am not aware of any similar horrific vision being shown that early at night since that time, and I hope that the voluntary code which now seems to have been accepted by the industry will ensure that that does not take place in years to come.

My main concern is what is broadcast in news programs. These days, news programs are often broadcast on the different networks later at night between 10 o'clock and 11 o'clock. It is fair for broadcasters to assume by that time of the evening that parents have put their younger and more impressionable children to bed. Some of the vision held back from the earlier news services should be able to be used later at night.

TALK.START.PARA: —Lateline.

—On a program like Lateline or The World Tonight with Clive Robertson or Steve Vizard's late night program. Channel 10 also has a news program at that time of the evening. Vision that cannot be shown earlier can be shown at that time of the evening. That is something which should be considered in a proper manner by the news directors concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: At the same time, our broadcasters do have a responsibility to show horrific events when they take place out there in the real world. There are occasions perhaps when we need to be shocked if terrible things are happening. For example, when the tanks rolled into Tiananmen Square it was right for the world to be told that terrible things were taking place in Tiananmen Square. It did not mean that broadcasters should show footage of human bodies being damaged physically or vision disturbing to individuals had to be shown early at night in news bulletins. But all of us who do live in the freer countries of the world did have a responsibility to learn what was happening in China.

TALK.START.PARA: —And be shocked by it.

—And be shocked, as the honourable member for Chifley said. We heard a debate in this House earlier about the events in the Baltic states. All of us are concerned about the future of the Baltic states. Several weeks ago violence was committed in one of the Baltic states when some of the defence forces of the Soviet Union got out of control. One television camera was able to record some of that footage. The fact that that footage got to the West and was broadcast around the world means that that violence is less likely to be repeated. If that violence had not been shown on television, because we had a policy that no violence could ever be shown on our news services, that would have been wrong. That is an example where it was important that we be shocked by seeing police beating people with night sticks and guns being fired at random. There is a second example where perhaps it is important that we know what is happening out there in the real world.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said, there needs to be a balance. I think we can allow broadcasters to decide what vision is acceptable early in the evening for the six and 7.30 bulletins. They have greater freedom for the late night bulletins, and it is up to them to use that freedom responsibly.

I also make a few comments about the level of violence in films broadcast on the commercial stations, the ABC and SBS. I know that the shadow Minister at the table, the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran), is a keen watcher of SBS television movies. I know that he is aware that SBS movies are not subject to the same censorship requirements that apply to the commercial networks. A film shown on the Channel 7 network perhaps would be required to be edited or censored because of violent or sexual scenes, but those same scenes could be broadcast without censorship or editing on SBS. That is a ridiculous situation.

I understand that when the great Australian film Bliss was shown on ABC television a number of complaints were received because some people objected to certain scenes being shown. If that film had been shown on a commercial network, the censors would have required some of the scenes in that entertaining film to have been deleted.

When the honourable member for Gippsland goes to the video store in Fyshwick or some other place to rent a video, as a responsible person-I think I can use that description about the honourable member for Gippsland-he is making an informed decision as to the video he wishes to see. Parents should pay greater attention to the sorts of videos that they hire or that their children can watch at home, but on the whole the classification system for videos can be made to work.

But television is different. Television programs are beamed into the television set via an antennae. There is not the same form of parental supervision of live to air television as there is with videos. Programs not broadcast live to air should be required to meet certain standards. The ABC and SBS should follow the same standards as the commercial networks. If the standards are good enough for the commercial networks, why do they not apply to the ABC?

I remind the House in the few minutes I have left of the research carried out by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal in its inquiry. We should not forget that that research showed that 60 per cent of the community felt that there was too much violence on television. So very strong concern was felt in the community about the level of violence on television. On the question of violence in news programs, over three-quarters of the adults sampled in one of the interviewing groups reported distaste for intrusive interviews with accident or tragedy victims. That goes to the point that the honourable member for Chifley was emphasising that news programs should not seek to hound victims of accidents or tragedies simply to get a story to air in order to boost their ratings. Any program that sought to use people in tragic circumstances like that deserves to be reprimanded strongly.

Finally, the same research from the discussion groups showed that, despite the belief of some viewers that the screening of real life violence was justified, six out of 10 adults thought that news showing explicit violent material should only be shown late in the evening. That goes to the heart of the point that I have sought to make tonight in this important debate. I know a large number of other members wish to make a contribution tonight, so I will restrict my comments to that and commend the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Beazley) for the statement he has made indicating that the voluntary standards now appear to have been adopted by the industry. I commend the report to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like others who have spoken previously, I am delighted to have the opportunity to address the House on the occasion of the tabling of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal report TV Violence in Australia. The background would be known to most honourable members. The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal (ABT) inquiry was established in August 1988 and it reported in January 1990. I have to express my regret that it is more than 12 months after the delivery of the report to the Minister for Transport and Communications that this House has a chance to address its content and its recommendations.

SPEECH.PARA: The ABT inquiry was established in the context of the National Committee on Violence report entitled Violence: Directions for Australia. Honourable members may recall that that report was commissioned in 1987 after the Hoddle Street massacre and other random acts of violence throughout Australia. It reported in 1990. The National Committee on Violence report called for a uniform code on violence to apply to the networks, exercised through the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. This issue was referred to the ABT, hence its report before us this evening. The ABT report will provide the basis of establishing the uniform code called for by the National Committee on Violence (NCV).

I wish tonight to concentrate my remarks on sports violence on television. The terms of reference set for the ABT inquiry by the former Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Gareth Evans, did not preclude an opportunity to consider closely the impact of violence in televised sport. The terms of reference were wide ranging. In part, those terms sought the inquiry to investigate:
The portrayal, presentation and reporting of violence on television including general entertainment programs, news and current affairs programs, cartoons, advertisements and other programs.

The terms of reference had the scope for an investigation into the impact of violence by way of televised sports broadcasts. Indeed, the findings of the report begged the very issue of the impact of televised sport. The qualitative research carried out by the inquiry found that males of all ages are more likely to watch television programs with high levels of action as well as all types of sport, and thus appeared to be more often exposed to television violence.

There is precious little evidence in all the four volumes of the report that the issue was addressed in any way whatsoever. A total of 1,114 submissions were made to the inquiry, but not one of these was from a formal sporting body. However, some 31 individual submissions dealt with the issue of violence and televised sport. These ranged from submissions from concerned private citizens to those from organisations such as the Australian Council for Children's Films and Television, departmental community welfare officers, officers of the Sport and Recreation Ministers' Council, the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, the National Viewers and Listeners Association, the Australian Family Association and the Tasmanian Minister for Education and the Arts, the Hon. Peter Rae.

Such has been the concern with violence in sport that two years ago all the Ministers for sport called for a reduction of televised sporting related violence. Last year's report by the National Committee on Violence entitled Violence: Directions for Australia, to which I referred earlier, highlighted concerns with sports related violence as portrayed in the national media. I will refer to its recommendations shortly.

The call for a uniform code of practice in regard to violence portrayed through the television networks sprang from the NCV report. However, the concern with sports related violence highlighted in the three-year inquiry into violence in Australia has not directly filtered through into this ABT inquiry, nor specifically into its recommendations. Unfortunately, the television networks themselves appear uninterested in the issue, or at least they are reluctant to raise it as an issue. The two networks, Nine and Ten, which submitted to the ABT inquiry their guidelines on presenting violence had precious little to say about their responsibilities on televising sport. Nine was concerned with martial arts and Ten said it was not in the interests of future generations of sports men and women to overemphasise violence which is not a normal part of the game. One is left wondering what `overemphasise' and `normal' mean in this context.

TALK.START.PARA: —What does it mean in boxing?

—A very good point is made by way of interjection by the honourable member for Perth, with his medical background. Certainly the graphic display and portrayal of boxers hitting the canvas following a knockout is an outright act of violence that worries me enormously. Ten's submission to the inquiry questions whether the network, or any of the other networks, have any idea whatsoever of the impact of sporting related violence on the community, especially the young.

SPEECH.PARA: The inquiry's research clearly found that children and adolescents, especially males, were exposed to a massive amount of televised sports. It also found that younger viewers were vastly more accepting of the level of violence displayed in the various broadcasts than were adults. It was fit and proper that the inquiry dealt with violence in the news and current affairs programs as well as those depicted in drama and light entertainment schedules, but it was disturbing that the impact of televised sport was neglected in its key recommendations. It was equally confusing as to why, given the prevalence of the concern in the submissions, sports related violence was not deemed a substantial or important part of the inquiry's focus.

Mr Deputy Speaker, you would appreciate that sport penetrates popular culture in this country on a staggering scale. It is a central feature of the lives of the bulk of the community. Unlike any other form of organised activity, unlike any institution, sport in its various forms virtually dominates this society. The honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones), the former Minister for Science and Technology, has spent a lifetime railing against the preoccupation of Australian society with sport at the expense of so many of the other higher callings of the human spirit. Again, that is reflected in the research of the ABT inquiry.

Given this mass viewing audience of televised sport, why has the ABT not concentrated, in some part at least, on the aspect of violence in televised sport? It seems to me that Australia has a blind spot when it comes to criticising sporting activities which exhibit high levels of violence. The violence which is portrayed in sport is socially sanctioned violence. We may condemn violence, as other speakers have this evening, as portrayed in fictional programs-movies, dramas, soap operas. We can even express revulsion at real life violence presented in news and current affairs programs. But we are incapable of casting a critical eye on violence in the various sporting activities we ourselves indulge in, as spectators or participants.

We do not have to have the research figures to assess the scale of the impact of sport on the national life and we do not have to have the surveys and the reports to know that sport is a key medium through which the young build their social relationships, both on and off the sporting fields. Sport and the individual role models it presents are powerful determinants in child and adolescent development. Sporting heroes figure deeply in the lives of all the young and sporting incidents are key channels for communicating. As such, the nature of the conduct of those heroes and the character of those incidents are potent vehicles for transmitting formative ideas, values and attitudes. Ultimately they play a role in determining how the young relate to others and how they respond to circumstances.

There is something special about the character of sports related violence. It is not removed from life, as is a cartoon or drama program. It is not an event which can appear to happen almost abstractly in another country or to other people, as it often appears on the news. Sporting violence penetrates deeply and personally into the lives of young. It is lived over and over again in repetitive conversations; it is mimicked on the sporting fields and in the schoolyards. As such, television networks have a profound responsibility to work cooperatively with sporting bodies to suppress the levels of violence which frequently puncture sporting events. Of course there will be problems and difficulties in achieving this.

Sport by its very nature is combative, aggressively physical, competitive and stressful. It is associated with great risks in esteem and safety, which are matched by great returns in victory and triumph. It is driven by emotion and always verging on chaos and loss of control. Consequently, the networks have a responsibility to promote vigorously fair play at the expense of hard play and the other more explicitly gratuitous acts of violence which erupt over the course of a competition. I just do not believe that networks are fulfilling their responsibilities in this regard.

Clubs and players are under enormous commercial and TV network induced pressure to maintain high levels of excitement in the game. This pressure is added to by commentators who are forever glorifying and eulogising acts of violence and overtly rough play. Channel 7's Australian football league commentator, Don Scott, is renowned for this. He, like his Sydney based rugby league colleagues such as Rex Mossop, constantly equates good play with rough play and justifies unsettling the opposition and taking out key players as being intelligent tactics. In so doing, they create a sense that skill, control and excitement are secondary to direct physical confrontations. What lesson is this to the thousands upon thousands of young viewers? Is it a lesson that sporting prowess is expressed through violence?

That is a criticism of Channel 7. Channel 9 is no better. Its Sports Sunday program constantly promotes and packages violent sporting incidents from around the world: ice hockey violence, tragic racehorse falls, baseball brawls and potentially brain damaging knockouts in boxing. Channel 9 commentators endorse violence in sport by way of their amused style of presentation and their emphasis on pain and conflict as being entertaining. Hinch on Channel 7 is guilty of the same crime. On a weekly basis, the Hinch program packages an array of violent sports incidents and presents them to viewers in a jocular, amusing context.

The sports package called Sports Machine has as its commentator Mike Raymond, who provides a comic commentary-if it can be called that-on thuggery in Canadian ice hockey or in any other sports. The program frequently depicts graphic violent incidents on sports fields, and it does so in a childish context which makes one suspicious of the high moral integrity that the program, its producers and the presenter lay claim to.

The message from the networks that violence is part of sport is also conveyed by the insidious tendency of networks to replay violent incidents. Perhaps it is a generalisation to suggest that there is more violence in sport today than in the past, but broadcasting technology has certainly exposed the community to a greater amount of sports related violence than at any time in the past. Last year during the play-offs of the National Basketball Association, the coach of the Canberra Cannons headbutted an opposing player. It was repeatedly replayed in slow motion and became a centrepiece of the commentary from there on.

I am very disappointed indeed that our television networks do not regard the issue of televised sport and the violence so often contained in it more seriously because, after all, we do believe that there is no need to have a regulatory body presiding over matters such as this. There is a great deal of understandable community scepticism regarding the capacity of networks to balance their commercial interests with wider community obligations. The recommendations of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal that have been floated should be taken up as a matter of commonsense by the networks. To trade on violence in search of ratings and commercial success might serve the financial interests of the networks well, but in the long term it may well destroy the sports themselves.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charlesworth Dr R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) has pursued the issue of violence in sport and his concern that this aspect of violence on television has not been pursued by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. I will go to that issue later. I broadly endorse the remarks he has made, although I would question some of the criticisms and suggestions with respect to the value of sport to our society.

SPEECH.PARA: It has been suggested that the most vulnerable group in respect of violence is children, but sometimes I believe that we underestimate children. It is important that we consider the way in which they view these things. I remember as a child hearing stories about dragons, ogres, witches and monsters. All of us have participated in sharing fairy tales, sometimes graphically gruesome in their carriage. But I do not think they are necessarily permanently damaging, because they are part of the normal fantasy life of a child.

Indeed I might relate one or two of my experiences. I am interested in and occasionally watch Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles. I remember my daughter telling me the names of the various turtles. I asked, `Where do you think these names came from?'. She said, `Of course, they are Renaissance painters-Donatello, Michelangelo, et cetera'. From time to time I think we tend to underestimate the understanding of children and the way in which they view these things.

If one reads a story like The Hobbit and reads about the exploits of Gandalf and Bilgo Baggins, one reads about terrible dragons, goblins and monsters. These are all part of the upbringing that I am sure the honourable member for Gippsland had, as did many of us. It is not necessarily the case that children unrealistically view these sorts of programs.

I see that the report suggests that the most dangerous programs from the point of view of children are those of the style of Rambo, which shows indiscriminate killing and destruction in a way that none of us would endorse. It might also be suggested that a young child waiting for Sesame Street, which begins at 3 o'clock in the afternoon, has to endure the violence of Federal Parliament during Question Time. Perhaps this could be a damaging experience.

The honourable member for Gippsland made a number of points on sport. There are many examples in sport of gratuitous violence. This is not the sort of thing that should be condoned. Indeed sport administrators have a responsibility to very closely watch their codes and to try very hard to produce a game which is competitive and fair and in which the spirit of competition is one which does not allow violence to seep in.

But I think that to suggest that all of those things that we see in respect of sport on television are damaging is not accurate and in fact unfair. Many pleasing things can be said about the way in which sport is depicted on television. In this life we are separated from others in other lands. In Australia we are separated by various things. We are separated by geographical distances; by language from people in other countries; and by political and cultural views.

To some extent it is true to say that sport can be a very unifying influence and an important one in teaching us of the need for various characteristics if our society is to be successful. For instance, team sports and the image of watching a team succeed and play well together are important lessons in cooperation. Cooperation is one of the very important things that come out of that.

On the subject of children watching sport, we should be very concerned about violent activities which occur on the field in a gratuitous way. Certainly I believe the most pleasing aspect of watching sport is to observe those sports which contain a great deal of skill and which indicate by their activity that, indeed, this skill is not easily achieved; it is the result of a great deal of training and effort on the part of the participants. When that message is passed through sporting performances on television, it is very positive. What we need to do is make sure that those competitions that are depicted on television do not involve gratuitous and violent acts, and indeed all administrators are trying to do that.

But there is an aspect of sport which is real-and that is competition. I am sure that the honourable member for Gippsland agrees with me. I have found life to be very competitive. Indeed, in this House it is a competitive environment. That is not necessarily an aspect of our lives that should be removed from the purview of society. Indeed, it is an aspect which can provide people with a very good and positive example. It is not a difficult or bad thing; it is something that is real and it is part of the way in which all of us grow up and learn.

Indeed, I recently had the example of my young son sitting in front of the television watching a sporting program, a soccer program. He said to me, `You know, Dad, West Germany and East Germany used to be two separate countries, and now they're only one country', and I said, `Well, that's very interesting; how did you come to think about that, Jonathan?'. He said to me, `Well, just imagine what a good soccer team they're going to have now'. So, from that aspect, just the geographical lessons that can be learnt are important. But it indicates that children think beyond what may be depicted on the screen and, in fact, they have greater capacity than that for which we sometimes give them credit to see through things that occur on television.

One of my concerns about this is, of course, that voluntary codes have been tried in various ways to monitor the activity of organisations. Indeed, in respect of violence on television, a voluntary code is the way in which we think it is most appropriate to proceed. If we are going to have voluntary compliance in a case such as this, then it is necessary, of course, to have some scrutiny as to the success or otherwise of that voluntary code and the way in which it operates. I would hope that the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal is able, in its deliberations, to scrutinise accurately what is done, and to apply to television programs appropriate criteria.

An example of the sorts of criteria that are important is: at the time when this program is shown, who is going to be watching? As was rightly pointed out by both the honourable member for Gippsland and the honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee), there are times when the audience is predominantly young children, and of course there are programs we would like not to be shown at those particular times. We also want to know whether or not the material that is being shown is centrally relevant-is this something that is necessary; do we really need to show this? Those are the sorts of questions that need to be asked.

The other question that needs to be asked, I think, is what can be the cumulative effect? That question needs to be asked because, if we watch television for two or three hours-and I think the statistics show that, generally, most Australians watch for three hours a night or some horrific figure like that-then there are cumulative and repetitive effects that can cause damage. So they are the sorts of criteria that need to be taken into account. Then, of course, we have the criteria concerning what actually, explicitly, is shown in particular programs. Of course there are prohibitions about the moment of death, dead bodies, and those sorts of restrictions which I think are generally understood and accepted.

I do believe that there is a broad community consensus about what things are acceptable, but we will always have an argument about censorship when we come to those things which are close to the border. For example, when we do an examination, if someone gets 50 per cent and someone else gets 49 per cent then the difference between passing and failing is very little-and there will always be a number of issues in respect of television where there will not be a consensus as to whether or not the particular behaviour depicted represents violent activity which should be excluded or an activity which is acceptable and real.

Determining those sorts of borders will be something that of course is particularly difficult. The sorts of criteria that we are going to apply to a current affairs program which is shown at 9.30 at night is different from the sorts of criteria we might be using for the news flash that occurs during the children's hour or the criteria that may apply at 7 o'clock. I think that those are the sorts of considerations that are important.

Also, of course, besides violence to humans, we need to consider activities which include animals. Indeed, we often see programs in which there are animals suffering in various ways. Sometimes there are lessons to be learned and these are important things to show; and examples of animals that have been injured as a result of an oil slick or whales washed up on the beach are cases in point. But there are other occasions when, of course, in various programs one sees violence towards animals which is an unacceptable thing and certainly something that we should be concerned about.

Another difficulty that we face when we look at violence is of course the cultural relativity-the difference that occurs between one culture and another. If we watch cops and robbers programs-and they are pretty popular and always have been since television has abounded in this country-then there seems to be a signi-ficant difference between the sorts of cops and robbers programs we see from the United Kingdom and those we see from the United States. Indeed, perhaps what we see there is a reflection of the society in which those programs are made. I think that it is important that we understand that those sorts of programs are things that create a mood and influence the way in which society develops.

My view has been for some time that the sorts of programs that emanate from the United States are infinitely less realistic and significantly more violent than those which we see from the United Kingdom. Perhaps that reflects the society in which those programs are made, because it is clear that two cities such as London and New York, although similar in size, are significantly different in respect of their crime rates and the ways in which their different police forces behave. What we see when we watch programs like that is indeed a reflection of the society in which they are made. The unreality of those sorts of programs is mind-boggling. Someone being hit on the jaw and then getting up and copping it again is very unreal, because anyone who understands a blow such as that would know that of course once one has been hit once like that one does not get up and carry on. Indeed, that unreality is something that is frightening and I believe very dangerous-in exactly the same way as are programs like Miami Vice, Rambo and Tour of Duty. Those programs engender an air of unreality which is dangerous and frightening.

If there were to be significant sanctions against such programs, I believe I would then find myself supporting that view, because it is true that unbalanced behaviour, unrealistic behaviour, is more likely to evoke violence in our society as a result of its explicit detail than many of the other things that we are concerned about. Some of the concerns about pornography, for instance, receive more attention but perhaps should not receive the same attention as that violent sort of behaviour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bradford Mr J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was interested to see the honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth) rise to speak tonight. The earlier list of speakers showed that only a couple of Government members were interested in this topic; whereas I am amongst a significant number of Opposition members who have had their names down for some time to speak on this topic. It is of genuine concern to me, as I know it is to all the Opposition speakers who have been planning for some time now to speak on this subject.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Perth is certainly right about one thing, and that is the timeliness of our discussion on the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal report TV Violence in Australia, occurring two weeks after the initial televising of the proceedings of the House of Representatives. One could say that in many respects that ought to be R-rated-the `R' standing for rabble, because that is the impression viewers get when viewing Question Time in this place.

One could even describe the treatment by the Treasurer (Mr Keating)-there are others but he is pretty good at this-of the Australian people as an act of violence, and that is now portrayed live on television across the country. I cannot help but mention the Minister for Community Services and Health (Mr Howe), because whenever he answers a question he becomes almost physically violent. One would not want to get too close to him. Indeed, I wonder how the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) sometimes survives. One feels that somebody ought to rescue him and put him out of his misery. However, the topic really is much more serious than this.

The report was tabled by the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Beazley) in May 1990. I believe it is a worthwhile contribution to the debate on this subject, which has now been going on for some time. The decision to initiate the inquiry arose out of a concern expressed at a Premiers Conference on gun control in December 1987. There are 13 significant recommendations as a result of the inquiry by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal that I believe are worthwhile. Evidence given to the Tribunal showed that a significant number of people are concerned about violence on television.

Interestingly, the evidence also showed that people do not know how to allay their concerns, whether for themselves or their children. Consequently, one of the significant recommendations deals with the conduct of an awareness campaign to inform the public about violence on television and specifically to offer advice on classifications of programs and program content. Apparently 60 per cent of people surveyed, which is a rather large number, had no knowledge of the current regulations in respect of violence on television and only about one-fifth were aware of what the classification system was about. The report also points to the need for strategies to be developed and implemented by the industry so as to improve understanding of the classification system and specifically that the industry should consider time zone promotion program guides and warnings.

The report takes the view that the answer to violence on Australian television is not censorship and that violence can best be held to socially acceptable levels on television by the industry itself through self-regulation. However, to be most effective a uniform approach by the commercial and public sectors of the industry is required. The most important and in fact the first recommendation of the report is that the industry be requested to draw up a uniform self-regulating code on the treatment of violence on television. This code would be used as a basis for the Tribunal interim television program standards and consolidate and strengthen the existing internal industry guidelines.

Some people may have doubts about whether a voluntary code will work. Perhaps some honourable members on both sides of the House may think that we should take even stronger steps, but I am prepared to take the view that we ought to give it a go. We would generally prefer to see self-regulation. Generally speaking, I believe that the Australian television industry has served Australians pretty well over the years and that reasonable standards have been maintained. I notice the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones) in the chamber. With his interests he may find programs such as No. 96, Neighbours or Home and Away anything but intellectually stimulating. However, they are the daily diet of culture for a lot of people. Perhaps such programs do not reach the greatest intellectual heights, but in my judgment we have not done too badly.

As the report shows, it is ultimately the individual's responsibility to regulate his own and, more importantly, his children's viewing. I am pleased to note that the recommendations of the report are indeed far-reaching and that the Minister, in tabling the report, indicated that he fully supported all 13 recommendations. The industry is apparently now committed to drafting a uniform code, and I understand that it will shortly be available for public scrutiny. I hope that at that time the Minister will bring it into the Parliament for detailed examination and further debate.

Watching television has become a major Australian pastime. For many people it is their primary recreation; they get their daily exercise sitting in front of the television. Much research that I have seen over the years shows that both adults and children have in many respects become almost addicted to watching television. The downside is that there is plenty of evidence to show that children are watching television at the expense of reading books or engaging in more creative activities.

Generally speaking, I subscribe to the view that adults, within broad community standards, should be able to choose what they watch on television and, in doing so, be guided by classifications and, where necessary, specific content warnings. As a parent, however-and a number of parents have spoken in the debate-I am very concerned about what children watch on television and the effect that violence has on children. Since 1963 a lot research has been done in this area, and it is generally agreed in most of the research I have seen that at least in the short term violent television programs make children behave badly. The research is somewhat more ambivalent on effects on children in the longer term.

A significant piece of American research I came across showed that there was a quite high correlation between children who watched a great number of hours of television during elementary school years and aggressive behaviour as teen-agers. That was quite conclusive. There is no doubt that this issue of the effect of violence on children is a particularly complex one, and it is important that parents be extremely vigilant about what their children watch on television.

There are a number of guidelines available for parents, and perhaps I should place on record a couple that we found helpful with our younger children. Firstly, parents should watch at least one episode of the television program their children view. It is amazing what happens if children turn the television on and get inte-rested in a program. It is very good for parents to sit down and see what their children are digesting. Parents should be prepared to discuss with the child what motivated a character they have seen to commit a violent act. Of course, parents can encourage their children to watch programs that are positive in terms of demonstrating help, care and cooperation-the converse to the situation where children behave badly.
