Children can learn to imitate good behaviour and to behave in socially acceptable ways by watching the right sorts of television programs. So in that sense there is a very positive aspect to what children can learn from tele-vision.

Parents ultimately can and should ban programs for their children which are obviously violent or offensive in some way. There is an argument going around that children sooner or later are going to encounter the real world and are going to find that it is characterised by injustice, thoughtlessness and a desire to exact retribution- all of which can be described as violence. It seems to me that, on balance, parents are probably best advised to err on the safe side and be very selective about what they allow their children to watch on television.

The point is that children are often subjected to incidental violence on television. There has been quite a lot of discussion in this debate about that so far. Mention has been made of news broadcasts. From what I read, children do not really like watching the news. They do not choose to watch the news at night. But when it comes on at 6 o'clock it is on in most homes, around dinner time, and parents mostly like to watch it so kids are subjected to it. They are exposed in most news broadcasts to violence of some sort. Often the difficulty with violence in that context is that children are less likely to find that understandable because they do not see it in any particular context. From my understanding, the violence in the news is more dangerous than perhaps the violence in an understandable or explainable context.

I would hope that the code would pick this particular point up and perhaps a G rating should apply to the 6 o'clock news, whereas a more explicit news could be shown later in the evening and that would tend to overcome that sort of problem. It is very important that news is not censored in any way. Sometimes I think it is probably fair to say that violent images add very little and they could be kept for viewing later in the evening.

We have viewed evidence of violence and graphic real life scenes in the Gulf war. I suppose we have been exposed to them almost ad nauseam over the last few weeks. I found it important with my young children when they are seeing that on the news to put it in some sort of a context for them, otherwise I found that they were quite concerned that that war was happening down the street or in the backyard or something. I wanted to help them understand just exactly what was going on in the world.

There is no doubt that children are not in any way as immune to shock and horror as are adults. Children feel very vulnerable and unprotected when they see explicit violence and suffering, particularly as they do on the news, often out of context. The report states:

Children need to understand violence, know alternatives to expression and have an informed appreciation of how it should be viewed in conjunction with more positive pro social motivations and attitudes.
This highlights the importance of parental guidance and the need for individuals to exercise stricter control over the viewing habits of their children.

Another factor highlighted by the report in terms of children viewing violence incidentally is the advertising of violent movies within and immediately following family viewing programs. This is something that the code will obviously need to deal with. Of course, the introduction of appropriate time zones would mean that the advertising of violent movies would only be appropriate in those time zones.

Quite a lot has been said about cartoons. The research that I have read in this area probably indicates some ambivalence about the effect of cartoons on kids at least eight years old and above to recognise reality and unreality. The under eight-year-old group is still a very uncertain area.

I suppose a lot of us have been brought up with Popeye and Bugs Bunny and probably have not been terribly badly affected by it, although I think Noddy and Big Ears have since been banned for other reasons. Although I guess in this enlightened age for the same reasons they will probably be brought back before too long to show that we treat everybody equally.

However, as the honourable member for Perth said, we have gone beyond that. We live in the age of He Man and Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles. Those particular characters in my view do exhibit extreme violence. Yet Ninja Turtles has become a favourite playground pastime for most younger kids. My own six-year-old boy has not taken it terribly seriously but he is giving his young sister a terrible time with all these Ninja Turtles kicks that they get up to. I suppose in a sense it has affected his behaviour somewhat.
When I look back to my own childhood I guess I saw Superman leaping off tall buildings. I do not think I ever attempted to do that.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was not as graphic as that.

—That is right. We could make some distinction. We are certainly now seeing a graphic portrayal of violence. I am going to run out of time in a moment. In the few seconds I have left I wish to say that the report is welcomed by all members of the House. I think we have all said that. We believe it is a valuable contribution to the debate and relates to a very important area. I, along with other honourable members, will wait with a great deal of interest to see the presentation of the regulatory code. I believe, as I said before, that the industry should be given an opportunity to self-regulate in this area. I personally have a preference for that as an alternative to outright regulation through legislation.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the report TV Violence in Australia because we are being kept in this House by the dilettantes of the Australian Democrats who are messing around with the wool legislation in the other House. They are messing around with legislation which they know very little about, but no doubt they want to stamp their feet upon their little drum while they have the opportunity.

SPEECH.PARA: I was not going to speak on this report because, quite frankly, I do not think it is all that significant. It is a nonsense to suggest that today's society is more violent than it has been in previous times. My mind goes to quite an old poem written by that most prolific of English poets, Anonymous. It goes something like this:
He took castle and town,
he cut short limb and life,
he made orphans and widows of children and wives.
This course many years he triumphantly ran,
and did mischief enough to be called a great man.

Violence is nothing new. Violence in the past has been far worse than it is today. However, we are entering a new era of authoritarianism, of puritanical actions and attitudes. We see this in some of the violent assaults on civil liberties that we get in this country. We have had this damn nonsense from the courts recently about the dangers of passive smoking. As a non-smoker I feel absolutely affronted at this assault on the civil liberties of other people. This is a violent action, in my view.

I have read in some detail books of the Old Testament. If one runs through Genesis, Exodus, Leviticus, Numbers-there is a good one-Judges, Samuel, Kings and Chronicles, one will find them fraught with violence. At one stage there is an injunction to put 30,000 people to the sword because they were in the way; their land was wanted. This violent act was at the behest of God. What higher authority can one get for violence?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is TV violence, by the way.

—This is about television violence; it cannot be isolated. We have to deal with the nature of violence in the whole of society. The reason that violence can be separated is that there is violence to which people relate and violence to which they do not relate. People who saw footage of the First World War and the bloody battles of Gallipoli and of France, where people got blown up and there was absolute mayhem, did not relate to that violence. They do not relate to violence when a bomb is dropped on Hiroshima. However, they do relate much more to personal violence. I think the honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth) raised a very pertinent point: it is in the nature of the culture, and if one does look at the cops and robbers on American television or American programs generally, one sees enormous personal violence.

SPEECH.PARA: Having not been immune from violence myself in the past, while it may be true that twice is he blessed whose cause is just, I can tell honourable members that thrice is he blessed who gets his blow in first. It is very hard to come back from that first punch. Yet repeatedly on television we see people get absolutely massacred and mauled beyond what any human body could endure, then get up and win. That creates in people's minds a view that the body is much stronger than it is.

I have seen a situation recently where a man stopped five close range slugs from a revolver and he then went on to conquer his assailant. But then he was an American policeman. I can tell you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that being the recipient of a bullet-I still have the bullet in my arm-I did not feel like getting up and fighting anyone. Indeed, I could not because I could not move my arm. It felt extremely dead and painful. I know from experience that the body does not tolerate the sort of violence that we see it continue to be subjected to on American television.

We do not see this violence to anything like the same degree on British television. I think the honourable member for Perth was right when he said that it was more realistic; it is much more realistic and in my view it is no less entertaining. I have asked the opinion of people who have watched the various programs. It seems to me a lot of the English programs have a big following because they are realistic and they are clever; they do not rely just on violence.

When it comes to Ninja turtles, I think it is absurd to suggest that society generally is going to relate to Ninja turtles and that they are going to be the cause of aggression or undue violence in teenagers. After all, the Ninja turtles are the goodies and there is far less fear and loathing raised in the minds of anyone, even children, when the goodies win. They are still animated characters, not people to whom we actually relate except in perhaps a very small minority of cases.

I know that we could find 100 psychologists who will tell us about the ill-effects of violence on television and how it should be curbed and banned. We could also find 100 psychologists who will tell us the opposite. That is the nature of psychology and it has to be taken with a large grain of salt.

Let us look at the history of violence. I recall the national anthem we used to have. The second verse said something like, `Oh Lord our God arise, scatter our enemies and make them fall'. I would certainly say that is a call for violence, albeit from a high authority. That raises in people the view that violence is right in some circumstances and I have to say that I believe that is the case. We are being subjected to a lot of violence now on television from the war in the Middle East. That is horrendous violence. Abhorrent as that violence is, I am drawn to the inevitable conclusion that it must take place for the long term outcome.

I would support a self-monitoring of violence on television, but we should be realistic. This is far preferable to any sort of regulation and I am very worried about regulation. I see a lot of regulation as an assault on people's liberties. It would be much more effective to leave it to Customs to whack a solid tariff on American television because it is this American invasion, the cultural invasion on television, that brings the violence most people are concerned about.

The American culture is a much more violent culture than ours and I do not believe that it has created in America anything that we would want to emulate. It is true that the American culture is also a much more religious culture than ours. I ask myself sometimes whether religion and violence are not synonymous and interchangeable. It is true that nothing engenders as much passion, as much moral authority as religion. We see this today very much with the fundamentalist Islam, but no less do we see it with fundamentalist Christianity, particularly that emanating from the United States.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where is the violence there? Where is their violence?
—The violence in fundamentalist Islam is where--
—No, in Christianity.

—I will get to the answer because the honourable member for Gippsland could obviously do with a lot of education. It is not his fault and I am quite prepared to devote the rest of my time to educating him.
—You are speaking in generalisations only.

—Of course I am speaking in generalisations; in a debate like this one can only speak in generalisations. But any religion that preaches hellfire and damnation, that preaches the right to punish people severely for not agreeing with it is a violent creed. In Islam people are punished for breaching a fundamental basis of our society, the right of free of speech--
—And in Christianity?
—I just mentioned Christianity.
—No, you said Islam.
—If the honourable member for Gippsland would like me to look at Christianity, I would advise him to look at history, the first Crusades.
—You said Christianity in America.
—If the honourable member for Gippsland does not understand the nature of violence in fundamentalist Christianity, I would suggest that he do a little more reading.
—I am asking for some examples of violence.
—Order! The honourable member for Kalgoorlie will come back to the debate before the House.

—If necessary, I will spend an hour educating the honourable member for Gippsland. On the question of regulation, I do not think it is necessary to have regulations set too stringently. In my own family I have one child who is an avid television addict. He watches virtually everything; he can recite commercials virtually word for word. I see no evidence in him that he is unduly influenced by this violence. It is true that there may be a subliminal effect; there may be a compounding effect, but I somehow doubt it. I doubt whether he is going to be any the better or any the worse because of his exposure to this.

SPEECH.PARA: We must make sure that self-regulation in television does not go down the Calvinist, puritanical road which Australia and a lot of other countries seem to be going down at the moment. As I said earlier in my speech, this to me is the greater violence-when we deny people their individuality, when we deny people basic rights or freedoms in the name of some common good or some perceived common good. I think that is an extremely dangerous course to take and one which we should certainly try to avoid.

We have to ask ourselves whether we want television to entertain us or to educate us. The answer to that is that in the main we want television to entertain us. We need to encourage much more Australian programming. What we have seen of Australian programming has been good-for example, All the Rivers Run was an excellent program. It was not full of violence.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mad Max.
—That is an interesting point because Mad Max is what one would call surrealist violence.
—Limbs being torn off is surrealist?
—It is the sort of violence which people can look at and say that it is a caricature of violence.
—Children see that.
—You have not read the inquiry. There is a large reference to--
—Order! The honourable member for Gippsland has had his chance to debate this matter.

—If anyone were to suggest to me that a film like Mad Max should be banned, I would say that perhaps it should be banned on other grounds, maybe on some sort of artistic merit. But that is the sort of violence that people in general do not relate to. The most dangerous and pernicious violence is that where individuals are assaulted by individuals, where we see violence in the family situation. That is the most pernicious and dangerous sort of violence on television-the violence where it shows that it is okay to punch up women and to kick people to the ground. That is the dangerous sort of violence, not the violence we see in a military situation, because people generally do not relate to it, and they see it as a thing apart.

SPEECH.PARA: This gets back to what I was saying earlier about the difference in artistic merit between British programming and American programming. I might also say that I have seen programming in Europe. I have seen some very good French programs which do not have this level of violence that is portrayed in the modern American programs. We have seen the nature of violence grow in American programs. Back in the old days of cowboys and Indians, there was a clear-cut distinction between right and wrong. To my recollection in those days the baddies conveniently wore the black hats, but there again it was tempered by the fact that justice prevailed in the end. Today's violence is much more muddy than that; we are receiving a much more convoluted message.

I believe that if we are serious about violence and we want to do something about it then we should be looking to Australian programs to develop our own culture and to stop the spread of cheap American programs throughout the world.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sullivan Mrs K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — Mr Deputy Speaker, I am going to make a couple of comments I really had not meant to make tonight. I just have to say that the contribution we have just heard from the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) is one of the best illustrations we will ever have as to why people should not speak for the sake of speaking. Secondly, something I learned many years ago in public speaking and debating is that one should never try to debate nonsense. I am about to break that second rule. The honourable member's speech was the stupidest speech I have heard in this place in a long time-and I make no apologies for saying that.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a serious subject. It was being pursued in a non-adversarial way, but we have just had adversaries put into it. One thing I will not live with and will not just let go over my shoulder is this nonsense about, `It is all the fault of American television'. I agree with the member for Kalgoorlie that the United States of America has a fundamentally more violent society than Australia has. The issue of violence and the subject of violence on television is that there are many Australians saying, `We do not want Australian television to go down that path'. I will deal specifically with the news and other items too.

I interjected at one stage when the honourable member opposite was off on a tangent and saying that we never see anything violent that is made in Australia. I said, `What about Mad Max?'. Then we had some other dissertation there.

Certainly there is much in American television programs that reflects the violent nature of American society, but it is not confined to American television. The spurious solution the honourable member opposite came up with, in contrast to the recommendations in this report that we are debating tonight, that all we have to do is put a tax on American film, is really nonsense. He said that British films were okay. British cops and robbers films and television series can be the most grotesquely violent things we could ever watch. They will match anything we see. On occasions I have flipped on SBS without actually knowing what the program is-I am usually searching for something I want to watch, so I will flip by. One sees films on SBS, albeit only fleetingly, which are extremely violent. The honourable member's comments are just nonsense.

What we are debating is Australian television and what is shown on television here, whatever the source. Like many people, I really welcome this debate. I am delighted that we have this opportunity here in the House of Representatives tonight-no matter that it is a totally obscene hour of the night and no matter that the reasons we are debating at this hour of the night are totally unworthy of the subject.

For years, in my life as a parliamentarian, I have been concerned about and involved in the public arena with the subject of the portrayal of violence on television and in videos. This goes back well before my membership of this chamber, back to when I was in the Senate. I have found this to be a subject which stirs the greatest concern-deep, real concern-in the Australian public. But as deep as the concern about incidents of violence which may be shown on television is the concern that people have expressed about their powerlessness to do anything about it. That is really, surely, the issue of this report, and I hope not to run out of time before I can give my own views about where I think the report is deficient. I would like to make a couple of simple suggestions about how that deficiency might be overcome.

Over the years I have spoken with many people involved in the television industry, particularly the television news industry, about the subject of portraying violent scenes on television news. I remember being told by a spokesman for one of the channels in Queensland, my State, that it had surveyed audiences to find out what were the sorts of items on news programs which people most wanted to see. I will share a little bit of that with honourable members.

The No. 1 item was so-called medical stories. People liked news stories about breakthroughs in treatments of disease, particularly the sort of disease that strikes a common chord of fear, like cancer, heart disease or something like that. That was the No. 1 choice of people. No. 2 was stories of trauma-that is, violence. That could be the trauma of a road accident or the trauma of crime.

People were being asked what they liked, but what was not asked was what they did not like. So it could well have been that when the television channel found out that the No. 2 choice amongst the people they were talking to was stories of trauma, if it had asked exactly the same people what were the things they did not like, it would have got a bigger percentage who did not like stories of trauma.

The television industry has been very dishonest about this subject over the years. It is only of late that we are starting to get data coming out from reputable sources which is showing the sorts of things being talked about in this debate, which I do not intend to canvass. There is resistance to certain matters. But television executives and news editors for years have been holding up the sorts of statistics I have just referred to and saying, `This is what people want, we cannot censor it. It is news, it has happened and people want to watch it'. They have been very dishonest.

I wish to come back to that because I wish to make a very particular reference to the Seven Network in Australia and to mention some of the positive things it has been attempting to do, at the expense of its ratings on occasions, in this area. I think it should get credit for it. The overwhelming, principal concern on the subject of television violence is that there are violent scenes in news and current affairs being shown at a time when children are likely to be watching. But it is not only children we should be concerned about. Unlike what some other speakers have said, that children are unwilling watchers of television, I have had parents say to me children come home from school saying their teachers have said they have to watch the news for a particular reason, or they want the children to watch the news for certain educational reasons. Parents, being conscientious, and in trying to accede to the teacher's request-or maybe feeling, quite independent of school, that it is something they want their children to become conditioned to as an interest in what happens in the world- find their children exposed to the most awful trauma.

Of course, not only are children affected by news violence. This is the issue I wish to pose to the House and also to the honourable member for Kalgoorlie. Surely, is the issue not what we as Australians want to set as public standards? Should not our television news in particular, but not only our television news, reflect that?

In the last decade we have been seeing increasingly on television scenes of grief and trauma which to me are an offence to a sense of human decency. This report refers to the Hoddle Street massacre in particular, and credit has been given to a meeting of Attorneys-General. I say it is to the shame of a lot of people that it took the Hoddle Street massacre and a meeting of the Attorneys-General concerned about gun laws to get this going, because thousands of Australians have been crying out about it for a long time.

This nauseous habit of television journalists going to a recently bereaved parent or spouse-a child or a spouse may have been murdered-and shoving a television camera in that person's face and a microphone up the nostril, and asking, `Well, how do you feel about your daughter having been raped, strangled and thrown in a ditch?', to which mum says, `I really feel dreadful' is just horrendous. It makes one want to be ill.

I think those of us in public life who have had the experience of television know that there is something about it that is implicitly intimidating. I am not saying the journalists mean to be intimidating, but people do feel a bit intimidated, instinctively, by the approach of a television camera. The average John and Mary Citizen, who never dreamed they would ever face one, are just completely overwhelmed by it. It is not enough to say people can decline to answer. People who are traumatised are numbed; they are defenceless; their senses are suspended; and they should not be asked. It is an offence against human dignity.

The very worst incident of this I ever saw on television was quite by accident when I was in a motel in Melbourne with a committee inquiry early in 1988. I cannot say which channel it was-I wish I could. I wish I could have screamed from the house tops! I was so horrified when I saw this incident I turned the television off and walked out of the room.

A little three-year-old boy went missing in Adelaide at 8 o'clock at night. His body was discovered later in the evening in the driveway of a home approximately one kilometre from his house. He had been riding his tricycle on the footpath outside his home after dinner. The police had had a report of the missing child from the father. The police went to get the father to bring him to see the body of the little boy, who had been sexually molested and strangled, so that he could identify his son. Somehow, a television channel found that a child's body had been found. The camera crew was there before the father. Here on the six o'clock news we saw the father cross the street, be shown the body, and we heard his screams. I have never forgotten. As I said, I instinctively turned off the television and walked out of the room. If anybody can justify putting that on television at any time of the night, I want to hear the justification.

Because my time is running out I want to refer to what had been, up until that stage, the worst thing I had seen either on television news or in the print media. I am going to talk about the Challenger disaster very briefly. At 7 o'clock one morning I heard on radio news that the Challenger had exploded on take-off. My instant feeling was one of horror. In those days Challenger blast-offs were broadcast live on television. I thought, `My God, that girl's parents will have seen that on television'. I went and turned on the television because that is the best source of news under those circumstances.

Not only did her parents see it-they were there and saw it live; they saw their daughter being incinerated. And we saw their reaction. The smart television cameraman instantly thought, `Ah, the girl's parents' and whizzed the camera on to them. We saw, first, the look of disbelief and then the grief and horror as her mother and father realised that that ball of flame was their daughter dying. I watched television until President Reagan came on at 11 o'clock that morning. That shot of the explosion and the girl's parents was shown over and over again.

I thought that I could not see anything worse, until I opened the Courier-Mail the next day, which went one better. Next to a picture of the explosion there was a close-up of the girl's sister, screaming hysterically. That is just about as low as it is possible to go. That is what we are told is news. That is what we are told we ought to accept. The final thing I want to say about that is that for two nights on the news, whenever the newsreader referred to the Challenger disaster and the inquiries that were being established, the picture in the background was the explosion. So 48 hours afterwards we were still looking at a picture of five people being incinerated. Absolutely unnecessary. Totally unnecessary. I just wish we could have a few more debates like this, and I wish that it had not taken the Hoddle Street massacre to bring it on.

Very quickly, I will refer now to the gratuitous violence that is shown. This is my last example. There was a case in America of a felon being chased by police. Television news crews got in a helicopter and followed the police chase. The felon's car crashed. He was armed. He leapt out of the car. The police shot him dead, on camera. We saw this in Australia. What did it have to do with us? It was some dinky town in America I do not think I had ever heard of, but Australian television was showing it. Let us not blame the Americans; blame the Australian news editors and the Australian programmers.

I am nearly out of time so I will have to be very brief, but I want to pay tribute to the Seven Network in Australia, which years ago set a code for what it would show. Channel 7 has come second to Channel 9 in news ratings by and large over the years, but Channel 7 has not deviated from its code. In my experience, Channel 9 has shown no taste at all on the subject of personal trauma, violence, tragedy, offence to human decency and all the things that we would want to have as Australian standards. I hope that not only does the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal have a say but also that consumers will be empowered to make their complaints from now on.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired. Before I call the honourable member for Capricornia, I call the honourable member for Ballarat on a point of order.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek your indulgence to raise a matter of current concern.
—You may proceed.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I have just returned from the Senate. I was sitting in the President's Gallery and it was pointed out to me that if indeed there was a division in this House I would not have any notification of that. I am not too sure whether that is indeed the situation. If it is, Mr Deputy Speaker, could I ask you to please pass on to the Speaker my concerns on that matter and ask whether he could investigate it accordingly. I think it puts at risk the transfer of members between the two Houses. If that is indeed the situation, that would cause me a great deal of concern.
—I thank the honourable member for Ballarat for drawing it to my attention. I will refer the matter to the Speaker.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I enter this debate to place on record my hope that the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal report on TV violence in Australia presented to the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Beazley) will result in initiatives within the television industry specifically. I realise that when one thinks about initiatives and is dealing with a subject such as this, one really has two choices: the choice of introducing deterrents to those people who continue to portray violence on television-violence at those times when children tend to watch television; or the choice of incentives-incentives for the industry and, I think, for the parents to think through the present and look to a different future.

SPEECH.PARA: I personally opt for the choice of incentives. I hope that as honourable members carefully consider the report, the recommendations and the evidence that have been presented to this House, we will argue for incentives that will in fact impact positively on our own television industry. I am not talking about the industry presenting programs on the channels, but that part of the industry that produces the programs. I see a real difficulty here. I take up the cudgels for those who make films in that there is no real incentive today for them to spend their time and their money producing better quality films, films that are different in their emphasis-an emphasis that comes back to the family and the children-and which come within the G classification.

If it comes to dollars, it is far easier to get someone to smack another person in the mouth than it is to come up with a script that is family oriented or to really spend the money to ensure that the documentary that is produced will be educational in its purpose. So I think there is a real challenge to our Parliament to ensure we do not leave all the effort that has been put into this report as just a report. There is a real challenge to ensure that something good comes out of it.

I note many of the recommendations and am impressed by them. However, I want to go to a couple of issues-it is impossible in the 15 minutes members have to canvass every aspect. I want to refer to that emphasis which I believe needs to be given to public awareness. It is stressed in the report that most people do not know the current regulations. Most people do not understand the current classifications. Yet, the report also says that most people are concerned. It stated that the large percentage of people interviewed were concerned about the predominance of violence in films that are available to them and their children. The report also stresses that these people do not know what to do. I think that leads us to one of the important tasks of the Parliament and the government of the day, which is ensuring that we come to grips with this problem.

It was said to me some time back, when a mother was accused of abusing her child, that we really should not blame her because she knew no better; that she had been abused and her mother before her had been abused. Sometimes I think we take parenthood for granted; we believe that parenthood and parental responsibility somehow just happen, although we teach and try to inculcate into people many other skills.

I believe this report is saying to us that it does not just happen. There is a need for people out in the community not only to be aware of the effects of violence on their children but also to come to some solutions as to what they themselves can do about it. It is very easy to say that, but it will also come back to a question of alternatives. It is easy to say to parents `You should not be letting your children watch a particular film or program', but when one goes through the television guide one finds that there is not a lot else that children can watch.

Many other speakers have stressed the violence content of news. The report argues at length about the violent impact that some cartoons can have-although I have some differing views about that. We need to ensure in the first instance that there is an alternative, and that comes back to my original point. We need to provide an incentive to the producers in this country who are prepared to produce family films. If this means going to a tax situation of 150 per cent-a discriminating tax situation-whereby if a person produces particular types of films he or she obtains particular tax gains, I think we ought to put that on the agenda as a matter for consideration.

I applaud the emphasis the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and a number of commercial channels are now giving to environment-related documentaries. They are tending to develop pro-nature segments in their program agendas. But that is expensive and people also want to watch the movie; they want to watch serials and a variety of other things. They will not sit down and watch programs about nature night after night. They will turn to the video, which is a point I want to raise later in my remarks because I believe it is related, even though it is not a part of this report.

I suggest that we need some incentives. We need some incentives for the film producer, and I am raising the possibility of a tax incentive. There could also be deterrents for those who continue to produce the rubbish that often appears on our television screens. It is suggested that under the present regulations there is always the threat of loss of licence, but I would rather that we opted for better programs and that we tried to give those incentives. I seek leave to continue my remarks at a later time.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.
House adjourned at 12.43 a.m. (Friday) until Tuesday, 5 March 1991, at 2 p.m., in accordance with the resolution agreed to at this sitting.

The following answer to a question was circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kemp Dr D.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 20 December 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did he or the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade at any time as a consequence of the Government's decision to phase out the subsidised overseas students program and introduce a full fee/scholarship program for overseas students in tertiary institutions make a statement, either privately or in public, to the effect that the loss of revenue to higher education institutions arising from the phasing out of the subsidised program would be fully offset by direct revenue accruing from new scholarship places so that the change would have a revenue neutral impact on the tertiary education sector; if such assurances were made, (a) when were they made, (b) how were they made and (c) to whom.

(2) Will the higher education sector suffer any loss in revenue as a consequence of the Government's decision to phase out the subsidised overseas students program and introduce a full fee/scholarship; if so, what will that loss be in (a) 1990, (b) 1991, (c) 1992 and (d) 1993.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) (b) (c) The change in overseas student policy was announced in a joint public statement issued by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and myself on 18 December 1988. In that statement we pointed out that the institutions themselves would benefit from the abolition of the subsidised program which would no longer attract students away from the full fee program. In addition, losses to revenue arising from the phasing out of the existing subsidised system would be offset by direct revenue accruing from the new scholarship places.

(2) (a) (b) (c) (d) The system wide reductions to institutions operating grants were based on estimates of numbers of scholarships and course costs. Due to constraints in the aid budget and less than expected average course costs the estimated income to institutions was not sufficient to fully offset the reduction to operating grants in 1990, and is expected to have a similar result in 1991 and 1992. This matter was addressed by the Government in July 1990 and it was agreed that any shortfall between the increase in full fee scholarship income and the reduction in operating grants should not exceed $4 million in each of the 1991-1992 calendar years. The exact shortfall for 1990 is still being determined in consultation with AVCC and this may impact on future years, hence it would not be appropriate to provide figures at this stage. It should be noted that any shortfall arising from the less than expected income through Commonwealth full fee scholarships has more than been offset by the income from full fee places (approximately $65 million in 1990) which arose from the removal of quotas.
